description:
This series of videos covers the knowledge and skills needed to plan, configure, and manage the advanced features in a SharePoint 2016 environment, including implementing high availability, disaster recovery, service application architecture, and Microsoft Business Connectivity Services. It also covers social computing features, productivity, and collaboration platforms and features, as well as business intelligence solutions, Enterprise Content Management, web content management infrastructure.

This is the second in a sequence of two courses for IT Professionals and is aligned with the SharePoint 2016 IT Pro certification.
name: Advanced SharePoint 2016 - 70-339
subtitle: Advanced Technologies of SharePoint 2016

this page ASAP in your exam journey for

42

43

Find out what the test is on.

Pretty fundamental, right?

45

A lot of people thought well,
I'll just do the courses first,

then I'll think about it.

By reviewing all the exam objectives and
reading the content.

It'll make your ears perk up when you hear

50

All right, that said, let's talk

51

We've got a lot to cover.

52

53
00:03:06.060 --> 00:03:12.230
Always, exam fodder is new functionality

54
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:14.140
Maybe new names for the old things.

55
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:17.420
So any changes compared to
the previous version is fair game and

56
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:20.050

designed to confuse you

57

58
00:03:24.210 --> 00:03:25.620
For example, SharePoint 2013.

59
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:28.279
But now in the new era

60
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:33.590
So core Microsoft SharePoint

61
00:03:33.590 --> 00:03:37.170

62

63

64
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:48.970

a combination of online and on print.

65
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:53.760
So we'll look at hybrid architectures, and

66

67
00:03:56.210 --> 00:03:58.840
We'll also look at business
continuity management.

68
00:03:58.840 --> 00:04:00.390
Always in season.

69
00:04:00.390 --> 00:04:01.780

70
00:04:01.780 --> 00:04:04.160
Your data center may burn to a crisp.

71
00:04:04.160 --> 00:04:05.340
What's your strategy?

72
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:07.630
So we'll look at various
high-availability strategies,

73
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:13.060
both local and maybe geolocated
somewhere else beyond where you are.

74
00:04:13.060 --> 00:04:17.748
We'll look at the benefit of using
Azure as a DR site, if you will.

75
00:04:17.748 --> 00:04:21.261
And various back-up and restore plans,

76
00:04:21.261 --> 00:04:27.500
various SQL topologies which will help
you in your back-up and DR rules.

77
00:04:27.500 --> 00:04:32.180
We'll also look at business connectivity
services in secure store service.

78
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:36.609
So the ability to connect in to any
organized data source creating middleware,

79
00:04:36.609 --> 00:04:40.840
essentially, connect in to that other
data source and the secure storage server

80
00:04:40.840 --> 00:04:44.740
stores credentials used to
access the other data source.

81
00:04:44.740 --> 00:04:49.430
The benefit here is that, individual users
can access a variety of data repositories

82
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:52.330
to do their work or pulling in data for
reports for example.

83
00:04:52.330 --> 00:04:54.740
Don't spend half their
time authenticating.

84
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:59.550
So we can move towards the holy grail of
single sign-on by leveraging the secure

85
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:01.950
store service.

86
00:05:01.950 --> 00:05:05.420
We'll also look at productivity services,
so we'll look at SharePoint apps and

87
00:05:05.420 --> 00:05:06.480
the app architecture.

88
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:13.800
Access services, PowerPoint automation
services, Word automation services.

89
00:05:13.800 --> 00:05:17.010
And we'll talk about solutions
as a way of introducing

90
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:19.870
functionality in your
SharePoint environment.

91
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:25.060
Connecting people, so
we'll talk about planning user profiles,

92
00:05:25.060 --> 00:05:28.520
my sites, profile synchronization.

93
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:32.900
We'll look at community sites as a way
of setting up discussion boards and

94
00:05:32.900 --> 00:05:37.310
fostering knowledge exchange
within your organization.

95
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:40.570
Web content managements
we'll look at as well.

96
00:05:40.570 --> 00:05:45.650
So especially considerations regarding
multiple locals and languages.

97
00:05:45.650 --> 00:05:48.740
We'll look at managed navigation and

98
00:05:49.790 --> 00:05:53.700
And web content management is part of
enterprise content management we'll look

99
00:05:53.700 --> 00:05:54.478
at that as well.

100
00:05:54.478 --> 00:05:57.620
So including e-discovery for

101
00:05:57.620 --> 00:06:02.640
legal discovery, records management
we'll cover in that episode as well.

102
00:06:02.640 --> 00:06:05.930
And site based retention policies.

103
00:06:05.930 --> 00:06:09.840
We'll also look at some BI solutions,
some really cool BI technologies like

104
00:06:09.840 --> 00:06:14.590
Power BI for example,
we can leverage within Office 365, so

105
00:06:14.590 --> 00:06:20.440
a variety of business intelligence tools
are available to us and productivity.

106
00:06:20.440 --> 00:06:24.880
So we'll look at integration with
SharePoint and project server and

107
00:06:24.880 --> 00:06:26.770
also project team sites.

108
00:06:26.770 --> 00:06:29.690
We'll show you how to set those up and

109
00:06:29.690 --> 00:06:32.580
project server integration
we'll talk about as well.

110
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:36.030
And also upgrading and
migrating to SharePoint 2016.

111
00:06:36.030 --> 00:06:41.020
So we'll look at planning considerations
before you consider upgrading and

112
00:06:41.020 --> 00:06:44.220
the flexibility in terms of
site collection upgrades and

113
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:46.660
then some advanced scenarios, as well.

114
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:51.440
So all this and more is coming at
you in these series of episodes.

115
00:06:51.440 --> 00:06:52.630
>> All right, Mark.

116
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:56.260
Fantastic, you've got me excited
about Advanced SharePoint 2016.

117
00:06:56.260 --> 00:07:00.930
I hope you are excited as I am,
so we are ready to get started.

118
00:07:00.930 --> 00:07:04.945
Hope to see you there.

119
00:07:04.945 --> 00:07:11.704
[SOUND]

episodes.title: SharePoint 2016 Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.413 --> 00:00:15.949
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.949 --> 00:00:20.411
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.411 --> 00:00:23.470
And specifically in this
episode we're gonna

5
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:25.720
be looking at Architectural design right?

6
00:00:25.720 --> 00:00:28.800
A very important part of
planning our SharePoint

7
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:30.360
architecture is figuring out what we need.

8
00:00:30.360 --> 00:00:32.510
How we're going to lay all that out and

9
00:00:32.510 --> 00:00:35.450
here to help us with that is
none other than Mr. Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:35.450 --> 00:00:36.290
How you doing Mark?

11
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.830
>> Good Mike, thanks very much,
good to be here.

12
00:00:38.830 --> 00:00:43.140
So many of you have watched
the first course on SharePoint 2016.

13
00:00:43.140 --> 00:00:48.155
This is the advanced course,
advanced meaning more thinking required.

14
00:00:48.155 --> 00:00:51.225
For some of you it's good news,
for some it's bad news.

15
00:00:51.225 --> 00:00:56.610
[LAUGH] As IT admins,
if you're like me, at

16
00:00:56.610 --> 00:01:02.230
least the old me, was very keen on
getting hands on technology immediately.

17
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:03.215
Planning's for other people.

18
00:01:03.215 --> 00:01:05.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> So is documentation for that matter,

19
00:01:05.400 --> 00:01:09.830
but no, if you're gonna progress
on from basic admin roles,

20
00:01:09.830 --> 00:01:15.560
planning and governance becomes more
a part of your day to day role.

21
00:01:15.560 --> 00:01:19.630
The actual doing, which we showed you
a lot of in the first course, and there'll

22
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:25.420
certainly be lots more demos this week,
the actual doing, people can do that.

23
00:01:25.420 --> 00:01:30.150
There's often guidance, checklist to
follow, but the planning in governance.

24
00:01:30.150 --> 00:01:36.040
That's where people fall down and as
the saying goes, you don't time to plan,

25
00:01:36.040 --> 00:01:40.575
you have to make time to plan later
after you've already deployed.

26
00:01:40.575 --> 00:01:42.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then it becomes more expensive and

27
00:01:42.300 --> 00:01:45.650
more of a headache
>> To undo or

28
00:01:45.650 --> 00:01:50.380
patch your existing environment in some
kind of model which is not optimal.

29
00:01:50.380 --> 00:01:54.350
So I realize that not everyone watching
will be starting fresh with their

30
00:01:54.350 --> 00:01:55.260
SharePoint environment.

31
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:57.932
You may have an older version of
SharePoint, hopefully not 2001.

32
00:01:57.932 --> 00:02:01.099
>> [LAUGH]
>> But let's say, more realistically,

33
00:02:01.099 --> 00:02:03.880
2007 or 2010 or 2013.

34
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:06.550
And some of you may be
looking to upgrade as well.

35
00:02:06.550 --> 00:02:13.415
So our last module this week, actually, is
on upgrading from SharePoint 2013 to 2016.

36
00:02:13.415 --> 00:02:19.100
That being said in the planning realm
we have to consider architecture.

37
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:22.730
Now that's a fundamental decision
that has to be made up front

38
00:02:22.730 --> 00:02:24.960
because it'll affect
other design decisions.

39
00:02:24.960 --> 00:02:27.780
Now in the old days of
SharePoint back in the 2001,

40
00:02:27.780 --> 00:02:32.450
2003 era some of you may have been
around that long in terms of SharePoint.

41
00:02:33.780 --> 00:02:36.420
We had a lot less flexibility.

42
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:38.900
In other words whatever architectural
model you chose in the beginning

43
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:42.140
you were stuck with absent
some major hacks that

44
00:02:42.140 --> 00:02:44.960
it would have been easier just to
start over with a brand new farm.

45
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:49.750
>> I remember being a newbie at SharePoint
and you would install and one of

46
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:53.610
the first things you had to choose was is
this going to be a stand alone or a farm.

47
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:57.590
And it gave you this big warning that
you can not change this after the fact.

48
00:02:57.590 --> 00:02:58.860
And I remember freezing right there and

49
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:02.620
going, okay, I can't go any further cause
I don't know which decision is right.

50
00:03:02.620 --> 00:03:05.610
>> It's a good thing your froze, because
a lot of people would say I can't stand

51
00:03:05.610 --> 00:03:06.735
the uncertainty, i'm just gonna pick one.

52
00:03:06.735 --> 00:03:09.642
>> [LAUGH]
>> I am hoping the boss did not find out

53
00:03:09.642 --> 00:03:11.540
or I hope I made the right choice.

54
00:03:11.540 --> 00:03:15.160
Well, with this episode we are gonna
help you make the right choice for

55
00:03:15.160 --> 00:03:18.830
your business and if you are a consultant
and you work with a variety of businesses.

56
00:03:18.830 --> 00:03:24.290
We will look at four different models,
one of which tends to be the more

57
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:28.520
logical choice, if you will for a given
customer or your environment at work.

58
00:03:28.520 --> 00:03:31.520
So let's look at those
four models shall we?

59
00:03:31.520 --> 00:03:35.120
We got again, four fundamental models

60
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:40.050
which we'll talk about in
detail in this episode.

61
00:03:40.050 --> 00:03:45.220
And Mike is kindly gonna
bring up the first model.

62
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:48.190
>> Very good, Diana one letter by
nowhere we're getting this diagram from.

63
00:03:48.190 --> 00:03:49.380
Make sure you guys can go out there and

64
00:03:49.380 --> 00:03:52.400
get the same information,
help you study, things like that.

65
00:03:52.400 --> 00:03:54.840
This is straight off a Microsoft site.

66
00:03:54.840 --> 00:03:59.790
Just do the Google search for
SharePoint 2016 Architectural Models.

67
00:03:59.790 --> 00:04:04.348
You can download the PDF and I've got
that already downloaded for us here, so

68
00:04:04.348 --> 00:04:07.309
let's start I guess,
Mark, with this diagram.

69
00:04:07.309 --> 00:04:08.634
>> Yeah, that's perfect, thanks, Mike.

70
00:04:08.634 --> 00:04:13.774
So in brief, the four architectural
models are SharePoint Online also known

71
00:04:13.774 --> 00:04:18.611
as Software as a service,
that's the first column represented there.

72
00:04:18.611 --> 00:04:23.881
We'll talk about different elements
of those columns shortly and this is

73
00:04:23.881 --> 00:04:29.670
a software as a service model, which means
your SharePoint is always up to date.

74
00:04:29.670 --> 00:04:31.130
You don't have to worry about patching,
but

75
00:04:31.130 --> 00:04:33.430
you do have to manage the SharePoint
content, which makes sense.

76
00:04:35.060 --> 00:04:37.810
Actually, I'll just describe all four and

77
00:04:37.810 --> 00:04:39.560
then we'll get into
more detail about them.

78
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:41.928
I've got to stop myself, I'm so
excited to talk about the models.

79
00:04:41.928 --> 00:04:44.931
>> [LAUGH]
>> Keep it focused on what makes sense to

80
00:04:44.931 --> 00:04:45.790
the viewer.

81
00:04:45.790 --> 00:04:51.771
So SharePoint hybrid, so
you've got SharePoint

82
00:04:51.771 --> 00:04:56.900
on premises and in online
component your SharePoint as well.

83
00:04:56.900 --> 00:05:02.080
So some of your SharePoint services
are hosted by Microsoft and

84
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:03.330
this is good for a couple of reasons.

85
00:05:03.330 --> 00:05:06.400
One is you can sort of dip
your toe in the water,

86
00:05:06.400 --> 00:05:09.580
in terms of storing some of your
content with SharePoint Online.

87
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:12.270
And then move workloads
increasingly as you become more

88
00:05:12.270 --> 00:05:14.680
comfortable working in
that online interface.

89
00:05:14.680 --> 00:05:16.260
Some organizations also pull back.

90
00:05:16.260 --> 00:05:19.240
So they might have had some
kind of workload in the clouds.

91
00:05:19.240 --> 00:05:21.330
I know we want to manage that on premises,
but

92
00:05:21.330 --> 00:05:22.830
we'll move this other
workload to the cloud.

93
00:05:22.830 --> 00:05:25.690
So it's a flexible dynamic
kind of architecture,

94
00:05:25.690 --> 00:05:27.600
if you choose the SharePoint Hybrid model.

95
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:30.030
The third model is SharePoint in Azure,

96
00:05:30.030 --> 00:05:32.970
that's the Infrastructure
as a Service model.

97
00:05:32.970 --> 00:05:34.690
This is great for high availability.

98
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:39.025
In other words, you can fail over to
Azure with virtually no downtime.

99
00:05:39.025 --> 00:05:43.303
So you want to have an on-prem,
that environment fail over to Azure, and

100
00:05:43.303 --> 00:05:46.090
also good for your test and
or dev environment.

101
00:05:46.090 --> 00:05:49.960
So that's, some of you may be familiar
with Azure, have some workload there or

102
00:05:49.960 --> 00:05:51.500
be experimenting with Azure.

103
00:05:51.500 --> 00:05:53.490
The fourth option is On-premesis.

104
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:55.500
So we've always had that option.

105
00:05:55.500 --> 00:05:58.010
You're handling everything to
do the SharePoint yourself.

106

So a group of five servers in your farm.

334
00:19:17.810 --> 00:19:20.370
For example, and
then you can see outbound requests so

335
00:19:20.370 --> 00:19:24.850
there's a line going across
the screen from right to left.

336
00:19:24.850 --> 00:19:26.750
Request headed to SharePoint online.

337
00:19:27.980 --> 00:19:30.530
And directory synchronization,
this is important.

338
00:19:30.530 --> 00:19:33.580
You want single sign-on, so people can
sign on with the same credentials.

339
00:19:33.580 --> 00:19:39.240
Whether they're accessing content on-prem,
or online through Microsoft Azure.

340
00:19:40.540 --> 00:19:44.799
And we also have Active Directory
Federation Services enabled as well,

341
00:19:46.540 --> 00:19:49.890
so this is a nice flexible model.

342
00:19:49.890 --> 00:19:50.560
Why?

343
00:19:50.560 --> 00:19:56.050
You can start slowly,
maybe you're ramping up skills, frankly,

344
00:19:56.050 --> 00:19:59.610
understanding how to utilize Office 365 so
you don't want to move everyone, let's say

345
00:19:59.610 --> 00:20:02.640
you have 1,000 employees, you don't want
to move everyone to the cloud right away.

346
00:20:02.640 --> 00:20:07.310
You're gonna have some test group, maybe
of 20 users asnd when you're choosing

347
00:20:07.310 --> 00:20:10.135
a test group, make sure it's people
that aren't likely to freak out.

348
00:20:10.135 --> 00:20:11.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which could include, but

349
00:20:11.880 --> 00:20:15.250
not necessarily people in the IT,
cuz we're all users, too, right?

350
00:20:15.250 --> 00:20:17.710
We're more knowledgeable
than the average user, but

351
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:19.150
at the end of the day we're still users.

352
00:20:20.170 --> 00:20:23.770
We want to have a seamless experience for
everyone, where possible.

353
00:20:23.770 --> 00:20:26.020
Okay, so we're gonna do a little trial.

354
00:20:26.020 --> 00:20:28.120
And then, as time goes on,
we get more comfortable.

355
00:20:28.120 --> 00:20:30.109
Maybe we're moving everyone to the cloud.

356
00:20:31.230 --> 00:20:33.890
We're hosting more site collections and
other resources in the cloud,

357
00:20:33.890 --> 00:20:37.340
and people are getting used to search
functionality, and the ability to search

358
00:20:37.340 --> 00:20:41.250
once and have results come from
either on-prem or on the cloud.

359
00:20:42.590 --> 00:20:46.559
All right, so speaking of search.

360
00:20:46.559 --> 00:20:50.203
Again, we can run search against
the whole SharePoint environment,

361
00:20:50.203 --> 00:20:54.093
which wasn't always the case it was
a bit kludgy before, in terms of having

362
00:20:54.093 --> 00:20:57.760
to actually execute separate searches for
on-prem and in the cloud.

363
00:20:59.230 --> 00:21:03.340
And in terms of user adoption,
anyone that's used a web browser,

364
00:21:03.340 --> 00:21:08.110
any kind of Office documents is not
going to be flummoxed by Office 365.

365
00:21:08.110 --> 00:21:08.760
There's the word of the day.

366
00:21:08.760 --> 00:21:09.670
>> That's a good one, yeah.

367
00:21:09.670 --> 00:21:10.880
>> I don't know where it came from.

368
00:21:12.080 --> 00:21:14.170
Too much Scrabble playing,
Dave, I don't know.

369
00:21:14.170 --> 00:21:18.528
Anyway, again you'll probably get some
help desk calls though because actions

370
00:21:18.528 --> 00:21:21.538
users could take on-prem and
can still take on-prem,

371
00:21:21.538 --> 00:21:24.310
they won't be able to do
necessarily in the cloud.

372
00:21:24.310 --> 00:21:25.860
So there's gonna be a learning curve.

373
00:21:25.860 --> 00:21:28.800
So I always stress this.

374
00:21:28.800 --> 00:21:33.110
If you don't have end-user training as
part of your SharePoint deployment,

375
00:21:33.110 --> 00:21:37.290
it's not gonna succeed, or
the success of it will be greatly limited.

376
00:21:37.290 --> 00:21:42.620
I'm not saying you need formal training,
certainly watching videos,

377
00:21:42.620 --> 00:21:45.810
maybe you're doing a lunch and
learn session.

378
00:21:45.810 --> 00:21:49.218
Three days a week, one week, and
come learn about SharePoint.

379
00:21:49.218 --> 00:21:52.900
They use to a little demo, or maybe it's
a video you put up on your intranet.

380
00:21:52.900 --> 00:21:56.660
But you can't just throw people in a new
environment and give them some emails.

381
00:21:56.660 --> 00:21:58.380
They will need some hand-holding.

382
00:21:58.380 --> 00:22:00.770
Another strategy that's very useful for
SharePoint, or

383
00:22:00.770 --> 00:22:05.920
any new technology deployment is
you give people a lot of lead time.

384
00:22:05.920 --> 00:22:09.940
Announce when a change is going to occur
and then you make a resource, one or

385
00:22:09.940 --> 00:22:15.700
two people per office depending on your
size, make them available to walk around

386
00:22:15.700 --> 00:22:20.010
for a day say, to help people as
they learn to use the new system.

387
00:22:20.010 --> 00:22:21.740
People will sabotage your efforts.

388
00:22:21.740 --> 00:22:26.484
Myself included, we generally hate change,

389
00:22:26.484 --> 00:22:30.810
even intellectually now this change is for
the better.

390
00:22:30.810 --> 00:22:32.900
This is going to be better,
I know it's better.

391
00:22:32.900 --> 00:22:34.910
Intellectually, to
understand it is better.

392
00:22:34.910 --> 00:22:37.070
Still there's a resistance.

393
00:22:37.070 --> 00:22:38.530
So make it easy on people.

394
00:22:38.530 --> 00:22:42.620
Provide formal or informal training or
have someone available.

395
00:22:42.620 --> 00:22:47.300
If you don't do it that way, you're gonna
get de facto training by someone who

396
00:22:47.300 --> 00:22:50.560
appears to know more than anyone
else in their particular work area.

397
00:22:50.560 --> 00:22:55.220
And they'll be bugged consistently because
you didn't assign or create a formal or

398
00:22:55.220 --> 00:22:56.444
informal training environment.

399
00:22:56.444 --> 00:22:58.720
So there's going to be some
kind of training going on,

400
00:22:58.720 --> 00:23:01.720
it might as well be training from
someone that knows what they're doing.

401
00:23:01.720 --> 00:23:02.360
Right?

402
00:23:02.360 --> 00:23:06.505
So maybe, again, maybe you train up one or
two people for a department, and they,

403
00:23:06.505 --> 00:23:10.655
sort of train the trainer format, they get
a authorized and encourage and required

404
00:23:10.655 --> 00:23:14.975
frankly, to train other users in the
department on the new way of doing things.

405
00:23:14.975 --> 00:23:19.275
Okay, so search,
another thing is it's useful with hybrid.

406
00:23:19.275 --> 00:23:24.045
OneDrive for Business, now there have
been some problems with OneDrive which

407
00:23:24.045 --> 00:23:28.480
many of them have been fixed and we'll
look at this as we go later in the week.

408
00:23:28.480 --> 00:23:30.850
And it's called now OneDrive for
Business redirect.

409
00:23:30.850 --> 00:23:32.880
It used to be SkyDrive.

410
00:23:32.880 --> 00:23:36.710
And then through trademark
litigation Microsoft lost, so

411
00:23:36.710 --> 00:23:38.630
they had to change the name to OneDrive.

412
00:23:38.630 --> 00:23:40.060
And now OneDrive for Business.

413
00:23:40.060 --> 00:23:43.280
The idea if you've used Dropbox
you kind of get the idea.

414
00:23:43.280 --> 00:23:47.590
And in terms of the redirect,
that means users may

415
00:23:47.590 --> 00:23:51.530
think they're saving on-prem, but
it's actually being stored in the Cloud.

416
00:23:51.530 --> 00:23:53.625
Just like folders
are redirection of desktop.

417
00:23:53.625 --> 00:23:57.320
Right, so
again with a more common Windows example,

418
00:23:57.320 --> 00:24:01.188
people have a folder on the desktop,
they assume that.

419
00:24:01.188 --> 00:24:05.813
Whatever content they put there lives on,
is stored on the desktop, but no,

420
00:24:05.813 --> 00:24:10.726
through policy setting, we can make sure
any content that gets saved there goes to

421
00:24:10.726 --> 00:24:15.351
a file folder on a file server where it
can be properly backed up and checked for

422
00:24:15.351 --> 00:24:17.920
compliance or audited or what have you.

423
00:24:17.920 --> 00:24:20.240
Same idea with one drive for
business redirect.

424
00:24:20.240 --> 00:24:24.580
This way you are putting that
storage in the cloud with all

425
00:24:24.580 --> 00:24:30.350
the high availability and built-in
backup capability that that entails.

426
00:24:30.350 --> 00:24:32.480
Now again, it's a workload.

427
00:24:32.480 --> 00:24:34.610
It's gonna cost you some
money to put in the cloud.

428
00:24:34.610 --> 00:24:38.560
It may or may not be worth the money
compared to buying more storage on-prem.

429
00:24:38.560 --> 00:24:42.100
So my point is,
there's lots of design decisions to make.

430
00:24:44.150 --> 00:24:50.250
And then some cloud services through
Office 365 include Office 365 video.

431
00:24:50.250 --> 00:24:52.630
That's kind of cool, because as you know,

432
00:24:52.630 --> 00:24:56.370
because you're watching this episode,
people love to learn from video.

433
00:24:56.370 --> 00:25:00.340
Or be entertained or
have information communicated that way.

434
00:25:00.340 --> 00:25:02.320
So the video is not going away.

435
00:25:02.320 --> 00:25:05.410
It's growing, becoming increasingly
popular whether it's YouTube videos,

436
00:25:05.410 --> 00:25:07.980
Facebook Live Facebook streams now.

437
00:25:07.980 --> 00:25:10.750
I forget what they call it,
Facebook Live or something.

438
00:25:10.750 --> 00:25:12.920
Even MPR is live and

439
00:25:12.920 --> 00:25:18.100
now it's frankly cluttered up my Facebook
feed, but the point is people love video.

440
00:25:18.100 --> 00:25:19.740
And a lot of organizations,

441
00:25:19.740 --> 00:25:23.049
they wouldn't necessarily want
to invest in storage space.

442
00:25:24.060 --> 00:25:28.320
But with Office 365 it's very flexible,
and a great thing about Azure and

443
00:25:28.320 --> 00:25:32.440
SharePoint online and Office 365,
it's pay for what you use.

444
00:25:32.440 --> 00:25:33.640
It lets you ramp up and

445
00:25:33.640 --> 00:25:38.340
scale back very easily on the fly,
well not really on the fly.

446
00:25:38.340 --> 00:25:42.610
It's a very flexible solution as
opposed to budgeting, planning,

447
00:25:42.610 --> 00:25:47.250
requesting funding for, say,
a few terabytes more storage on-prem.

448
00:25:47.250 --> 00:25:50.200
Well that could take a year, right,
depending on the bureaucracy and

449
00:25:50.200 --> 00:25:51.400
how big your organization is.

450
00:25:51.400 --> 00:25:56.170
So Delve is very cool, the Office graph,

451
00:25:56.170 --> 00:25:58.740
this is available to you
in a hybrid environment.

452
00:25:58.740 --> 00:26:01.200
And it's like Facebook
graph if you used that.

453
00:26:01.200 --> 00:26:03.390
Remember Microsoft bought 5% of Facebook.

454
00:26:03.390 --> 00:26:07.550
So you're going to see some cross
pollination just like all companies,

455
00:26:07.550 --> 00:26:10.060
borrow, steal, reinvent from others.

456
00:26:10.060 --> 00:26:14.080
So this is a great way for
users to find out information

457
00:26:14.080 --> 00:26:18.350
about other people in their organization
or filter based on various parameters.

458
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:21.640
Just like you could with office graph.

459
00:26:21.640 --> 00:26:23.497
So what would be the benefit or

460
00:26:23.497 --> 00:26:27.823
what kind of people should gravitate
towards a hybrid environment?

461
00:26:27.823 --> 00:26:32.906
Again, you can move workloads
to the cloud at your own pace,

462
00:26:32.906 --> 00:26:36.030
you may not wanna set up an extranet.

463
00:26:36.030 --> 00:26:39.461
So if you were called from
the first SharePoint week,

464
00:26:39.461 --> 00:26:44.414
it can be quite cumbersome to set up
external sharing or set up an extranet, or

465
00:26:44.414 --> 00:26:49.677
provide a federated services to provide
a partner organization state with access

466
00:26:49.677 --> 00:26:54.583
to some of your Active Directory
infrastructure, or resources on-prem.

467
00:26:54.583 --> 00:26:58.199
So instead of setting up an extranet
you can use Office 365 as a way

468
00:26:58.199 --> 00:27:01.310
of setting up external sharing and
collaboration.

469
00:27:01.310 --> 00:27:02.750
So that might be of interest to you.

470
00:27:04.470 --> 00:27:09.070
Now again, I mentioned in

471
00:27:09.070 --> 00:27:13.800
user training well it's also in
terms of SharePoint admin skills.

472
00:27:13.800 --> 00:27:18.210
You want to develop those overtime and
by using this hybrid model again,

473
00:27:18.210 --> 00:27:20.620
I give an example using,
putting twenty uses to the cloud.

474
00:27:20.620 --> 00:27:24.970
Or maybe it's just you the IT admin maybe
you're the only user for a week or two.

475
00:27:24.970 --> 00:27:28.790
And you're experimenting and
know that whatever you do it's only

476
00:27:28.790 --> 00:27:31.010
probably gonna effect you and
not others in your organization.

477
00:27:31.010 --> 00:27:35.780
So getting your skills up to speed and
having an environment to do that without

478
00:27:35.780 --> 00:27:40.500
risk is another compelling reason
to use the hybrid environment.

479
00:27:42.190 --> 00:27:45.210
And again you might want to reduce
your on premises footprint.

480
00:27:46.730 --> 00:27:51.410
So your architecture tasks, you want to
plan your network con activity between you

481
00:27:51.410 --> 00:27:54.655
on pram and your o 360 E5 environment.

482
00:27:54.655 --> 00:28:00.335
You will be required to set up server
to server trusts using certificates.

483
00:28:00.335 --> 00:28:02.521
Figure out your identity
synchronization model.

484
00:28:02.521 --> 00:28:06.914
Do you wanna synchronize your on-prem
with Azure Active Directory, for example.

485
00:28:06.914 --> 00:28:10.502
Are you gonna move your
user profiles from your

486
00:28:10.502 --> 00:28:14.004
SharePoint online environment to O365?

487
00:28:14.004 --> 00:28:14.626
And again,

488
00:28:14.626 --> 00:28:18.432
what features do you wanna enable do
wanna enable in SharePoint online?

489
00:28:18.432 --> 00:28:21.776
What work loads do wanna move to the
cloud, keep in your mind, you're not gonna

490
00:28:21.776 --> 00:28:25.936
be able to do everything you can on prem
in the SharePoint online environment.

491
00:28:27.586 --> 00:28:31.306
And then if you wanna use the OneDrive for
Business redirect,

492
00:28:33.216 --> 00:28:38.870
first decide to do that, and then plan how
that content is gonna move to the cloud.

493
00:28:38.870 --> 00:28:40.650
In terms of licensing requirements and

494
00:28:40.650 --> 00:28:45.160
subscription models with Office
365 the subscriptions cover it.

495
00:28:45.160 --> 00:28:47.736
So again per user per month,
no additional licensing required.

496
00:28:47.736 --> 00:28:53.638
And then on-prem as you probably know
if you've got an existing environment,

497
00:28:53.638 --> 00:28:57.250
you'll need your Server 2012 R2 license,

498
00:28:57.250 --> 00:29:01.302
your SharePoint 2016 server license and
CALs, so

499
00:29:01.302 --> 00:29:06.961
client access license and their
SQL Server 2014 SP1 license or later.

500
00:29:10.476 --> 00:29:14.025
Okay, housekeeping.

501
00:29:14.025 --> 00:29:14.655
I got one more.

502
00:29:14.655 --> 00:29:15.368
I could probably [CROSSTALK]
I got 8 minutes left.

503
00:29:15.368 --> 00:29:17.573
>> We got one or two more models to go?

504
00:29:17.573 --> 00:29:19.605
>> I got one more I believe.

505
00:29:19.605 --> 00:29:20.435
No, two.
>> Yeah.

506
00:29:20.435 --> 00:29:21.198
>> Yeah.
>> We got IaaS as well.

507
00:29:21.198 --> 00:29:23.055
>> [CROSSTALK] another episode,
If we could.

508
00:29:23.055 --> 00:29:24.065
>> Very good.
>> Yup.

509
00:29:24.065 --> 00:29:25.285
>> All right, ladies and gentlemen.

510
00:29:25.285 --> 00:29:28.905
As we covered two of the four models,
unfortunately we are out of time for

511
00:29:28.905 --> 00:29:30.095
this particular episode.

512
00:29:30.095 --> 00:29:31.965
So what we're going to do is
we're going to break this one.

513
00:29:31.965 --> 00:29:36.550
We'll come back with a part 2 and
cover we've got the IaaS or

514
00:29:36.550 --> 00:29:39.070
the infrastructure as a service model.

515
00:29:39.070 --> 00:29:42.660
And we've got the complete
on-prem model to go as well.

516
00:29:42.660 --> 00:29:43.430
So Mark, we thank you for

517
00:29:43.430 --> 00:29:46.380
those great discussions here
on those first two models.

518
00:29:46.380 --> 00:29:47.880
Hope everybody enjoyed watching.

519
00:29:47.880 --> 00:29:50.410
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

520
00:29:50.410 --> 00:29:50.950
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

521
00:29:50.950 --> 00:29:54.059
>> And we'll see you next time.

522
00:29:54.059 --> 00:30:01.980
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: SharePoint 2016 Architecture Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.087 --> 00:00:10.087
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.426 --> 00:00:15.901
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.901 --> 00:00:20.623
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.623 --> 00:00:25.098
And specifically in this episode we're
actually continuing our thought process,

5
00:00:25.098 --> 00:00:28.700
this is a part two to our SharePoint
architectural design, right?

6
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:32.040
We've got a couple more models
that we've gotta go over, and

7
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:34.170
here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

8
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:35.010
How you doing, Mark?

9
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:36.360
>> Good, Mike, thank you.

10
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:39.630
Let's move right along with
our third of four models.

11
00:00:39.630 --> 00:00:43.474
This is the on-prem model,
which many of you will be familiar with,

12
00:00:43.474 --> 00:00:46.802
the traditional way of getting
involved with SharePoint.

13
00:00:46.802 --> 00:00:51.183
Maybe some test environment or
full-fledged on-premises environment.

14
00:00:51.183 --> 00:00:54.785
So this may or may not look
exactly like your environment, but

15
00:00:54.785 --> 00:00:56.820
the principles do apply.

16
00:00:56.820 --> 00:01:00.230
You've got some users
clustered together there.

17
00:01:00.230 --> 00:01:02.250
They look like little chemical bonds.

18
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:04.476
Maybe if you put them together the right
way, they make caffeine, I'm not sure.

19
00:01:04.476 --> 00:01:07.492
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Anyway, and users,

20
00:01:07.492 --> 00:01:13.805
actually before I go there, on the bottom,
you can see the request arrow, so requests

21
00:01:13.805 --> 00:01:19.290
go from left to right in this diagram,
and replies go from right to left.

22
00:01:19.290 --> 00:01:22.940
So in other words, the users on
the left are never interacting with

23
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:27.750
the database server clusters directly
on the right-hand side, but rather,

24
00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:31.570
they interact with one or
more front end servers.

25
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:35.600
And in fact, for the demos that
we'll be seeing throughout the week,

26
00:01:35.600 --> 00:01:38.250
this is our on-prem
equivalent environment,

27
00:01:38.250 --> 00:01:44.040
where we have a representative of
these different layers, if you like.

28
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:48.603
So we'll have a web front end server,
distributed cache, application server,

29
00:01:48.603 --> 00:01:51.090
search server and database server.

30
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:53.215
So we don't have the clustering but
the point is,

31
00:01:53.215 --> 00:01:56.460
you get the idea of the tiers
available in SharePoint.

32
00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:57.840
And we'll talk more about that later.

33
00:01:57.840 --> 00:02:00.752
I'll resist the urge to go into
more detail now, but the point is,

34
00:02:00.752 --> 00:02:04.081
this is gonna be something like what
your on-prem environment looks like,

35
00:02:04.081 --> 00:02:05.810
if you have any kind of workload at all.

36
00:02:05.810 --> 00:02:10.597
And it's not just a simple single machine
or a two machine test environment.

37
00:02:10.597 --> 00:02:15.640
So, and
it's very expandable as needed as well.

38
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:18.139
Flexible in terms of if
you want to add resources,

39
00:02:19.560 --> 00:02:24.590
often due to poor performance or expected
capacity being reached for a given server.

40
00:02:24.590 --> 00:02:28.960
>> And with an architecture like this, it
looks like it would really lead itself or

41
00:02:28.960 --> 00:02:33.620
lend itself to be enabled to expand
one particular area, not everything.

42
00:02:33.620 --> 00:02:36.320
If I found that my front ends
weren't carrying the workload right,

43
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:37.660
I can add a front end server.

44
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:40.140
It's not gonna affect my
database in the back.

45
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:42.990
>> Exactly, so
you've got that flexibility.

46
00:02:42.990 --> 00:02:44.760
And you'll always be measuring as well.

47
00:02:44.760 --> 00:02:48.360
There's a built in measuring tool
that SharePoint has to alert you.

48
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:51.930
And then, as we talked about
extensively in the first course,

49
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:56.590
Systems Center Operations Manager has a
management pack just for SharePoint 2016.

50
00:02:56.590 --> 00:03:00.670
And because there's so
many technologies related to SharePoint,

51
00:03:00.670 --> 00:03:06.570
you're gonna have management packs for
Windows Server, SQL Server, and more.

52
00:03:06.570 --> 00:03:10.039
IIS, even there's a management pack for,
so, the point is,

53
00:03:10.039 --> 00:03:12.331
some things unexpected will, happen but

54
00:03:12.331 --> 00:03:16.796
lot of what's going on your SharePoint
environment shouldn't be surprising.

55
00:03:16.796 --> 00:03:21.392
Or you'll be alerted enough in advance
to be able to plan appropriately either

56
00:03:21.392 --> 00:03:24.735
by throttling some workload,
adding another machine,

57
00:03:24.735 --> 00:03:28.791
establishing quotas maybe if your
storage base is growing too high.

58
00:03:28.791 --> 00:03:30.477
Okay, I went on a tangent there.

59
00:03:30.477 --> 00:03:32.605
>> [LAUGH]
>> Gotta focus.

60
00:03:32.605 --> 00:03:35.540
All right, more and
more caffeine is always the answer.

61
00:03:35.540 --> 00:03:37.570
Okay, so this is a traditional model.

62
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:43.090
Again, you have an enterprise agreement in
terms of licensing or volume licensing.

63
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:46.450
And Microsoft,
you can buy support as well.

64
00:03:46.450 --> 00:03:49.940
In fact, you're gonna get X number
of hours of support annually anyway,

65
00:03:49.940 --> 00:03:51.330
depending on your license.

66
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:53.810
You could buy more if you need it.

67
00:03:53.810 --> 00:03:54.542
Okay, so

68
00:03:54.542 --> 00:03:59.680
what are your tasks architecturally
on premises with this model?

69
00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:04.457
Well, you want to figure out what
SharePoint services your organization

70
00:04:04.457 --> 00:04:05.003
needs.

71
00:04:05.003 --> 00:04:07.790
And when we look at new features
in a different episode,

72
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:10.934
very exciting, we'll look at
a way that that's automated for

73
00:04:10.934 --> 00:04:15.060
you, in terms of once you've
decided what services are required.

74
00:04:15.060 --> 00:04:19.760
And you still need to design a farm
topology and logical architecture, and

75
00:04:19.760 --> 00:04:23.200
we covered that at length in
our first course as well.

76
00:04:23.200 --> 00:04:26.720
You'll need to size the hardware
appropriately, again, by measuring,

77
00:04:26.720 --> 00:04:28.430
you can adjust on the fly.

78
00:04:28.430 --> 00:04:34.090
You can use a physical or virtual workload
or some combination thereof, depending

79
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:36.990
on what you're currently using and
where you see your organization headed.

80
00:04:36.990 --> 00:04:39.145
Some organizations have
virtualized the whole workload.

81
00:04:39.145 --> 00:04:43.310
You'll also be responsible for
validation testing, especially for

82
00:04:43.310 --> 00:04:44.895
customizations or apps.

83
00:04:44.895 --> 00:04:46.650
Running custom apps you may have created,

84
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:49.038
running your SharePoint
on-prem environment.

85
00:04:49.038 --> 00:04:52.210
And then your DR environment, so
one of the nice things about one

86
00:04:52.210 --> 00:04:57.130
of the online models, which we talked
about in a different episode, is that at

87
00:04:57.130 --> 00:05:02.130
least some of your DR can be handled
automagically through Azure.

88
00:05:02.130 --> 00:05:07.100
If you're using all SharePoint, it's all
on-prem, then disaster recovery again is

89
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:10.380
back, the ball is in your court for
making sure you have a plan there.

90
00:05:11.780 --> 00:05:17.010
Okay so, under what circumstances
does this model make sense for

91
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:19.870
you or
an organization you work with or for?

92
00:05:19.870 --> 00:05:23.639
Well, maybe you've got
customized solutions.

93
00:05:23.639 --> 00:05:27.669
In fact, they're so customized that
there's no resources to try and

94
00:05:27.669 --> 00:05:32.200
figure out how to make that workload
work in a SharePoint Online environment.

95
00:05:32.200 --> 00:05:34.010
It's just probably not gonna work.

96
00:05:34.010 --> 00:05:36.250
And even if it does, it's gonna require so

97
00:05:36.250 --> 00:05:38.590
much work to adjust
that it's not worth it.

98
00:05:38.590 --> 00:05:44.511
So that is a good indication to keep
all or some of the workload on prem.

99
00:05:45.760 --> 00:05:48.400
Now, you might have
governance issues again,

100
00:05:48.400 --> 00:05:51.805
relating to the laws about
where data can reside.

101
00:05:52.890 --> 00:05:57.010
Now Microsoft, depending on the,
if you're a government organization or

102
00:05:57.010 --> 00:06:00.080
what industry you work in, or what
country or even what state you work in,

103
00:06:00.080 --> 00:06:02.600
there may be laws, again,
about where that data can be stored.

104
00:06:02.600 --> 00:06:05.300
So online might not be
a legitimate option.

105
00:06:05.300 --> 00:06:09.950
Or as Microsoft adds more data
centers around the world,

106
00:06:09.950 --> 00:06:15.330
Canada, for example, came online in
2016 in Toronto and Quebec City.

107
00:06:15.330 --> 00:06:19.630
Before that point,
government organizations and others had

108
00:06:19.630 --> 00:06:23.620
a legitimate concern that they would lose
sovereignty of the data, essentially.

109
00:06:23.620 --> 00:06:28.086
If it's stored out of country, basically,
they're losing control of the ability to

110
00:06:28.086 --> 00:06:31.957
have it audited or prevent auditing,
that sort of thing, or prying eyes.

111
00:06:31.957 --> 00:06:34.957
Now, the whole data prying,
I'm not gonna go there,

112
00:06:34.957 --> 00:06:37.707
because that has to be a whole course,
actually.

113
00:06:37.707 --> 00:06:38.768
>> [LAUGH] Right.

114
00:06:38.768 --> 00:06:39.903
>> Guest speaker, Edward Snowden.

115
00:06:39.903 --> 00:06:42.148
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just kidding.

116
00:06:42.148 --> 00:06:45.540
Okay, but the point is,
that's a legitimate concern.

117
00:06:45.540 --> 00:06:46.630
If you're a government organization,

118
00:06:46.630 --> 00:06:49.130
you don't necessarily want your
data going out of the country.

119
00:06:49.130 --> 00:06:52.989
So you may want to wait for
Microsoft, for example,

120
00:06:52.989 --> 00:06:57.828
to provide cloud solutions
physically located in your country.

121
00:06:57.828 --> 00:06:59.060
>> Mm-hm.

122
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:01.839
>> You might have a private
cloud solution, which again,

123
00:07:01.839 --> 00:07:04.980
SharePoint, entirely on-prem
would lend itself to nicely.

124
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:10.280
You might have a situation where
you've got third party components or

125
00:07:10.280 --> 00:07:14.508
some kind of legacy solution provided by
some vendor that's no longer in business.

126
00:07:14.508 --> 00:07:18.870
The hardware and/or software combination
might not work with Azure, for

127
00:07:18.870 --> 00:07:21.210
example, might not be supported on Azure.

128
00:07:21.210 --> 00:07:23.380
So then you have to use
an on-prem workload.

129
00:07:24.960 --> 00:07:27.370
And you might have also
privacy restrictions.

130
00:07:27.370 --> 00:07:30.460
We talked about having
a Active Directory on-premises.

131
00:07:30.460 --> 00:07:33.300
And then if you go this route
in Azure Active Directory,

132
00:07:33.300 --> 00:07:35.960
you may not be allowed to
synchronize between on-prem and

133
00:07:35.960 --> 00:07:38.565
Azure Active Directory again for
a legal or business reasons.

134
00:07:38.565 --> 00:07:39.280
>> Mm-hm.

135
00:07:39.280 --> 00:07:40.850
>> And those are legitimate concerns.

136
00:07:40.850 --> 00:07:44.362
I'm not knocking any one of these
solutions because as you can see,

137
00:07:44.362 --> 00:07:48.438
there's different reasons that make good
sense to use one of the four models.

138
00:07:48.438 --> 00:07:53.098
And maybe, frankly, a model that makes
sense today might not make sense tomorrow,

139
00:07:53.098 --> 00:07:56.000
depending on the direction
your business is going.

140
00:07:56.000 --> 00:08:00.100
Maybe they wanted to redeploy some
of the IT staff, for example.

141
00:08:00.100 --> 00:08:02.870
Then you might lose a database
administrator from the organization

142
00:08:02.870 --> 00:08:03.866
because Microsoft realizes,

143
00:08:03.866 --> 00:08:07.700
we can just have Microsoft do it by
moving the workload to the cloud.

144
00:08:07.700 --> 00:08:12.230
>> You might have gone on-premises
because you've got legacy software.

145
00:08:12.230 --> 00:08:15.150
And now comes time where we don't
need that software anymore.

146
00:08:15.150 --> 00:08:17.790
So now we can think about
moving up to the cloud.

147
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:18.450
>> Excellent point.

148
00:08:18.450 --> 00:08:20.580
Yes, so circumstances can change.

149
00:08:20.580 --> 00:08:21.740
Maybe you go with a new vendor for

150
00:08:21.740 --> 00:08:25.530
whatever that software used
to handle in your business.

151
00:08:25.530 --> 00:08:26.230
Good point.

152
00:08:26.230 --> 00:08:30.870
Now, there's also control issues which
sometimes are more political than

153
00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:32.060
technical.

154
00:08:32.060 --> 00:08:34.020
And again, I'm not knocking it.

155
00:08:34.020 --> 00:08:35.852
Frankly, who doesn't want more control?

156
00:08:35.852 --> 00:08:38.853
>> [LAUGH]
>> I do.

157
00:08:38.853 --> 00:08:40.537
There's at least one.

158
00:08:40.537 --> 00:08:44.788
So you might want end to end control
over your data, where it lives,

159
00:08:44.788 --> 00:08:46.290
where it's backed up.

160
00:08:46.290 --> 00:08:50.640
And still, there's gonna be some maybe
old school business people, for example,

161
00:08:50.640 --> 00:08:54.460
that just aren't comfortable,
they don't even know what the cloud is.

162
00:08:54.460 --> 00:08:58.437
They're not comfortable not knowing where
the data is, and that might be something

163
00:08:58.437 --> 00:09:02.314
that's just not gonna change, you're
not gonna convince them that it's safe.

164
00:09:02.314 --> 00:09:05.758
Although nowadays it's so
ubiquitous and so

165
00:09:05.758 --> 00:09:12.280
mainstream that even those kinds of
reactions or resistances are fading away.

166
00:09:12.280 --> 00:09:15.409
Especially if a business person,
for example,

167
00:09:15.409 --> 00:09:20.448
sees their competitor realize huge cost
savings in terms of human resources,

168
00:09:20.448 --> 00:09:24.005
hardware, data storage,
high availability, etc.

169
00:09:24.005 --> 00:09:28.862
Then they're going to start thinking,
if I'm the laggard here,

170
00:09:28.862 --> 00:09:33.275
and 80% of my competitors
have utilized some resource,

171
00:09:33.275 --> 00:09:36.905
then I'm essentially wasting money,
and I'm falling behind.

172
00:09:36.905 --> 00:09:39.725
So even those people can come around, or
maybe they leave the organization, and

173
00:09:39.725 --> 00:09:43.625
the next person is far more,
maybe not experimental,

174
00:09:43.625 --> 00:09:47.525
but far more at least willing to try new
solutions rather than just stick with

175
00:09:47.525 --> 00:09:49.780
the way it's always been done.

176
00:09:49.780 --> 00:09:53.146
Again, if you've been
watching this episode or

177
00:09:53.146 --> 00:09:57.992
other episodes on SharePoint 2016
architecture in this course,

178
00:09:57.992 --> 00:10:01.750
a lot of what we're talking
about is not technical.

179
00:10:01.750 --> 00:10:05.910
It's related to governance and
planning and decision making.

180
00:10:07.190 --> 00:10:09.880
Okay, so, licensing requirements.

181
00:10:09.880 --> 00:10:15.786
You need a Server 2012 R2 license,
you'll need SQL 2014 SP1,

182
00:10:15.786 --> 00:10:21.407
SharePoint 2016 Server license and
a sufficient number of CALs,

183
00:10:21.407 --> 00:10:26.280
Client Access Licenses, for
SharePoint 2016 as well.

184
00:10:27.990 --> 00:10:30.590
All right,
that brings us to our last model, and

185
00:10:30.590 --> 00:10:34.270
this is SharePoint 2016
in Microsoft Azure.

186
00:10:36.040 --> 00:10:39.750
Okay, so this scenario,

187
00:10:39.750 --> 00:10:43.340
you're offloading your servers to
Azure infrastructure as a service.

188
00:10:43.340 --> 00:10:47.829
You still control your
SharePoint 2016 environment, but

189
00:10:47.829 --> 00:10:52.494
as you can see from the slide,
the entire farm is hosted in Azure.

190
00:10:52.494 --> 00:10:54.289
How cool is that?

191
00:10:54.289 --> 00:10:55.231
>> That's sweet.

192
00:10:55.231 --> 00:10:56.790
[LAUGH] I like that.

193
00:10:56.790 --> 00:10:59.345
Cuz now they're taking care
of the infrastructure,

194
00:10:59.345 --> 00:11:03.206
you're just basically deciding, having
the machines you need at the different

195
00:11:03.206 --> 00:11:05.635
tiers or if you're gonna do the tiers.

196
00:11:05.635 --> 00:11:08.895
They're gonna take care of a lot
of that background work for you.

197
00:11:08.895 --> 00:11:13.195
>> Exactly, so it's the ultimate
in delegation, if you will.

198
00:11:13.195 --> 00:11:16.425
Now some of you have
experimented with Azure,

199
00:11:16.425 --> 00:11:19.290
may be running actual
business workloads in Azure.

200
00:11:19.290 --> 00:11:22.946
It can take a while to
navigate that platform, or

201
00:11:22.946 --> 00:11:27.593
the menu options,
which again are always subject to change.

202
00:11:27.593 --> 00:11:31.281
But once you've got some experience
provisioning machines in Azure, then you

203
00:11:31.281 --> 00:11:35.257
realize, it's just another interface,
and we're using interfaces all day.

204
00:11:35.257 --> 00:11:38.979
So in a sense, who cares whether
it's in the cloud or on prem,

205
00:11:38.979 --> 00:11:42.486
it's just an interface we need
to have some mastery over,

206
00:11:42.486 --> 00:11:47.870
and be willing to be flexible, learn as
new options come or some other options go.

207
00:11:47.870 --> 00:11:50.090
But from a management perspective, I mean,

208
00:11:50.090 --> 00:11:56.100
you can see almost the entire slide
shows resources hosted in Azure.

209
00:11:56.100 --> 00:11:58.720
Now from the end user
perspective on the left there,

210
00:11:58.720 --> 00:12:03.600
they can access through port 80 or
443 for SSL.

211
00:12:03.600 --> 00:12:06.500
And just like with our
on-prem architecture example,

212
00:12:06.500 --> 00:12:10.540
you can see the tiers look very similar,
because they are.

213
00:12:10.540 --> 00:12:14.126
I mean, from a user perspective, do they
really care where the resource is hosted?

214
00:12:14.126 --> 00:12:14.937
>> No.

215
00:12:14.937 --> 00:12:18.157
>> No, they just wanna know
that they can access it,

216
00:12:18.157 --> 00:12:22.459
whether it's a file share,
a website, content hosted in Azure.

217
00:12:22.459 --> 00:12:25.841
They don't need to know or care,
just tell them how to get there,

218
00:12:25.841 --> 00:12:30.226
maybe it's a shortcut or favorite on their
browser, and boom, they're in there.

219
00:12:30.226 --> 00:12:34.896
Okay, some other components here, we've
got Windows Server Active Directory and

220
00:12:34.896 --> 00:12:38.000
DNS also hosted in Azure, so
that has to be maintained.

221
00:12:39.830 --> 00:12:43.401
Although Azure definitely helps
you with the setup for DNS,

222
00:12:43.401 --> 00:12:46.050
but there is some work
that you need to do.

223
00:12:46.050 --> 00:12:52.252
And then in terms of, on the right hand
of the screen there, an on-premises

224
00:12:52.252 --> 00:12:57.450
connection, you can use a VPN tunnel,
you can also use express route.

225
00:12:57.450 --> 00:13:00.240
So this is something that costs you more,

226
00:13:00.240 --> 00:13:03.520
I mean you get a bigger
pipe to the Azure content.

227
00:13:04.980 --> 00:13:10.915
So that's something to consider
depending on your requirements there.

228
00:13:10.915 --> 00:13:15.285
Now, so, again the whole
farm is hosted in Azure, and

229
00:13:15.285 --> 00:13:19.465
it's great because it hosts SQL for
your backend and

230
00:13:19.465 --> 00:13:24.410
SharePoint various resources,
it's so flexible, Azure.

231
00:13:24.410 --> 00:13:25.080
That's why I love it.

232
00:13:25.080 --> 00:13:28.850
You get instant ramp up and
modification on the fly.

233
00:13:30.630 --> 00:13:34.490
No commitment, so there's no long-term
commitment like there would be if you were

234
00:13:34.490 --> 00:13:38.300
buying a data center worth of servers,
for example.

235
00:13:38.300 --> 00:13:42.290
It's totally flexible, scale up,
scale down as needed in advance, for

236
00:13:42.290 --> 00:13:44.420
example, of expected peak times.

237
00:13:44.420 --> 00:13:46.320
Every business has peak times.

238
00:13:46.320 --> 00:13:49.920
If you're retail, then Christmas time
would be, or after Black Friday,

239
00:13:49.920 --> 00:13:50.840
I guess, for a month.

240
00:13:50.840 --> 00:13:54.860
So you know this, you can plan for
it, you can execute it on the day.

241
00:13:54.860 --> 00:13:58.490
Again, it's pay for what you use.

242
00:13:58.490 --> 00:14:00.770
This lets you focus on applications.

243
00:14:00.770 --> 00:14:03.690
A lot of people use SharePoint as
a dev environment to customize.

244
00:14:03.690 --> 00:14:06.680
So your organization could focus
on that element of the work,

245
00:14:06.680 --> 00:14:11.420
that aspect as opposed to
the infrastructure and the data centers.

246
00:14:11.420 --> 00:14:13.688
So another compelling advantage there.

247
00:14:13.688 --> 00:14:20.127
And you can, in terms of various software
solutions that you may introduce,

248
00:14:20.127 --> 00:14:25.380
you could make them accessible
only from users on premises.

249
00:14:25.380 --> 00:14:28.660
In other words, they have to go through
your VPN or express route tunnel.

250
00:14:28.660 --> 00:14:33.130
Or you can say that anyone with a browser
can access those solutions directly from

251
00:14:33.130 --> 00:14:38.607
any browser, they don't have to first
go in through your on-prem environment.

252
00:14:38.607 --> 00:14:41.820
And then you've got far more
flexibility in terms of customization

253
00:14:41.820 --> 00:14:45.210
as well because remember, this is
the actual software for SharePoint,

254
00:14:45.210 --> 00:14:47.952
SQL, etc.,
running in a hosted environment.

255
00:14:47.952 --> 00:14:51.150
In Azure, but you don't have those
customization restrictions that you would

256
00:14:51.150 --> 00:14:53.610
if you were to use SharePoint Online.

257
00:14:53.610 --> 00:14:55.560
So that's good, too.

258
00:14:55.560 --> 00:14:59.030
So what are your architecture tasks
if you decide to go this route?

259
00:14:59.030 --> 00:15:01.562
Well, you've gotta design
your Azure virtual network.

260
00:15:01.562 --> 00:15:04.909
So again, it could take a while to set up
things we're used to doing on prem with

261
00:15:04.909 --> 00:15:05.833
our familiar tools.

262
00:15:05.833 --> 00:15:10.109
It does take a while to learn the new
interface of Azure to set up some basic

263
00:15:10.109 --> 00:15:12.774
things like networking, virtual network,

264
00:15:12.774 --> 00:15:17.420
it's the kind of thing that once you've
done it once, it becomes far easier.

265
00:15:17.420 --> 00:15:20.040
It's probably gonna take
you longer the first time.

266
00:15:20.040 --> 00:15:22.020
Just, that's the way it is.

267
00:15:22.020 --> 00:15:27.707
You want to design your domain environment
and integration with your on-prem servers.

268
00:15:27.707 --> 00:15:34.549
Let's see,
you wanna use the min rule architecture.

269
00:15:34.549 --> 00:15:39.129
We'll look at the min
rule in a later episode,

270
00:15:39.129 --> 00:15:43.598
when we talk about new features of 2016.

271
00:15:43.598 --> 00:15:47.570
You wanna have virtual machine sizes,
you wanna pick those.

272
00:15:47.570 --> 00:15:49.989
External endpoints,
no need for public access.

273
00:15:53.170 --> 00:15:54.730
Okay so this is best for,

274
00:15:54.730 --> 00:15:58.565
this environment is best for,
if we go back to the diagram, please.

275
00:15:58.565 --> 00:16:00.500
>> Mm-hm.

276
00:16:00.500 --> 00:16:03.330
>> Public facing sites
that use Azure AD for

277
00:16:03.330 --> 00:16:06.920
accounts authentication
>> It's great if you just wanna set up

278
00:16:06.920 --> 00:16:10.520
a dev environment or testing or
staging environment and then tear it down.

279
00:16:10.520 --> 00:16:14.780
And of course, you can automate this
process as well, which is handy.

280
00:16:14.780 --> 00:16:17.840
If you have an application that you
need to expand both on-prem and

281
00:16:17.840 --> 00:16:19.560
cloud resources, you can use Azure.

282
00:16:21.240 --> 00:16:25.890
Very good for
a recovery environment as well, and

283
00:16:25.890 --> 00:16:28.330
data encryption at rest,
that might be important to you,

284
00:16:28.330 --> 00:16:32.660
so by default, data is encrypted
in SQL databases in Azure.

285
00:16:32.660 --> 00:16:36.699
So, especially today, when there's so
many, maybe not daily, but

286
00:16:36.699 --> 00:16:40.464
it seems weekly, there's some new
data breach affecting a few or

287
00:16:40.464 --> 00:16:44.588
potentially millions of customers,
say, at the retail store level.

288
00:16:44.588 --> 00:16:47.470
So a little paranoia is good,
is what I always say.

289
00:16:47.470 --> 00:16:53.305
So having data encrypted in your
single databases is significant.

290
00:16:53.305 --> 00:16:54.840
>> Mm-hm.

291
00:16:54.840 --> 00:16:58.660
>> Okay, so we've got licensing
requirements, need an Azure subscription,

292
00:16:58.660 --> 00:17:03.240
and then also licenses for SQL 2014 SP1.

293
00:17:03.240 --> 00:17:10.264
And your SharePoint server license and
sufficient CALs for SharePoint 2016.

294
00:17:10.264 --> 00:17:12.590
So that's all I've got for architecture.

295
00:17:12.590 --> 00:17:13.420
>> All right, Mark.

296
00:17:13.420 --> 00:17:14.720
Great way to round that out.

297
00:17:14.720 --> 00:17:19.140
We took a look at those last two models,
we had the Azure IaaS,

298
00:17:19.140 --> 00:17:20.740
infrastructure as a service.

299
00:17:20.740 --> 00:17:25.730
As well as the complete on-prem where
you're in control of everything.

300
00:17:25.730 --> 00:17:29.337
And then remember,
in the previous episode, in the part one,

301
00:17:29.337 --> 00:17:31.448
we took a look at SharePoint online,

302
00:17:31.448 --> 00:17:35.893
as well as doing a hybrid model we get
a mix of some maybe online, some on prem.

303
00:17:35.893 --> 00:17:39.293
So, great look at that and
a lot of decisions to make,

304
00:17:39.293 --> 00:17:43.677
we start to see how planning is a very
important part in the successful

305
00:17:43.677 --> 00:17:46.260
deployment of our SharePoint servers.

306
00:17:46.260 --> 00:17:49.970
So understanding the different models, the
benefits as you so greatly went through.

307
00:17:49.970 --> 00:17:53.110
Why we might consider one over the other.

308
00:17:53.110 --> 00:17:54.060
So we appreciate that.

309
00:17:54.060 --> 00:17:55.180
We thank you for that.

310
00:17:55.180 --> 00:17:56.990
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

311
00:17:56.990 --> 00:17:59.580
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

312
00:17:59.580 --> 00:18:00.320
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

313
00:18:00.320 --> 00:18:02.848
>> And we'll see you next time.

314
00:18:02.848 --> 00:18:11.059
[SOUND]

episodes.title: SharePoint 2016 What's New
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.738 --> 00:00:15.552
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode of here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.552 --> 00:00:20.540
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.540 --> 00:00:24.654
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be taking a look at some of the new

5
00:00:24.654 --> 00:00:27.634
features that we're gonna
find in SharePoint 2016.

6
00:00:27.634 --> 00:00:31.980
And here to point those out for us is Mr.
Mark Ingram, how are you doing Mark?

7
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:34.706
>> Thanks very much, all right.

8
00:00:34.706 --> 00:00:39.060
People often when they're preparing for
an exam, remember

9
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:41.634
there's a saying in remnant, if you're
not writing code, you're selling code.

10
00:00:41.634 --> 00:00:45.088
>> [LAUGH]
>> So even the act of taking an exam is in

11
00:00:45.088 --> 00:00:47.250
a sense selling code.

12
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:48.770
Right, you're preparing for an exam why?

13
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:50.000
Because you're learning new features,

14
00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:54.040
because they often feature
prominently on exams, and

15
00:00:54.040 --> 00:00:57.040
then of course you'll know those
features and be able to specify them.

16
00:00:57.040 --> 00:00:59.660
Or recommend them for
upgrade or what have you.

17
00:00:59.660 --> 00:01:04.730
So finding out what's new
is a key part of any exam,

18
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:07.670
especially if you're familiar
with product before.

19
00:01:07.670 --> 00:01:12.460
As I've said before, in some ways people
new to product have an advantage because

20
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:13.600
they don't have to unlearn anything.

21
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:14.450
>> That's right.

22
00:01:14.450 --> 00:01:19.500
>> Whereas it's quite common on
Microsoft exams to get an answer

23
00:01:19.500 --> 00:01:21.830
that would have been right
in the previous version.

24
00:01:21.830 --> 00:01:26.550
Or the question writer's intentionally
trying to distract you from

25
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:29.360
the right answer by referencing something
that might have been in the product for

26
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:31.020
several versions.

27
00:01:31.020 --> 00:01:33.610
Before this one, but now is not.

28
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:36.270
So it's always important
to know what's new.

29
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:39.570
We'll be going into detail about a lot
of what's new throughout the week.

30
00:01:39.570 --> 00:01:43.040
But it's nice to get an overview of
that because that often what people

31
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:44.100
wanna know first.

32
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:46.340
What's different?

33
00:01:46.340 --> 00:01:47.810
So let's go into that.

34
00:01:47.810 --> 00:01:53.060
So we have Access Services,
there's some new things there.

35
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:59.900
Support for apps for Office, there's
a download an Excel feature, that's new,

36
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:06.730
for users to pivot access tables,
we will go into much detail on that.

37
00:02:06.730 --> 00:02:11.490
Another thing that's new, that's frankly
is better from a security perspective, and

38
00:02:11.490 --> 00:02:12.090
that is this.

39
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:15.860
Its central admin site, by default,
used to be provisioned on all servers.

40
00:02:15.860 --> 00:02:19.570
So no matter what role you chose for
the server, whether it was an application

41
00:02:19.570 --> 00:02:24.140
server or web front end, you would get
the central admin site by default.

42
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:31.190
Now, the central admin site is
not provisioned by default.

43
00:02:31.190 --> 00:02:34.420
Because how can you administer the farm
if the very first server you're

44
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:36.420
creating the farm doesn't
have the central admin site?

45
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:37.915
That wouldn't make sense at all.

46
00:02:37.915 --> 00:02:42.500
[LAUGH] Remember,
what is the farm creation process?

47
00:02:42.500 --> 00:02:46.720
That is creating a new configuration
database in a nutshell.

48
00:02:47.830 --> 00:02:51.080
So when you add additional
SharePoint servers to the farm,

49
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:55.950
you might remember for the wizard, I know
our first week course on SharePoint,

50
00:02:55.950 --> 00:02:58.290
you get to ask that fundamental question.

51
00:02:58.290 --> 00:03:01.040
Are you creating a new
configuration data base or

52
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:03.750
are you connecting to an existing
configuration database?

53
00:03:03.750 --> 00:03:07.660
That's another way of asking,
are we creating a brand new farm here or

54
00:03:07.660 --> 00:03:09.650
are you adding a serve
to an existing farm.

55
00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:15.540
Okay, so first server in the farm
gets a central item site by default.

56
00:03:15.540 --> 00:03:19.640
Now what if you decide,
let's say you install a web or

57
00:03:19.640 --> 00:03:23.530
an end server, you don't have a central
admin site, but you want to add it later?

58
00:03:23.530 --> 00:03:25.860
You can do that and I'm gonna show you,

59
00:03:25.860 --> 00:03:28.395
just to demo something,
because it's fun to demo.

60
00:03:28.395 --> 00:03:32.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> And also, by way of pointing out that

61
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:39.345
what you can expect in this week of class
here ITPRO.TV and certainly on the exam.

62
00:03:39.345 --> 00:03:43.705
Another thing Microsoft loves to do
not only test you on your knowledge of

63
00:03:43.705 --> 00:03:46.845
new functionality but
also see how many ways you can do it.

64
00:03:46.845 --> 00:03:50.825
In fact often the hardest way
possible you'll be asked about.

65
00:03:50.825 --> 00:03:52.017
>> [LAUGH] Of course.
>> So in other words,

66
00:03:52.017 --> 00:03:56.746
something you wouldn't necessarily do in
the real world because you probably use

67
00:03:56.746 --> 00:03:58.230
the GUI.

68
00:03:58.230 --> 00:04:00.797
But there's always gonna be
a PowerShell equivalent to the GUI.

69
00:04:00.797 --> 00:04:03.510
There's not always gonna be a GUI
equivalent to the PowerShell command.

70
00:04:05.000 --> 00:04:08.340
But let's say you're used to
creating something with the GUI.

71
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:11.090
It's likely on a test, you'll get asked

72
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:16.610
to pick an answer from how to create
it in PowerShell or psconfig.

73
00:04:16.610 --> 00:04:21.570
For example, so I'm going to show you
how to provision or make available

74
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:27.580
essential admin site on a SharePoint
server that didn't originally get it.

75
00:04:27.580 --> 00:04:29.258
So I'll go to my demo machine here.

76
00:04:32.784 --> 00:04:38.457
Excellent, and I'm going to go into

77
00:04:38.457 --> 00:04:45.230
My SharePoint 2016 Management shell.

78
00:04:47.810 --> 00:04:50.140
And wait a while for
that PowerShell prompt to appear.

79
00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:54.700
>> That's loading up the modules
necessary to work with SharePoint?

80
00:04:54.700 --> 00:04:57.800
>> Yeah, and
that happened lickety split, thankfully.

81
00:04:59.040 --> 00:05:03.600
All right, so
I'm say new SPCentralAdministration.

82
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:06.610
Using tab complete,
there's the commandlet.

83
00:05:06.610 --> 00:05:09.380
That's it, hit Enter and
wait a few seconds and

84
00:05:09.380 --> 00:05:14.500
boom, I will have the SharePoint
central lab insight available

85
00:05:14.500 --> 00:05:16.790
in this case a web front end server.

86
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:21.580
So it makes sense to only have essential
admin site on the application server

87
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:22.400
most of the time.

88
00:05:22.400 --> 00:05:25.520
But if there's some reason that you need
to have it on a different SharePoint

89
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:32.010
server, then that's a simple, simple
as that power stroke command and run.

90
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:33.490
And let's say you change your mind or

91
00:05:33.490 --> 00:05:37.120
you make some configuration change a good
practice would be to remove that central

92
00:05:37.120 --> 00:05:39.980
admin site if it was
a one-off thing you're doing.

93
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:43.420
Remember you can always add in later, you
can always add in a group permission for

94
00:05:43.420 --> 00:05:46.630
example where people get caught
out sometimes and share a point,

95
00:05:46.630 --> 00:05:49.160
another admin task is to get lazy.

96
00:05:49.160 --> 00:05:54.190
For example, giving local admin rights
to users just so software application

97
00:05:54.190 --> 00:05:58.510
can run which is sometimes you have to do
it that way to get the software to work.

98
00:05:58.510 --> 00:06:00.080
But in a case like this, you might say,

99
00:06:00.080 --> 00:06:03.880
we'll just leave that central admin
site available on the way of front

100
00:06:03.880 --> 00:06:06.210
end server because we might need it later,
that's a bad practice.

101
00:06:06.210 --> 00:06:11.050
People that need to access the central
admin site, we'll always be able to do it

102
00:06:11.050 --> 00:06:13.750
where it's hosted on the application
server, where it belongs, right.

103
00:06:13.750 --> 00:06:17.812
So think about the principle
of least privilege and

104
00:06:17.812 --> 00:06:21.660
don't add unnecessary risk, it's my point.

105
00:06:21.660 --> 00:06:25.770
So let's say you change your mind now and
or you've configured whatever you wanted

106
00:06:25.770 --> 00:06:31.240
to configure by enabling that central
admin site on your web front-end server.

107
00:06:31.240 --> 00:06:31.779
And you wanna remove it?

108
00:06:31.779 --> 00:06:39.815
Well, you simply do
Remove-SPCentralAdministration,

109
00:06:39.815 --> 00:06:42.070
as easy as that.

110
00:06:42.070 --> 00:06:46.020
So, this week will there be
a lot of demos using PowerShell.

111
00:06:46.020 --> 00:06:50.610
Now, I'm doing that purposely because,
again, for the example, the real world,

112
00:06:50.610 --> 00:06:53.310
you'll need to know the PowerShell
equivalent to the GUI action.

113
00:06:53.310 --> 00:06:57.380
So I did show you a lot of GUI actions for

114
00:06:57.380 --> 00:07:01.490
regular SharePoint admin, so what we'll
talk about, entirely new topics this week.

115
00:07:01.490 --> 00:07:06.450
And my bias will be towards PowerShell,
the PowerShell way of doing something.

116
00:07:06.450 --> 00:07:09.850
Cuz you're gonna need to get hands on and
get conversant with that method,

117
00:07:09.850 --> 00:07:12.930
even though you may be
used to doing it via GUI.

118
00:07:12.930 --> 00:07:16.770
Okay and often I'll show two different
ways to do the same different thing,

119
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:17.460
if not three.

120
00:07:17.460 --> 00:07:18.470
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

121
00:07:18.470 --> 00:07:18.985
>> Cuz as we know,

122
00:07:18.985 --> 00:07:20.612
in Microsoft technologies
there's often two or

123
00:07:20.612 --> 00:07:21.890
three ways to do the exact same thing.

124
00:07:21.890 --> 00:07:22.634
>> Absolutely.

125
00:07:22.634 --> 00:07:27.180
>> And so it never hurts to be nimble,
if you will.

126
00:07:27.180 --> 00:07:28.290
Okay, what else is new?

127
00:07:28.290 --> 00:07:31.990
Because that is the purpose
of this episode.

128
00:07:31.990 --> 00:07:32.500
What's new?

129
00:07:32.500 --> 00:07:35.480
We have compliance features that are new.

130
00:07:35.480 --> 00:07:36.700
And, for example,

131
00:07:36.700 --> 00:07:41.780
we can delete documents in a user's
One Drive after a period of time.

132
00:07:41.780 --> 00:07:42.690
That's kind of cool.

133
00:07:42.690 --> 00:07:45.360
So we can essentially expire the content.

134
00:07:45.360 --> 00:07:48.170
We always have to be conscious
of storage growth and

135
00:07:48.170 --> 00:07:50.840
making sure we have relevant
content being stored.

136
00:07:50.840 --> 00:07:53.150
Wether it's publicly available or
just for the individual user.

137
00:07:53.150 --> 00:07:57.061
Or perhaps, user plus whoever he or
she share content with.

138
00:07:57.061 --> 00:08:02.980
Pruning content is under rated, frankly,
and definitely a best practice.

139
00:08:02.980 --> 00:08:06.894
One way to get departments or
divisions on board with the pruning, and

140
00:08:06.894 --> 00:08:11.468
I'm using that term an English word, not
database pruning or that kind of thing,

141
00:08:11.468 --> 00:08:15.681
that more technical term, but just to
get rid of old stuff you don't need.

142
00:08:15.681 --> 00:08:17.462
>> Mm-hm, kinda cleaning house.

143
00:08:17.462 --> 00:08:18.118
>> Yeah, cleaning house.

144
00:08:18.118 --> 00:08:19.260
Exactly.

145
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:22.915
Especially if you're moving to a new
system, that's a whole other conversation.

146
00:08:22.915 --> 00:08:27.510
My point is there's tools now to make
it easier to delete old content and

147
00:08:27.510 --> 00:08:30.460
this is one of them,
in terms of compliance.

148
00:08:30.460 --> 00:08:34.610
We have a whole episode or
two on compliance this week as well.

149
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:42.090
Also an in hold policy, or in place hold
policy which lets us put say, legal hold

150
00:08:42.090 --> 00:08:47.180
on content even if it's not in a specified
repository wherever that content lives.

151
00:08:48.260 --> 00:08:51.320
In my sites or a document library,
wherever that content is,

152
00:08:51.320 --> 00:08:55.160
it's been tagged to be held for
legal reasons, we can do that now.

153
00:08:55.160 --> 00:08:55.990
>> Nice.

154
00:08:55.990 --> 00:08:59.390
>> So we can preserve documents and
other files as well as emails.

155
00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:03.350
So again we'll have a whole episode or
two on that.

156
00:09:03.350 --> 00:09:05.960
There is improvement to
document library accessibility.

157
00:09:05.960 --> 00:09:09.615
So in terms of keyboard shortcuts,
for example, so

158
00:09:09.615 --> 00:09:15.025
many of us can use all ten fingers,
not everyone has that liberty.

159
00:09:15.025 --> 00:09:20.485
Some people might be using a pen in their
mouth, for example, with sticky keys.

160
00:09:21.612 --> 00:09:24.412
So they can hit Alt first and
then hit E, and

161
00:09:24.412 --> 00:09:26.592
it's as if they hit Alt and
E at the same time.

162
00:09:26.592 --> 00:09:29.292
So there's improvements
to keyboard shortcuts for

163
00:09:29.292 --> 00:09:30.778
document library accessibility.

164
00:09:30.778 --> 00:09:35.052
And also call-out reading,

165
00:09:35.052 --> 00:09:39.122
and just whether you're
physically impaired or

166
00:09:39.122 --> 00:09:43.982
perhaps have problems hearing or
seeing visual cues, there's improvements

167
00:09:43.982 --> 00:09:49.060
there in terms of call-outs and
color to make it easier to apprehend.

168
00:09:49.060 --> 00:09:52.602
A little sideline, if I may.

169
00:09:52.602 --> 00:09:56.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> A fellow that's been involved with

170
00:09:56.090 --> 00:09:57.470
Microsoft for many years.

171
00:09:57.470 --> 00:10:00.550
Muhammad Ali died recently.

172
00:10:00.550 --> 00:10:03.650
And he mentioned, out of the blue one day,

173
00:10:03.650 --> 00:10:08.290
he had a meeting at Microsoft and Muhammad
Ali walked by with a couple of people.

174
00:10:08.290 --> 00:10:10.910
And nobody knew he was coming or
at least he didn't but he was,

175
00:10:10.910 --> 00:10:13.640
Mohammed Ali was there to help Microsoft
with their accessibility features.

176
00:10:13.640 --> 00:10:14.280
>> Really?
>> Because he had

177
00:10:14.280 --> 00:10:16.920
Parkinson's disease late in life so
he thought it was cool.

178
00:10:16.920 --> 00:10:19.850
>> That's neat.
>> Of all the spokespeople or

179
00:10:19.850 --> 00:10:24.560
I guess test users, if you like,
who you're getting feedback from,

180
00:10:24.560 --> 00:10:27.940
why not one of the greatest boxers if
not the greatest boxer of all time?

181
00:10:27.940 --> 00:10:30.460
Okay so, accessibility is key.

182
00:10:30.460 --> 00:10:31.390

again when we get some more

00:10:48.535 --> 00:10:51.725

00:10:51.725 --> 00:10:56.695

00:10:56.695 --> 00:11:00.215
Another thing new is

00:11:00.215 --> 00:11:06.690

00:11:06.690 --> 00:11:07.960
Part of the reason for

00:11:12.490 --> 00:11:17.590

00:11:17.590 --> 00:11:22.510

00:11:22.510 --> 00:11:27.126

00:11:43.580 --> 00:11:47.140

00:11:47.140 --> 00:11:49.500

00:11:49.500 --> 00:11:50.980

00:12:55.980 --> 00:12:59.650
It might seem inconsequential, but you

o n mass in your entire environment so

00:14:41.990 --> 00:14:44.830

There's new technology related to

00:17:46.410 --> 00:17:50.731

00:17:50.731 --> 00:17:53.076
It can include things like

00:17:53.076 --> 00:17:56.186
So, if you've enabled that, the ability

A policy setting at the web application

332
00:19:15.000 --> 00:19:20.178
Now the MinRole farm topology,
this is very good from an admin

00:19:20.178 --> 00:19:25.461
perspective because now we can
automatically have SharePoint

00:19:25.461 --> 00:19:30.742
configure services on a SharePoint
server we're deploying,

335
00:19:30.742 --> 00:19:35.230
depending on the role we're using it for.

336
00:19:35.230 --> 00:19:38.820
As opposed to us specifying okay, we wanna
make this a web front end server, and

337
00:19:38.820 --> 00:19:42.830
after the fact going in and turning on,
or disabling certain services.

338
00:19:42.830 --> 00:19:45.344
No, with MinRole, it's a bit misleading,

00:19:45.344 --> 00:19:48.854
because MinRole sounds to me
like some stripped down version,

340
00:19:48.854 --> 00:19:53.370
like a server core installation for

341
00:19:53.370 --> 00:19:58.130
I guess, think of it as minimum hassle,
[LAUGH] to set up.

342
00:19:58.130 --> 00:20:01.410
Or minimum installation, if you like.

343
00:20:01.410 --> 00:20:02.790
But I mean, that's not official.

344
00:20:02.790 --> 00:20:04.920
So MinRole is the official term for it.

345
00:20:04.920 --> 00:20:08.260
So for example,
we have several different role types.

346
00:20:08.260 --> 00:20:11.290
And in our lab environment for
this course,

00:20:11.290 --> 00:20:13.750
