00:20:13.750 --> 00:20:14.600
So what are those roles?

349
00:20:14.600 --> 00:20:16.070
We have a front end role.

350
00:20:16.070 --> 00:20:19.250
So this is our web front end server,
which if you're familiar with SharePoint,

351
00:20:19.250 --> 00:20:19.930
you'd be familiar with,

352
00:20:19.930 --> 00:20:25.650
that's the server type that end users
connect to with various machines.

353
00:20:25.650 --> 00:20:30.620
And then the web front end servers
proxy requests to the SQL storage

354
00:20:30.620 --> 00:20:35.410
in the backend on behalf of the client and
then return whatever content is supposed

355
00:20:35.410 --> 00:20:39.410
to be returned to the client based on
access to the content in the SQL database.

356
00:20:39.410 --> 00:20:44.487
So the point is with the MinRole I
click on a button saying Frontend,

357
00:20:44.487 --> 00:20:50.633
boom, all the services are configured
correctly to have that physical machine or

358
00:20:50.633 --> 00:20:54.572
VM I configure, optimized for

00:20:54.572 --> 00:20:57.651
Similarly, there is
an application server role.

00:20:57.651 --> 00:21:01.935
This is optimized to run
service applications, services,

00:21:01.935 --> 00:21:04.965
crawl requests, background jobs, etc.

362
00:21:04.965 --> 00:21:07.146
So that's another role type, and

00:21:07.146 --> 00:21:12.032
we'll be having demos run on all these

00:21:12.032 --> 00:21:16.640
because remember we got one of each

00:21:16.640 --> 00:21:19.146
Well, actually all but one,
which I'll explain in a minute.

366
00:21:19.146 --> 00:21:23.790
The distributed cache role is another
server role, so distributed cache,

367
00:21:23.790 --> 00:21:29.100
the more content that's cached
the faster content can be returned

368
00:21:29.100 --> 00:21:30.950
to clients requesting data.

369
00:21:30.950 --> 00:21:34.590
It also takes some heat off the SQL
servers in the backend, right?

370
00:21:34.590 --> 00:21:37.085
Why?
Because the content has already been

371
00:21:37.085 --> 00:21:40.233
requested, there's a time of life,
if you like,

372
00:21:40.233 --> 00:21:43.967
a time to live on that content
depending on what we set up, and

373
00:21:43.967 --> 00:21:47.920
how volatile the content is and
how timely it needs to be.

374
00:21:47.920 --> 00:21:50.959
Maybe the content lives in cache for
an hour or more, again,

375
00:21:50.959 --> 00:21:54.251
depending on how important it is

376
00:21:54.251 --> 00:21:57.118
But the point is, we're taking some
load off the web front end servers so

377
00:21:57.118 --> 00:21:59.090

378
00:21:59.090 --> 00:22:02.468
And again,
taking load off the SQL backend servers,

379
00:22:02.468 --> 00:22:07.670
because each new request doesn't require
a full round-trip to the SQL backend.

380
00:22:07.670 --> 00:22:08.770
And also,

381
00:22:08.770 --> 00:22:14.210
let's not forget the bandwidth in-between
these server types is also reduced.

382
00:22:14.210 --> 00:22:19.550
So if you set up the MinRole and specify
the distributed cache radio button,

383
00:22:19.550 --> 00:22:24.820
then you get a server optimized with
services, applications and components

384
00:22:24.820 --> 00:22:30.390
to make it the best possible cache
server because that's what its role is.

385
00:22:30.390 --> 00:22:34.210
That's its role in life,
to cache things and serve them up.

386
00:22:34.210 --> 00:22:37.780
Similarly, we have a search MinRole, and

387
00:22:37.780 --> 00:22:41.500
as you've guessed by now,
that means it's optimized for search.

388
00:22:41.500 --> 00:22:43.980
All the components, services,
applications relating to search.

389
00:22:45.090 --> 00:22:48.298
There is also a single server farm role.

00:22:48.298 --> 00:22:53.143
And again, it would be for dev or testing,
not for any kind of decent production use,

391
00:22:53.143 --> 00:22:56.574
it's just a test environment,
if you don't have the time or

392
00:22:56.574 --> 00:23:00.775
the desire to install multiple roles,
just install single server farm.

393
00:23:02.255 --> 00:23:05.448
Okay, but
you will need a SQL Server to connect to.

394
00:23:06.888 --> 00:23:12.134
The other role type,
MinRole type, is custom, and

395
00:23:12.134 --> 00:23:17.978
let's say the default role types for
MinRole like cache,

396
00:23:17.978 --> 00:23:22.761
and search, and
application, and front end.

397
00:23:22.761 --> 00:23:26.706
Let's say those don't quite meet your
needs for whatever custom role you need.

398
00:23:26.706 --> 00:23:29.253
Maybe it's a special
application you wanna run.

00:23:29.253 --> 00:23:33.804
But it doesn't really fit in
well with the default services,

00:23:33.804 --> 00:23:38.106
etc., that would run on
an application server MinRole.

401
00:23:38.106 --> 00:23:39.813
Well, you can customize it, so

402
00:23:39.813 --> 00:23:44.117
that gives you the flexibility if you need
it with custom roles and just the ease of

403
00:23:44.117 --> 00:23:47.937
install and optimization available
just by selecting a radio button.

404
00:23:47.937 --> 00:23:52.500
So the point is Microsoft has already
done the research as to the best

405
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:56.025
combination of application and
services, etc.,

406
00:23:56.025 --> 00:23:59.484

407
00:23:59.484 --> 00:24:00.696
The SharePoint server four.

408
00:24:00.696 --> 00:24:02.496
It's not one size fits all.

409
00:24:02.496 --> 00:24:04.670
This is a huge benefit.

410
00:24:04.670 --> 00:24:09.960
In fact, if your deployment somehow falls
out of line with Microsoft recommendation

411
00:24:09.960 --> 00:24:13.990
in terms of an extra service running or
one isn't running that should be.

412
00:24:13.990 --> 00:24:15.680
You'll get notified about that.

413
00:24:15.680 --> 00:24:19.910
So very handy,
again we always wanna be notified.

414
00:24:19.910 --> 00:24:22.990
We don't want to have to go
looking in the event logs, or

415
00:24:22.990 --> 00:24:25.020
you know running reports
to find out what's wrong.

416
00:24:25.020 --> 00:24:27.400
I mean sometimes that's useful for
historical analysis,

417
00:24:27.400 --> 00:24:30.950
but whenever possible we want to be
alerted when something is wrong.

418
00:24:30.950 --> 00:24:34.790
Because who has time, nobody has
time to scour all the event logs.

419
00:24:34.790 --> 00:24:36.940
Because you're probably not just running
share point in your organization,

420
00:24:36.940 --> 00:24:39.270
you're probably responsible for
other jobs as well.

421
00:24:39.270 --> 00:24:41.990
So the more we can have
information coming to us

422
00:24:41.990 --> 00:24:43.780
Relevant information coming to us,
the better.

423
00:24:43.780 --> 00:24:46.900
So again, you'll be alerted if
any of the rules you're running

424
00:24:46.900 --> 00:24:49.840
somehow fall out of compliance
with Microsoft's best practices.

425
00:24:51.290 --> 00:24:52.240
What else is new?

426
00:24:52.240 --> 00:24:55.900
Since that is the theme of this episode,
mobile experience.

427
00:24:57.630 --> 00:25:00.900
So better mobile view it.

428
00:25:00.900 --> 00:25:03.550
We're also touch optimizing now and
have been since 2013.

429
00:25:03.550 --> 00:25:07.270
So assuming that people are going
to use a variety of devices,

430
00:25:07.270 --> 00:25:08.620
many of them are touch enabled.

431
00:25:08.620 --> 00:25:12.760
So that means if you're thinking
from a user experience perspective,

432
00:25:12.760 --> 00:25:15.470
you don't want links crammed in together,
because it's very easy,

433
00:25:15.470 --> 00:25:21.680
even if you're using a proper pen
with a rubber tip, it's still,

434
00:25:21.680 --> 00:25:24.880
if the links are too close together, for
example, it's easy to click the wrong one.

435
00:25:24.880 --> 00:25:28.540
So by touch optimizing,
we have enough space around each option so

436
00:25:28.540 --> 00:25:31.970
that it's more likely the user is
gonna click on what they intended to.

437
00:25:33.050 --> 00:25:36.200
Okay, so there's tiles and

438
00:25:36.200 --> 00:25:39.530
links available as well when you
go into a site on a mobile device.

439
00:25:39.530 --> 00:25:41.870
So again, a better experience for
mobile users.

440
00:25:43.190 --> 00:25:45.880
Okay, there's new controls if
you're using OneDrive for Business.

441
00:25:45.880 --> 00:25:47.420
Again, we're gonna be
demoing a lot of this.

442
00:25:49.140 --> 00:25:52.070
Coming up later this week.

443
00:25:52.070 --> 00:25:55.030
So when you go use OneDrive and

444
00:25:55.030 --> 00:25:59.810
click the waffle,
that's in the upper left there for you.

445
00:25:59.810 --> 00:26:02.160
We've got different
OneDrive options available.

446
00:26:02.160 --> 00:26:08.370
So the ability to upload files with a tile
there, to be able to synchronize files for

447
00:26:08.370 --> 00:26:12.600
offline use, and the ability for
you to share your files as well.

448
00:26:12.600 --> 00:26:14.660
So these are some of the simple controls.

449
00:26:14.660 --> 00:26:17.920
We've got the open
document format available,

450
00:26:17.920 --> 00:26:20.490
so you know Microsoft does
play nice with others.

451
00:26:20.490 --> 00:26:23.850
It's not entirely a close shop especially
on the new leadership with Satya.

452
00:26:23.850 --> 00:26:26.758
I mean he's pretty much
about collaboration, and

453
00:26:26.758 --> 00:26:31.449
I guess competition is the jargon word
where you're competing and cooperating.

454
00:26:33.640 --> 00:26:37.600
With frenemies I guess,
corporate frenemies if you will.

455
00:26:37.600 --> 00:26:44.220
Okay, so the point is we can use,
users can save files in the ODF format

456
00:26:45.670 --> 00:26:50.680
so they can use non Microsoft
technologies to edit whatever they save.

457
00:26:50.680 --> 00:26:51.470
Now, this is something cool.

458
00:26:51.470 --> 00:26:54.110
The next one is Project Server 2016.

459
00:26:54.110 --> 00:26:56.410
So there's a lot of capabilities,

460
00:26:56.410 --> 00:27:00.440
it's, Project 2016 is installed with
Enterprise version of SharePoint,

461
00:27:00.440 --> 00:27:05.910
that's how closely integrated they are,
but Project Server is licensed separately.

462
00:27:05.910 --> 00:27:10.930
And I'm gonna show you later in the week
how to enable, to turn on or unlock that

463
00:27:10.930 --> 00:27:14.770
project server functionality, because
a lot of organizations will use it.

464
00:27:14.770 --> 00:27:17.310
Some will and there's been some
great success stories about

465
00:27:17.310 --> 00:27:21.490
organizations successfully
integrating sheriff went project.

466
00:27:21.490 --> 00:27:25.310
We definitely wanna do things like
eliminate multiple iterations of task list

467
00:27:25.310 --> 00:27:28.900
so the ability to synchronize task lists
is available now which is super handy.

468
00:27:28.900 --> 00:27:32.610
So whether you're using your
outlook client, project server or

469
00:27:32.610 --> 00:27:34.560
your project client, your share point.

470
00:27:34.560 --> 00:27:37.900
It's gonna be a synchronized unified
task list, and that is super handy.

471
00:27:37.900 --> 00:27:41.290
I mean, I don't know about you, but
I don't need another place to go for

472
00:27:41.290 --> 00:27:44.720
reminders or
another list online or offline.

473
00:27:44.720 --> 00:27:46.600
It's overwhelming.

474
00:27:46.600 --> 00:27:47.270
Certainly can be.

475
00:27:47.270 --> 00:27:52.290
So whatever we can do to get
a handle on how data comes to us and

476
00:27:52.290 --> 00:27:53.970
avoid duplication, I'm all for it.

477
00:27:53.970 --> 00:27:57.730
So I'll show you how to enable
project server this week.

478
00:27:57.730 --> 00:28:01.490
And let's see, if you're into

479
00:28:01.490 --> 00:28:05.470
BI Business intelligence functionality
with SharePoint, you're gonna love this,

480
00:28:05.470 --> 00:28:11.190
PowerPivot add-in, and Power View
are available to use with SharePoint 2016.

481
00:28:11.190 --> 00:28:14.080
So there's so many cool,
it's one of my favorite technologies.

482
00:28:14.080 --> 00:28:17.230
And I'd say SharePoint's number one,
but the related BI technology's number

483
00:28:17.230 --> 00:28:20.430
two in terms of my favorite
technology is Microsoft.

484
00:28:20.430 --> 00:28:23.950
There's so much you can do visually
in terms of displays and reports.

485
00:28:23.950 --> 00:28:25.720
So those of you who have stuff in there,

486
00:28:25.720 --> 00:28:28.290
either with single server
analysis services,

487
00:28:28.290 --> 00:28:32.810
integration services, reporting services,
will love the Power Pivot add in.

488
00:28:32.810 --> 00:28:35.110
Okay, we'll get to that
later in the week as well.

489
00:28:35.110 --> 00:28:36.779
Various Power View reports.

490
00:28:38.110 --> 00:28:39.730
Workbooks is a data source.

491
00:28:39.730 --> 00:28:41.350
All this is available in SharePoint.

492
00:28:43.180 --> 00:28:47.770
Okay, in terms of sharing there's
improvements there as well.

493
00:28:47.770 --> 00:28:50.830
So the ability to create and
share a folder.

494
00:28:50.830 --> 00:28:54.060
The ability to see, let's say you've
shared a folder already with certain

495
00:28:54.060 --> 00:28:55.450
people, but you can't remember who.

496
00:28:55.450 --> 00:28:59.420
It's easier to see who you've
shared a folder with now.

497
00:28:59.420 --> 00:29:03.315
Members have the ability to share,
not just owners.

498
00:29:03.315 --> 00:29:03.815
First.

499
00:29:05.965 --> 00:29:09.655
There is a one-click email to approve or
deny a request for access.

500
00:29:09.655 --> 00:29:11.995
So again,
whatever we can streamline the better.

501
00:29:11.995 --> 00:29:17.185
I was at a GoToMeeting session recently,
and

502
00:29:17.185 --> 00:29:22.300
there was a few steps to do from my
client email on my computer, and

503
00:29:22.300 --> 00:29:24.960
then I got disconnected,
actually my battery dies is what happened.

504
00:29:24.960 --> 00:29:28.410
So I went to my iPhone, and
I went to the same email, and one click.

505
00:29:28.410 --> 00:29:29.730
Boom, the quote immediately opened up.

506
00:29:29.730 --> 00:29:30.930
>> [LAUGH]
>> I didn't have to log in.

507
00:29:30.930 --> 00:29:33.270
That's how simple we should be making.

508
00:29:33.270 --> 00:29:37.370
And a lot of organizations realize this,
and Amazon, others are pioneering in that.

509
00:29:37.370 --> 00:29:41.820
As simple as possible for
the user, no complicated log on.

510
00:29:41.820 --> 00:29:44.130
Ideally one click, and so

511
00:29:44.130 --> 00:29:49.270
we have one click to approve or
deny requests for access.

512
00:29:49.270 --> 00:29:55.020
I've also heard people say if I
send more than one request for

513
00:29:55.020 --> 00:29:57.940
information, or one question to my boss,

514
00:29:57.940 --> 00:30:01.090
my boss only answers whatever
the first question is in an email.

515
00:30:01.090 --> 00:30:04.000
So then they get trained to send
separate emails for each request.

516
00:30:04.000 --> 00:30:08.430
Well, you know people want simplicity,
want to click yes or no on grant or

517
00:30:08.430 --> 00:30:10.290
denying access to this resource.

518
00:30:12.640 --> 00:30:16.680
Okay, in terms of the Share Point search
service application improvements there,

519
00:30:16.680 --> 00:30:22.320
we can index up to 500 million items
per search server application.

520
00:30:22.320 --> 00:30:25.740
That sounds like a lot, but I think in
a few years it won't seem like that much.

521
00:30:25.740 --> 00:30:29.650
>> True. [LAUGH] >> So the need to create
a separate surge server application,

522
00:30:29.650 --> 00:30:32.190
a search service
application is going down.

523
00:30:32.190 --> 00:30:34.710
There maybe again political reasons,
they have two separate ones but

524
00:30:34.710 --> 00:30:36.380
that's another story.

525
00:30:36.380 --> 00:30:40.120
We may wanna set up SSL for
a central admin site.

526
00:30:40.120 --> 00:30:45.310
We can do that now simply
with a commandlet using use

527
00:30:45.310 --> 00:30:50.830
sp central administration and specify a
port number and then the whatever port is.

528
00:30:50.830 --> 00:30:53.190
And then your sockets there parameter.

529
00:30:53.190 --> 00:30:54.210
I won't show you that one.

530
00:30:54.210 --> 00:30:58.580
But it's very easy to set up as a cell for
central admin.

531
00:30:58.580 --> 00:31:00.960
We have three options for
site collection upgrades.

532
00:31:00.960 --> 00:31:03.940
We're gonna look at that late in the week
as well upgrading from 2013 to 2016, so

533
00:31:03.940 --> 00:31:08.470
we got more options now to
upgrade our site collections.

534
00:31:08.470 --> 00:31:11.430
We can also encrypt our SMTP connection.

535
00:31:13.680 --> 00:31:17.250
And then we're gonna also have site
pages pinning is something new as well.

536
00:31:17.250 --> 00:31:21.090
So let's say we want to
follow certain sites,

537
00:31:21.090 --> 00:31:24.690
we can pin them at the top as opposed to
unnecessarily having to scroll around,

538
00:31:24.690 --> 00:31:26.110
look around for sites you want to follow.

539
00:31:26.110 --> 00:31:27.700
We can pin them.

540
00:31:27.700 --> 00:31:28.440
That's handy.

541
00:31:28.440 --> 00:31:31.600
>> Very convenient.

542
00:31:31.600 --> 00:31:32.830
>> Okay, that's enough for

543
00:31:32.830 --> 00:31:37.010
what's new, becoming almost everything
I touched on in this episode.

544
00:31:37.010 --> 00:31:40.410
I'll be showing you more detail
on as we go through the week.

545
00:31:40.410 --> 00:31:41.390
>> Fantastic, Mark.

546
00:31:41.390 --> 00:31:44.920
Really good look and hopefully getting
everyone excited about some of the new

547
00:31:44.920 --> 00:31:48.120
things and things we're going to be doing
in our SharePoint series, as you said,

548
00:31:48.120 --> 00:31:49.530
we progress through the week.

549
00:31:49.530 --> 00:31:52.720
Lot of really cool new features that
I know I'm excited about seeing

550
00:31:52.720 --> 00:31:53.440
with SharePoint 2016.

551
00:31:53.440 --> 00:31:56.240
So we thank you for that,
laying all that out for us.

552
00:31:56.240 --> 00:31:58.080
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

553
00:31:58.080 --> 00:32:00.760
Signing out for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

554
00:32:00.760 --> 00:32:03.971
>> I'm Mark Ingram
>> And we'll see you next time.

555
00:32:03.971 --> 00:32:12.270
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: SharePoint 2016 What's Removed
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.109 --> 00:00:10.109
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.346 --> 00:00:15.881
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.881 --> 00:00:20.510
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing Advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:23.740
And specifically in this episode we're
going to be talking about what's been

5
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:25.880
removed from this new edition, right?

6
00:00:25.880 --> 00:00:28.310
We had an episode where we talked
about some of the new features,

7
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:31.310
we also need to be familiar with
what's not going to be there

8
00:00:31.310 --> 00:00:32.590
when we migrate to 2016 or install 2016.

9
00:00:32.590 --> 00:00:36.410
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:36.410 --> 00:00:37.190
How are you doing, Mark?

11
00:00:37.190 --> 00:00:38.980
>> Good Mike, thanks very much.

12
00:00:38.980 --> 00:00:40.440
Yeah, let's.

13
00:00:40.440 --> 00:00:41.940
So, it's one thing to know what's new.

14
00:00:41.940 --> 00:00:45.130
We covered that in another episode,
people generally want to know what's new,

15
00:00:45.130 --> 00:00:48.250
the latest and greatest and
start work right away.

16
00:00:48.250 --> 00:00:51.880
But as we talked about in another episode,
the importance of planning,

17
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:54.130
architectural design are very important.

18
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:56.390
If you want to know what's new,
that's good.

19
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:59.910
You also need to be prepared for
what's not there anymore, or

20
00:00:59.910 --> 00:01:01.529
what functionality has been deprecated.

21
00:01:02.560 --> 00:01:06.690
Unlearning what used to be there is
important as well, so let's get to it.

22
00:01:06.690 --> 00:01:11.957
And the first item is duet, and that's
not what Mike and I are doing right now.

23
00:01:11.957 --> 00:01:12.830
>> [LAUGH] Thank goodness.

24
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:15.265
>> This is, yes, well,
it's a form of duet.

25
00:01:15.265 --> 00:01:17.000
>> [LAUGH] You can sing, I can't, so-
>> No,

26
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:18.585
I was talking about just the banter.

27
00:01:18.585 --> 00:01:19.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> There will be

28
00:01:19.460 --> 00:01:21.630
no on-air performance of that sort.

29
00:01:21.630 --> 00:01:25.610
Anyway, Duet Enterprise for SharePoint,
that was a collaboration between SAP P and

30
00:01:25.610 --> 00:01:27.930
Microsoft middleware essentially,

31
00:01:27.930 --> 00:01:31.600
to help some of SAP's technologies
integrate better with SharePoint.

32
00:01:31.600 --> 00:01:35.360
Unfortunately, there's no support for
it [LAUGH] in SharePoint 2016, which means

33
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:41.510
you could go the custom coding route,
or just remain on SharePoint 2013.

34
00:01:41.510 --> 00:01:46.620
So, one of the things we haven't
talked about is the Importance for

35
00:01:46.620 --> 00:01:50.240
certain organizations to log behind.

36
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:53.480
Even two or
three major versions behind in SharePoint.

37
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:57.520
Certain military environments for example,
there's so much testing required, and

38
00:01:57.520 --> 00:02:00.860
they standardize on a platform for
x number years in the future.

39
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:03.510
So, some organizations
are actually surprising.

40
00:02:03.510 --> 00:02:05.630
You might think they'll be a little
more cutting edge, but actually no,

41
00:02:05.630 --> 00:02:06.370
they're behind the curve.

42
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:09.860
Banking as well as another example,
sometimes they seem to be cutting edge,

43
00:02:09.860 --> 00:02:11.380
other times way behind.

44
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:16.590
Now behind sounds like a bad thing,
it's a smart thing if that's what your

45
00:02:16.590 --> 00:02:19.730
software support and allows for,
X number years of testing.

46
00:02:19.730 --> 00:02:23.970
I'm not denigrating previous versions,
but this is an example of a time where

47
00:02:23.970 --> 00:02:27.550
if this duet integration was very
important to our organization, and

48
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:30.370
or you didn't want to spend
the money to create middleware,

49
00:02:30.370 --> 00:02:33.851
then it makes sense to
remain on SharePoint 2013.

50
00:02:33.851 --> 00:02:36.420
Other technology has been deprecated or

51
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:41.340
at least not being renewed or
advanced an info path.

52
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:45.680
So, if you work with forums design,
there's a 2013 edition and

53
00:02:45.680 --> 00:02:46.698
there isn't going to be no more.

54
00:02:46.698 --> 00:02:48.130
[LAUGH]
>> There will be support for

55
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:51.460
ten more years at least
which is kind of weird,

56
00:02:51.460 --> 00:02:53.400
you'd think they'd just
put a new number on it so

57
00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:58.040
it seems like it's current with
the current version of SharePoint, but no.

58
00:02:58.040 --> 00:03:00.070
At least Microsoft's
being upfront about it.

59
00:03:00.070 --> 00:03:02.570
They're not going to create
another InfoPath version.

60
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:04.830
At least, that's the story at this point.

61
00:03:04.830 --> 00:03:08.830
So you can use, it's totally fine to
use InfoPath 2013 with 2016 in future

62
00:03:08.830 --> 00:03:10.660
releases of SharePoint.

63
00:03:10.660 --> 00:03:11.980
There's no problems there.

64
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:14.270
Just don't look for
the new number of that version.

65
00:03:16.020 --> 00:03:19.810
Similarly, SharePoint Designer won't
be updated to reflect the number 2016,

66
00:03:19.810 --> 00:03:24.690
that version SharePoint,
but you can still use it.

67
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:28.920
Okay, SharePoint foundation is out,
so that was the free version.

68
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:32.480
Used to be Windows SharePoint services
came with your server license,

69
00:03:32.480 --> 00:03:34.500
the idea there was,
you know, like Starbucks,

70
00:03:34.500 --> 00:03:37.230
we would want to sample a new product,
same kind of idea.

71
00:03:37.230 --> 00:03:38.878
Oops, there's branding, again.

72
00:03:38.878 --> 00:03:41.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Product placement.

73
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:42.960
Okay, anyway.

74
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:46.180
The point is, a lot of businesses
want to give a free teaser offer.

75
00:03:46.180 --> 00:03:49.410
And the idea there is with
Windows SharePoint services and

76
00:03:49.410 --> 00:03:51.740
Windows foundation, or
SharePoint foundation rather,

77
00:03:51.740 --> 00:03:54.930
was that companies would
dip their toe in the water,

78
00:03:54.930 --> 00:03:58.610
get familiar with SharePoint and then bump
up against limitation in the free product.

79
00:03:58.610 --> 00:04:02.520
And some of them would invest
the big bucks in a standard or

80
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:05.120
enterprise full SharePoint license.

81
00:04:05.120 --> 00:04:09.032
They're by design, and
for obvious reasons,

82
00:04:09.032 --> 00:04:11.740
there would be limitations in
the free version of the product.

83
00:04:11.740 --> 00:04:12.690
So that's gone.

84
00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:16.360
SharePoint foundation's gone,
stan low install mode is gone as well.

85
00:04:16.360 --> 00:04:19.030
You can install the SharePoint
components of one machine, but

86
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:22.950
you would have had to installed SQL
server on that machine in advance.

87
00:04:22.950 --> 00:04:23.670
When I'm saying machine,

88
00:04:23.670 --> 00:04:27.004
I'm always referring to either virtual or
physical machines.

89
00:04:27.004 --> 00:04:31.100
So that standalone mode requires
a little more work on your part.

90
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:35.420
You have to set up SQL in advance and then
install all the SharePoint components on

91
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:38.970
a single server and that's available
from the Startup Wizard, but

92
00:04:38.970 --> 00:04:41.810
more likely these days you're going to
choose one of the mini role options we

93
00:04:41.810 --> 00:04:45.080
covered in another episode like search,
or web front end,

94
00:04:46.530 --> 00:04:51.190
cash, and custom possibly, so other roles.

95
00:04:51.190 --> 00:04:55.290
Another thing that's gone is FIM,
the forefront identity manager client.

96
00:04:55.290 --> 00:04:59.191
Some of you may be using FIM,
it's been replaced with MIM,

97
00:04:59.191 --> 00:05:02.790
got to love the acronyms
Microsoft Identity Manager.

98
00:05:02.790 --> 00:05:04.526
You could impress your friends or

99
00:05:04.526 --> 00:05:08.128
alienate your friends at cocktail
parties by speaking in acronyms.

100
00:05:08.128 --> 00:05:10.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> LOL.

101
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:11.040
>> As well, yeah.

102
00:05:11.040 --> 00:05:12.270
>> What's that?
>> Good for trivia as well.

103
00:05:12.270 --> 00:05:14.020
>> Yes, for trivia, you never know.

104
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:15.768
Playing at the bar with all
those multiplayer games.

105
00:05:15.768 --> 00:05:17.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so.

106
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:22.168
The technology behind FIM is still around,
it's just that FIM client is gone,

107
00:05:22.168 --> 00:05:26.545
Forefront Identity Manager, which is a
great tool to synchronize from a different

108
00:05:26.545 --> 00:05:28.840
application identity information.

109
00:05:28.840 --> 00:05:32.700
You might have HR database, Active
Directory, some other line of business

110
00:05:32.700 --> 00:05:35.800
database, FIM takes care of
the integration and synchronization of

111
00:05:35.800 --> 00:05:40.100
changes made in one database replicating
those changes to other databases.

112
00:05:40.100 --> 00:05:42.010
That FIM client is gone.

113
00:05:42.010 --> 00:05:44.980
Another thing that's
changed in this version of

114
00:05:44.980 --> 00:05:47.750
SharePoint 2016 is Excel services.

115
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:51.620
So, we're no longer
hosting Excel services and

116
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:54.070
related BI technologies
on a SharePoint server.

117
00:05:55.410 --> 00:06:00.140
That fundamental technology to Excel
is now hosted with Excel Online

118
00:06:01.530 --> 00:06:03.250
in the Office Online Server.

119
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:07.440
And if you're familiar with
Office web apps server in 2013,

120
00:06:07.440 --> 00:06:10.260
that's the same function,
Office Online Server.

121
00:06:10.260 --> 00:06:14.230
And as I've been saying, that's something
we'll be covering in more detail, and

122
00:06:14.230 --> 00:06:17.910
with some hands-on,
I'll show you later in the week.

123
00:06:17.910 --> 00:06:18.740
So that's different.

124
00:06:20.450 --> 00:06:25.727
And so, if you're using Excel
services now in 2013, and

125
00:06:25.727 --> 00:06:30.380
you want to upgrade Excel services, you'd
have to then deploy the Office Online

126
00:06:30.380 --> 00:06:34.640
server to make sure your Excel services
functionality remains available.

127
00:06:37.120 --> 00:06:38.075
Okay.

128
00:06:38.075 --> 00:06:42.555
There's some SharePoint BI capabilities,
and

129
00:06:42.555 --> 00:06:47.325
things like a PowerPivot Gallery,
a schedule data refresh.

130
00:06:47.325 --> 00:06:51.695
So these are some new BI capabilities
that weren't available before or

131
00:06:51.695 --> 00:06:53.885
modified from the 2013 version.

132
00:06:53.885 --> 00:06:56.670
PowerPivot Management dashboard,
we'll be covering.

133
00:06:56.670 --> 00:07:00.770
The BI integration with SharePoint
2016 later in the week as well.

134
00:07:00.770 --> 00:07:05.430
In terms of deprecated features, the
definition of deprecated in this context

135
00:07:05.430 --> 00:07:09.660
means that the role of
the feature has been diminished,

136
00:07:09.660 --> 00:07:13.010
it still works, it may not be
supported in the next versions.

137
00:07:13.010 --> 00:07:18.220
The idea is they want you transition
away to another tool while there's time,

138
00:07:18.220 --> 00:07:20.950
before it's an urgent situation.

139
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:26.930
So, tags and notes falls under
the category of deprecate items, and

140
00:07:26.930 --> 00:07:31.350
you could still work with your existing
tags notes, anchoring new tags and notes.

141
00:07:31.350 --> 00:07:35.329
But the next release, at this point,
I mean, everything's subject to change,

142
00:07:35.329 --> 00:07:38.186
but this point tag notes will be gone for
the next release.

143
00:07:38.186 --> 00:07:46.540
And finally, STS 80M.exe now, the death
of STM STS 80M has been long predicted.

144
00:07:46.540 --> 00:07:48.425
It will not die.

145
00:07:48.425 --> 00:07:53.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, the PowerShell is the way to go.

146
00:07:53.160 --> 00:07:58.390
So, I strongly recommend whatever
there might be one or two tasks or

147
00:07:58.390 --> 00:08:02.850
routines you're still using
with a Script using SDS ADM.

148
00:08:02.850 --> 00:08:06.000
Definitely now is the time to
transition away from that.

149
00:08:06.000 --> 00:08:08.690
If you never use it again,
I'd be happy for you.

150
00:08:08.690 --> 00:08:12.470
PowerShell can accomplish whatever
you were doing with SDS ADM before.

151
00:08:12.470 --> 00:08:12.970
>> Absolutely.

152
00:08:15.370 --> 00:08:20.310
>> And that's it for,
those are remove re-deprecated features.

153
00:08:20.310 --> 00:08:23.820
>> And not too long of a list there, but
again, just an extremely important part of

154
00:08:23.820 --> 00:08:27.470
understanding SharePoint and learning
SharePoint, because especially with

155
00:08:27.470 --> 00:08:30.430
the deprecated stuff I find,
you know having that warning.

156
00:08:30.430 --> 00:08:32.680
Because you might have hours and

157
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:35.725
hours of development on scripts
that are going that you use in you

158
00:08:35.725 --> 00:08:41.400
SharePoint environment, and if they just
yanked them, you'd be kind of stuck.

159
00:08:41.400 --> 00:08:44.740
Whereas by telling you hey look,
they're still there, but

160
00:08:44.740 --> 00:08:47.070
we're saying you should start
migrating away from them.

161
00:08:47.070 --> 00:08:50.240
Start now, planning some way
to move away from them, so

162
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:53.250
then when we do pull the plug on those,
you're not left in the dark and

163
00:08:53.250 --> 00:08:55.340
just kind of up the creek
without a paddle.

164
00:08:55.340 --> 00:08:57.830
So, you got to pay attention
to those deprecated features.

165
00:08:57.830 --> 00:09:01.280
If we use them, we got to make
sure we're getting away from them

166
00:09:01.280 --> 00:09:04.800
before that next release because you'll
never know what's going to happen.

167
00:09:04.800 --> 00:09:05.587
All right, Mark.

168
00:09:05.587 --> 00:09:09.690
We thank you for that list of removed and
deprecated features in Sharepoint 2016.

169
00:09:09.690 --> 00:09:11.900
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

170
00:09:11.900 --> 00:09:14.420
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

171
00:09:14.420 --> 00:09:15.110
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

172
00:09:15.110 --> 00:09:17.962
>> And we'll see you next time.

173
00:09:17.962 --> 00:09:24.989
[SOUND]

episodes.title: High Availability and Disaster Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.804 --> 00:00:15.565
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.565 --> 00:00:19.708
I'm your host Mike Roderick and
today, we're doing SharePoint 2016,

4
00:00:19.708 --> 00:00:21.450
the advanced version.

5
00:00:21.450 --> 00:00:25.980
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at high availability and

6
00:00:25.980 --> 00:00:30.390
disaster recovery, both very important
parts in our SharePoint design.

7
00:00:30.390 --> 00:00:32.354
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

8
00:00:32.354 --> 00:00:33.534
How are you doing, Mark?

9
00:00:33.534 --> 00:00:34.386
>> Thanks, Mike.

10
00:00:34.386 --> 00:00:38.186
Yeah, so critical to your success
as a SharePoint admin and

11
00:00:38.186 --> 00:00:40.618
your continued employment frankly.

12
00:00:40.618 --> 00:00:42.626
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is the ability to plan ahead for

13
00:00:42.626 --> 00:00:48.170
potential disaster scenarios, and also to
be able to recover from those scenarios.

14
00:00:48.170 --> 00:00:54.230
And that includes things from backup
to failover of the data center or

15
00:00:54.230 --> 00:00:58.260
to the cloud in the event of tornadoes or-
>> Hurricanes.

16
00:00:58.260 --> 00:00:59.213
>> Wash outs, yeah.

17
00:00:59.213 --> 00:01:01.785
I was gonna say acts of God,
but it's a vengeful God.

18
00:01:01.785 --> 00:01:03.507
>> [LAUGH]
>> That would wreak such havoc on

19
00:01:03.507 --> 00:01:04.115
the people.

20
00:01:04.115 --> 00:01:07.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

21
00:01:07.070 --> 00:01:10.469
can you tell it's late in the day.

22
00:01:10.469 --> 00:01:11.330
>> Yeah, right.

23
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:15.722
>> So before getting into some of the
theory, it's time for a little demo here.

24
00:01:15.722 --> 00:01:19.723
So we covered some of this in the first
course, but it bears repeating,

25
00:01:19.723 --> 00:01:20.866
repeating is good.

26
00:01:20.866 --> 00:01:24.950
If we could switch over to my computer,
formerly Mike's computer.

27
00:01:24.950 --> 00:01:25.709
I stole it.

28
00:01:25.709 --> 00:01:26.600
>> Thief.

29
00:01:26.600 --> 00:01:27.479
>> Not getting it back.

30
00:01:27.479 --> 00:01:29.330
So we're in central admin here.

31
00:01:29.330 --> 00:01:32.197
This won't be a surprise
to any of you to see this.

32
00:01:32.197 --> 00:01:34.117
If you were with us in
the first course and

33
00:01:34.117 --> 00:01:38.740
have any experience at all at SharePoint,
you're used to the central admin site.

34
00:01:38.740 --> 00:01:42.825
And from under the Backup and
Restore section,

35
00:01:42.825 --> 00:01:49.170
I'm gonna select to perform a backup and
let me get used to this computer.

36
00:01:49.170 --> 00:01:53.830
So we can see here, we can choose what
to back up only from the farm level.

37
00:01:53.830 --> 00:01:58.080
Which includes not everything you need to
recover from a disasters we talked about

38
00:01:58.080 --> 00:02:02.470
in the first course, but
a lot of the SharePoint related content.

39
00:02:02.470 --> 00:02:05.920
We can also get more specific than that,
more granular.

40
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:07.825
And you can see the various
checkboxes here.

41
00:02:07.825 --> 00:02:10.764
A checkbox denotes something
you can back up by itself.

42
00:02:10.764 --> 00:02:15.490
And for example,
the SharePoint service states service.

43
00:02:15.490 --> 00:02:19.475
And one of the things I like about this
interface, Microsoft did a good job in

44
00:02:19.475 --> 00:02:22.409
making it really obvious what
you're about to back up.

45
00:02:22.409 --> 00:02:25.167
And by extension,
what's not gonna be backed up,

46
00:02:25.167 --> 00:02:29.650
because it's not in that nice little
slate color or is it teal, I'm not sure.

47
00:02:29.650 --> 00:02:33.270
But at this point, I've selected
the SharePoint service date service, and

48
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:35.960
I can actually expand this date
service application if I wanted.

49
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:40.170
But the point is, it's gonna be included,
awesome database settings there.

50
00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:44.697
So the programming's intelligent
enough to not let you select something

51
00:02:44.697 --> 00:02:49.306
that's sort of partial or incomplete or
that you couldn't restore from.

52
00:02:49.306 --> 00:02:53.325
So you can get granular like that or
forum level or

53
00:02:53.325 --> 00:02:57.650
individual site collections,
that kind of thing.

54
00:02:57.650 --> 00:03:00.800
So for now, I'm gonna show you
how to back up at the farm level.

55
00:03:03.450 --> 00:03:05.095
And right, thanks.

56
00:03:05.095 --> 00:03:10.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's Windows on a Mac, and I'm getting

57
00:03:10.620 --> 00:03:15.791
coaching here on the gestures, reminders
about how to navigate the screen.

58
00:03:15.791 --> 00:03:17.520
Yes cool, all right.

59
00:03:17.520 --> 00:03:20.354
So then I can click on Next, and

60
00:03:20.354 --> 00:03:26.028
then I've done a backup already,
if you're wondering why?

61
00:03:26.028 --> 00:03:32.403
Hey, wait a minute the backup location
here whoops, is prepopulated.

62
00:03:32.403 --> 00:03:38.323
Here we go, you can see it,
the backup location says SQL,

63
00:03:38.323 --> 00:03:42.470
backup, and estimated disk space required.

64
00:03:42.470 --> 00:03:47.764
So this is based on whatever we selected,
I selected the entire farm.

65
00:03:47.764 --> 00:03:50.686
If I had chosen just the service app or
site collection of course,

66
00:03:50.686 --> 00:03:52.350
it'd be much less.

67
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:55.700
And then there's a backup type of full and
differential.

68
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:58.280
You get other options if
you use third party for

69
00:03:58.280 --> 00:04:00.380
your backups like incremental for example.

70
00:04:01.410 --> 00:04:05.510
And here I can choose to Back
up only config settings, but

71
00:04:05.510 --> 00:04:09.460
at this point, I wanna Back up content and
configuration settings.

72
00:04:09.460 --> 00:04:12.810
So then I can click on Start Back Up.

73
00:04:12.810 --> 00:04:14.241
So I'm not gonna do that now,

74
00:04:14.241 --> 00:04:17.179
because this back up will take
approximately 15 minutes.

75
00:04:17.179 --> 00:04:22.341
I did it before, so I cancel out of there.

76
00:04:22.341 --> 00:04:27.294
There we go, and I'm gonna show
you what it's like when we're

77
00:04:27.294 --> 00:04:31.319
gonna delete something,
a service application.

78
00:04:31.319 --> 00:04:34.853
And then we're gonna do a restore,
and we'll see what that looks like.

79
00:04:34.853 --> 00:04:40.258
So I'm going to go into

80
00:04:40.258 --> 00:04:44.818
back to-
>> [LAUGH]

81
00:04:44.818 --> 00:04:46.902
>> Backup and Restore.

82
00:04:46.902 --> 00:04:53.419
And I'm gonna click on Check backup and
restore our job status.

83
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:57.900
And the restore a job failed,
actually it didn't.

84
00:04:57.900 --> 00:04:59.235
That's an old.

85
00:04:59.235 --> 00:05:00.563
>> Is it the one that cancelled?

86
00:05:00.563 --> 00:05:03.495
>> No,
because this refers to a restore a job.

87
00:05:03.495 --> 00:05:04.632
>> Okay.
>> This is not a backup job.

88
00:05:04.632 --> 00:05:05.321
This is old,

89
00:05:05.321 --> 00:05:09.471
lingering information because I was
actually successfully able to restore.

90
00:05:09.471 --> 00:05:14.166
So I'm not sure why that's
actually there at this point, but

91
00:05:14.166 --> 00:05:18.692
this shows the status of restores,
so we can get a history.

92
00:05:18.692 --> 00:05:23.638
You can see what the success or
failure was of a given restore operation,

93
00:05:23.638 --> 00:05:25.560
or a backup operation.

94
00:05:25.560 --> 00:05:31.983
So for now, I wanna restore From a Backup,
and I only have one completed backup,

95
00:05:31.983 --> 00:05:35.682
so it makes it easy to
know which one to select.

96
00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:41.375
And I can expand if I want to make
absolutely sure I'm restoring

97
00:05:41.375 --> 00:05:44.176
the right one, or
restoring part of a certain backup.

98
00:05:44.176 --> 00:05:47.200
So that's the one I want,
that's the only one that exist.

99
00:05:47.200 --> 00:05:52.041
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'll click on Next.

100
00:05:57.015 --> 00:06:04.902
And it's waiting I think it might have
to take my two fingers together here.

101
00:06:04.902 --> 00:06:07.203
>> [LAUGH]
>> To make sure that using two fingers at

102
00:06:07.203 --> 00:06:07.706
a time.

103
00:06:07.706 --> 00:06:11.111
This is a new operation here.

104
00:06:11.111 --> 00:06:12.926
>> It's a beautiful thing.

105
00:06:12.926 --> 00:06:15.224
>> Yes, it's a learning organization.

106
00:06:15.224 --> 00:06:16.485
>> It's a skills market.

107
00:06:16.485 --> 00:06:17.886
>> [LAUGH]
>> You don't do operating

108
00:06:17.886 --> 00:06:19.079
system in front of him.

109
00:06:19.079 --> 00:06:22.085
It doesn't even faze him,
he just keeps on trucking with SharePoint.

110
00:06:22.085 --> 00:06:26.443
>> [LAUGH] Thanks for
the behind the scenes prompt from Mike.

111
00:06:26.443 --> 00:06:27.987
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's not like I type with two fingers

112
00:06:27.987 --> 00:06:29.827
either, so I'm not used to that operation.

113
00:06:29.827 --> 00:06:33.850
At last, what's going on now?

114
00:06:33.850 --> 00:06:35.053
I must have pressed one finger.

115
00:06:35.053 --> 00:06:36.801
It's still waiting,
still loading up there.

116
00:06:36.801 --> 00:06:40.042
You can see a little circle and
now is loaded.

117
00:06:40.042 --> 00:06:43.491
So because I backed up the full farm,

118
00:06:43.491 --> 00:06:49.068
I can choose the entire farm or
any elements of it to back up.

119
00:06:49.068 --> 00:06:52.444
Actually my bad, first I have to
delete something to make sure-

120
00:06:52.444 --> 00:06:53.028
>> Here we are.

121
00:06:53.028 --> 00:06:54.726
>> So the restore operation.

122
00:06:54.726 --> 00:06:58.510
>> [LAUGH]
>> I got confused on the way to that link.

123
00:06:58.510 --> 00:07:00.780
So I'm gonna go Managed
service applications.

124
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:06.290
ADD are us, and I just want to delete,

125
00:07:06.290 --> 00:07:12.290
let's say the machine translation service
So I select it by highlighting or

126
00:07:12.290 --> 00:07:15.640
clicking next to the link,
not gonna click the link itself.

127
00:07:15.640 --> 00:07:22.325
And for the ribbon I click eDlete,
and Delete data associated absolutely,

128
00:07:22.325 --> 00:07:28.103
and figure out the navigate
>> [LAUGH]

129
00:07:28.103 --> 00:07:30.076
>> I can click okay anyway.

130
00:07:30.076 --> 00:07:31.240
I always do that.

131
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:34.470
Model without scrolling, and
it says it shouldn't take long.

132
00:07:34.470 --> 00:07:36.720
My question is, why does it take so long?

133
00:07:36.720 --> 00:07:37.289
>> Yeah.

134
00:07:37.289 --> 00:07:40.351
[LAUGH]
>> I'm agreeing with the dialogue box.

135
00:07:40.351 --> 00:07:42.188
>> [LAUGH]
>> Later,

136
00:07:42.188 --> 00:07:46.632
we'll get a even smaller rectangle,
still saying it shouldn't take long.

137
00:07:46.632 --> 00:07:49.125
>> Long is relative, evidently.

138
00:07:49.125 --> 00:07:51.100
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, that's right.

139
00:07:51.100 --> 00:07:52.372
What would Einstein say?

140
00:07:52.372 --> 00:07:55.691
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we'll wait for it, and

141
00:07:55.691 --> 00:07:57.398
inject witty banter.

142
00:07:57.398 --> 00:07:58.500
>> That's right.

143
00:07:58.500 --> 00:08:02.996
Yeah, it was nice though to see that error
on the restore screen I thought, because.

144

00:21:34.885 --> 00:21:38.460
That's a less of an increase
capacity required.

376
00:21:38.460 --> 00:21:40.020
I think you get my drift.

377
00:21:40.020 --> 00:21:42.755
If not, write to Mike.

378
00:21:42.755 --> 00:21:45.100
>> [LAUGH] And
just to let everyone know as before,

379
00:21:45.100 --> 00:21:47.500
that came straight off of
TechNet site from Microsoft.

380
00:21:47.500 --> 00:21:51.520
I'll make sure I throw a link to
their article in your show notes, so

381
00:21:51.520 --> 00:21:54.030
you can have access to
those diagrams as well.

382
00:21:54.030 --> 00:21:56.280
All right, Mark, so
we've got our backup and restore.

383
00:21:56.280 --> 00:22:00.300
We've talked about some high availability
and redundancy in our architecture,

384
00:22:00.300 --> 00:22:05.140
whether it's on premises, or on premise,
I should say, or farm deployed.

385
00:22:05.140 --> 00:22:06.350
What's next?

386
00:22:06.350 --> 00:22:08.830
>> Well, let's go to fail over clustering.

387
00:22:08.830 --> 00:22:12.380
So there's a variety of fail over
options when it comes to SQL.

388
00:22:12.380 --> 00:22:16.950
We'll look at various options and then I
have a recommendation as to what the best

389
00:22:16.950 --> 00:22:20.520
one is in your 2016 environment for
SharePoint.

390
00:22:20.520 --> 00:22:24.855
So SQL server fail over cluster
as a possibility, and so

391
00:22:24.855 --> 00:22:29.130
we've got fail over between cluster nodes.

392
00:22:29.130 --> 00:22:32.994
Database mirroring is also a possibility,
although,

393
00:22:32.994 --> 00:22:38.253
what's better now is SQL server always on,
availability groups, because

394
00:22:38.253 --> 00:22:43.124
we get the benefits of data redundancy and
it's a lot easier to set up.

395
00:22:43.124 --> 00:22:47.417
And you don't need special hardware or
shared disks, for example.

396
00:22:47.417 --> 00:22:50.561
You can use the disks
of the cluster members,

397
00:22:50.561 --> 00:22:53.140
of the availability group members.

398
00:22:54.650 --> 00:22:57.396
You still could use database mirroring,
but

399
00:22:57.396 --> 00:23:01.160
it's recommended to use the always
on availability groups.

400
00:23:01.160 --> 00:23:02.440
If you have any SQL experience,

401
00:23:02.440 --> 00:23:07.240
you're probably familiar
with that since SQL 2014.

402
00:23:07.240 --> 00:23:13.700
Okay, so when it comes time to
look at any kind of backup or

403
00:23:13.700 --> 00:23:17.470
high availability option, there's
a couple concepts that always appear.

404
00:23:17.470 --> 00:23:20.340
Recovery time objective and
recovery point objective.

405
00:23:20.340 --> 00:23:24.980
Recovery point objective refers to,
how much data are you willing to lose?

406
00:23:26.050 --> 00:23:29.940
So for some organizations,
they might say no data.

407
00:23:29.940 --> 00:23:32.130
>> [CROSSTALK] Most people
probably start with no data.

408
00:23:32.130 --> 00:23:37.111
>> Yeah, but then when you, given the cost
estimate for that, they might say okay, we

409
00:23:37.111 --> 00:23:41.970
can use five minutes of data, say, or the
last one minute of data, what have you.

410
00:23:41.970 --> 00:23:44.330
So that's a factor to consider.

411
00:23:44.330 --> 00:23:46.610
That's recovery point objective.

412
00:23:46.610 --> 00:23:49.601
Recovery time objective means
how long is it gonna take you

413
00:23:49.601 --> 00:23:50.950
to get back to that point?

414
00:23:50.950 --> 00:23:52.285
What's the process involved?

415
00:23:52.285 --> 00:23:55.099
Is it simply a manual fail over option?

416
00:23:55.099 --> 00:23:57.260
You have to run a little script or
something?

417
00:23:57.260 --> 00:24:02.570
So that is something to
be decided in advance.

418
00:24:02.570 --> 00:24:05.280
As an admin, you want to be measured and
have known metrics.

419
00:24:05.280 --> 00:24:09.190
So rather than have your boss scream at
you on the phone because a database is

420
00:24:09.190 --> 00:24:14.590
down, better to have performance metrics,
that if a content database goes offline,

421
00:24:14.590 --> 00:24:17.089
for example,
you have an hour to restore it.

422
00:24:18.500 --> 00:24:21.280
That can be your service level agreement.

423
00:24:21.280 --> 00:24:26.120
So we talked in the first course about the
importance of service level agreements.

424
00:24:26.120 --> 00:24:29.170
But it bears repeating that even if
you don't have a formal service level

425
00:24:29.170 --> 00:24:32.070
agreement for uptime,
let's say in a SharePoint context or

426
00:24:32.070 --> 00:24:35.910
Exchange, or whatever else you're working
with, I suggest you have an informal

427
00:24:35.910 --> 00:24:40.710
service level agreement, which is fix
this asap or start looking for a job.

428
00:24:40.710 --> 00:24:43.390
Especially in the heat of
battle when you're trying to

429
00:24:43.390 --> 00:24:46.950
restore a conduit database,
say, from a backup perhaps,

430
00:24:46.950 --> 00:24:52.110
much better to know in advance what
the standards are for how long you've got.

431
00:24:52.110 --> 00:24:53.950
Might be four hours, might be a day.

432
00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:55.870
Depends on, of course,
how critical the workload is.

433
00:24:55.870 --> 00:24:59.160
So different content databases
in the SharePoint context.

434
00:24:59.160 --> 00:25:01.810
You might have different service
level agreements as to how

435
00:25:01.810 --> 00:25:03.340
fast you have to get those back online.

436
00:25:05.220 --> 00:25:09.490
So a lot of the comparisons between
recovery point objective and recovery time

437
00:25:09.490 --> 00:25:12.760
objective are the kinds of things
that are better looked at in a table.

438
00:25:12.760 --> 00:25:15.686
So we're not going to go through
every parameter there but

439
00:25:15.686 --> 00:25:19.388
I'm just giving you options to consider or
characteristics if you like,

440
00:25:19.388 --> 00:25:22.931
parameters, recovery time objective,
recovery point objective.

441
00:25:22.931 --> 00:25:24.467
Okay.

442
00:25:24.467 --> 00:25:27.293
And then you can compare against
the database mirror option,

443
00:25:27.293 --> 00:25:30.760
fail over clustering and
always on availability groups.

444
00:25:30.760 --> 00:25:35.810
Another option is a stretched farm,
this means it's like you're encapsulating

445
00:25:35.810 --> 00:25:39.290
two data centers which could be a long
way apart and treating them as one.

446
00:25:39.290 --> 00:25:43.690
Now, you definitely need very low latency.

447
00:25:43.690 --> 00:25:46.820
So, that precludes a large
geographic distance,

448
00:25:46.820 --> 00:25:49.355
unless you have fiber
connection which is possible.

449
00:25:49.355 --> 00:25:50.160
>> Mm-hm.

450
00:25:50.160 --> 00:25:53.500
>> So, generally there's some
relationship to physical proximity.

451
00:25:54.550 --> 00:26:01.680
And different options for ensuring
concurrency, or consistency of the data.

452
00:26:01.680 --> 00:26:05.300
So it could be an asynchronous or
a synchronous situation where synchronous

453
00:26:05.300 --> 00:26:09.700
means the data gets written in the remote
data center before it's committed

454
00:26:09.700 --> 00:26:12.870
at the local center, asynchronous
means there'll be some lag there.

455
00:26:15.000 --> 00:26:16.380
Okay.

456
00:26:16.380 --> 00:26:16.980
So that's that.

457
00:26:16.980 --> 00:26:19.570
Let's move on to the next concept here.

458
00:26:19.570 --> 00:26:21.110
Just checking the time.

459
00:26:21.110 --> 00:26:25.250
Let's look at supported high availability
and disaster recovery options for

460
00:26:25.250 --> 00:26:25.830
SharePoint.

461
00:26:25.830 --> 00:26:28.710
So the key thing here in terms of

462
00:26:28.710 --> 00:26:32.640
high availability groups which I mentioned
is the preferred way of going forward.

463
00:26:32.640 --> 00:26:36.130
There's two critical components
of SharePoint that cannot be

464
00:26:36.130 --> 00:26:37.610
made highly available this way.

465
00:26:37.610 --> 00:26:39.288
And that is your central admin database.

466
00:26:39.288 --> 00:26:43.980
And also your config database.

467
00:26:43.980 --> 00:26:46.080
Remember the config database is the farm.

468
00:26:46.080 --> 00:26:49.240
Your central admin database
pretty critical as well.

469
00:26:49.240 --> 00:26:52.140
They cannot be part of a high availability
group which means you need another

470
00:26:52.140 --> 00:26:54.990
strategy maybe involving log shipping for

471
00:26:54.990 --> 00:27:00.010
example to make those two particular
databases highly available.

472
00:27:01.190 --> 00:27:07.462
And depending on the service application,
there are different requirements as well.

473
00:27:07.462 --> 00:27:11.410
Because SharePoint can do so much,
there's dozens of service applications.

474
00:27:11.410 --> 00:27:15.280
I would love to be able to tell you
there's a one size fits all solution for

475
00:27:15.280 --> 00:27:18.190
making each of those service applications
highly available, but there isn't.

476
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:21.744
So depending on your workloads
that you're running whether you're

477
00:27:21.744 --> 00:27:24.317
running App Management for
example, or the BDC,

478
00:27:24.317 --> 00:27:27.030
the Business Data Connectivity
Service Database.

479
00:27:27.030 --> 00:27:29.338
By the way I'll be covering
that in another episode.

480
00:27:29.338 --> 00:27:31.992
That BDC service has its own episode.

481
00:27:31.992 --> 00:27:37.835
Manage Metadata Service Database,
which again has its own episode.

482
00:27:37.835 --> 00:27:40.945
[LAUGH] We're managing
high availability for

483
00:27:40.945 --> 00:27:43.610
these different application
databases differently.

484
00:27:43.610 --> 00:27:47.210
And again, that's not something that
lends itself to talking about but

485
00:27:47.210 --> 00:27:48.670
I'm just giving the heads up on that and
then,

486
00:27:48.670 --> 00:27:51.985
depending on the workloads you're running
you should definitely investigate for

487
00:27:51.985 --> 00:27:56.245
each of those service applications how to
make those databases highly available.

488
00:27:56.245 --> 00:27:59.375
Keep in mind, as well, if you're
watching the first week we learned that

489
00:27:59.375 --> 00:28:03.430
each service application that we
create creates at least one database.

490
00:28:03.430 --> 00:28:04.710
But often several or

491
00:28:04.710 --> 00:28:08.500
more than one especially in terms of
the user profile service, for example.

492
00:28:08.500 --> 00:28:12.010
So that's another reason why there's
no one size fits all approach

493
00:28:12.010 --> 00:28:14.260
to making service applications
highly available.

494
00:28:15.740 --> 00:28:19.025
Come to think of it, we have
a service applications episode too.

495
00:28:19.025 --> 00:28:21.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's like I tell people if they're

496
00:28:21.840 --> 00:28:25.630
new to SharePoint, I realize this is the
advanced course, but often, let's say you

497
00:28:25.630 --> 00:28:29.130
were watching the first week, and you'd
never interacted with SharePoint before.

498
00:28:29.130 --> 00:28:34.100
It's quite common to get progressively
more overwhelmed until the Friday,

499
00:28:34.100 --> 00:28:36.120
when things start to come together.

500
00:28:36.120 --> 00:28:41.080
Because it's tough to talk about concepts
in SharePoint in isolation, because so

501
00:28:41.080 --> 00:28:42.800
many concepts relate to others.

502
00:28:42.800 --> 00:28:46.090
And until you've got
a grasp of all the others,

503
00:28:46.090 --> 00:28:47.590
it's tough to make sense of the whole.

504
00:28:47.590 --> 00:28:49.950
So if you're,
you know that's just par for the course.

505
00:28:49.950 --> 00:28:51.050
It is a beast.

506
00:28:51.050 --> 00:28:52.160
>> Yes
>> It's a big animal.

507
00:28:52.160 --> 00:28:56.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> So search database is another example

508
00:28:56.140 --> 00:28:59.790
of different concepts to
make them highly available.

509
00:28:59.790 --> 00:29:01.450
Okay, that's all I want to say there.

510
00:29:01.450 --> 00:29:06.340
And now some best practices for
backup and restore.

511
00:29:06.340 --> 00:29:11.860
You definitely want to have low
latency between your SQL server and

512
00:29:11.860 --> 00:29:12.770
the backup location.

513
00:29:12.770 --> 00:29:15.700
In other words, don't have the backup
location you might get clever and think

514
00:29:15.700 --> 00:29:19.140
okay, I'm gonna put that backup location
in Siberia because that's thousands of

515
00:29:19.140 --> 00:29:25.555
miles away, not a good idea because
latency issues will cause problems.

516
00:29:25.555 --> 00:29:28.480
You also want to make sure to
eliminate I/O as a bottle neck so

517
00:29:28.480 --> 00:29:30.490
I have a lot of throughput there.

518
00:29:30.490 --> 00:29:35.114
Processing conflicts is a factor to keep
in mind If you work in IT you're probably

519
00:29:35.114 --> 00:29:37.240
aware there's many cycles.

520
00:29:37.240 --> 00:29:41.120
SharePoint itself has many cycles
as we looked at in the first week.

521
00:29:41.120 --> 00:29:45.040
Timer jobs run activities,
some happen in the matter of minutes,

522
00:29:45.040 --> 00:29:47.780
some are done hourly,
daily, weekly, monthly.

523
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:50.578
So that's just within SharePoint.

524
00:29:50.578 --> 00:29:54.990
But within the bigger IT picture
you've probably got exchange databases

525
00:29:54.990 --> 00:29:59.800
to back up, file servers to back up,
other routine maintenance operations.

526
00:29:59.800 --> 00:30:04.920
If you have a monthly calendar and
chunk it out into one hour blocks,

527
00:30:04.920 --> 00:30:08.208
there often is not a lot of spare time for
a new process.

528
00:30:08.208 --> 00:30:10.900
Either it's gonna have too big
of an impact on production users

529
00:30:10.900 --> 00:30:15.310
especially if you're a 24/7 shop where
the sun never sets on your business.

530
00:30:15.310 --> 00:30:17.470
And then other routine backup activities.

531
00:30:17.470 --> 00:30:21.330
So you want to in terms of

532
00:30:21.330 --> 00:30:25.080
keeping some best practices you wanna
have smaller content databases.

533
00:30:25.080 --> 00:30:29.918
I talked in the first week the basic
course 100 to 200 gigabytes max

534
00:30:29.918 --> 00:30:31.513
per content database.

535
00:30:31.513 --> 00:30:35.410
That gives you faster back up and
faster restore times right?

536
00:30:35.410 --> 00:30:40.756
So that is a key driver of the maximum
size of a given content database is,

537
00:30:40.756 --> 00:30:42.870
how fast can you restore it?

538
00:30:42.870 --> 00:30:44.770
Again, that goes back to
service level agreements.

539
00:30:44.770 --> 00:30:48.635
So in this episode, there's been
a lot of concepts intertwining.

540
00:30:48.635 --> 00:30:50.390
>> Mm-hm.
>> Just in this episode.

541
00:30:50.390 --> 00:30:53.079
Anyway, so smaller databases are better.

542
00:30:54.740 --> 00:31:00.190
Incremental backup strategy is totally
acceptable for larger databases.

543
00:31:00.190 --> 00:31:02.590
So the first database
backup would be huge, and

544
00:31:02.590 --> 00:31:04.810
then subsequent ones would be much faster.

545
00:31:04.810 --> 00:31:09.640
Using compression during
backup is a good idea.

546
00:31:09.640 --> 00:31:12.992
Whenever we talk compression, like
many things in IT, there's a tradeoff.

547
00:31:12.992 --> 00:31:16.400
There's gonna be a processor hit on
each end when you use compression.

548
00:31:16.400 --> 00:31:20.070
However the benefit there is you
get better bandwidth utilization,

549
00:31:20.070 --> 00:31:23.110
more efficient utilization of bandwidth.

550
00:31:23.110 --> 00:31:27.570
RAID, if you're gonna use RAID,
RAID 10 recommended.

551
00:31:27.570 --> 00:31:32.132
So if you have the budget for
it so that's a mirror.

552
00:31:32.132 --> 00:31:33.540
Okay.

553
00:31:33.540 --> 00:31:36.830
And let's see, what else do we wanna say?

554
00:31:39.150 --> 00:31:42.880
You wanna test your back ups do trial
restore as Mike alluded to that earlier.

555
00:31:42.880 --> 00:31:43.410
>> Very important.

556
00:31:46.420 --> 00:31:50.808
>> And you know what, that is a long
episode, so I'm gonna stop talking now.

557
00:31:50.808 --> 00:31:53.839
>> [LAUGH] All right Mark,
well important stuff.

558
00:31:53.839 --> 00:31:58.174
We appreciate you taking the time to give
us all of that information because it

559
00:31:58.174 --> 00:32:01.709
really is a fundamental part of
designing our architectures,

560
00:32:01.709 --> 00:32:05.330
understanding that back up and
restore process as you hit into.

561
00:32:05.330 --> 00:32:09.973
We've got to worry about
the what do we call it, the time?

562
00:32:09.973 --> 00:32:11.615
>> RPO and RTO?

563
00:32:11.615 --> 00:32:12.770
>> Yeah, the RPO and the RTO.

564
00:32:12.770 --> 00:32:16.145
The recovery time objective,
the recovery point objective.

565
00:32:16.145 --> 00:32:19.180
SLAs, all of these come into play.

566
00:32:19.180 --> 00:32:22.250
And we need to know these before
we design everything, right.

567
00:32:22.250 --> 00:32:24.430
Because that's gonna change
the way we design it,

568
00:32:24.430 --> 00:32:27.490
the way we implement the fault towers or
the load balancing, or

569
00:32:27.490 --> 00:32:31.850
the redundancy, how big we make
the maximum size on these databases.

570
00:32:31.850 --> 00:32:35.080
So you can see that there's
a lot to the planning phase, and

571
00:32:35.080 --> 00:32:36.620
we have to have all this
information ahead of time.

572
00:32:36.620 --> 00:32:39.790
So we appreciate you spending
the time explaining all that to us.

573
00:32:39.790 --> 00:32:42.300
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

574
00:32:42.300 --> 00:32:44.746
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

575
00:32:44.746 --> 00:32:45.925
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

576
00:32:45.925 --> 00:32:47.147
>> And we'll see you next time.

577
00:32:47.147 --> 00:32:53.946
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Business Connectivity Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.288 --> 00:00:15.420
Hello Welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.420 --> 00:00:20.289
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.289 --> 00:00:21.958
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.150
we're gonna be looking at
business connectivity services.

6
00:00:25.150 --> 00:00:27.770
And we got a lot of moving
parts in Enterprise and

7
00:00:27.770 --> 00:00:31.500
SharePoint can really get his fingers
out into a lot of those pieces.

8
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:34.010
We got to make sure we can
connect those different pieces.

9
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:36.310
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:37.213
How are you doing Mark?

11
00:00:37.213 --> 00:00:38.235
>> Mike, thanks very much.

12
00:00:38.235 --> 00:00:41.433
So if you're work at
organization like many,

13
00:00:41.433 --> 00:00:46.435
you're not gonna have all of the business
data you need to make decisions

14
00:00:46.435 --> 00:00:51.201
stored in house on a SharePoint
environment or on your file servers.

15
00:00:51.201 --> 00:00:54.041
Often we have to connect
into external systems, and

16
00:00:54.041 --> 00:00:57.700
that is the purpose of business
connectivity services.

17
00:00:57.700 --> 00:01:01.185
The acronym in BCS,
it's not the Bull Championship Series.

18
00:01:01.185 --> 00:01:02.744
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is business connectivity services.

19
00:01:02.744 --> 00:01:07.569
Now Microsoft has renamed this middleware
over the course of the SharePoint's

20
00:01:07.569 --> 00:01:09.880
history, but it does the same thing.

21
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:13.444
It's middleware,
it connects our SharePoint environment and

22
00:01:13.444 --> 00:01:17.736
office applications for example,
to one or more external content sources.

23
00:01:17.736 --> 00:01:19.970
And so anyway,
think of it like a translator.

24
00:01:19.970 --> 00:01:23.729
The middleware, the BCS middleware is
a translator between our SharePoint

25
00:01:23.729 --> 00:01:26.557
environment and
applications that our users would use.

26
00:01:26.557 --> 00:01:29.427
Like we're gonna Excel in
line of business apps and

27
00:01:29.427 --> 00:01:32.240
that external content
source wherever it lives.

28
00:01:32.240 --> 00:01:35.820
So that's the purpose of this episode.

29
00:01:35.820 --> 00:01:40.880
So we're gonna look at the diagram
coming up shortly that will help you
