00:16:09.571 --> 00:16:12.854
you to isolate issues with
a given service application.

258
00:16:12.854 --> 00:16:15.985
So there, you know, there is no limit to
the ones that you can create, you do it

259
00:16:15.985 --> 00:16:19.370
once then it's available for the service
app, so it's definitely best practice.

260
00:16:21.070 --> 00:16:21.800
Let's see here.

261
00:16:21.800 --> 00:16:27.810
Other past options, go, users expires,
user cannot change password and okay.

262
00:16:27.810 --> 00:16:34.020
And now, I'm going to register
the service account as a managed account.

263
00:16:34.020 --> 00:16:37.317
So I'm going to go over
to my SharePoint box.

264
00:16:53.000 --> 00:16:54.480
That was much faster than I expected.

265
00:16:54.480 --> 00:16:56.140
Hallelujah.
Actually I want my shell.

266
00:16:56.140 --> 00:16:59.780
I'm in the wrong,
let's get this management shell up here.

267
00:16:59.780 --> 00:17:03.790
But we'll need that lab and
site later anyway.

268
00:17:05.860 --> 00:17:07.020
So, that's okay.

269
00:17:07.020 --> 00:17:10.800
Let's wait for
the PowerShell prompt to appear here.

270
00:17:10.800 --> 00:17:15.560
I'm gonna change that font.

271
00:17:15.560 --> 00:17:19.315
>> That's good,
I was having trouble reading that one.

272
00:17:19.315 --> 00:17:20.700
>> [LAUGH] You're here to help.

273
00:17:20.700 --> 00:17:24.570
Wow, that's almost accessibility size,
but it can't be too big.

274
00:17:24.570 --> 00:17:28.500
Especially when you need to troubleshoot
some glitch in a PowerShell.

275
00:17:28.500 --> 00:17:30.380
Commandlet or parameter.

276
00:17:30.380 --> 00:17:32.100
So I want to create a new
SP managed account.

277
00:17:32.100 --> 00:17:36.640
This is kind of a hybrid, if you like,
between using the shell and a GUI.

278
00:17:36.640 --> 00:17:38.070
So I hit tab complete.

279
00:17:38.070 --> 00:17:41.000
And you see a credential box opens up.

280
00:17:41.000 --> 00:17:46.115
And I'm gonna specify the account
that I've just created, which is

281
00:17:46.115 --> 00:17:51.150
railtown/ BDC.

282
00:17:51.150 --> 00:17:57.620
And give it the right password.

283
00:18:00.470 --> 00:18:03.890
And we know it's successful because almost
instantly we get a result back with user

284
00:18:03.890 --> 00:18:07.380
name, password expiration,
this information about the user name, so

285
00:18:07.380 --> 00:18:09.220
that's now a managed account.

286
00:18:09.220 --> 00:18:14.820
As a refresher, a managed account means
Windows takes care of refreshing,

287
00:18:14.820 --> 00:18:17.020
or renewing if you like, the passwords,

288
00:18:17.020 --> 00:18:20.230
changing them on a schedule that
can be based on a domain policy.

289
00:18:20.230 --> 00:18:24.480
That way you get the security benefit
of rotating passwords every, say,

290
00:18:24.480 --> 00:18:27.890
six weeks or so, whatever you specified.

291
00:18:27.890 --> 00:18:31.920
Without the hassle of manually
changing that password.

292
00:18:31.920 --> 00:18:39.670
So again, recommendation, one manager
account per service application.

293
00:18:39.670 --> 00:18:42.130
So you might end up with 10 or
20 accounts for

294
00:18:42.130 --> 00:18:44.980
various service apps without the hassle
of having to manually change them.

295
00:18:44.980 --> 00:18:45.800
If you think about it,

296
00:18:45.800 --> 00:18:48.220
you want to eliminate any kind
of manual process like that.

297
00:18:48.220 --> 00:18:49.570
We've got enough to worry about.

298
00:18:49.570 --> 00:18:53.960
Fires come up, putting out fires,
planning for next year, without having to

299
00:18:53.960 --> 00:18:57.680
worry about this minutiae, which should
be handled automatically, and it is.

300
00:18:57.680 --> 00:19:00.720
Okay, so, that's good.

301
00:19:00.720 --> 00:19:03.540
Now I wanna start the business
data connectivity service, and

302
00:19:03.540 --> 00:19:07.550
to do that we'll go into Central Admin.,
which is over here.

303
00:19:07.550 --> 00:19:14.700
And we'll go into System Settings, and
I want to manage services on server.

304
00:19:18.170 --> 00:19:23.480
If you're low on coffee, you could easier
confuse and get the wrong item here.

305
00:19:23.480 --> 00:19:25.190
So make sure you're
actually thinking through.

306
00:19:25.190 --> 00:19:26.790
Okay, is it in the servers.

307
00:19:26.790 --> 00:19:27.960
Servicing the farms.

308
00:19:27.960 --> 00:19:29.640
Services on the servers.

309
00:19:29.640 --> 00:19:32.100
It's almost like a Dr. Seuss thing.

310
00:19:32.100 --> 00:19:32.710
All right.

311
00:19:32.710 --> 00:19:33.920
That's the one I want.

312
00:19:33.920 --> 00:19:36.410
If not, you can just hit the back
button and select the correct ones.

313
00:19:36.410 --> 00:19:38.910
No consequence for hitting the wrong one.

314
00:19:38.910 --> 00:19:39.540
All right.

315
00:19:39.540 --> 00:19:43.650
I'm just going to restart my
business data connectivity service.

316
00:19:43.650 --> 00:19:45.580
Something you like to do.

317
00:19:45.580 --> 00:19:46.110
And that's good.

318
00:19:46.110 --> 00:19:51.070
Now I'm going to create a new service
application instance for my BDC service,

319
00:19:51.070 --> 00:19:56.810
and I'll go into application management
for that and manage service applications.

320
00:19:59.730 --> 00:20:03.390
And then, with the new button here.

321
00:20:03.390 --> 00:20:05.570
Those various options,
but we'll keep it focused.

322
00:20:05.570 --> 00:20:08.200
We want the business data
connectivity service.

323
00:20:09.670 --> 00:20:13.620
The good thing about learning creating
service apps is once you've created one or

324
00:20:13.620 --> 00:20:16.480
two, you'll know how to
create all the others.

325
00:20:16.480 --> 00:20:19.910
I'm not saying they're all identical, but
there's going to be nothing that will

326
00:20:19.910 --> 00:20:23.370
throw you in the wizard that you're
prompted for certain entries,

327
00:20:23.370 --> 00:20:26.680
depending on the service
app you're creating.

328
00:20:26.680 --> 00:20:28.190
All right.
Service app name,

329
00:20:28.190 --> 00:20:32.617
we're going to call this rail

330
00:20:32.617 --> 00:20:39.310
town bdc and database name here.

331
00:20:39.310 --> 00:20:42.720
This is a guid, which we don't need
because it's not like we'll be creating

332
00:20:42.720 --> 00:20:44.330
thousands of databases this week.

333
00:20:44.330 --> 00:20:50.054
So I'm going to eliminate the unnecessary
complexity represented by the guid.

334
00:20:55.490 --> 00:20:57.569
Now, I'm using a Macintosh
piece of hardware,

335
00:20:57.569 --> 00:20:59.050
I don't know if there is a delete.

336
00:20:59.050 --> 00:21:00.355
I mean a delete as in backspace.

337
00:21:00.355 --> 00:21:01.670
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

338
00:21:01.670 --> 00:21:02.420
>> Anyway.

339
00:21:02.420 --> 00:21:03.820
>> A little different.

340
00:21:03.820 --> 00:21:05.570
>> Yeah, never hurts, I guess.

341
00:21:05.570 --> 00:21:14.840
So I'm gonna call this
RailTown BDC service database,

342
00:21:14.840 --> 00:21:18.720
always good, I always harp on this,
I don't care if I repeat it,

343
00:21:18.720 --> 00:21:23.520
it's worth repeating, keep these
consistent with your naming conventions,

344
00:21:23.520 --> 00:21:26.560
whether it's groups,
in this case it's the database name,

345
00:21:26.560 --> 00:21:31.000
I mean I'm using a domain name
in front of The BDC service db.

346
00:21:31.000 --> 00:21:33.700
Well thankfully Microsoft
has pre populated that,

347
00:21:33.700 --> 00:21:38.120
so, you wanna make it really obvious
what the name of something represents,

348
00:21:38.120 --> 00:21:44.260
whether it's a list, a group, a, you know,
a path or in this case a database name.

349
00:21:45.430 --> 00:21:46.260
All right.

350
00:21:46.260 --> 00:21:49.810
So that anyone meeting it down the road or
anybody trouble shooting can look at this

351
00:21:49.810 --> 00:21:54.200
and know exactly, maybe they go into
SQL now and look at the database and

352
00:21:54.200 --> 00:21:55.980
see what issue might have occurred.

353
00:21:55.980 --> 00:21:56.860
Is it just mounted?

354
00:21:56.860 --> 00:21:58.800
Is there some corruption in that database?

355
00:21:58.800 --> 00:22:01.665
As opposed to trying to wade
through some cute Star Trek names.

356
00:22:01.665 --> 00:22:05.845
>> [LAUGH]
>> Teletubbies names or something.

357
00:22:05.845 --> 00:22:07.645
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can't believe I said that on the air.

358
00:22:07.645 --> 00:22:09.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay.

359
00:22:09.030 --> 00:22:11.315
And now application pool.

360
00:22:11.315 --> 00:22:13.610
Remember when we're
creating a service app,

361
00:22:13.610 --> 00:22:16.720
we can always choose to create
a new application pool,

362
00:22:16.720 --> 00:22:22.320
which is like carving out, say,
250 megs or RAM for the application pool.

363
00:22:22.320 --> 00:22:24.800
You do get the security
benefit of isolation.

364
00:22:24.800 --> 00:22:27.560
But nobody has unlimited
hardware resources.

365
00:22:27.560 --> 00:22:30.460
Maybe you do, or it seems like unlimited.

366
00:22:30.460 --> 00:22:33.200
In certain context,
cuz you can always buy more.

367
00:22:33.200 --> 00:22:37.240
But, so there's a tradeoff between the
security isolation having the service app

368
00:22:37.240 --> 00:22:41.710
in its own app pool, isolated
processes versus running out of RAM,

369
00:22:41.710 --> 00:22:42.810
because you've had too many app pool.

370
00:22:42.810 --> 00:22:47.680
So in other words, I could choose the
rating button to use an existing app pool,

371
00:22:47.680 --> 00:22:50.700
but I'm not going to because hey, why not.

372
00:22:50.700 --> 00:22:51.450
Let's create a new app pool.

373
00:22:51.450 --> 00:22:55.680
This'll be RailTown,

374
00:22:55.680 --> 00:23:01.190
the SharePoint RailTown BDC.

375
00:23:01.190 --> 00:23:03.180
And then, here's the security count.

376
00:23:03.180 --> 00:23:06.440
This is the manage account it
just created a few minutes ago.

377
00:23:06.440 --> 00:23:09.281
It's the RailTown SP BDC.

378
00:23:09.281 --> 00:23:13.940
Now, you see register new manage account.

379
00:23:13.940 --> 00:23:17.290
You may think great a link but,
if you open that often,

380
00:23:17.290 --> 00:23:19.000
you'll loose the entire form contents.

381
00:23:19.000 --> 00:23:22.730
So, it's kind of annoying,
but it's another place to.

382
00:23:22.730 --> 00:23:26.180
The reason they put it here is you might
realize, I forgot to create the manage

383
00:23:26.180 --> 00:23:30.070
account that I wanted to use to
associate with service application and

384
00:23:30.070 --> 00:23:31.020
application pool.

385
00:23:31.020 --> 00:23:34.080
So it's a reminder and a chance to create
one that you're gonna lose whatever you

386
00:23:34.080 --> 00:23:35.860
entered in the form already.

387
00:23:35.860 --> 00:23:37.570
So but I already created, so okay.

388
00:23:39.350 --> 00:23:43.600
So now we've created the new
BDC service application,

389
00:23:43.600 --> 00:23:45.820
nice to get the actual
confirmation dialog.

390
00:23:45.820 --> 00:23:48.830
Some dialogs you'll notice
in SharePoint 2016,

391
00:23:48.830 --> 00:23:52.640
particularly the managed metadata service,
it can leave you hanging.

392
00:23:52.640 --> 00:23:55.253
You're wondering wondering is it working,
is it not.

393
00:23:55.253 --> 00:24:00.057
Most of them, the service apps including
this one, do give you the feedback you

394
00:24:00.057 --> 00:24:03.588
want that it's working and
it was created successfully.

395
00:24:03.588 --> 00:24:04.572
Okay.
>> That was good.

396
00:24:04.572 --> 00:24:06.259
>> Yes, nice to get that feedback.

397
00:24:06.259 --> 00:24:09.454
Or if something didn't work,
you wanna know as soon as possible,

398
00:24:09.454 --> 00:24:11.289
then you can take corrective action.

399
00:24:11.289 --> 00:24:18.810
Okay, now I'm gonna select my service
application I just created, Real Town BDC.

400
00:24:18.810 --> 00:24:21.556
Remember when it comes to
working with service apps,

401
00:24:21.556 --> 00:24:25.320
you don't want to click on
the service app necessarily,

402
00:24:25.320 --> 00:24:28.058
depending on what you're doing you,
can select the line.

403
00:24:28.058 --> 00:24:30.010
Well, the line will appear.

404
00:24:30.010 --> 00:24:32.130
If you click it, the line will appear.

405
00:24:32.130 --> 00:24:35.070
Next to the appropriate service app.

406
00:24:35.070 --> 00:24:40.561
And it's the application
Real Town BDC in this case.

407
00:24:40.561 --> 00:24:43.044
And, oops, okay.

408
00:24:43.044 --> 00:24:46.503
And I'm going to click on Manage now.

409
00:24:46.503 --> 00:24:51.523
Notice if you hover over
these icons in the ribbon,

410
00:24:51.523 --> 00:24:54.450
you get tool tip quite often.

411
00:24:55.500 --> 00:24:56.470
F2 for more help.

412
00:24:56.470 --> 00:24:57.190
That's unusual.

413
00:24:57.190 --> 00:24:58.212
Whatever happened to F1?

414
00:24:58.212 --> 00:25:00.750
>> I guess F2 is the new F1.

415
00:25:00.750 --> 00:25:05.660
>> I'll click manage, And
other thing I was thinking

416
00:25:05.660 --> 00:25:09.420
about the other day is this little circle
that's going around in the tab here.

417
00:25:09.420 --> 00:25:12.960
It would be cool if you
could change the color.

418
00:25:12.960 --> 00:25:15.890
Just to make it really obvious that
something is happening because often I'm

419
00:25:15.890 --> 00:25:16.880
thinking did that work?

420
00:25:16.880 --> 00:25:19.120
And then I have to look up
at this tiny little circle.

421
00:25:19.120 --> 00:25:23.930
Anyway these are what we
call first world problems.

422
00:25:23.930 --> 00:25:26.402
[LAUGH] I want the circle to be bigger.

423
00:25:26.402 --> 00:25:31.190
All right, now I want to set
metadata store permissions.

424
00:25:33.420 --> 00:25:36.359
And I'm gonna specify my admin account.

425
00:25:38.461 --> 00:25:40.631
Now, I could type
the whole thing correctly,

426
00:25:40.631 --> 00:25:42.534
and hit Enter, and a line would appear.

427
00:25:42.534 --> 00:25:45.628
I get lazy sometimes, or efficient,

428
00:25:45.628 --> 00:25:50.567
I type part of it, hit Enter and
then you get a squiggly line.

429
00:25:50.567 --> 00:25:53.539
Which you see in other versions
of SharePoint and that

430
00:25:53.539 --> 00:25:57.910
I can just click on what I've typed and
then choose the actual name that I want.

431
00:25:57.910 --> 00:26:00.970
Notice how it's underlined, so
I know it's a legitimate account.

432
00:26:00.970 --> 00:26:02.100
And now I need to click add.

433
00:26:04.260 --> 00:26:08.439
Now there's various permissions we
talked about earlier in the episode.

434
00:26:09.660 --> 00:26:13.720
So I'm granting metadata stores
permissions to my account,

435
00:26:13.720 --> 00:26:15.190
administrator account.

436
00:26:15.190 --> 00:26:16.270
I'm gonna include all of them.

437
00:26:16.270 --> 00:26:21.090
So edit, execute, selectable clients,
and the ability to set permissions.

438
00:26:22.530 --> 00:26:24.120
And then, the last check box here.

439
00:26:24.120 --> 00:26:28.090
I'm gonna select that and that's gonna
allow me to propagate permissions to

440
00:26:28.090 --> 00:26:32.490
the BDC models, external systems and
external content types.

441
00:26:32.490 --> 00:26:34.390
We talked about all those earlier.

442
00:26:34.390 --> 00:26:38.620
And then a warning that whatever
permissions I'm setting now,

443
00:26:38.620 --> 00:26:39.860
all four of them in this case,

444
00:26:39.860 --> 00:26:42.740
will overwrite whatever permissions
may have already have been set.

445
00:26:42.740 --> 00:26:45.330
In this case, it doesn't matter because
it's the first time I'm establishing

446
00:26:45.330 --> 00:26:46.533
any permissions.

447
00:26:46.533 --> 00:26:50.560
But we always wanna make sure, okay, when
we're adding or modifying permissions,

448
00:26:50.560 --> 00:26:52.950
are we going to erase the permissions
that currently exist or

449
00:26:52.950 --> 00:26:55.520
are we adding on extra permissions?

450
00:26:55.520 --> 00:26:59.246
You need clarity of thought [LAUGH].

451
00:26:59.246 --> 00:27:02.900
If you're fuzzy, go away, come back and
think through the ramifications.

452
00:27:02.900 --> 00:27:04.920
Sometimes we get lazy and
just hit okay, okay, okay,

453
00:27:04.920 --> 00:27:08.670
just to get the wizard over with, and then
realize actually, I didn't wanna do that.

454
00:27:08.670 --> 00:27:10.160
And then you have to uninstall something.

455
00:27:10.160 --> 00:27:12.220
It's, so clarity of thought.

456
00:27:12.220 --> 00:27:13.140
So hit okay.

457
00:27:13.140 --> 00:27:15.270
So that dialog box completed.

458
00:27:15.270 --> 00:27:18.230
>> Great look at setting up that
business connectivity service.

459
00:27:18.230 --> 00:27:21.330
Creating that service account,
getting everything set up that we need.

460
00:27:21.330 --> 00:27:22.320
We still have a little more to do,

461
00:27:22.320 --> 00:27:25.940
I know, cuz we haven't worked with
our secure store service yet.

462
00:27:25.940 --> 00:27:28.390
But unfortunately we're out of time for
this particular episode so

463
00:27:28.390 --> 00:27:30.260
we're gonna have to make
a part two out of it.

464
00:27:30.260 --> 00:27:32.680
So make sure you come back and
join us for that one.

465
00:27:32.680 --> 00:27:35.760
For now, that's gonna do it,
again, we appreciate the look.

466
00:27:35.760 --> 00:27:38.300
We talked about business
connectivity services,

467
00:27:38.300 --> 00:27:42.500
and where we might find that useful in our
enterprise connecting to those external

468
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:44.990
data sources, if I can say that correctly.

469
00:27:44.990 --> 00:27:49.100
Being able to index those
external sources and setting up,

470
00:27:49.100 --> 00:27:51.140
as Mark has said several times,

471
00:27:51.140 --> 00:27:55.770
the ability to search from one location
all of these different data sources.

472
00:27:55.770 --> 00:27:58.950
Just makes it more convenient for
your users, for everybody.

473
00:27:58.950 --> 00:28:00.220
And you're gonna get that buy in.

474
00:28:00.220 --> 00:28:04.750
People will just start using Share Point
more and it just snowballs from there.

475
00:28:04.750 --> 00:28:06.590
People start loving Share Point.

476
00:28:06.590 --> 00:28:07.960
Which they should right?

477
00:28:07.960 --> 00:28:10.860
Especially after watching
these videos here.

478
00:28:10.860 --> 00:28:11.430
All right Mark.

479
00:28:11.430 --> 00:28:12.780
Well, we appreciate that demonstration.

480
00:28:12.780 --> 00:28:13.890
Look forward to the next one.

481
00:28:13.890 --> 00:28:16.100
But for now, signing off,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

482
00:28:16.100 --> 00:28:16.650
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

483
00:28:16.650 --> 00:28:18.859
>> And we'll see you next time.

484

WEBVTT

Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.430 --> 00:00:19.220
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing an advance SharePoint 2016.

00:00:19.220 --> 00:00:21.840
And specifically in this episode,

00:00:21.840 --> 00:00:26.690
we're gonna be continuing on with
our business connectivity services.

6
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:27.630

00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:31.200
Remember that previous episode,
we got everything kind of set up.

00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:33.700
We created that business
connectivity service,

00:00:33.700 --> 00:00:37.230

00:00:37.230 --> 00:00:40.140
Now we're going to be working
with the secure store service,

11
00:00:40.140 --> 00:00:44.320
where we store the credentials used
by the business connectivity service.

12
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:46.620
And here to show us the way,
is Mr. Mark Ingram.

13
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:47.600
How are you doing, Mark?

14
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:48.820
>> And Mike, thank you.

15
00:00:48.820 --> 00:00:51.410
All right, now,
we done some preliminaries.

16
00:00:51.410 --> 00:00:55.570
Now we wanna create a service account
to run the secure store service, so

17
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:57.280
I'll do that for my DC.

18
00:00:57.280 --> 00:01:00.660
I'm in my actual directory
administer of center still and

19
00:01:00.660 --> 00:01:02.740
I'm gonna click in new user.

20
00:01:04.570 --> 00:01:10.975
And this will be SPSSS,
sounds like senior secondary school.

21
00:01:10.975 --> 00:01:11.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, that's not it.

22
00:01:11.740 --> 00:01:16.580
It's secure store service,
I am all for acronyms.

23
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:19.845
Make sure I got that right,
and the password!

24
00:01:29.489 --> 00:01:32.560
That's good, and
then we'll make it password never expires.

25
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:33.985
User cannot change password.

26
00:01:33.985 --> 00:01:40.320
And that's good and we're gonna
register another managed account,

27
00:01:40.320 --> 00:01:44.408
so for
that we'll go back to SharePoint box,

28
00:01:46.748 --> 00:01:53.330
And back into the shell, so the up arrow
cuz we're doing the exact same thing.

29
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:56.800
So this time would be SPSSS.

30
00:01:56.800 --> 00:01:59.938
Actually no, we want domain name first.

31
00:01:59.938 --> 00:02:05.864
Realtown/password and

32
00:02:05.864 --> 00:02:11.050
right away we can see the creation
of the kennel was successful, so

33
00:02:11.050 --> 00:02:12.180
that's all we need there.

34
00:02:12.180 --> 00:02:17.520
Now I'll go back into central admin
on this same machine here, and

35
00:02:17.520 --> 00:02:24.740
this time we want to go to system
settings and managed services on service.

36
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:25.580
It's helpful.

37
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:29.350
The hyperlinks of options you've used
recently appear in a different color,

38
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:30.800
just like other hyperlinks would so

39
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:35.080
that helps you if you frequently use
certain options in central admin.

40
00:02:35.080 --> 00:02:36.830
Saves you a bit of time there and

41
00:02:36.830 --> 00:02:40.820
I'm gonna scroll down to
secure a story service.

42
00:02:40.820 --> 00:02:43.680
I like to restart it so will do that.

43
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:46.200
>> And you change the account that
service was running under, so

44
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:49.970
you wanna restart it so it knows,
hey I got a new account to use.

45
00:02:49.970 --> 00:02:54.360
>> Indeed and now we're going
to application managements and

46
00:02:54.360 --> 00:02:58.760
manage service applications and

47
00:02:58.760 --> 00:03:03.130
we want new secure or store service.

48
00:03:03.130 --> 00:03:04.672
I'm tricking myself up with it now.

49
00:03:04.672 --> 00:03:05.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

50
00:03:05.830 --> 00:03:06.950
we'll give it an intelligent name.

51
00:03:06.950 --> 00:03:11.930
Let's call it Railtown Secure Store and

52
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:18.085
database name,
I'll get rid of that GUID again.

53
00:03:26.478 --> 00:03:28.452
And put Railtown in front of it.

54
00:03:36.005 --> 00:03:43.366
All right, and
create new application pool,

55
00:03:43.366 --> 00:03:47.518
so scroll down for that and

56
00:03:47.518 --> 00:03:54.710
this will be SharePoint's, real town SSS.

57
00:03:54.710 --> 00:03:57.110
And we'll use the manage
account just created.

58
00:03:58.740 --> 00:04:04.730
Slash SPSSS and there's an option there
for the audit log, 30 days until purged.

59
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:08.060
Now, you maybe an organization where
you're not allowed to purge audit logs.

60
00:04:08.060 --> 00:04:11.110
You may have to keep them indefinitely,
certain military applications, or for

61
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:15.270
an extended period, so In that case,
you deselect that option.

62
00:04:15.270 --> 00:04:16.230
Sorry, you wouldn't deselect.

63
00:04:16.230 --> 00:04:19.210
You'd change the days until purge
to something much higher than 30.

64
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:20.900
I'll leave it at default, hit OK.

65
00:04:23.990 --> 00:04:26.040
That worked and I'll hit OK.

66
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:31.573
That secure store was successfully
created, was there any doubt?

67
00:04:31.573 --> 00:04:33.469
>> [LAUGH]
>> No.

68
00:04:33.469 --> 00:04:38.032
>> No.
>> [LAUGH] So select Railtown Secure Store

69
00:04:38.032 --> 00:04:42.781
and up on the ribbon I'll click on manage.

70
00:04:47.923 --> 00:04:50.315
And now I need to generate a new key.

71
00:04:50.315 --> 00:04:54.885
And in case,
there's any doubt about that, there's

72
00:04:54.885 --> 00:04:58.667
a pink background box here, and notice
the other options aren't even available.

73
00:04:58.667 --> 00:05:01.187
So it makes it pretty obvious
what the next step is.

74
00:05:02.207 --> 00:05:06.997
Now sometimes, we use pass phrases
in Windows administration.

75
00:05:06.997 --> 00:05:11.837
This is one of those examples which is
presumably more secure than a password,

76
00:05:11.837 --> 00:05:13.217
because you can includes spaces in there.

77
00:05:13.217 --> 00:05:17.647
It's much tougher to crack
a sentence than a word.

78
00:05:17.647 --> 00:05:19.350
All right, so I'll enter that info.

79
00:05:26.918 --> 00:05:29.469
And a warning here in the dialog box,

80
00:05:29.469 --> 00:05:33.600
the pass phrase will not be stored and
it is case sensitive.

81
00:05:33.600 --> 00:05:37.230
So if you wanna add a new
secure store service server or

82
00:05:37.230 --> 00:05:43.080
if you need to do a restore from
a back up, you'll need this password.

83
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:48.490
So sometimes writing things down
is not an insecure practice or

84
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:51.710
maybe you save it on a USB key and
you stick that in a safe.

85
00:05:51.710 --> 00:05:53.859
But the point is you need
to know this passphrase.

86
00:05:53.859 --> 00:05:54.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you don't and

87
00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:55.610
you're trying to restore,

88
00:05:55.610 --> 00:05:58.690
you're gonna have to recreate everything
to do with your Secure Store service.

89
00:05:58.690 --> 00:06:01.499
So write it down, please.

90
00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:05.380
Unless it's your dog name, okay.

91
00:06:05.380 --> 00:06:09.170
That worked and now,
that warning has gone away and

92
00:06:09.170 --> 00:06:12.884
it gives guidance for
the next step there as well.

93
00:06:12.884 --> 00:06:16.216
Right now at this point, we've created and

94
00:06:16.216 --> 00:06:20.731
configured a secure store
service application instance.

95
00:06:20.731 --> 00:06:24.204
Now we want to create a target
application, so in other words,

96
00:06:24.204 --> 00:06:26.710
what are we connecting to.

97
00:06:26.710 --> 00:06:31.660
That's the purpose of this next phase here
so go back into application management

98
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:39.970
here's applications and
we're back to Railtown Secure Store.

99
00:06:41.180 --> 00:06:45.760
And manage, and now I'm gonna select new.

100
00:06:45.760 --> 00:06:50.730
And I'm gonna call this

101
00:06:50.730 --> 00:06:57.250
Target Application ID Railtown,
I'll say data warehouse.

102
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:03.490
TA for Target Application and
let's give it a display name.

103
00:07:03.490 --> 00:07:08.660
That never hurts either, so
I'll say Realtown data warehouse.

104
00:07:11.090 --> 00:07:15.976
Database target application and

105
00:07:15.976 --> 00:07:24.550
again display name helpful
often there's a tool tip.

106
00:07:24.550 --> 00:07:27.630
Just extra confirmation that
you're on the right path.

107
00:07:27.630 --> 00:07:30.125
Contact email sure I'll say administrator

108
00:07:30.125 --> 00:07:38.090
@realtown.com, and

109
00:07:39.100 --> 00:07:40.520
now, the target application type.

110
00:07:40.520 --> 00:07:43.840
Remember we can use individuals or
groups, we can even specify

111
00:07:43.840 --> 00:07:47.700
tickets which have a 2 hour expiry, so
it can be leveraged by other users.

112
00:07:47.700 --> 00:07:53.434
I'll just keep it simple and
I'll click on a group and

113
00:07:53.434 --> 00:07:57.014
that's all I need there, next.

114
00:08:01.304 --> 00:08:04.670
Okay, so these are the default options
here, Windows User Name and Password.

115
00:08:04.670 --> 00:08:07.430
If I click on Add Field
it exposes different

116
00:08:07.430 --> 00:08:10.950
field types I can use to authenticate
to the target application.

117
00:08:10.950 --> 00:08:16.242
So I might wanna use this,
t he certificate for

118
00:08:16.242 --> 00:08:19.650
example or a PIN or even a key.

119
00:08:19.650 --> 00:08:22.560
So we have a variety of ways to
authenticate that target application.

120
00:08:22.560 --> 00:08:24.490
For now,
I'll delete that additional field,

121
00:08:24.490 --> 00:08:28.680
and stick with the default Windows
username and Windows password.

122
00:08:28.680 --> 00:08:33.510
Hit Next, and
then I'll specify my admin account

123
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:46.528
and that resolves successfully and
I will add me as a member as well.

124
00:08:46.528 --> 00:08:50.103
[SOUND] Administrator accounts

125
00:08:55.831 --> 00:08:57.110
All right, and then okay.

126
00:09:00.335 --> 00:09:06.103
Now, I'm gonna set the credentials for
the target application,

127
00:09:06.103 --> 00:09:11.466
so I will select my real town DWTA and
then in the credentials.

128
00:09:11.466 --> 00:09:15.410
This is a little confusing here because
There's a set button for credentials and

129
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:16.920
a set button for permissions.

130
00:09:16.920 --> 00:09:20.150
So you know, if I was designing this
I would just say set credentials or

131
00:09:20.150 --> 00:09:23.255
set permissions on the button,
but I didn't code the product.

132
00:09:23.255 --> 00:09:24.003
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

133
00:09:24.003 --> 00:09:27.060
make sure you're clicking on set
credentials that's the next step.

134
00:09:32.949 --> 00:09:39.535
And let's say for
user name it will be Railtown/,

135
00:09:39.535 --> 00:09:45.060
I'm gonna use administrator here again.

136
00:09:48.185 --> 00:09:53.341
And plus for the password confirm.

137
00:10:00.198 --> 00:10:03.199
So, in the field, you probably have
a separate username here instead of just

138
00:10:03.199 --> 00:10:07.570
administrator again, but for convenience,
I'm just showing you with administrator.

139
00:10:07.570 --> 00:10:08.070
I hit OK.

140
00:10:10.217 --> 00:10:14.230
Next stop and lastly we're going to
import and configure BDC models.

141
00:10:14.230 --> 00:10:18.940
So I'll go back into Application
Management > Manage service applications.

142
00:10:20.560 --> 00:10:29.220
Go down to Railtown BDC > Manage and
now we want to import the model.

143
00:10:31.210 --> 00:10:35.030
And this is where I would choose
browse and I would link to,

144
00:10:35.030 --> 00:10:37.620
or click on, a file with extension BDCM.

145
00:10:37.620 --> 00:10:43.090
This is something you can create in
SharePoint Designer, takes about 13 steps.

146
00:10:43.090 --> 00:10:46.820
The idea is you're setting up credentials,
the mapping, to create the model.

147
00:10:46.820 --> 00:10:50.314
You end up with a very large XNL
file that scrolls several pages.

148
00:10:50.314 --> 00:10:54.201
That's beyond the scope of what we're
showing here, but the point is that you or

149
00:10:54.201 --> 00:10:56.791
probably someone else,
a Dev in your organization.

150
00:10:56.791 --> 00:11:00.669
Would have already created that model
at that point, you browse to it and

151
00:11:00.669 --> 00:11:03.270
just select that file and import it.

152
00:11:03.270 --> 00:11:06.490
And then you would associate
the external system,

153
00:11:06.490 --> 00:11:09.280
the BDC, with a target application.

154
00:11:09.280 --> 00:11:13.230
And then from then on, you just with
correct permissions can interact with that

155
00:11:13.230 --> 00:11:16.710
target application, do things like
choose lists, modify permissions, or

156
00:11:16.710 --> 00:11:19.070
whatever permissions
we'd allow them to do.

157
00:11:19.070 --> 00:11:20.620
So that completes this demo.

158
00:11:20.620 --> 00:11:23.228
>> So that model then might
created by the actual data.

159
00:11:23.228 --> 00:11:28.330
Store owner, or if you were connecting to
a database that somebody was managing.

160
00:11:28.330 --> 00:11:31.302
They might give us the model that we
could use to connect our SharePoint to

161
00:11:31.302 --> 00:11:32.100
their database.

162
00:11:32.100 --> 00:11:34.260
>> Exactly, and they'd probably
want to have a say in it, frankly.

163
00:11:34.260 --> 00:11:36.430
>> Yes, because it affects what they do.

164
00:11:36.430 --> 00:11:39.740
So the model is, again it's many
pages of XML it turns out into,

165
00:11:39.740 --> 00:11:44.230
you can create it easily in SharePoint
just designer have someone do it for you.

166
00:11:44.230 --> 00:11:44.820
>> Very good.
Mark again,

167
00:11:44.820 --> 00:11:46.190
another great demonstration there,

168
00:11:46.190 --> 00:11:50.640
looking at secure store service
where we can put the credentials

169
00:11:50.640 --> 00:11:54.440
in that we're gonna be using to connect
to those different external data sources.

170
00:11:54.440 --> 00:11:56.960
So we can start tying it all together,
set up our search to work, and

171
00:11:56.960 --> 00:11:59.820
search our enterprise no matter
where that data is stored.

172
00:11:59.820 --> 00:12:01.010
So we thank you for that.

173
00:12:01.010 --> 00:12:04.406
Hope everybody out there enjoyed those
demonstrations and watching this episode.

174
00:12:04.406 --> 00:12:06.696
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mark Rodrick.

175
00:12:06.696 --> 00:12:07.712
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

176
00:12:07.712 --> 00:12:08.939
>> And we'll see you next time.

177
00:12:08.939 --> 00:12:18.939
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Enterprise Content Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.096 --> 00:00:10.096
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:14.189
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode

3
00:00:14.189 --> 00:00:16.616
here at ITVPro TV I'm your
host Mike Roderick and

4
00:00:16.616 --> 00:00:19.230
today we're doing
Advanced SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:19.230 --> 00:00:21.543
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:21.543 --> 00:00:25.712
we're gonna be focusing in on
Enterprise Content Management.

7
00:00:25.712 --> 00:00:31.070
And here to help us with all that fun
stuff is the one and only Mr. Mark Ingram.

8
00:00:31.070 --> 00:00:32.040
How you doing Mark?

9
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:33.902
>> Nice Mike.
When you're this big they call you Mister.

10
00:00:33.902 --> 00:00:34.587
>> That's right.

11
00:00:34.587 --> 00:00:37.802
[LAUGH]
>> ECM If nothing else you'll leave with

12
00:00:37.802 --> 00:00:42.060
acronym knowledge,
Enterprise Content Management.

13
00:00:42.060 --> 00:00:45.250
So, how do you keep control
over your sites and content?

14
00:00:45.250 --> 00:00:47.850
That's the subject of ECM and

15
00:00:47.850 --> 00:00:52.970
again as I've said many times
already in this week's class and

16
00:00:52.970 --> 00:00:59.090
the first SharePoint week we did a lot of
what we're doing is not that difficult.

17
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:00.930
Click here, select this.

18
00:01:00.930 --> 00:01:02.850
It's the planning, the governance,

19
00:01:02.850 --> 00:01:07.400
the deciding who gets to decide
about what information to retain.

20
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:09.140
Where should it be stored?

21
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:10.440
Who gets access to it?

22
00:01:10.440 --> 00:01:15.290
All these are non technical decisions
that definitely effect the overall

23
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:17.019
utility of your SharePoint environment.

24
00:01:18.590 --> 00:01:19.580
So we'll look at document and

25
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:24.560
file management capabilities,
information management policies as well.

26
00:01:25.580 --> 00:01:29.300
And so we were talking
enterprise content management,

27
00:01:29.300 --> 00:01:34.720
we're really talking about a few areas
including web content management,

28
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:38.740
which is so significant it gets
its own episode, maybe two.

29
00:01:39.790 --> 00:01:42.330
Records management and
document management,

30
00:01:42.330 --> 00:01:46.720
all those fall under the umbrella
of enterprise content management.

31
00:01:46.720 --> 00:01:49.470
So in terms of document management,

32
00:01:49.470 --> 00:01:54.590
now a lot of these are activities
that end users would do or

33
00:01:54.590 --> 00:01:59.830
sometimes power users but not, generally
users of the SharePoint platform.

34
00:01:59.830 --> 00:02:04.600
This is not a farm administrative a task
or even a administration task often.

35
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:07.620
So with SharePoint we have
a delegated administration model.

36
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:10.980
Do not be the farm administer
that says yes to all requests for

37
00:02:10.980 --> 00:02:14.900
basic administration that really should
be handled at more of a department level.

38
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:18.110
For one thing department managers or
information managers say,

39
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:22.520
are gonna be more in tune with
their needs and requirements for

40
00:02:22.520 --> 00:02:26.320
information classification and
search and categorization.

41
00:02:26.320 --> 00:02:28.170
Then you would be as a farm administrator.

42
00:02:28.170 --> 00:02:30.490
You can't know everything
in the enterprise,

43
00:02:30.490 --> 00:02:34.530
information management wise, so you
definitely wanna make sure site collection

44
00:02:34.530 --> 00:02:39.120
administrators are trained up to do and
manage their part of the SharePoint world.

45
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:43.460
Much like in Windows administration, we'd
have delegated administration for OUs for

46
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:46.150
example, similar idea there.

47
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:51.420
So however but as SharePoint
admins we're also users as well.

48
00:02:51.420 --> 00:02:54.460
So what are some of the document
management functions, checking out and

49
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:55.060
checking in.

50
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:58.770
This let's you restrict
editing to one user at a time.

51
00:03:00.120 --> 00:03:04.170
Unless you have Office online server,
it used to be the Office Web Apps Server.

52
00:03:04.170 --> 00:03:06.710
If you install that,
which we will this week,

53
00:03:06.710 --> 00:03:10.890
you can get concurrent
authoring capabilities.

54
00:03:10.890 --> 00:03:13.540
So multiple people can work
on the exact same document.

55
00:03:13.540 --> 00:03:16.010
You can see who's working on what,
who's editing on what.

56
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:17.037
It's kind of freaky, actually.

57
00:03:17.037 --> 00:03:18.927
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

58
00:03:18.927 --> 00:03:20.846
>> If you're used to working solo or

59
00:03:20.846 --> 00:03:24.412
maybe sending somebody changes or
in the case of SharePoint,

60
00:03:24.412 --> 00:03:28.750
checking in a document you've checked
out so someone else can make edits.

61
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:33.838
So if you're not used to current editing,
it can be something to get used to.

62
00:03:33.838 --> 00:03:38.530
Versioning so, we look at something
that's new and versioning then later on

63
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:43.410
in this episode but the idea there is
you want to save users from themselves.

64
00:03:43.410 --> 00:03:48.550
By retaining x number of previous
versions of a document and in the first

65
00:03:48.550 --> 00:03:53.170
the basic admin or SharePoint admin cuz we
looked at the difference between major and

66
00:03:53.170 --> 00:03:54.160
minor versions.

67
00:03:55.320 --> 00:04:00.540
Content approval, so
depending on the size or the number

68
00:04:00.540 --> 00:04:05.260
of users viewing your content ultimately,
the more users you have viewing

69
00:04:05.260 --> 00:04:08.540
could be in the millions in the case of
popular websites, or tens of millions.

70
00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:13.650
The more likely you are to have multiple
levels of approval in between one

71
00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:17.680
single content creator and its ultimate
publication out to the real world.

72
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:22.360
So, content approval is part
of document management.

73
00:04:22.360 --> 00:04:23.730
And then document sets,

74
00:04:23.730 --> 00:04:28.000
this is a way that we can identify
documents that belong together or

75
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:32.760
should be managed together even if they
move around throughout the enterprise.

76
00:04:32.760 --> 00:04:35.280
So they might start off say in
a certain document library,

77
00:04:35.280 --> 00:04:40.130
get processed, moved to other areas for
further processing.

78
00:04:40.130 --> 00:04:44.680
But with document sets you have the
ability to apply retention policies for

79
00:04:44.680 --> 00:04:47.920
example, to all items in a particular
document set, even though

80
00:04:47.920 --> 00:04:51.120
you don't know exactly where those items
live in your SharePoint environment.

81
00:04:51.120 --> 00:04:53.800
It could be potentially in hundreds
of different document libraries but

82
00:04:53.800 --> 00:04:55.360
you can manage them as one.

83
00:04:55.360 --> 00:04:56.020
>> That's convenient.

84
00:04:56.020 --> 00:04:57.280
>> That's very convenient.

85
00:04:57.280 --> 00:05:01.215
Content types, we looked at at length
in the first week but as refresher

86
00:05:01.215 --> 00:05:05.480
cuz they're so vital and impact so
many areas of our SharePoint deployment.

87
00:05:05.480 --> 00:05:11.180
A content type is a unique grouping
of meta data columns, and depending

88
00:05:11.180 --> 00:05:14.860
on what you're working with, you could
have different combination requirements.

89
00:05:14.860 --> 00:05:19.259
So for a patient ID, or patient records
for example, you might have patient name.

90
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:24.760
Insurance policy provider,
insurance policy number,

91
00:05:24.760 --> 00:05:27.060
maybe some kind of patient id.

92
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:30.650
So those are specific columns that
metadata you can capture and you can

93
00:05:30.650 --> 00:05:36.110
associate them and create all those in
a patient content type, for example.

94
00:05:36.110 --> 00:05:38.910
And depending on your business,
you can probably imagine

95
00:05:38.910 --> 00:05:41.800
different metadata columns that would
make sense for different aspects of

96
00:05:41.800 --> 00:05:43.890
your business depending on whether
you're a sales organization or

97
00:05:43.890 --> 00:05:46.500
marketing or research, for example.

98
00:05:46.500 --> 00:05:51.930
Government organization, military, so
lots of different applications of creating

99
00:05:51.930 --> 00:05:55.640
multiple content types, and again,
we can use content types in many areas.

100
00:05:55.640 --> 00:06:00.780
For search, as a search scope, for
applying information rights management or

101
00:06:00.780 --> 00:06:05.810
retention policies to all files
of a certain content type.

102
00:06:05.810 --> 00:06:08.690
>> Mm hm.
>> A given document library can be

103
00:06:08.690 --> 00:06:12.770
exclusively for one content type or
maybe the user has a choice of two or

104
00:06:12.770 --> 00:06:14.840
three content types when uploading or

105
00:06:14.840 --> 00:06:18.120
saving content to that document
library for the first time.

106
00:06:18.120 --> 00:06:20.840
Additionally in terms of
metadata it makes it easier to

107
00:06:20.840 --> 00:06:23.510
find documents if you've
got content types.

108
00:06:23.510 --> 00:06:26.790
So the more metadata we can capture
especially if we can do it automatically

109
00:06:26.790 --> 00:06:28.810
where the user doesn't
have to select an option.

110
00:06:28.810 --> 00:06:34.540
So it might be a calculated column, or the
metadata to populate a documents a column

111
00:06:34.540 --> 00:06:38.660
for example might come from some other
source, the possibilities are limitless.

112
00:06:38.660 --> 00:06:41.246
I can ramble on, entertain.

113
00:06:41.246 --> 00:06:43.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> Edutain for a day on content types.

114
00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:44.660
So, that's all I'll say about that.

115
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:49.980
So, you may wanna brush up on
content types just to refresh your

116
00:06:49.980 --> 00:06:53.280
particular environment what you can
do with them in your organization.

117
00:06:55.020 --> 00:06:57.530
Okay, so
planning information management policies.

118
00:06:57.530 --> 00:07:01.620
We've got several policies there including

119
00:07:03.520 --> 00:07:07.940
concepts like information
rights management, retention.

120
00:07:07.940 --> 00:07:11.370
So how long should content be retained.

121
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:14.750
And we can sort of start
the timer if you like so

122
00:07:14.750 --> 00:07:19.340
it could be five years after
the document was created.

123
00:07:19.340 --> 00:07:21.970
Or after it was last accessed, or after,

124
00:07:21.970 --> 00:07:25.130
if it's a contract,
although that would probably be a record,

125
00:07:25.130 --> 00:07:27.450
which we'll talk about later,
but let's say it was a contract.

126
00:07:27.450 --> 00:07:28.810
It was just a plain old document.

127
00:07:28.810 --> 00:07:33.175
You could say,
whatever the contract expiry date is,

128
00:07:33.175 --> 00:07:38.270
five years after that, take some kind of
action, which could be archive, delete.

129
00:07:38.270 --> 00:07:42.770
Kick off a work flow, so the manager, at
that point, five years after the contract

130
00:07:42.770 --> 00:07:46.610
expiration, could then decide
what to do with that content.

131
00:07:46.610 --> 00:07:47.690
That's important as well,

132
00:07:47.690 --> 00:07:51.120
especially if you're talking about
multi-year retention periods.

133
00:07:51.120 --> 00:07:55.281
Because frankly, the business rules might
have changed in the intervening years, or

134
00:07:55.281 --> 00:07:56.655
the law might have changed.

135
00:07:56.655 --> 00:07:59.757
Typically, seven years for financial
information required to retain data.

136
00:07:59.757 --> 00:08:02.922
Although, different countries would
have different rules on that.

137
00:08:02.922 --> 00:08:08.860
So again, you might be in compliance and
about to delete some documents.

138
00:08:08.860 --> 00:08:11.510
But the law might have changed
in the intervening years.

139
00:08:11.510 --> 00:08:13.780
And then all of a sudden,
you might be out of compliance, and

140
00:08:13.780 --> 00:08:18.010
subject to regulatory censure,
fines, that sort of thing.

141
00:08:18.010 --> 00:08:20.370
So it never hurts to decide later,

142
00:08:20.370 --> 00:08:24.060
when it comes time to disposal or
archiving of documents.

143
00:08:24.060 --> 00:08:28.200
But to do nothing, that's my main
point in this little section here.

144
00:08:28.200 --> 00:08:33.010
Don't just have no policy, and let content
build up in your SharePoint environment.

145
00:08:33.010 --> 00:08:36.240
That's a recipe for poor performance, and

146
00:08:36.240 --> 00:08:40.780
an expensive, bloated,
search infrastructure.

147
00:08:40.780 --> 00:08:44.758
That becomes less useful over time as more
and more unnecessary information exists.

148
00:08:44.758 --> 00:08:47.600
You know, the spring cleaning,
the pruning and

149
00:08:47.600 --> 00:08:51.170
automating that procedure
will make your life easier.

150
00:08:51.170 --> 00:08:53.970
>> Auditing as well, so again,
depending on the industry or

151
00:08:53.970 --> 00:08:58.636
the geography in which you work, you may
have different requirements for auditing.

152
00:08:58.636 --> 00:09:02.510
So, you can audit almost any

153
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:05.850
kind of event ensured of what
you can dream up can be audited.

154
00:09:05.850 --> 00:09:11.070
But just like for auditing, you don't
want to audit more than necessary.

155
00:09:11.070 --> 00:09:12.490
Don't just check all the boxes, for

156
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:16.470
example, and think, let's audit everything
just in case my boss might want to

157
00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:20.980
know who signed out that fantasy
football Excel spreadsheet in 1999.

158
00:09:20.980 --> 00:09:26.150
>> Might end up with some very large
log files that really becomes difficult

159
00:09:26.150 --> 00:09:29.790
to find the important, you start missing
the important stuff in those log files.

160
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:30.670
>> Indeed, indeed.

161
00:09:30.670 --> 00:09:32.790
So always, you know?

162
00:09:32.790 --> 00:09:35.780
I'm not saying, be irresponsible
what you prune, but, you know?

163
00:09:35.780 --> 00:09:38.480
Less rather than more
is often the way to go.

164
00:09:38.480 --> 00:09:42.390
And being proactive when it
comes to disposal, and auditing,

165
00:09:42.390 --> 00:09:43.348
in this case, you know?

166
00:09:43.348 --> 00:09:45.850
Audit, the bare minimum of what you need,
or

167
00:09:45.850 --> 00:09:51.306
if there's some regulatory or business
rule that requires auditing, fine.

168
00:09:51.306 --> 00:09:54.270
And also, it comes,
then there's a decision to make on

169
00:09:54.270 --> 00:09:56.010
how long to retain audit logs.

170
00:09:56.010 --> 00:09:57.290
Indefinitely?

171
00:09:57.290 --> 00:09:59.170
You know, first in, first out.

172
00:09:59.170 --> 00:10:04.150
Once the log file hits 500 megs or
500 gigs or whatever limit you want.

173
00:10:04.150 --> 00:10:06.002
Do you purge the old content?

174
00:10:06.002 --> 00:10:12.620
Now, I met a fellow recently with
high clearance in a military branch,

175
00:10:12.620 --> 00:10:15.820
and where he worked they were not
allowed to delete any audit logs.

176
00:10:15.820 --> 00:10:18.000
So, it was an indefinite retention period.

177
00:10:18.000 --> 00:10:23.200
Now that's an outlier, most organizations
don't need to keep them that long,

178
00:10:23.200 --> 00:10:26.280
but you know, that's something to decide,
again, it's a governance issue.

179
00:10:26.280 --> 00:10:29.090
You may want to have a repository for

180
00:10:29.090 --> 00:10:32.020
large documents, so
>> In general, we

181
00:10:32.020 --> 00:10:37.030
preach about 100 to 200 gigabytes as being
the maximum size for a content database.

182
00:10:37.030 --> 00:10:39.440
But sometimes you want a repository

183
00:10:41.560 --> 00:10:45.520
to contain a lot of historical data or
product documentation or

184
00:10:45.520 --> 00:10:49.340
whatever it is, it makes sense
to store and manage together.

185
00:10:49.340 --> 00:10:54.070
And there's no rule saying you can't
grow beyond 100 or 200 gigs for

186
00:10:54.070 --> 00:10:56.990
COND database, but you want to
have special considerations for

187
00:10:56.990 --> 00:10:58.470
such a large repository.

188
00:11:00.700 --> 00:11:04.920
And you can have up to 30 million
items in a library, for example,

189
00:11:04.920 --> 00:11:08.950
up to 60 million items in a content data
base which sounds like a lot and is a lot.

190
00:11:08.950 --> 00:11:12.720
But again, depending on what your business
is, if you're a 100 year old Law Firm,

191
00:11:12.720 --> 00:11:14.440
I like to use that example,
you're going to have a lot of paper.

192
00:11:14.440 --> 00:11:16.730
And if you decide to digitize it,

193
00:11:16.730 --> 00:11:20.321
you can get into the millions very
quickly, think of Erin Brockovich [LAUGH].

194
00:11:20.321 --> 00:11:22.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is that product place?

195
00:11:22.020 --> 00:11:25.470
I'm not sure, well, it was a real person
>> Yes, absolutely.

196
00:11:25.470 --> 00:11:28.240
>> What's her name there?

197
00:11:28.240 --> 00:11:29.045
Julia Roberts, Okay.

198
00:11:29.045 --> 00:11:30.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> Good movie.

199
00:11:30.650 --> 00:11:34.840
So my point is, in general you want to
keep your content databases nimble.

200
00:11:34.840 --> 00:11:36.530
Which means, keep in mind,

201
00:11:36.530 --> 00:11:40.980
a site collection can only exist
in a single content database.

202
00:11:40.980 --> 00:11:44.550
You can move an entire site collection
to a different content database, but

203
00:11:44.550 --> 00:11:47.450
you cannot move part of a site collection
to a different content database.

204
00:11:47.450 --> 00:11:49.440
Database.
That's not doable.

205
00:11:49.440 --> 00:11:53.250
And also,
what we talked about in week one.

206
00:11:53.250 --> 00:11:57.880
The initial SharePoint week,
about your content database size is

207
00:11:57.880 --> 00:12:01.820
related to how fast you need
to recover from disaster.

208
00:12:01.820 --> 00:12:05.570
If you have to restore a content database
that's 200 gigs, it's going to happen

209
00:12:05.570 --> 00:12:11.240
a lot faster than ten times that size, so
keep your databases nimble and workable.

210
00:12:11.240 --> 00:12:15.780
It's also good in terms of rotating your
back up schedules and fitting in windows

211
00:12:15.780 --> 00:12:20.580
so you can have maybe one content database
skits backed up every night in full, and

212
00:12:20.580 --> 00:12:24.320
you have another incremental plan for
the other days of the week.

213
00:12:24.320 --> 00:12:28.470
So there's many compelling reasons for
small content databases, sometimes you

214
00:12:28.470 --> 00:12:34.200
want a larger, okay,
I think we beat that one to death.

215
00:12:34.200 --> 00:12:35.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, another factor

216
00:12:37.850 --> 00:12:42.975
that makes it okay for a very large
repository is the percentage of content.

217
00:12:42.975 --> 00:12:46.505
Attendance Access that gives you a week or
a month, or the depositors.

218
00:12:46.505 --> 00:12:49.075
It is just there, it is rarely accessed.

219
00:12:49.075 --> 00:12:53.985
It's helpful on one place, but
it is not like a project themed site for

220
00:12:53.985 --> 00:12:57.385
current project where there is lot
of interaction, new documents,

221
00:12:57.385 --> 00:12:59.755
modified documents,
maybe multiple authors.

222
00:12:59.755 --> 00:13:01.986
This is more of a static, or

223
00:13:01.986 --> 00:13:08.014
archival reference kind of document
center we're talking about there.

224
00:13:08.014 --> 00:13:14.970
Okay, site-based retention
is another concept as well.

225
00:13:14.970 --> 00:13:16.568
How long should sites be kept?

226
00:13:16.568 --> 00:13:21.039
Now, you can have the primary
site collection administrator and

227
00:13:21.039 --> 00:13:23.520
secondary if one is specified.

228
00:13:23.520 --> 00:13:25.410
Notified, say, after six moths.

229
00:13:25.410 --> 00:13:27.420
Let's say six moths after site created.

230
00:13:27.420 --> 00:13:29.860
A little message, email,
do you want to keep this site?

231
00:13:29.860 --> 00:13:31.170
Do you need to keep this site?

232
00:13:31.170 --> 00:13:34.440
And often if it's a purpose built site,
for

233
00:13:34.440 --> 00:13:37.610
particular, it could be a document
workspace, for example.

234
00:13:37.610 --> 00:13:40.660
So collaborating on one document that's
created, do you need the site anymore?

235
00:13:40.660 --> 00:13:44.080
Probably not, because the document
probably lives somewhere else now, or

236
00:13:44.080 --> 00:13:47.860
if it's a project to put on some kind
of event, and that event has past and

237
00:13:47.860 --> 00:13:52.820
maybe you've retained some kind of work
document of best practices for the event.

238
00:13:52.820 --> 00:13:56.140
Do you still need that site or
site collection for the event?

239
00:13:56.140 --> 00:13:56.660
No.

240
00:13:56.660 --> 00:13:57.830
So again,

241
00:13:57.830 --> 00:14:02.550
being proactive and by automatically
emailing site collection administrator,

242
00:14:02.550 --> 00:14:07.060
say six months after site creation, you
can have a process there where nobody has

243
00:14:07.060 --> 00:14:11.080
to, you want to get away from where people
have to remember things in their head.

244
00:14:11.080 --> 00:14:14.240
So information overload,
many of us suffer from it.

245
00:14:15.250 --> 00:14:19.540
A prime way to suffer is to try and
remember everything in your head.

246
00:14:19.540 --> 00:14:22.640
The more you cannot remember,
but have in existence or

247
00:14:22.640 --> 00:14:25.850
coming to you, in this case,
six month reminders, so

248
00:14:25.850 --> 00:14:29.180
you don't have to remember or
even put it in your task management.

249
00:14:29.180 --> 00:14:32.640
I have to decide about this cycle action,
no, it comes to you in an email,

250
00:14:32.640 --> 00:14:37.380
it's automatic ,and you can decide on
the spot, retain or delete that site.

251
00:14:39.100 --> 00:14:43.350
And then if there's no response,
we can automatically close that site and

252
00:14:43.350 --> 00:14:45.780
then X number of days after it's closed,
in other words,

253
00:14:45.780 --> 00:14:50.670
it can't be edited, then we can as
admins choose to delete that site.

254
00:14:50.670 --> 00:14:53.550
>> Kind of wait and see how many phone
calls you get about why isn't this site

255
00:14:53.550 --> 00:14:54.658
accessible anymore?

256
00:14:54.658 --> 00:14:55.850
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

257
00:14:55.850 --> 00:14:57.950
Well, did you get the email that was sent?

258
00:14:57.950 --> 00:14:59.567
>> Yeah.
>> Because I show that it was sent.

259
00:14:59.567 --> 00:15:00.940
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

260
00:15:00.940 --> 00:15:02.090
>> Mr. Site Collection Owner.

261
00:15:03.380 --> 00:15:04.320
Yeah, I forgot about that.

262
00:15:05.650 --> 00:15:08.980
Shredded storage is an improvement
that's been around, and

263
00:15:08.980 --> 00:15:14.390
the benefit here is we use SQL blobs,
and in the old days, we had.

264
00:15:14.390 --> 00:15:16.460
Let's say if we had five
versions of a document,

265
00:15:16.460 --> 00:15:20.480
that meant we have five times
the document size in storage.

266
00:15:20.480 --> 00:15:23.000
In other words,
we couldn't just save the deltas.

267
00:15:23.000 --> 00:15:26.419
But now we can with shredded storage.

268
00:15:26.419 --> 00:15:29.580
So we don't have to make
a trade off like we would.

269
00:15:29.580 --> 00:15:32.079
Maybe there's a business
need to keep ten major.

270
00:15:33.130 --> 00:15:38.130
The ten previous major versions of
a document and associated minor or

271
00:15:38.130 --> 00:15:39.560
draft versions.

272
00:15:39.560 --> 00:15:41.120
We might have been reluctant to do that,

273
00:15:41.120 --> 00:15:43.720
knowing how fast that
could grow our storage.

274
00:15:43.720 --> 00:15:45.835
And there's not an unlimited
storage budget.

275
00:15:45.835 --> 00:15:49.383
But now, because with shredded storage,
we can just save the deltas,

276
00:15:49.383 --> 00:15:52.948
in other words only the changes to
the original document are retained.

277
00:15:52.948 --> 00:15:59.413
Now, the storage impact on retaining
ten versions is much less.

278
00:15:59.413 --> 00:16:02.041
I mean,
it's not much bigger than one version.

279
00:16:02.041 --> 00:16:06.332
Whereas in the old days would've been 10
times the storage of the original version,

280
00:16:06.332 --> 00:16:09.742
so huge benefit there with shredded
storage which has been around for

281
00:16:09.742 --> 00:16:11.710
a few years and blob storage in sequel.

282
00:16:13.260 --> 00:16:17.920
Okay, next stop we're gonna
talk about e-discovery and

00:16:17.920 --> 00:16:22.607
this is to do with electronic discovery,

00:16:22.607 --> 00:16:28.090
So often, if we're being sued,
our company then the courts might request,

285
00:16:28.090 --> 00:16:33.050
or demand really, access to content that

286
00:16:33.050 --> 00:16:37.445
a particular VP might have accessed or

00:16:37.445 --> 00:16:38.500
>> Mm-hm.

00:16:38.500 --> 00:16:41.730
>> And so, from our E discovery

00:16:41.730 --> 00:16:44.500
I'll show you how to create In SharePoint.

00:16:44.500 --> 00:16:46.950
We can use that as a home base,
if you like,

00:16:46.950 --> 00:16:51.570
to pull data from email, and
SharePoint, and files as well.

00:16:51.570 --> 00:16:55.250
So, it's a nice solution for

293
00:16:55.250 --> 00:17:00.210
we can pull in information based on

00:17:00.210 --> 00:17:05.690
particular VP might have worked on or
