know what they did the first 18 or

536
00:32:25.025 --> 00:32:27.650
maybe the last two you do,
you can specify.

537
00:32:27.650 --> 00:32:32.210
And then you can also filter by author,
or sender and

538
00:32:32.210 --> 00:32:34.870
some other parameters as well if you want.

539
00:32:36.020 --> 00:32:42.150
So I'm going to scroll down now and

540
00:32:42.150 --> 00:32:45.609
I'm going to enable in place
hold this radio button here.

541
00:32:47.720 --> 00:32:52.940
So this way we can hold content
in place wherever it lives and

542
00:32:52.940 --> 00:32:55.400
share, but we don't have to
move it somewhere to hold it.

543
00:32:55.400 --> 00:32:58.750
It can be held, in other words
protected from modification and

544
00:32:58.750 --> 00:33:02.550
deletion, exactly where it is now.

545
00:33:02.550 --> 00:33:06.040
Now, let's say that a certain source
that does not support in place hold,

546
00:33:06.040 --> 00:33:08.740
in that case you'd have to export it.

547
00:33:08.740 --> 00:33:11.440
And you can do that,
which we'll look at a little later.

548
00:33:11.440 --> 00:33:14.340
So now,
I'm going to click on preview results.

549
00:33:14.340 --> 00:33:17.017
Now there's nothing in Exchange
here in the exchange tab.

550
00:33:17.017 --> 00:33:20.446
But that's because we don't have Exchange
set up, and we didn't search exchange.

551
00:33:20.446 --> 00:33:21.821
But if I click on the SharePoint tab.

552
00:33:25.939 --> 00:33:29.152
So, now is it takes going back in
to get actually results appearance,

553
00:33:29.152 --> 00:33:30.070
let's do that.

554
00:33:30.070 --> 00:33:31.910
I'll go back in the preview results.

555
00:33:34.160 --> 00:33:34.970
This may take a while.

556
00:33:36.536 --> 00:33:39.399
So, again sometimes you have to
click Preview results more than one,

557
00:33:39.399 --> 00:33:40.427
sort to just be patient.

558
00:33:40.427 --> 00:33:44.089
I'm not a patient person, you may be.

559
00:33:44.089 --> 00:33:49.679
So now we can see here on the SharePoint
tab that we've got a variety of returns

560
00:33:49.679 --> 00:33:54.934
here, and the preview results which
is all I wanted to see at this point.

561
00:33:54.934 --> 00:33:58.852
And now I'm gonna click on Save
to save the eDiscovery set.

562
00:34:02.044 --> 00:34:05.395
And we can see the item there
acuity contractual documents.

563
00:34:06.415 --> 00:34:12.470
Now let's run the eDiscovery in place
hold processor timing job or timer jobs.

564
00:34:12.470 --> 00:34:15.998
So I'll go back to my
central admin site and

565
00:34:15.998 --> 00:34:22.330
go to monitoring And
then I want Timer Jobs.

566
00:34:22.330 --> 00:34:23.794
I wanna review jobs definition.

567
00:34:26.485 --> 00:34:28.525
Remember, a lot of
repetitive events happen,

568
00:34:28.525 --> 00:34:33.345
SharePoint from every number of seconds or
minutes to hours, days, weeks, months.

569
00:34:33.345 --> 00:34:36.150
We don't have time to wait for
this normal cycle for

570
00:34:36.150 --> 00:34:41.275
e-discovery in place hold processing
to occur, so we're gonna kick start it.

571
00:34:42.805 --> 00:34:48.807
So, scroll down here and
it's right here so

572
00:34:48.807 --> 00:34:53.998
I can click on it, it's scheduled for

573
00:34:53.998 --> 00:34:57.582
once an hour processing.

574
00:34:57.582 --> 00:35:01.445
So, normally in production
you don't run it manually,

575
00:35:01.445 --> 00:35:04.823
you just wait usually working on for
other cases or

576
00:35:04.823 --> 00:35:09.830
the natural hour cycle is sufficient but
in our case again I am impatient.

577
00:35:09.830 --> 00:35:13.880
So any timer job you have the ability to
go into the timer job like I just did by

578
00:35:13.880 --> 00:35:14.590
clicking on it.

579
00:35:14.590 --> 00:35:18.868
And then you see at the bottom
there there's a run now option so

580
00:35:18.868 --> 00:35:20.189
I'll click that.

581
00:35:23.722 --> 00:35:27.370
And now I'm gonna test the in
place hold functionality.

582
00:35:28.530 --> 00:35:31.670
Okay, so
now I'm back in my documents library.

583
00:35:31.670 --> 00:35:37.180
Let's see what happens when trying to
delete a document that's under hold.

584
00:35:37.180 --> 00:35:45.741
So, I am going to Select the document,
context menu here.

585
00:35:45.741 --> 00:35:47.569
Delete.

586
00:35:49.857 --> 00:35:50.630
And I'll say OK.

587
00:35:53.540 --> 00:35:55.270
Now I'll go into site contents.

588
00:35:57.440 --> 00:36:00.800
Now you can see there's a new app created.

589
00:36:00.800 --> 00:36:04.360
Remember an app, now a days
everything's an app in SharePoint so

590
00:36:04.360 --> 00:36:06.691
what used to be known
as document library or

591
00:36:06.691 --> 00:36:10.856
list which is quite explanatory is now
known as an app to be cool, all right.

592
00:36:10.856 --> 00:36:11.823
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

593
00:36:11.823 --> 00:36:15.962
this is a new preservation
hold library app, if you like.

594
00:36:15.962 --> 00:36:20.781
And this will contain
the object I tried to delete.

595
00:36:31.381 --> 00:36:32.585
Which is right here.

596
00:36:32.585 --> 00:36:34.540
>> Mm-hm, so

597
00:36:34.540 --> 00:36:38.210
the user actually thought they deleted it,
but, they were unsuccessful.

598
00:36:38.210 --> 00:36:38.720
>> Right, and

599
00:36:38.720 --> 00:36:43.209
as you'd expect, not everyone can
see this Preservation Hold Library.

600
00:36:44.470 --> 00:36:49.130
Now the user might be very glad to
think the document is deleted but

601
00:36:49.130 --> 00:36:52.460
because there's specific reasons
it's on hold in the first place

602
00:36:52.460 --> 00:36:55.930
we want to make sure that
it's inaccessible to them.

603
00:36:55.930 --> 00:36:59.360
So you'd have to have sufficient
privileges to be able to see

604
00:36:59.360 --> 00:37:01.829
this Preservation Hold Library and
the contents within it.

605
00:37:03.300 --> 00:37:06.110
All right next up is query and
exporting content.

606
00:37:06.110 --> 00:37:07.910
Sometimes you want this,

607
00:37:07.910 --> 00:37:13.520
the results of your scouring of email,
file server, and Sharepoint.

608
00:37:13.520 --> 00:37:16.410
You want want that explorer to save
to a thumb drive or a hard drive.

609
00:37:16.410 --> 00:37:17.080
So how do we do that?

610
00:37:21.670 --> 00:37:22.910
Now we're gonna do another crawl.

611
00:37:22.910 --> 00:37:24.627
So I'll go back into.

612
00:37:27.108 --> 00:37:28.373
Central Admin.

613
00:37:36.142 --> 00:37:37.263
And Service Apps.

614
00:37:44.938 --> 00:37:46.437
Content sources

615
00:37:57.296 --> 00:38:00.637
And we'll do another full crawl
on local SharePoint sites.

616
00:38:02.100 --> 00:38:03.370
So that crawl is complete.

617
00:38:03.370 --> 00:38:03.930
>> All right, Mark.

618
00:38:03.930 --> 00:38:06.850
Thanks for that look on
Enterprise content management.

619
00:38:06.850 --> 00:38:08.740
Taking a look at managing the content.

620
00:38:08.740 --> 00:38:12.230
A lot of information being stored in our
SharePoint sites that we've gotta be able

621
00:38:12.230 --> 00:38:14.790
to take good care of retention policies.

622
00:38:14.790 --> 00:38:17.780
And we also looked at the setting
up e-discovery, right?

623
00:38:17.780 --> 00:38:23.240
The special site that gets created so
we can put documents on legal hold.

624
00:38:23.240 --> 00:38:26.120
Even documents can be part
of more than one legal hold.

625
00:38:26.120 --> 00:38:28.150
A lot of neat stuff there,
Mark, thank you for that.

626
00:38:28.150 --> 00:38:30.240
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

627
00:38:30.240 --> 00:38:33.140
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

628
00:38:33.140 --> 00:38:34.003
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

629
00:38:34.003 --> 00:38:37.093
>> And we'll see you next time.

630
00:38:37.093 --> 00:38:42.054
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Web Content Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.136 --> 00:00:15.632
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.632 --> 00:00:16.979
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.979 --> 00:00:19.990
And today we're doing
Advanced SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:19.990 --> 00:00:23.976
And specifically in this episode
we're gonna be looking at web content

6
00:00:23.976 --> 00:00:25.050
management.

7
00:00:25.050 --> 00:00:27.710
We've taken a look at
enterprise content management.

8
00:00:27.710 --> 00:00:30.800
Now we're going to divide that up,
break it down a little bit and

9
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:35.180
get into web content management, and
here to do that for us is Mr. Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:35.180 --> 00:00:35.980
How you doing, Mark?

11
00:00:35.980 --> 00:00:37.540
>> Thanks, Mike, great.

12
00:00:37.540 --> 00:00:41.570
All right, so, yes, web content management
is a subset of enterprise content

13
00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:43.210
management, a prime driver for

14
00:00:43.210 --> 00:00:47.460
companies adopting SharePoint, is to
get away from a multi-vendor solution.

15
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:52.070
They might have had a separate
provider for intranet, extranet and

16
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:53.640
Internet applications.

17
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:57.930
Wouldn't it be better and more streamlined
to have the same platform for all three?

18
00:00:57.930 --> 00:00:59.545
Absolutely, of course it would.

19
00:00:59.545 --> 00:01:02.232
Thank you.
[LAUGH] I said, wait a beep there for

20
00:01:02.232 --> 00:01:03.767
the audience respond.

21
00:01:03.767 --> 00:01:04.348
>> [LAUGH].

22
00:01:04.348 --> 00:01:05.775
>> My host, Mike.

23
00:01:05.775 --> 00:01:08.250
Awesome, so how does this relate?

24
00:01:08.250 --> 00:01:11.670
So we know we can use SharePoint for
all those applications I just mentioned,

25
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:15.160
whether we're communicating
internally with employees or

26
00:01:15.160 --> 00:01:18.640
using extranet for partners,
or Internet for customers.

27
00:01:18.640 --> 00:01:22.330
Maybe they have millions of customers,
they wanna publish their catalog so

28
00:01:22.330 --> 00:01:24.340
they can view and make their choices.

29
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:28.190
I'll show you how to do that,
to create a catalog later.

30
00:01:28.190 --> 00:01:33.760
But, we have a publishing portal, which is
one of the templates we get in SharePoint.

31
00:01:33.760 --> 00:01:36.570
So remember we've got a variety of
templates we could choose depending on

32
00:01:36.570 --> 00:01:39.140
what the website to
the function of the website.

33
00:01:40.240 --> 00:01:42.380
This includes things
like enabling features,

34
00:01:42.380 --> 00:01:43.770
if I enable the publishing portal for

35
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:47.300
example, certain web parts would appear
on the page and we're introducing certain

36
00:01:47.300 --> 00:01:50.220
functionality that wasn't there
before installing the template.

37
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:52.650
So it's not just the template
you're selecting, but

38
00:01:52.650 --> 00:01:57.820
other actions take place to enable
the use of the publishing template.

39
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:00.650
In some cases,
especially the publishing portal,

40
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:04.100
there are features we have to enable at
the site level as well to take advantage,

41
00:02:04.100 --> 00:02:06.920
to be able to use
the publishing functionality.

42
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:11.330
Enterprise Wiki is another option
you can use for publishing.

43
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:15.670
Some organizations don't bother
deploying Wiki technology at all.

44
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:21.170
Others swear by it as an informal
way to get ideas curated or

45
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:26.600
started and people can add content,
another communication channel.

46
00:02:26.600 --> 00:02:28.750
It may or
may not work in your environment, or

47
00:02:28.750 --> 00:02:34.180
it may not be adopted by many users but
those that use it, do swear by it.

48
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:39.800
So, the product catalog I mentioned,
it's a way to we can set up the terms.

49
00:02:39.800 --> 00:02:44.498
I'll show you how to do that, so
that a user can navigate down through

50
00:02:44.498 --> 00:02:48.710
the term hierarchy to find
a product they're looking for, or

51
00:02:48.710 --> 00:02:51.153
want to reorder, or what have you.

52
00:02:51.153 --> 00:02:56.373
All right, we have special groups and
permissions enabled as well,

53
00:02:56.373 --> 00:03:01.150
depending on whether we choose
a publishing site, say or not.

54
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:05.635
And we have navigation available like we
have with many templates, when we create

55
00:03:05.635 --> 00:03:09.795
them we can choose to use separate
navigation compared to the current site,

56
00:03:09.795 --> 00:03:11.670
or just use the same navigation.

57
00:03:11.670 --> 00:03:16.750
So we always want to make it as easy as
possible for users to know where they are,

58
00:03:16.750 --> 00:03:20.910
how they can get back to where they were,
so they don't waste a lot of energy trying

59
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:24.430
to figure out again where they
are in your SharePoint hierarchy.

60
00:03:24.430 --> 00:03:25.930
And I wanna make this
as easy as possible for

61
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:28.460
them to do what they
came to your site to do.

62
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:35.160
We also have master pages which we can
customize the overall look and feel.

63
00:03:36.440 --> 00:03:40.200
Now that is a very dangerous tool to
be able to edit those master pages,

64
00:03:40.200 --> 00:03:41.800
it affects the whole look and feel and

65
00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:45.830
usability of your site, so very few
people should have the capability to just

66
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:49.600
randomly change a site template look and
feel, for example.

67
00:03:49.600 --> 00:03:53.090
So, typically your SharePoint designers.

68
00:03:53.090 --> 00:03:57.840
People with design skills would have
access to modifying those if necessary and

69
00:03:57.840 --> 00:04:00.550
not the general user population.

70
00:04:01.840 --> 00:04:05.130
Device channels we have as well,
so this lets us

71
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:08.400
render content differently depending
on the device accessing SharePoint.

72
00:04:08.400 --> 00:04:13.060
We've seen,
just from our own use in the real world,

73
00:04:13.060 --> 00:04:16.430
we're often using a variety of form
factors to access the same content.

74
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:19.715
We can't just have,
let's say we're used to seeing content

75
00:04:19.715 --> 00:04:22.936
on a regular laptop screen,
it doesn't make sense to try and

76
00:04:22.936 --> 00:04:26.242
squish it down into a tablet or
phone, it would be illegible.

77
00:04:26.242 --> 00:04:29.302
So it's reformatting required.

78
00:04:29.302 --> 00:04:34.246
So there's tools to be able to do that
automatically once you set up a device

79
00:04:34.246 --> 00:04:39.110
channels, so that you know the content
will be legible and functional and

80
00:04:39.110 --> 00:04:44.384
usable no matter what device the user's
accessing your SharePoint site with.

81
00:04:44.384 --> 00:04:48.340
Web parts,
we have content related web parts.

82
00:04:48.340 --> 00:04:53.470
Things like content roll ups,
support for multilingual sites.

83
00:04:53.470 --> 00:04:55.980
So some of you working in
international environments or

84
00:04:55.980 --> 00:05:00.170
international divisions where having
a multilingual interface is important, or

85
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:04.710
the option for the user to choose,
or in many cases it's based on their

86
00:05:04.710 --> 00:05:09.700
OS language, they would automatically get
their SharePoint's information rendered in

87
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:14.048
the correct language, assuming you've
setup the correct language packs for that.

88
00:05:14.048 --> 00:05:18.642
And caching is available as well, so
to reduce round trips to the SQL storage

89
00:05:18.642 --> 00:05:24.195
the backend and also to get faster
service of user requested pages.

90
00:05:24.195 --> 00:05:26.842
Okay, so planning.

91
00:05:26.842 --> 00:05:30.687
Again, there's could be different
planning stages depending on what

92
00:05:30.687 --> 00:05:33.710
you're using SharePoint for
in the publishing realm.

93
00:05:33.710 --> 00:05:36.270
Is it just for internal use,
as an intranet?

94
00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:37.600
Is it external use,

95
00:05:37.600 --> 00:05:42.790
maybe some partner organizations,
in an extranet format or Internet.

96
00:05:42.790 --> 00:05:47.710
So maybe just read only anonymous access
to potentially millions of customers or

97
00:05:47.710 --> 00:05:48.990
viewers of your page.

98
00:05:50.396 --> 00:05:53.630
So there's different methods
of authentication or

99
00:05:53.630 --> 00:05:58.990
no authentication depending on which
type or which audience you're serving.

100
00:06:01.250 --> 00:06:05.640
Okay, there's also this concept of
cross site collection publishing.

101
00:06:05.640 --> 00:06:08.390
This is where you offer
the content at one site and yet

102
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:11.330
it gets consumed in one or
more other sites.

103
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:14.060
So you update it once in
the authoring site, and

104
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:18.070
then these other sites automatically get,
for example, a product list updated in

105
00:06:18.070 --> 00:06:22.260
those sites, as opposed to you having
to make multiple changes one per site.

106
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:26.183
No, you change the content once and
those consuming sites through cross site

107
00:06:26.183 --> 00:06:29.635
publishing get the updated say,
pricelist, for a given product.

108
00:06:29.635 --> 00:06:31.921
>> Nice.

109
00:06:31.921 --> 00:06:35.019
>> Okay, so if you don't have a need,
if it's a very small,

110
00:06:35.019 --> 00:06:38.820
maybe a departmental Internet for
example, or it's a small company,

111
00:06:38.820 --> 00:06:41.500
you may not have a need for
cross site publishing.

112
00:06:41.500 --> 00:06:45.369
Therefore, the authoring site becomes
the only place to view the content you're

113
00:06:45.369 --> 00:06:48.917
creating, so cross-site publishing
doesn't enter into the equation.

114
00:06:51.467 --> 00:06:52.081
Okay.

115
00:06:54.916 --> 00:06:58.772
Let's look now at, we're gonna look at
managed navigation and catalog sites,

116
00:06:58.772 --> 00:06:59.460
as promised.

117
00:06:59.460 --> 00:07:04.459
We're gonna use some clothing examples
just to get some reality around

118
00:07:04.459 --> 00:07:08.190
managed navigation and catalog sites.

119
00:07:08.190 --> 00:07:10.280
So you might have a situation.

120
00:07:10.280 --> 00:07:12.960
Another way to think
of managed navigation,

121
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:15.610
maybe you've got sports equipment.

122
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:20.100
For example, so
maybe you're selling unicycles,

123
00:07:20.100 --> 00:07:23.688
hoverboards, and amphibious cars.

124
00:07:23.688 --> 00:07:24.585
>> Hm, nice.

125
00:07:24.585 --> 00:07:28.358
>> [LAUGH] So then you could
drill down under amphibious cars,

126
00:07:28.358 --> 00:07:31.823
do you want a convertible
amphibious car or do you want

127
00:07:31.823 --> 00:07:36.450
an armored car to go through the water and
on land like those duck boats?

128
00:07:37.710 --> 00:07:38.620
Where people are going quack,

129
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:42.750
quack on these city tours, or
bicycles is a better example,

130
00:07:42.750 --> 00:07:48.580
maybe there's a tricycle category you can
drill down into gold-plated tricycles.

131
00:07:48.580 --> 00:07:50.170
It's getting silly now,
but you get the point.

132
00:07:50.170 --> 00:07:53.672
There's gonna be natural hierarchies,
taxonomies, if you will.

133
00:07:53.672 --> 00:07:58.367
If you think the animal kingdom or
the plant kingdom, there's natural ways of

134
00:07:58.367 --> 00:08:03.295
organizing data that make sense to people
studying or researching in that field.

135
00:08:03.295 --> 00:08:06.116
You might think of maybe
school population of students,

136
00:08:06.116 --> 00:08:09.360

00:25:37.210 --> 00:25:41.570
to other sites so they can consume it,
that content, via cross-site publishing.

373
00:25:41.570 --> 00:25:44.130
We update the catalog in one place,

374
00:25:44.130 --> 00:25:47.470
it automatically gets
updated everywhere else.

375
00:25:47.470 --> 00:25:50.353
Next up is configuring publishing sites.

376
00:25:50.353 --> 00:25:53.703
So I'll create a publishing
site collection to do that.

377
00:25:53.703 --> 00:25:57.466
I'm in central admin,
we'll go back to it anyway,

378
00:25:57.466 --> 00:26:02.263
and then Create site collections
under Application Management.

379
00:26:02.263 --> 00:26:05.903
Call this one staging.

380
00:26:05.903 --> 00:26:11.287
And I will say, staging for

381
00:26:11.287 --> 00:26:16.684
cross-site publishing.

382
00:26:16.684 --> 00:26:22.246
And let's put it under /site/staging.

383
00:26:26.723 --> 00:26:31.432
And we want, under the Publishing tab,

384
00:26:31.432 --> 00:26:35.180
this time a publishing portal.

385
00:26:35.180 --> 00:26:36.754
And I'll put my user name in.

386
00:26:41.661 --> 00:26:43.910
And okay.

387
00:26:43.910 --> 00:26:49.212
And we see that was successful, so
I'll click on that staging link.

388
00:26:54.022 --> 00:26:57.232
It says, welcome to your publishing site,
and again, very helpful, right.

389
00:26:57.232 --> 00:27:00.369
On the left hand side, we've got,
I'm the information architect.

390
00:27:00.369 --> 00:27:02.678
And on the right-hand side,
I'm the visual designer.

391
00:27:02.678 --> 00:27:07.480
So different people involved in SharePoint
would have a different interest in various

392
00:27:07.480 --> 00:27:11.374
elements of the SharePoint deployment,
depending on your job role.

393
00:27:11.374 --> 00:27:15.179
Okay, so now I wanna connect
the Publishing site to a product catalog.

394
00:27:15.179 --> 00:27:18.204
I do that by going to Site Settings.

395
00:27:18.204 --> 00:27:23.190
And under Site Administration,
scroll down a bit here, and

396
00:27:23.190 --> 00:27:26.630
I wanna Manage the catalog connections.

397
00:27:28.530 --> 00:27:31.592
I'll click on Connect to a catalog,
I love it when they make it so

398
00:27:31.592 --> 00:27:33.080
obvious what the next step is.

399
00:27:33.080 --> 00:27:37.811
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think I'll click this one.

400
00:27:37.811 --> 00:27:39.018
And let that load up.

401
00:27:45.390 --> 00:27:47.190
And again,
there's only one thing to do here.

402
00:27:47.190 --> 00:27:48.660
We click on Connect.

403
00:27:56.154 --> 00:28:00.967
Okay, so I do want to keep the default,
which is to integrate the catalog into

404
00:28:00.967 --> 00:28:05.484
my site, which includes things like
catalog terms and navigation, and

405
00:28:05.484 --> 00:28:07.354
any design elements as well.

406
00:28:07.354 --> 00:28:12.580
And the navigation hierarchy,
let's scroll down a bit here,

407
00:28:12.580 --> 00:28:16.826
I want to make sure item
category is selected here.

408
00:28:16.826 --> 00:28:17.830
That's the only option,
so that makes it easy.

409
00:28:17.830 --> 00:28:20.330
And I'm gonna browse
through a valid choice.

410
00:28:20.330 --> 00:28:23.876
Now, this is one of those icons that
if you're not familiar with it,

411
00:28:23.876 --> 00:28:27.000
there's these two little
tags over here on the right.

412
00:28:27.000 --> 00:28:32.230
But that actually is the symbol for browse
for a valid choice, believe it or not.

413
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:37.461
And I'm gonna select a clothing product,

414
00:28:37.461 --> 00:28:40.670
click on Select, and OK.

415
00:28:40.670 --> 00:28:44.300
There's various other options here
we're not gonna get into now.

416
00:28:44.300 --> 00:28:45.066
And I'll hit OK.

417
00:28:49.377 --> 00:28:52.646
And the pièce de résistance.

418
00:28:52.646 --> 00:28:55.164
Drum roll, please.

419
00:28:56.971 --> 00:28:57.506
[SOUND]
>> Sorry,

420
00:28:57.506 --> 00:28:58.925
you didn't mean a literal drum roll.

421
00:28:58.925 --> 00:29:00.168
>> Absolutely, literal drum roll.

422
00:29:00.168 --> 00:29:00.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so

423
00:29:00.950 --> 00:29:04.860
now we see this quick launch
hierarchy should look very familiar.

424
00:29:04.860 --> 00:29:09.900
It include the terms that we just
created under Accessories, Denim, and

425
00:29:09.900 --> 00:29:15.880
Featured, and they're displayed in the way
we created them in terms of indentation.

426
00:29:15.880 --> 00:29:20.790
So if I click on Belts,
for example, what happens?

427
00:29:20.790 --> 00:29:23.290
Okay, so this is something,
we have nothing there,

428
00:29:23.290 --> 00:29:26.330
I would have had to upload actual
information about one or more belts.

429
00:29:26.330 --> 00:29:30.785
Furthermore, this landing page would be
prettied up by your SharePoint designer.

430
00:29:30.785 --> 00:29:31.310
>> Mm-hm.

431
00:29:31.310 --> 00:29:34.810
>> People modifying the master page,
and making it look functional.

432
00:29:34.810 --> 00:29:39.887
But, this is, from our end, as our
SharePoint admins, this is what we do.

433
00:29:39.887 --> 00:29:43.370
And there'll be other people involved,
again, to pretty it up and

434
00:29:43.370 --> 00:29:47.049
actually upload the various product
catalog items in the first place.

435
00:29:47.049 --> 00:29:48.900
>> All right, Mark, fantastic.

436
00:29:48.900 --> 00:29:54.840
Some really good demonstrations there
on setting up the catalog site,

437
00:29:54.840 --> 00:29:58.710
the publishing site, connecting those two,
getting that set up so

438
00:29:58.710 --> 00:30:00.840
we can do that cross-site publishing.

439
00:30:00.840 --> 00:30:04.890
As well as don't forget we talked a lot
about web content management in general,

440
00:30:04.890 --> 00:30:07.920
we talked about all the different things
that are available within SharePoint

441
00:30:07.920 --> 00:30:10.935
2016 like a wiki, a product catalog,

442
00:30:10.935 --> 00:30:15.940
multilingual support, web ports, device
platform optimization, you know, when it

443
00:30:15.940 --> 00:30:19.490
can tell you're on a mobile device, we're
gonna change that page up a little bit to

444
00:30:19.490 --> 00:30:24.440
make sure it's presented in a useful way
on whatever device you're connecting from.

445
00:30:24.440 --> 00:30:25.530
So thank you for that.

446
00:30:25.530 --> 00:30:27.340
Great demonstrations there.

447
00:30:27.340 --> 00:30:29.079
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

448
00:30:29.079 --> 00:30:31.724
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

449
00:30:31.724 --> 00:30:32.718
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

450
00:30:32.718 --> 00:30:33.956
>> And we'll see you next time.

451
00:30:33.956 --> 00:30:43.290
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Productivity and Collaboration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.458 --> 00:00:16.080
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:17.590
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.590 --> 00:00:21.200
And today we're doing our
Advanced SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:21.200 --> 00:00:22.520
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:26.190
we're gonna be looking at productivity and
collaboration,

7
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:29.870
a couple of the key reasons we wanna
get into SharePoint in the first place.

8
00:00:29.870 --> 00:00:33.036
So here to help us to figure out how
we can accomplish all of this is Mr.

9
00:00:33.036 --> 00:00:33.700
Mark Ingram.

10
00:00:33.700 --> 00:00:34.367
How you doing Mark?

11
00:00:34.367 --> 00:00:35.621
>> Good, Mike, thanks very much.

12
00:00:35.621 --> 00:00:41.040
Yes, so this isn't the end all or be all
or end all when it comes to collaboration.

13
00:00:41.040 --> 00:00:46.236
We're gonna take a stab at it and we'll
look at to how project can integrate and

14
00:00:46.236 --> 00:00:50.804
with Word, PowerPoint and
other applications we normally use, and

15
00:00:50.804 --> 00:00:55.791
we'll look at integrated task lists as
well as we go through this episode.

16
00:00:55.791 --> 00:00:58.950
So, if you think of
the average user's work day,

17
00:00:58.950 --> 00:01:01.960
they're probably in multiple applications,

18
00:01:01.960 --> 00:01:06.852
they're working with Exchange,
SharePoint, various Office documents,

19
00:01:06.852 --> 00:01:11.313
and often task lists can appear in
different software they might use.

20
00:01:11.313 --> 00:01:16.420
So, we wanna make life easier for users.

21
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:18.960
We don't want them to have to go
to multiple places to get multiple

22
00:01:18.960 --> 00:01:19.760
task lists.

23
00:01:19.760 --> 00:01:21.780
No, we want them to be able to aggregate.

24
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:23.158
Well, we do that in the back end.

25
00:01:23.158 --> 00:01:26.848
Aggregate tasks list, so
they can go to one place, or

26
00:01:26.848 --> 00:01:32.014
any of the places they would normally
check for tasks, whether it's a team

27
00:01:32.014 --> 00:01:37.017
site on SharePoint, or from Exchange,
they get the same view of tasks.

28
00:01:37.017 --> 00:01:40.060
There's no missing tasks, so they don't
have to remember to go back to this task

29
00:01:40.060 --> 00:01:41.958
list to make sure they're
covering everything.

30
00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:47.008
No, that's adding stress, wanna de-stress
and we do that by a unified task list.

31
00:01:47.008 --> 00:01:51.558
All right,

32
00:01:51.558 --> 00:01:56.200
so we will have a little
demo on that later on.

33
00:01:56.200 --> 00:01:59.320
My Sites is another place where users,
if you enable it.

34
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:05.340
So My Sites is one of those
polarizing aspects of SharePoint.

35
00:02:05.340 --> 00:02:08.950
Some organizations love it and
it's a prime driver for deployment.

36
00:02:08.950 --> 00:02:11.840
Other users or other organizations rather

37
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:17.460
stay away from it because they
fear a total loss of control.

38
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:22.280
So, I don't know, I can make arguments
either way, but the point is,

39
00:02:22.280 --> 00:02:26.060
if you do enable My Sites in your
organization, you're essentially saying,

40
00:02:26.060 --> 00:02:29.900
anyone with My Site's capabilities
can create their own site collection.

41
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:33.110
Now that means there's extra
storage to manage, and

42
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:36.070
people essentially become their
own site collection administrator.

43
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:40.543
So again, I go back to training being
a fundamental driver of the success of

44
00:02:40.543 --> 00:02:42.690
a SharePoint deployment.

45
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:45.600
If you have enabled My Sites,
that's another user where users could see

46
00:02:45.600 --> 00:02:50.440
this integrated task list
from their My Sites page.

47
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:50.940
>> Very cool.

48
00:02:50.940 --> 00:02:53.722
>> Yeah, okay, so again,

49
00:02:53.722 --> 00:02:59.686
we can connect to Exchange
using the OAuth protocol.

50
00:02:59.686 --> 00:03:03.824
And that involves setting up trust
relationships, between Exchange and

51
00:03:03.824 --> 00:03:04.638
SharePoint.

52
00:03:04.638 --> 00:03:08.899
I won't show you that but
that's something you'll need to do if you

53
00:03:08.899 --> 00:03:12.734
want to enable that task list
integration within Exchange.

54
00:03:12.734 --> 00:03:14.877
And there's a variety of
PowerShell scripts to run.

55
00:03:14.877 --> 00:03:19.127
So again,
I've mentioned this several times.

56
00:03:19.127 --> 00:03:23.651
If you don't have PowerShell skills now,
I'm not saying you have to become

57
00:03:23.651 --> 00:03:28.335
a PowerShell expert, but there are certain
tasks you can only do in the shell.

58
00:03:28.335 --> 00:03:32.740
Whether you're talking about Exchange,
Project, SharePoint.

59
00:03:32.740 --> 00:03:36.710
Any major server technology, all server
technologies Microsoft's released

60
00:03:36.710 --> 00:03:41.470
since Exchange 2007 require
PowerShell to administer some or

61
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:45.700
many activities or options you
can configure in those platforms.

62
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:49.157
So, don't be afraid,
maybe add that to your learning list,

63
00:03:49.157 --> 00:03:51.060
PowerShell if you're new.

64
00:03:51.060 --> 00:03:54.140
I don't consider myself a coder or
a scripter.

65
00:03:54.140 --> 00:03:57.960
Even I found it fairly intuitive to
learn and lots of built-in help.

66
00:03:57.960 --> 00:04:00.990
So, using actual English words.

67
00:04:00.990 --> 00:04:04.290
So it's designed to take
the best of other shells and

68
00:04:04.290 --> 00:04:09.390
make it easy for new people that don't
have experience coding, for example,

69
00:04:09.390 --> 00:04:14.220
to quickly ramp up and
be able to create their own scripts and

70
00:04:14.220 --> 00:04:18.800
modify scripts available online or from
examples for use in your own environment.

71
00:04:18.800 --> 00:04:20.810
>> So,
it's really not as bad as people think.

72
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:23.511
I think it's something that, as you said,

73
00:04:23.511 --> 00:04:28.120
you're gonna need it in just about any
field with a server that you go into.

74
00:04:28.120 --> 00:04:30.800
So, you might as well start
playing around with it.

75
00:04:30.800 --> 00:04:35.755
>> Indeed, so when it comes to Project,
there's multiple levels of integration.

76
00:04:35.755 --> 00:04:39.805
I'll show you how to set up
a Project site and set up some of

77
00:04:39.805 --> 00:04:44.275
the functionality there, and
we'll create a little scenario in Project.

78
00:04:44.275 --> 00:04:48.094
We could also in SharePoint 2016,
with the right licensing key,

79
00:04:48.094 --> 00:04:49.656
enable the functionality.

80
00:04:49.656 --> 00:04:53.581
So Project is installed with
SharePoint in 2016 and you need, again,

81
00:04:53.581 --> 00:04:56.836
the right key to unlock
the functionality of Project server.

82
00:04:56.836 --> 00:04:58.654
But it's not an all or
nothing proposition.

83
00:04:58.654 --> 00:05:00.624
You don't have to spring for

84
00:05:00.624 --> 00:05:06.351
that Project server license to take
advantage of a Project site template.

85
00:05:06.351 --> 00:05:08.925
>> And so you can dip your toe in.

86
00:05:08.925 --> 00:05:12.520
And then if you're not integrating
Project with SharePoint now,

87
00:05:12.520 --> 00:05:16.563
by using some Project sites,
you might realize, hey, this makes sense,

88
00:05:16.563 --> 00:05:20.544
let's either port over from another
Project solution we're using now or

89
00:05:20.544 --> 00:05:25.190
let's go full bore with our integration
with Project server and SharePoint server.

90
00:05:25.190 --> 00:05:29.796
It makes sense because you want maximize
the amount of interfaces users have to

91
00:05:29.796 --> 00:05:31.696
go to to do their work day to day.

92
00:05:31.696 --> 00:05:33.669
And because they're
Microsoft technologies,

93
00:05:33.669 --> 00:05:35.650
you can expect them to
play nice with each other.

94
00:05:35.650 --> 00:05:42.130
And users generally are familiar with
Office, apps, and how to use a ribbon.

95
00:05:43.390 --> 00:05:46.095
Since Office, several versions ago now.

96
00:05:46.095 --> 00:05:47.100
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

97
00:05:47.100 --> 00:05:48.040
>> 2010, I believe it was.

98
00:05:48.040 --> 00:05:50.820
I lost track, maybe 2007, but
ribbon's been around for years.

99
00:05:50.820 --> 00:05:52.330
And anyone that's familiar with a browser.

100
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:56.270
So with basic Office and
browser skills, people can have a good

101
00:05:56.270 --> 00:06:01.250
experience working with SharePoint and
Project together in a 2016 environment.

102
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:08.291
Okay, so Project site template includes,
like all templates,

103
00:06:08.291 --> 00:06:10.019
a variety of web parts.

104
00:06:10.019 --> 00:06:14.921
And we have a Project summary web part,
task schedule,

105
00:06:14.921 --> 00:06:19.525
even a OneNote team notebook and
a shared calendar.

106
00:06:19.525 --> 00:06:25.000
So you can customize that site just
like any site template in SharePoint.

107
00:06:25.000 --> 00:06:28.310
You can certainly change the branding to
be inline with your corporate colors,

108
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:28.850
for example.

109
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:31.470
And you may have some
custom web parts that you

110
00:06:31.470 --> 00:06:33.160
use to access different databases.

111
00:06:33.160 --> 00:06:38.585
That's the beauty of SharePoint, you can
modify, customize to your heart's content.

112
00:06:38.585 --> 00:06:42.878
So you can bring in data that displays
in a dashboard like environment so that,

113
00:06:42.878 --> 00:06:47.172
again, we're restricting the amount of
trips users have to take to different

114
00:06:47.172 --> 00:06:49.646
interfaces, portals, applications, and

115
00:06:49.646 --> 00:06:54.160
we can consolidate a lot of the work in
one interface, which is extremely useful.

116
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:56.098
>> Mm-hm.

117
00:06:56.098 --> 00:06:56.954
>> Okay.

118
00:06:59.746 --> 00:07:05.333
There's also, you can utilize what
used to be called Office Web Apps and

119
00:07:05.333 --> 00:07:08.040
now is Office Online Server.

120
00:07:08.040 --> 00:07:12.670
Don't be confused by the name, Online
Server, it's not like SharePoint Online,

121
00:07:12.670 --> 00:07:14.780
in other words,
it's not a cloud-hosted service.

122
00:07:14.780 --> 00:07:18.663
It's something that's, you install in
your environment and it allows for

123
00:07:18.663 --> 00:07:19.883
extra functionality.

124
00:07:19.883 --> 00:07:25.768
So if you're familiar with Office Web Apps
from 2013, the principles are the same,

125
00:07:25.768 --> 00:07:30.161
it's a very similar experience,
it's just that Microsoft seems

126
00:07:30.161 --> 00:07:34.877
to like to rebrand technologies that
we've come to know and remember.

127
00:07:34.877 --> 00:07:36.477
And then the next version, it's changed.

128
00:07:36.477 --> 00:07:39.824
And we think, it's a brand new technology,
but not always the case.

129
00:07:39.824 --> 00:07:42.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sometimes just marketing, branding.

130
00:07:42.270 --> 00:07:43.808
>> Yes.
>> So Office Web Apps,

131
00:07:43.808 --> 00:07:46.497
almost identical to Office Online Server.

132
00:07:46.497 --> 00:07:50.328
And again, that's something
that runs in your enterprise.

133
00:07:50.328 --> 00:07:54.575
So why would someone install
Office Online Server?

134
00:07:54.575 --> 00:07:55.467
What's the benefit?

135
00:07:55.467 --> 00:07:56.587
You don't have to install it.

136
00:07:56.587 --> 00:07:57.649
It's definitely optional.

137
00:07:57.649 --> 00:08:02.141
You can still take great advantage of
Document libraries, and then working on

138
00:08:02.141 --> 00:08:06.990
documents, versioning, but you get change
tracking, so you get revision marks.

139
00:08:06.990 --> 00:08:10.950
If you've ever collaborated with others
on a document and there's some kind of

140
00:08:10.950 --> 00:08:15.770
markup, maybe you use some other software
for that, and then you can see comments,

141
00:08:15.770 --> 00:08:19.340
typically in the margin, just someone
has written in the body of the document.

142
00:08:19.340 --> 00:08:21.170
So you can see who made what comment, or

143
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:25.530
what change, you know strike through
on a certain sentence or word perhaps.

144
00:08:25.530 --> 00:08:30.435
So you get change tracking if you
install Office Online Server and

145
00:08:30.435 --> 00:08:34.200
co-authoring is available as well, so
we can get multiple people working on

146
00:08:34.200 --> 00:08:38.380
the document say, or
PowerPoint deck at the very same time.

147
00:08:38.380 --> 00:08:44.710
And you can imagine without, it could turn
into a gong show, but they've setup so

148
00:08:44.710 --> 00:08:48.510
that it's very plain which user's working
on which section of the document.

149
00:08:48.510 --> 00:08:53.400
So you're not fumbling over or overwriting
changes that your colleague just made

150
00:08:53.400 --> 00:08:56.646
then it leads to frustration, and
maybe a thrown doughnut or two.

151
00:08:56.646 --> 00:09:00.465
>> [LAUGH] Or however you take out

00:15:53.747 --> 00:15:55.930

00:16:06.370 --> 00:16:07.550

00:16:07.550 --> 00:16:13.270
Now, versioning is a concern because,

00:16:13.270 --> 00:16:17.100
with all the changes that could get made
with users collaborating on a document,

274
00:16:17.100 --> 00:16:20.440
that could translate to
a large number of versions.

275
00:16:20.440 --> 00:16:27.580
So, you could, again, the preference would
be to, in a document library setting,

276
00:16:27.580 --> 00:16:31.270
because versions are document library
specific settings, you could,

277
00:16:31.270 --> 00:16:36.170
rather than just allow unlimited versions
set a maximum number of major versions.

278
00:16:36.170 --> 00:16:37.948
For example, 10.

279
00:16:37.948 --> 00:16:45.280
And then as many associated minor versions
with each major version as necessary.

280
00:16:45.280 --> 00:16:50.130
So in other words, if you say 10 major
versions kept, if you're up to version 11,

281
00:16:50.130 --> 00:16:51.270
version one is deleted.

282
00:16:51.270 --> 00:16:52.960
Now, you may be able to
retrieve it from a backup, but

283
00:16:52.960 --> 00:16:56.250
that's a whole other scenario there.

284
00:16:56.250 --> 00:16:58.565
You can also create
a versioning period for

285
00:16:58.565 --> 00:17:04.120
co-authored documents, and
also a maximum number of co-authors.

286
00:17:04.120 --> 00:17:08.080
So this way, as an admin or at least,
this is something that could

00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:10.840
certainly be handled at the site
collection admin level.

00:17:10.840 --> 00:17:14.340
This way,
they have some control over, again,

289
00:17:14.340 --> 00:17:17.869
maximum number of co-authors, maximum
number of versions, versioning period.

290
00:17:18.900 --> 00:17:23.370
And something I would start on
a department by department basis,

291
00:17:23.370 --> 00:17:27.640
get sort of lessons learned from the first
department working on the co-authoring,

292
00:17:27.640 --> 00:17:32.280
and then you can make some policies or
guidelines that would apply to other site

00:17:32.280 --> 00:17:38.100

told to implement this co-authoring.

00:17:38.100 --> 00:17:41.950
And again, I keep saying governance is
key because, while a site collection

00:17:41.950 --> 00:17:46.680
administration can easily enable this

296
00:17:46.680 --> 00:17:50.670

00:17:50.670 --> 00:17:53.850
Because there may be business logic or
business rules that dictate no,

298
00:17:53.850 --> 00:17:55.970
we're not gonna allow co-authoring.

299
00:17:55.970 --> 00:18:00.590
Maybe it's in privacy concerns, or
classified information confidentiality.

300
00:18:00.590 --> 00:18:06.490
Those concerns may exclude
coauthoring from your environment.

301
00:18:06.490 --> 00:18:12.500
So, again, as admins we can implement
what we're told to implement,

302
00:18:12.500 --> 00:18:16.431
but we shouldn't necessarily be
deciding these governance issues.

00:18:16.431 --> 00:18:19.620
We can be perhaps on
a committee that decides, but

00:18:19.620 --> 00:18:24.870

00:18:24.870 --> 00:18:28.210

>> Let's switch it up
>> A little active directory users and

computers.

00:23:02.933 --> 00:23:04.217
>> Let's go old school.

384
00:23:04.217 --> 00:23:05.130
>> My favorite.

385
00:23:05.130 --> 00:23:09.967
>> ADOC, yeah.

386
00:23:09.967 --> 00:23:13.520
Okay, so let's, new user.

387
00:23:15.500 --> 00:23:16.912
Lets go with Kim.

388
00:23:18.634 --> 00:23:19.822
Smith.

389
00:23:25.964 --> 00:23:30.835
Kim, I like to use those
sort of androgynous names.

390
00:23:30.835 --> 00:23:31.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not sure that's

00:23:31.600 --> 00:23:32.380

392
00:23:32.380 --> 00:23:37.825

>> [LAUGH] Cuz that's what I was doing.

393
00:23:37.825 --> 00:23:40.177
>> [LAUGH] Pat.

394
00:23:40.177 --> 00:23:42.090
Okay,
>> [LAUGH]

395
00:23:42.090 --> 00:23:43.160
>> Can we joke about that?

396
00:23:43.160 --> 00:23:43.870
I think we can.

397
00:23:43.870 --> 00:23:45.480
>> I think we can, it's legit.

398
00:23:45.480 --> 00:23:47.670
>> All right, without offending anybody?

399
00:23:47.670 --> 00:23:49.134
We'll see.
>> [LAUGH]

400
00:23:49.134 --> 00:23:50.905
>> Let me check the Twitter feed.

401
00:23:50.905 --> 00:23:52.586
Okay, now, it's assigned Kim.

402
00:23:52.586 --> 00:23:57.410
And this is cool because I start typing
and I just added the user right away It's

00:23:57.410 --> 00:24:01.794
available to pick in this list here
that matches kim, so that's good,

404
00:24:01.794 --> 00:24:05.990
that wasn't always true often there
would have to be some syncing.

405
00:24:05.990 --> 00:24:06.600
>> Right.

406
00:24:06.600 --> 00:24:08.540
>> Or it would take a while for

407
00:24:08.540 --> 00:24:11.570
new objects created in active directory
to populate where you wanted them to.

408
00:24:11.570 --> 00:24:12.320
>> Yeah.

409
00:24:12.320 --> 00:24:15.510
>> So kudos to Microsoft on that one.

And now.

00:24:16.660 --> 00:24:19.948
I'm gonna click on task name

00:24:19.948 --> 00:24:26.270
And just funny,
more friendly this Microsoft.

00:24:26.270 --> 00:24:28.280
The first one's on us.

00:24:28.280 --> 00:24:31.850
All they're really doing for
us is adding a task to the timeline,

00:24:31.850 --> 00:24:36.660
otherwise I'd have to go to that ellipsis
menu and add a task, so thanks for that.

416

That's asking for a little too
much credit I think but anyway.

417
00:24:42.340 --> 00:24:45.770
So now we have an ellipsis

418
00:24:45.770 --> 00:24:49.400
And remember,
I didn't code the product but

now there's another ellipsis and
the plural is ellipses.

420
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:54.230
We have two ellipses here.

00:24:56.050 --> 00:24:58.010
Again, it's optimized for touch, right,

00:24:58.010 --> 00:25:01.615
because a lot of people will be using some
touch screen to configure SharePoint.

423
00:25:02.960 --> 00:25:06.620
So I guess I can't really complain,
it's easy to, it's almost like braille,

424
00:25:06.620 --> 00:25:08.210
just to find those three dots.

425
00:25:08.210 --> 00:25:08.780
>> Yes.
>> So

426
00:25:08.780 --> 00:25:14.580
I'm gonna click on the second set of

427
00:25:16.980 --> 00:25:20.368
And for the start date,

00:25:20.368 --> 00:25:24.942
I'm gonna say today and save and

now I'll click the task name here

00:25:29.686 --> 00:25:34.610
I'm gonna go, proof of concept.

431
00:25:34.610 --> 00:25:36.159
It's always good to have a POC.

432
00:25:36.159 --> 00:25:37.089
>> Mm-hm.

433
00:25:37.089 --> 00:25:41.702
>> And I'll go to the due date, and
let's say, it's a tight timeline here,

434
00:25:41.702 --> 00:25:45.450
our time is precious,
we're gonna give two weeks for that.

435
00:25:45.450 --> 00:25:48.085
And I'll sign to administrator.

436
00:25:52.134 --> 00:25:54.575
Excellent.

437
00:25:54.575 --> 00:25:56.640
And I'll go into task name again.

438
00:25:56.640 --> 00:26:04.130
And then the ellipsis next as proof

439
00:26:04.130 --> 00:26:04.720
How Exciting.

440
00:26:04.720 --> 00:26:08.906
[SOUND] Yeah, so we can see there,
product design, and

441
00:26:08.906 --> 00:26:14.098
next to proof of concept you're
gonna click on the ellipsis again.

442
00:26:14.098 --> 00:26:18.898
And the other ellipsis and edit item, and

443
00:26:18.898 --> 00:26:21.915
start date, let's say,

444
00:26:21.915 --> 00:26:27.283
I'm feeling cruel, I'll make it a holiday.

445
00:26:27.283 --> 00:26:32.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> And save.

446
00:26:32.180 --> 00:26:32.870
The new guy.

447
00:26:32.870 --> 00:26:34.820
It gets something-
>> It's terrible.

448
00:26:34.820 --> 00:26:36.287
Terrible.
[LAUGH]

449
00:26:36.287 --> 00:26:37.987
>> Horrible bosses.

450
00:26:37.987 --> 00:26:38.531
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

451
00:26:38.531 --> 00:26:39.623
>> All right now,

452
00:26:39.623 --> 00:26:44.747
it can be a little confusing frankly
with this interface with the color,

453
00:26:44.747 --> 00:26:50.470
is the blue and the gray, but at least
they make it clear that it's a hyperlink.

454
00:26:50.470 --> 00:26:55.600
I want to stop editing this less so
I'll gonna click on the stop,

455
00:26:55.600 --> 00:27:00.174
word there, and
now I'm going to click on the home link.

456
00:27:00.174 --> 00:27:03.797
And now we can see the overlap here
because often in projects there's some

457
00:27:03.797 --> 00:27:05.844
activities that happen concurrently and

458
00:27:05.844 --> 00:27:08.950
some have to happen only after
the previous one's completed.

459
00:27:08.950 --> 00:27:12.078
So there's some overlap here we
see between product design and

460
00:27:12.078 --> 00:27:13.030
proof of concept.

461
00:27:14.188 --> 00:27:19.300
And now I'm going to add a task,
and this is up on the right,

462
00:27:19.300 --> 00:27:22.885
again, when I talk about moving between
versions, not only often do you have to

463
00:27:22.885 --> 00:27:26.350
often unlearn the old name for
something like Office web apps, and

464
00:27:26.350 --> 00:27:30.010
the new name Office Online Server,
also, the things you are used to doing,

465
00:27:30.010 --> 00:27:33.099
the menu options, and
where the buttons were, move around.

466
00:27:34.480 --> 00:27:36.790
So, you know it used to be over here,
now it's over here,

467
00:27:36.790 --> 00:27:41.400
so that's I guess these are first world
problems, but anyway the point is we

468
00:27:41.400 --> 00:27:46.570
are gonna add a task, and
the task will be kick off meeting.

469
00:27:49.340 --> 00:27:55.290
And lets make this today,
lets strike while the iron it hot.

470
00:27:55.290 --> 00:27:58.908
And let's go to due date.

471
00:27:58.908 --> 00:28:03.549
I'll make this today as well, cuz nothing
worse than meetings that drag on over one

472
00:28:03.549 --> 00:28:07.850
day, so I think one day is plenty,
and we need to assign this now.

473
00:28:07.850 --> 00:28:10.661
So I can assign it to a person if I want.

474
00:28:10.661 --> 00:28:15.790
Let's say kim again or

475
00:28:15.790 --> 00:28:18.940
it could be to a group if I wanted and
then save.

476
00:28:20.170 --> 00:28:26.380
Now, again when we get a template
in SharePoint it's a suggested

477
00:28:26.380 --> 00:28:30.640
arrangement of web parts and a certain
look and feel based on the master page for

478
00:28:30.640 --> 00:28:33.500
example, it's totally customizable,
we're not stuck with what we've got.

479
00:28:33.500 --> 00:28:34.730
So let's customize a little bit.

480
00:28:34.730 --> 00:28:35.690
>> Let's do.

481
00:28:35.690 --> 00:28:39.510
>> Yeah.
So I am going to the proof of concept

482
00:28:39.510 --> 00:28:43.890
task, and

483
00:28:43.890 --> 00:28:48.110
on the timeline,
you can just click on display as call out.

484
00:28:48.110 --> 00:28:50.230
That's in the current selections there.

485
00:28:50.230 --> 00:28:56.280
Again, very useful to hover
over the item in the ribbon.

486
00:28:56.280 --> 00:28:59.240
And then if you are not exactly
sure what the item does,

487
00:28:59.240 --> 00:29:00.700
you get some guidance there.

488
00:29:00.700 --> 00:29:03.890
So display as call out, and
now I'm gonna go into settings,

489
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:07.470
that's the gear icon, and edit the page.

490
00:29:11.020 --> 00:29:15.120
And I'm gonna go down to the get
started with your site web part.

491
00:29:15.120 --> 00:29:19.705
Now, this is often the,
you notice when I move my mouse up there

492
00:29:19.705 --> 00:29:25.390
away from get started with your site,
the web part menu drop down disappears so

493
00:29:25.390 --> 00:29:27.600
it's kind of like you hover and
the menu will appear.

494
00:29:28.880 --> 00:29:31.155
Field of dreams, web part of dreams.

495
00:29:31.155 --> 00:29:31.932
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay so

496
00:29:31.932 --> 00:29:35.550
then I can click the down arrow and
I want to delete this web part,

497
00:29:35.550 --> 00:29:38.766
this is a generic,
get started with your site web part and

498
00:29:38.766 --> 00:29:42.921
I don't need any of these, sort of,
training wheel prompts if you will.

499
00:29:42.921 --> 00:29:46.700
So I'm going to delete the web part and,
are you sure?

500
00:29:46.700 --> 00:29:47.840
Sure, I'm sure.

501
00:29:47.840 --> 00:29:51.180
Now, I got rid of that one and
I wanna add a web part.

502
00:29:51.180 --> 00:29:52.092
So, how do I do that?

503
00:29:52.092 --> 00:29:56.890
I'm gonna go,
notice that we have panels or zones and so

00:29:56.890 --> 00:30:01.160
we want to make sure we're selecting the
web part in the correct area of the page.

505
00:30:01.160 --> 00:30:02.200
We can always move it later, but

506
00:30:02.200 --> 00:30:04.820
why not put it where you
want it in the first place?

507
00:30:04.820 --> 00:30:09.790
So I'll click on add a web part,
and notice how we

508
00:30:09.790 --> 00:30:14.060
have a variety of categories here I'm
gonna refrain from the desire to start

509
00:30:14.060 --> 00:30:18.950
talking about all the different categories
and keep it focused, so apps and calendar,

510
00:30:18.950 --> 00:30:21.980
those happen to be the defaults that are
highlighted, which is good that's exactly

511
00:30:21.980 --> 00:30:26.230
what I wanted, and then over on the right
hand side here, I'll click on add.

512
00:30:27.490 --> 00:30:32.450
And now I want the calendar web part,
scroll down a bit,

513
00:30:32.450 --> 00:30:35.010
and I'm going to minimize this web part.

514
00:30:35.010 --> 00:30:36.670
Sometimes when you're moving
web parts around a page,

515

especially if you have a lot of web parts,

516
00:30:38.090 --> 00:30:42.308
it helps to minimize the web part to
make it easier to move that web part or

517
00:30:42.308 --> 00:30:45.150
another web part underneath it which
is what we're about to do now.

518
00:30:45.150 --> 00:30:46.025
So I'll minimize this web part.

519
00:30:46.025 --> 00:30:50.976
I'm not deleting it, it's still there and
I'm gonna maximize it when I'm done,

520
00:30:50.976 --> 00:30:55.218
so it's not like the calendar where
the display is a less than helpful,

521
00:30:55.218 --> 00:30:59.848
tiny rectangle with no dates on it,
no I'll put it back the way it was before.

522
00:30:59.848 --> 00:31:05.970
And now I'm going to go
to the top panel again,

523
00:31:05.970 --> 00:31:09.890
and I want to drag that calendar web part

524
00:31:11.160 --> 00:31:14.700
under the project summary web parts.

525
00:31:15.770 --> 00:31:19.180
So notice I've selected it and right below
my mouse, I don't know if you can see it

526
00:31:19.180 --> 00:31:24.100
on the screen there, the calendar there's
a little box that says calendar so

527
00:31:24.100 --> 00:31:28.478
I know I've clicked on the right place and
I'm dragging it so I'll drag it down.

528
00:31:28.478 --> 00:31:32.954
Down, down like an alligator
into the river I guess I

529
00:31:32.954 --> 00:31:36.330
should just stop watching TV, scary.

530
00:31:36.330 --> 00:31:39.857
>> [LAUGH]
>> All those kind of shows, and then

531
00:31:39.857 --> 00:31:44.900
sometimes it takes some finagling to get
the web part release where you want it.

532
00:31:44.900 --> 00:31:47.202
Sometimes it goes on top or beside,
and you'll want it underneath.

533
00:31:47.202 --> 00:31:48.218
>> Mm-hm.
>> So it's something

534
00:31:48.218 --> 00:31:51.607
that you might have to futz with,
a technical term more than once.

535
00:31:51.607 --> 00:31:52.996
>> [LAUGH]
>> Thankfully

536
00:31:52.996 --> 00:31:54.481
it worked the first time here.

537
00:31:54.481 --> 00:31:56.816
And now I'm gonna maximize, or

538
00:31:56.816 --> 00:32:02.277
restore the size of that web part by
using the drop down, oops, wrong one.

539
00:32:02.277 --> 00:32:04.578
[LAUGH] That's easy to do.

540
00:32:04.578 --> 00:32:08.600
Restore the calendar web part and
it returns to its former glory.

541
00:32:08.600 --> 00:32:13.570
Now, I want to stop editing,
so how do I do that?

542
00:32:13.570 --> 00:32:19.081
I'm gonna go to the Page > Menu,
and then stop editing.

543
00:32:19.081 --> 00:32:20.979
So another thing to
know is the SharePoint,

544
00:32:20.979 --> 00:32:22.734
you've probably discovered already.

545
00:32:22.734 --> 00:32:26.943
Is sometimes buttons like stop editing
appear right on the page where you

546
00:32:26.943 --> 00:32:29.290
are editing other times where did it go?

547
00:32:29.290 --> 00:32:30.600
And you have to go to a different menu.

548
00:32:30.600 --> 00:32:32.628
In this case,
the page menu to find stop editing.

549
00:32:32.628 --> 00:32:37.916
So there is frankly, a lack of consistency
when it comes to where buttons appear and

550
00:32:37.916 --> 00:32:42.991
whether they're visible by default or
you have to go look for them a little bit.

551
00:32:42.991 --> 00:32:48.153
So if you get a little confused,
maybe that was the design, just kidding.

552
00:32:48.153 --> 00:32:50.364
>> They kinda force you to explore
the user interface, right?

553
00:32:50.364 --> 00:32:51.350
>> Maybe that's right.

554
00:32:51.350 --> 00:32:54.110
>> By moving those buttons around,
and putting the in different locations

555
00:32:54.110 --> 00:32:54.640
>> Where's Waldo?

556
00:32:56.080 --> 00:32:56.725
Where's that button?

557
00:32:56.725 --> 00:33:04.260
Okay, so I've stopped editing and now,
I can add an item to the project calendar.

558
00:33:04.260 --> 00:33:08.430
So I'll go to the calendar web part for

559
00:33:09.520 --> 00:33:14.650
today which is, there's a pretty settled
bar on top of the current day and

560
00:33:14.650 --> 00:33:20.040
then there's the, the number of the day
is also in blue so helps you locate it.

561
00:33:20.040 --> 00:33:24.630
And again if the add
appears once you've put

562
00:33:24.630 --> 00:33:28.700
the mouse on the date you want,
that box, I'll click on add.

563
00:33:31.200 --> 00:33:37.890
And I'll call this kick off meeting,
oops, not kickstarter, kick off meeting.

564
00:33:39.560 --> 00:33:44.310
And then category scroll down here,
category will be meeting,

565
00:33:44.310 --> 00:33:46.740
and there's some other options there.

566
00:33:47.790 --> 00:33:49.730
Where's the golf category?

567
00:33:49.730 --> 00:33:50.910
>> Yes a very important one.

568
00:33:50.910 --> 00:33:53.751
>> Okay, it's not here, well.

569
00:33:53.751 --> 00:33:56.458
Meeting, a lot of business gets
done on the golf course, or so

570
00:33:56.458 --> 00:33:57.873
they would like you to believe.

571
00:33:57.873 --> 00:33:58.501
>> Yes.

572
00:33:58.501 --> 00:34:01.193
[LAUGH]
>> And then is it in all the events,

573
00:34:01.193 --> 00:34:04.128
in other words we don't
have a specific start and

574
00:34:04.128 --> 00:34:09.067
end time it's in all day long And I could
theoretically make it a repeating event or

575
00:34:09.067 --> 00:34:13.670
something that recurs but if it's kickoff,
presumably that's a one off.

576
00:34:13.670 --> 00:34:15.050
We might have a kickoff for
another project.

577
00:34:15.050 --> 00:34:18.168
So this is not one of those schedule
a weekly meeting types of deals.

578
00:34:18.168 --> 00:34:22.910
It's a one-off, so I'll click Save, and

579
00:34:22.910 --> 00:34:27.290
that is how I've customized and
configured a Project Site.

580
00:34:28.290 --> 00:34:32.790
>> Very cool Mark, a great look there, and
a lot of the features and capabilities

581
00:34:32.790 --> 00:34:36.400
of SharePoint that are designed to help
us with productivity and collaboration.

582
00:34:36.400 --> 00:34:39.570
We talked about integrating our
Office applications that we're

583
00:34:39.570 --> 00:34:42.460
already familiar with
as we also talked about

584
00:34:42.460 --> 00:34:47.240
how Office Web Apps is now that
Office Online Server that's run locally.

585
00:34:47.240 --> 00:34:50.280
And then a really good look at
setting up a site designed for

586
00:34:50.280 --> 00:34:53.940
projects, using that project template,
adding a couple of events to that.

587
00:34:53.940 --> 00:34:56.955
Showing you really,
how customizable it is.

588
00:34:56.955 --> 00:35:00.555
You start with that template, and it
gives you some basics, some suggestions,

589
00:35:00.555 --> 00:35:02.795
which, if they're fine with you,
you keep it.

590
00:35:02.795 --> 00:35:05.895
But, just about everything about
that site was customizable.

591
00:35:05.895 --> 00:35:08.435
So, fantastic,
we thank you for that, Mark.

592
00:35:08.435 --> 00:35:10.225
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

593
00:35:10.225 --> 00:35:12.835
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

594
00:35:12.835 --> 00:35:13.545
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

595
00:35:13.545 --> 00:35:15.890
>> And we'll see you next time.

596
00:35:15.890 --> 00:35:24.390
[MUSIC]

WEBVTT

1

2
00:00:12.357 --> 00:00:15.551
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.551 --> 00:00:20.461
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.461 --> 00:00:24.879
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at upgrading and

5
00:00:24.879 --> 00:00:27.101
migrating to SharePoint 2016.

6
00:00:27.101 --> 00:00:30.035
We're gonna talk about what we can and
can't do and some of the dos and

7
00:00:30.035 --> 00:00:32.074
don'ts of that upgrade or
migration process.

8
00:00:32.074 --> 00:00:34.345
And here to walk us through that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

9
00:00:34.345 --> 00:00:35.167
How you doing, Mark?

10
00:00:35.167 --> 00:00:36.440
>> Thanks, Mike.

11
00:00:36.440 --> 00:00:43.050
Yeah, so a lot of people wait
to implement the latest feature,

12
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:47.570
the latest version of SharePoint
because of testing requirements.

13
00:00:47.570 --> 00:00:54.061
We're gonna talk about how to go from 2013
SharePoint to 2016, not from 2010 to 2016.

14
00:00:54.061 --> 00:00:56.522
[COUGH] Third party could get
away with it, there's a tool, but

15
00:00:56.522 --> 00:00:59.510
we're just gonna talk about
what's baked into the product.

16
00:00:59.510 --> 00:01:02.907
So if you're running SharePoint
2010 now and wanna get to 2016,

17
00:01:02.907 --> 00:01:05.883
first you'll have to upgrade to 2013 and
then to 2016.

18
00:01:05.883 --> 00:01:10.146
[COUGH] This is a reason, to avoid the
upgrade process, why some organizations

00:01:10.146 --> 00:01:13.829

considering a hybrid approach,

20
00:01:13.829 --> 00:01:17.940
because those updates happen continuously,
sometimes daily.

21
00:01:17.940 --> 00:01:19.920
So they never have to worry

22
00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:23.979
However, Microsoft has
promised on-prem support.

23
00:01:23.979 --> 00:01:28.090
They made some noises about threatening to

24
00:01:28.090 --> 00:01:31.370
But now due to pushback they've
committed to releasing on-premises

25
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:33.850
versions of SharePoint as long
as there's demand for it.

26
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.390
This is important because some
customizations will not work in the cloud,

27
00:01:38.390 --> 00:01:42.620
so some organizations have to
maintain an on-premises environment.

28
00:01:42.620 --> 00:01:44.956
So good news it's not going away, and

29
00:01:44.956 --> 00:01:49.632
to conceptualize what the on-prem version
is, think of it as a point in time

30
00:01:49.632 --> 00:01:54.623
snapshot of a functional SharePoint
online architecture tested, works fine.

31
00:01:54.623 --> 00:01:58.133
We'll make that the RTM
version of SharePoint 2016.

32
00:01:58.133 --> 00:02:02.243
Okay, so again, a trade-off between having
the latest and greatest functionality and

33
00:02:02.243 --> 00:02:05.967
having time to test it, so those of you
that wanna remain on-prem exclusively,

34
00:02:05.967 --> 00:02:07.390
no problem at all.

35
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:08.632
Let's look at the upgrade process.

36
00:02:08.632 --> 00:02:12.295
So [COUGH] back in the day if you've
been around SharePoint some time,

37
00:02:12.295 --> 00:02:14.960
there was at one point
an in place upgrade option.

38
00:02:14.960 --> 00:02:16.558
That's no longer available.

39
00:02:16.558 --> 00:02:21.280
What this means is you're gonna
have to create a brand new farm on

40
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:26.720
separate hardware and
then you migrate the databases over.

41
00:02:26.720 --> 00:02:32.740
Okay, so there's a database
attach migration option as well

42
00:02:32.740 --> 00:02:36.290
for certain service applications, which
we'll talk about, like the manage metadata

43
00:02:36.290 --> 00:02:41.430
service for example, a performance
point services, secure storage service.

44
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:43.450
And what is the upgrade process?

45
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:47.518
So first, you're gonna create
that new 2016 farm [COUGH] and

46
00:02:47.518 --> 00:02:51.785
you wanna copy the databases
into the new environment.

47
00:02:51.785 --> 00:02:56.410
Now, it has to be tested and
with virtualization now

48
00:02:56.410 --> 00:03:00.960
there's really no excuse to not test
because you have the capability to do so.

49
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:03.280
So that you reduce, not eliminate, but

50
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:07.490
reduce the surprises when you actually
do the migration in production.

51
00:03:08.730 --> 00:03:14.170
All right, let's see,
next step is planning the upgrade.

52
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:16.930
So you want to plan
business communications.

53
00:03:16.930 --> 00:03:20.150
This means that if people are gonna be
unable to access the site collection for

54
00:03:20.150 --> 00:03:23.880
a weekend, say, because you're doing
x number of site collections or

55
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:26.100
content databases per weekend.

00:03:26.100 --> 00:03:31.330
So your whole upgrade could take weeks or
months depending on how much data you

57
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:35.120
have in your SharePoint contacts and
how much testing you have to do after

58
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:40.340
the migration of a single content
database worth of site collections.

59
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:43.479
It could take months, so
there's no rush and slower is better.

60
00:03:43.479 --> 00:03:46.901
It's not something like maybe
an Exchange upgrade, for example, or

61
00:03:46.901 --> 00:03:50.615
a Windows Server upgrade where maybe it
is realistic to do that in a weekend.

62
00:03:50.615 --> 00:03:51.311
>> Mm-hm.

63
00:03:51.311 --> 00:03:53.983
>> This is not an upgrade in
a weekend kind of project for

64
00:03:53.983 --> 00:03:55.698
most SharePoint environments.

65
00:03:55.698 --> 00:03:56.988
So business communications,

66
00:03:56.988 --> 00:04:00.072
we're talking about letting people
know if there's gonna be an outage.

67
00:04:00.072 --> 00:04:05.042
Or perhaps site collections they're used
to making changes on, maybe they'll be

68
00:04:05.042 --> 00:04:09.311
read-only for this weekend, for
example, or this three day period.

69
00:04:09.311 --> 00:04:12.917
Business requirement survey, so
maybe find out what people don't like

70
00:04:12.917 --> 00:04:17.700
about the current environment, or what
they'd want to see in the new environment.

71
00:04:17.700 --> 00:04:20.510
It's a really good chance, just like if
you're moving house or moving office,

72
00:04:20.510 --> 00:04:24.710
it's a great chance to take stock,
eliminate what's not working,

73
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:28.670
figure out what you want in the new digs
in terms of how you wanna set up your

74
00:04:28.670 --> 00:04:31.620
space or furniture or whatever,
similar to SharePoint.

75
00:04:31.620 --> 00:04:35.984
What functionalities do you
wanna take advantage of now and

76
00:04:35.984 --> 00:04:37.912
plan that out in advance.

77
00:04:37.912 --> 00:04:41.171
>> Yeah, a great time to get rid of some
of those sites that maybe aren't being

78
00:04:41.171 --> 00:04:42.695
used as heavily or utilized much.

00:04:42.695 --> 00:04:45.816
And why spend the time migrating
those over to the new system if

80
00:04:45.816 --> 00:04:48.530
they're just gonna sit there and
not be used anyway?

81
00:04:48.530 --> 00:04:51.740
So a really good time to do
the spring cleaning, if you will.

82
00:04:51.740 --> 00:04:55.225
>> Indeed, and the answer to why is
some people are lazy or these types of

83
00:04:55.225 --> 00:04:59.029
information management projects always
get put to the bottom of the list.

84
00:04:59.029 --> 00:05:00.603
In other words, they never happen.

85
00:05:00.603 --> 00:05:04.193
I mean, it is easier in a sense
just to port over the old content,

86
00:05:04.193 --> 00:05:08.268
rather than having to do the tough
thinking work of do we need this or not?

87
00:05:08.268 --> 00:05:11.120
Do I really wanna get in touch with
this person to see if they need it?

88
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:13.360
Let's just move it all,
we might need it later.

89
00:05:13.360 --> 00:05:18.030
That's sloppy, and it does things like
it ends up cluttering search results.

90
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:21.512
And in terms of legal liability,
why not get rid of old content?

91
00:05:21.512 --> 00:05:25.235
Not that you've done anything wrong, but
why expose yourself to potential liability

92
00:05:25.235 --> 00:05:28.635
just because you've retained content
that really should have been deleted.

93
00:05:28.635 --> 00:05:30.512
>> Mm-hm.

94
00:05:30.512 --> 00:05:33.533
>> You definitely wanna test the upgrade.

95
00:05:33.533 --> 00:05:38.734
In terms of roll back and restore type
operations, I mean, you'll still have your

96
00:05:38.734 --> 00:05:44.360
existing 2013 farm in production and
working and serving requests from users.

97
00:05:44.360 --> 00:05:49.180
So it's not like you'd be caught in limbo
with no working SharePoint environment.

98
00:05:49.180 --> 00:05:55.100
No, he worst case scenario is you upgrade,
attach a new content database,

99
00:05:55.100 --> 00:05:57.890
or a content database to your new farm,
and there's some glitch.

100
00:05:57.890 --> 00:06:00.275
But you still have your
working 2013 environment so

101
00:06:00.275 --> 00:06:03.229
you're not gonna do anything
destructive to your old environment.

102
00:06:03.229 --> 00:06:08.093
The biggest impact it'll have on users is,
as I said, some sites might have

103
00:06:08.093 --> 00:06:12.047
turned into read-only access

104
00:06:12.047 --> 00:06:16.057
Post upgrade activities, there's always
things that are gonna not work the same in

105
00:06:16.057 --> 00:06:19.845
the new version, or some customizations

106
00:06:19.845 --> 00:06:23.439
Additionally, you wanna have someone or
people walking around and

107
00:06:23.439 --> 00:06:27.915
available to coach some users because some
things will look a little different, and

108
00:06:27.915 --> 00:06:29.824
I always use, who moved my cheese?

109
00:06:29.824 --> 00:06:31.607
>> [LAUGH]
>> People resist change or

110
00:06:31.607 --> 00:06:36.541
they get frustrated even though it might

111
00:06:36.541 --> 00:06:39.365
they tend to freak out if
they're on a deadline.

112
00:06:39.365 --> 00:06:43.638
So having people wandering around with
experience in SharePoint 2016 is really

113
00:06:43.638 --> 00:06:45.415
gonna help by easing the concern.

114
00:06:45.415 --> 00:06:48.110
There may be one person per department,
you train them up on

115
00:06:48.110 --> 00:06:52.750
some end user functionality, say,
of 2016 in advance, so that you have some

116
00:06:52.750 --> 00:06:56.640
expertise that can be disseminated
that way throughout your organization.

117
00:06:56.640 --> 00:06:59.060
>> All right, Mark, I know upgrades and
migrations can be tricky.

118
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:01.340
You got some best practices for us?

119
00:07:01.340 --> 00:07:05.195
>> Absolutely, Mike, so there's a five
stage process you should consider,

120
00:07:05.195 --> 00:07:06.471
a framework if you like.

121
00:07:06.471 --> 00:07:10.129
And if you've done any of the ITIL, the IT
Infrastructure Library courses based in

122
00:07:10.129 --> 00:07:13.280
London, England you'll be familiar

123
00:07:13.280 --> 00:07:18.780
So the first one is learning, learning

124
00:07:18.780 --> 00:07:23.540
You want to make sure you have enough
storage capacity, for example, in your new

125
00:07:23.540 --> 00:07:28.378
farm to account for not just your current
usage, but anticipated future growth.

126
00:07:28.378 --> 00:07:32.629
Not everyone has the ability to simply

127
00:07:32.629 --> 00:07:37.140
example, on the fly off and there's
a month long budget cycle to prepare for.

128
00:07:37.140 --> 00:07:41.761
So that's another reason to prune and
delete old content

129
00:07:41.761 --> 00:07:46.969
that's unused before moving
into your 2016 environment.

130
00:07:46.969 --> 00:07:49.422
And then preparation.

131
00:07:49.422 --> 00:07:54.605
So we wanna have a detailed list of
any customizations and solutions.

132
00:07:54.605 --> 00:07:57.180
That you may have implemented
in your environment now.

133
00:07:57.180 --> 00:07:57.758
Why?

134
00:07:57.758 --> 00:08:02.126
Because, generally, you should assume
that none of those customizations and

135
00:08:02.126 --> 00:08:05.690
solutions will work correctly
in your new environment.

136
00:08:05.690 --> 00:08:09.970
In fact, summarizations will
strip away any customizations and

137
00:08:09.970 --> 00:08:13.360
remove solutions before upgrade, and

138
00:08:13.360 --> 00:08:17.680
then add them in the 2016
environment after the upgrade.

139
00:08:17.680 --> 00:08:23.650
So, there's a lot of manual work

140
00:08:23.650 --> 00:08:27.750
So you have to factor that in, especially
if your boss, say, comes at you with

141
00:08:27.750 --> 00:08:32.440
an unrealistic timeline for completing
your SharePoint 2016 upgrade project.

00:08:32.440 --> 00:08:34.140
Months is realistic.

143
00:08:34.140 --> 00:08:35.980
Weeks is probably not realistic.

144
00:08:37.630 --> 00:08:39.360
Testing, I've been harping on that.

00:08:39.360 --> 00:08:42.260
And with the ubiquity of
virtualization technologies,

00:08:42.260 --> 00:08:45.275

00:08:45.275 --> 00:08:50.294
It's very quickly to reset, and if you

148
00:08:50.294 --> 00:08:55.465
for example, or a database attached, you

149
00:08:55.465 --> 00:09:00.432
before and then attempt it again once

150
00:09:02.596 --> 00:09:05.650
Then, implementation is the next step.

151
00:09:05.650 --> 00:09:07.460
There are status indicators, so

152
00:09:07.460 --> 00:09:11.290
you can monitor the health of
the upgrade process ongoingly.

153
00:09:13.150 --> 00:09:16.130
And validation, so
when it comes to validation,

00:09:16.130 --> 00:09:19.550
you wanna have people that are actually
gonna be using the product, end users.

155
00:09:19.550 --> 00:09:21.440
Of course, as admins we're end users, too.

156
00:09:21.440 --> 00:09:25.330
But I'm talking about the regular

157
00:09:25.330 --> 00:09:27.242
Have them interact with
the new environments,

158
00:09:27.242 --> 00:09:29.600
still in the test phase, right?

00:09:29.600 --> 00:09:33.410
So you've done a database attached,

00:09:33.410 --> 00:09:36.370
the old content database is now

161
00:09:36.370 --> 00:09:37.360
Have a user sit down,

00:09:40.910 --> 00:09:42.090
Maybe upload a document,

00:09:42.090 --> 00:09:46.700

00:09:46.700 --> 00:09:51.100
Just get a sense of, okay,

00:09:51.100 --> 00:09:54.260
normal tasks that

167
00:09:54.260 --> 00:09:57.810
And it's also,
you get some good feedback as well,

168
00:09:57.810 --> 00:09:59.720

00:09:59.720 --> 00:10:02.150
So you might get some ideas

00:10:02.150 --> 00:10:06.415
some clarification in your training

171
00:10:06.415 --> 00:10:11.175

172
00:10:12.395 --> 00:10:14.815
Okay, so what is the pre-upgrade
steps to complete then?

173
00:10:14.815 --> 00:10:16.285
You wanna have a farm inventory.

174
00:10:16.285 --> 00:10:20.405
So, you wanna know certainly all
your SharePoint servers running

175
00:10:20.405 --> 00:10:23.475
in your environment, a detailed list

176
00:10:23.475 --> 00:10:26.440
You might as well have a site
collection list as well.

177
00:10:26.440 --> 00:10:27.860
Clean up your environments.

178
00:10:27.860 --> 00:10:31.980
Get rid of the debris,
unused content, site collections.

179
00:10:31.980 --> 00:10:33.710
And there's a way to set that up to avoid

180
00:10:34.980 --> 00:10:38.740
accumulating debris in the first place
when you create a site collection.

181
00:10:38.740 --> 00:10:39.990
For example, you can say, okay,

182
00:10:39.990 --> 00:10:43.120
six months from that date,
site collection owner gets contacted.

183
00:10:43.120 --> 00:10:44.848
Do you wanna keep this site, yes or no?

184
00:10:44.848 --> 00:10:50.180
All right, now,

185
00:10:50.180 --> 00:10:55.040
in terms of working with your devs for
dependencies, now you're gonna have to,

186
00:10:55.040 --> 00:10:59.410
if you've made any customizations to
things like master pages, themes,

187
00:10:59.410 --> 00:11:05.030
any custom web parts or modifying of
default web parts, custom JavaScript or

188
00:11:05.030 --> 00:11:09.520
CSS files, these are some of
the content types, list types.

189
00:11:09.520 --> 00:11:14.090
So, really, any customization you made to
the plain vanilla install of SharePoint

190
00:11:14.090 --> 00:11:18.440
2013 is, you need to enumerate that.

191
00:11:18.440 --> 00:11:22.100
Because as I mentioned,
you're probably gonna have to recreate

192
00:11:22.100 --> 00:11:24.520
all those customizations in
the new 2016 environment.

193
00:11:24.520 --> 00:11:29.080
And if you've been around a few versions
of SharePoint, this is not news, and

00:11:29.080 --> 00:11:30.450
I would like to be able to say,

195
00:11:30.450 --> 00:11:34.540
Microsoft's invested a lot of work
in helping you port customizations.

196
00:11:34.540 --> 00:11:35.140
But, no.

197
00:11:35.140 --> 00:11:39.080
Partly because there are so
many ways you can customize, I suppose.

198
00:11:39.080 --> 00:11:42.600
It was determined to not even be
a worthwhile project to attempt

199
00:11:42.600 --> 00:11:46.430
to have to those customizations
moved to the new version.

200
00:11:46.430 --> 00:11:48.790
>> Kinda makes you wanna think
about staying on the older version.

00:11:48.790 --> 00:11:49.315
I mean,
>> [LAUGH]

00:11:49.315 --> 00:11:50.920

00:11:50.920 --> 00:11:54.060
So everything I've done over the last

00:11:54.060 --> 00:11:57.445
And then possibly won't work

I'm gonna have to re do it for

00:12:00.350 --> 00:12:01.210

One of those three.

00:12:02.230 --> 00:12:03.200
Well, that's a good point.

So, you may want to stick with 2013 for

00:12:08.060 --> 00:12:10.760
If there's no compelling reasons or

00:12:21.080 --> 00:12:22.970
So, there's another reason why.

00:12:22.970 --> 00:12:25.019
I mean, I joke about it sometimes, but

00:12:25.019 --> 00:12:28.560
it makes sense why some larger

00:12:28.560 --> 00:12:32.662
maybe three major versions behind

00:12:32.662 --> 00:12:37.300
the massive amount of resources
required to do a successful upgrade.

217
00:12:37.300 --> 00:12:39.900
Let's see, so solution ages,
web templates.

00:12:39.900 --> 00:12:42.145
You might have modified content types.

00:12:42.145 --> 00:12:44.980
Again, you probably have
to customize all these.

220
00:12:46.170 --> 00:12:49.676
So, that list I just gave to you,
it doesn't,
