00:12:49.676 --> 00:12:53.630
I'm not saying that any customizations
are guaranteed not to work, but all

00:12:54.640 --> 00:12:59.650

cause a failure of an upgrade,

223
00:12:59.650 --> 00:13:02.100
say, of a content database

00:13:02.100 --> 00:13:07.450
So, in terms of your troubleshooting,

00:13:07.450 --> 00:13:10.840
Those, the potential offenders as

00:13:10.840 --> 00:13:12.160
That's why we have to test.

00:13:12.160 --> 00:13:15.810
Maybe you can get away with not having

228
00:13:15.810 --> 00:13:19.550
because maybe they weren't too obscure and
during the upgrade process,

229
00:13:19.550 --> 00:13:22.710
it's understood it will actually
play nice out of the box.

230
00:13:22.710 --> 00:13:23.380
Well, not out of the box,

231
00:13:23.380 --> 00:13:26.300
but after the upgrade in your
SharePoint 2016 environment.

00:13:26.300 --> 00:13:27.190
And, it may not.

00:13:27.190 --> 00:13:31.500
So it's, I wish I could just give you a

00:13:45.572 --> 00:13:46.560
>> Yes.
[LAUGH]

240
00:13:46.560 --> 00:13:47.750
>> The knowledge you get right

241
00:13:47.750 --> 00:13:48.430
after you needed it.

242
00:13:49.740 --> 00:13:50.850
Okay.

243
00:13:50.850 --> 00:13:55.200
So, in terms of cleanup,
we talked about deleting site collections.

244
00:13:55.200 --> 00:13:57.680
Maybe you can get rid of
unnecessary versions.

245
00:13:57.680 --> 00:14:02.370
Do you really need the last 20 versions
of the, I don't know, company picnic?

246
00:14:02.370 --> 00:14:04.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Who's bringing what.

247
00:14:04.310 --> 00:14:04.810
Probably not.

248
00:14:07.160 --> 00:14:11.220
So, features, templates, web parts that
you may have been using before, and

249
00:14:11.220 --> 00:14:11.950
now you don't even need.

250
00:14:11.950 --> 00:14:14.660
They've already been
superseded by other web parts.

251
00:14:14.660 --> 00:14:15.500
Get rid of those.

252
00:14:17.810 --> 00:14:22.330
Okay, so again, this is because
site collection administrators have

253
00:14:22.330 --> 00:14:25.030
quite a lot of power as to what
happens in their own sites.

254
00:14:25.030 --> 00:14:28.910
There might be a different amount of work
for different site collection admins in

255
00:14:28.910 --> 00:14:31.080
your environment in terms of preparing for
the upgrade.

256
00:14:31.080 --> 00:14:34.330
One site collection administrator
might run a tight ship and

257
00:14:34.330 --> 00:14:36.900
is very pro-active about
deleting unused sites, and

258
00:14:36.900 --> 00:14:40.066
one it may have not even have occurred
to them to delete old content.

259
00:14:40.066 --> 00:14:41.726
So, again, training.

260
00:14:41.726 --> 00:14:44.000
Training before upgrade is very helpful.

261
00:14:44.000 --> 00:14:47.610
So maybe you have a two month window
before you even do anything resembling

262
00:14:47.610 --> 00:14:50.890
upgrade, just to encourage
people to clean up the old, and

263
00:14:50.890 --> 00:14:54.095
giving a specific example
of items to clean up.

264
00:14:54.095 --> 00:14:57.165
And then, as a reward, after they do that,

265
00:14:57.165 --> 00:15:00.655
you can prioritize them as being
first in line for an upgrade, right?

266
00:15:00.655 --> 00:15:01.405
>> Yeah.
>> And in fact,

267
00:15:01.405 --> 00:15:04.085
you can prevent an upgrade,
that's not good.

268
00:15:04.085 --> 00:15:05.125
Carrot and the stick.

269
00:15:05.125 --> 00:15:09.675
You could say, if you're not gonna do any
of these cleanup tasks, you're gonna be at

270
00:15:09.675 --> 00:15:12.505
the bottom of the line when it comes to,
in terms of upgrading to the new version.

271
00:15:13.555 --> 00:15:16.357
Okay, so you wanna test your
upgrade in a trial environment.

272
00:15:19.225 --> 00:15:22.531
You definitely wanna back up
your SharePoint 2013 databases,

273
00:15:22.531 --> 00:15:24.097
make sure you've got a back up,

274
00:15:24.097 --> 00:15:27.580
sort of up to the minute right before
you do any kind of upgrade process.

275
00:15:27.580 --> 00:15:28.290
So back them up.

276
00:15:28.290 --> 00:15:32.600
You're gonna make your site collections
Ready Only, so no changes can be made, and

277
00:15:32.600 --> 00:15:35.580
then do the upgrade process.

278
00:15:35.580 --> 00:15:39.309
You also wanna make sure that certain
service applications are backed up.

279
00:15:39.309 --> 00:15:44.277
So, for example, the BDC,
our business connectivity services,

280
00:15:44.277 --> 00:15:49.435
your search administration,
secure store services, back them up.

281
00:15:49.435 --> 00:15:51.791
Just an FYI about
the search admin database.

282
00:15:51.791 --> 00:15:55.910
You have to stop The search service
before backing up that database.

283
00:15:55.910 --> 00:15:58.050
And again,
that could have untoward impact.

284
00:15:58.050 --> 00:16:00.450
Depends, I mean, if you're a small shop,

285
00:16:00.450 --> 00:16:04.330
some of these gotchas that I'm
mentioning might not matter at all.

286
00:16:04.330 --> 00:16:07.410
But if you're a 24,
7 international organization,

287
00:16:07.410 --> 00:16:11.780
stopping the search service could cause
a lot of grief and may be problematic.

288
00:16:11.780 --> 00:16:13.576
So again, planning, planning, planning.

289
00:16:16.061 --> 00:16:16.642
Okay.

290
00:16:22.308 --> 00:16:26.761
So we want to, more customizations
that we need to reconfigure in the new

291
00:16:26.761 --> 00:16:29.900
environment include
alternate access mappings.

292
00:16:29.900 --> 00:16:32.470
Remember, that's a way to
access through a zone,

293
00:16:32.470 --> 00:16:36.820
the same content from a different way,
from the extranet, from the Internet, for

294
00:16:36.820 --> 00:16:39.820
example, or
from anywhere outside your firewall.

295
00:16:39.820 --> 00:16:42.680
So, those alternate access mappings will

296
00:16:42.680 --> 00:16:45.350
have to be recreated in
the new environment.

297
00:16:46.580 --> 00:16:47.860
Authentication providers,

298
00:16:47.860 --> 00:16:51.540
especially if you're using some kind of
multi-factor authentication, you might

299
00:16:51.540 --> 00:16:55.780
have some quota templates that are in use
when a new site collection is created.

300
00:16:55.780 --> 00:16:57.770
You'll have to recreate
the quota templates.

301
00:16:57.770 --> 00:17:00.650
Managed paths, we've looked at this week.

302
00:17:00.650 --> 00:17:03.630
Those will have to be recreated
in the new environment as well.

303
00:17:03.630 --> 00:17:06.170
And then,
incoming outgoing e-mail settings for

304
00:17:06.170 --> 00:17:10.728
things like receiving alerts when content
has changed in the document library.

305
00:17:10.728 --> 00:17:13.930
Or granting the users
the ability to upload or, sorry,

306
00:17:13.930 --> 00:17:17.780
to e-mail content to lists and libraries,
as opposed to having to navigate

307
00:17:17.780 --> 00:17:20.110
the Sharepoint infrastructure and
uploading that way.

308
00:17:21.660 --> 00:17:22.160
All right.

309
00:17:24.040 --> 00:17:25.340
What else do we have?

310
00:17:25.340 --> 00:17:27.740
We have farm-level security and
permission settings.

311
00:17:27.740 --> 00:17:29.170
We'll have to create the new farm.

312
00:17:29.170 --> 00:17:32.140
Again, you want to have a list so
you're not trying to do it from memory.

313
00:17:32.140 --> 00:17:34.330
You have the documentation
in the old farm, and

314
00:17:34.330 --> 00:17:38.030
it's creating the same
environment in the new farm.

315
00:17:38.030 --> 00:17:42.307
Blocked file types, those are configured
on a per web app basis, and you'll have to

316
00:17:42.307 --> 00:17:46.604
do any customizations of block file types
for every web app in your new environment.

317
00:17:48.924 --> 00:17:50.431
Settings and schedules for

318
00:17:50.431 --> 00:17:54.240
timer jobs, so this only applies
if you've customised a timer job.

319
00:17:54.240 --> 00:17:57.120
Remember, there are so
many repetitive processes in SharePoint

320
00:17:57.120 --> 00:18:01.560
that depend on a timer job running every
x number of minutes, days, hours, etc.

321
00:18:01.560 --> 00:18:05.997
If you've customized the timer jobs or
created brand new ones for

322
00:18:05.997 --> 00:18:09.144
whatever custom code you have,
for example,

323
00:18:09.144 --> 00:18:15.047
you'll have to recreate those timer jobs
in your SharePoint 2016 environments.

324
00:18:15.047 --> 00:18:15.547
Okay.

325
00:18:17.923 --> 00:18:20.601
So, performing the upgrade process,
we have to update,

326
00:18:20.601 --> 00:18:22.140
upgrade our content databases.

327
00:18:24.389 --> 00:18:28.904
We have to create web applications
which would involve specifying paths,

328
00:18:28.904 --> 00:18:33.062
host headers, DNS configurations,
whether or not we're allowing

329
00:18:33.062 --> 00:18:37.882
self-service site creation, are we
enabling the my site's functionality?

330
00:18:42.550 --> 00:18:45.687
And then we can mount a content
database to our new environment.

331
00:18:49.035 --> 00:18:53.810
We can use PowerShell to update or
upgrade our service applications.

332
00:18:53.810 --> 00:18:56.074
I'll be showing you some of these
things in a different episode.

333
00:19:04.760 --> 00:19:07.240
Troubleshooting upgrade issues.

334
00:19:07.240 --> 00:19:09.610
Definitely take advantage
of the log files.

335
00:19:09.610 --> 00:19:15.030
There's an upgrade error log file,
and you want to

336
00:19:15.030 --> 00:19:20.070
just by using the farm, having various
users use various customizations or

337
00:19:20.070 --> 00:19:24.190
programs or custom web parts you may
have created, when you recreate them in

338
00:19:24.190 --> 00:19:27.130
the new environment, just test them
to see if they work as expected.

339
00:19:27.130 --> 00:19:29.210
Remember, at this point,
you haven't deleted anything.

340
00:19:29.210 --> 00:19:31.344
You haven't damaged, altered,

341
00:19:31.344 --> 00:19:36.770
removed anything to do with your
existing SharePoint 2013 environment.

342
00:19:36.770 --> 00:19:39.710
This way, you've got a fallback
position if there's some

343
00:19:39.710 --> 00:19:42.020
issue that takes awhile to
resolve in the 2016 environment.

344
00:19:42.020 --> 00:19:45.820
So you're gonna have two farms running for
a period of time.

345
00:19:45.820 --> 00:19:50.530
And this is, that's helpful to know,

346
00:19:50.530 --> 00:19:54.130
takes some of the pressure off that
there's not gonna be a period of time when

347
00:19:54.130 --> 00:19:56.600
nothing works and there's no
SharePoint functionality available.

348
00:19:56.600 --> 00:20:00.490
So, again, the larger the organization,
the more likely you are to have

349
00:20:00.490 --> 00:20:04.945
a staged migration process,
as opposed to everybody all at once.

350
00:20:04.945 --> 00:20:05.565
>> All right, Mark.

351
00:20:05.565 --> 00:20:08.285
Lotta work it seems like
involved in upgrading or

352
00:20:08.285 --> 00:20:10.555
migrating our SharePoint 2016 environment.

353
00:20:10.555 --> 00:20:14.740
But as you said, you have done
properly and taken slowly over time,

354
00:20:14.740 --> 00:20:20.370
not something that we're gonna rush, can
be easily successful migration as well.

355
00:20:20.370 --> 00:20:23.870
And we've got that great
because we're not destroying or

356
00:20:23.870 --> 00:20:29.340
bringing our 2013 environment down until
we've done our migration and testing and

357
00:20:29.340 --> 00:20:33.960
validation, we know we've gotta roll back,
so that really does relieve some of that

358
00:20:33.960 --> 00:20:37.570
stress that we might be feeling during
that upgrade migration process.

359
00:20:37.570 --> 00:20:38.470
So we thank you for that.

360
00:20:38.470 --> 00:20:39.770
Great information there.

361
00:20:39.770 --> 00:20:41.470
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

362
00:20:41.470 --> 00:20:42.820
Signing off for IT Pro TV.

363
00:20:42.820 --> 00:20:44.210
I'm Mike Rodrick.

364
00:20:44.210 --> 00:20:44.910
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

365
00:20:44.910 --> 00:20:45.660
>> And we'll see you next time.

366
00:20:45.660 --> 00:20:53.005
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Social Computing Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.863 --> 00:00:15.584
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.584 --> 00:00:20.641
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our Advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.641 --> 00:00:24.743
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at social computing

5
00:00:24.743 --> 00:00:25.700
features.

6
00:00:25.700 --> 00:00:28.860
Our computers need to get out
there in the real world and date.

7
00:00:28.860 --> 00:00:29.701
No, just kidding.
>> [LAUGH]

8
00:00:29.701 --> 00:00:30.558
>> [LAUGH] No,

9
00:00:30.558 --> 00:00:37.050
we're gonna look at running, basically,
kinda like social media, in house.

10
00:00:37.050 --> 00:00:39.210
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

11
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:40.060
How you doing, Mark?

12
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:40.820
>> Good, Mike, thank you.

13
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:43.459
Yes, there's no Tinder app for SharePoint.

14
00:00:43.459 --> 00:00:45.509
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sorry to disappoint.

15
00:00:45.509 --> 00:00:48.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> But there some social features.

16
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:53.890
Now unfortunately there's also essentially
anti-social features built in.

17
00:00:53.890 --> 00:00:58.525
In other words, you can't really force
users to adopt things like My Sites or

18
00:00:58.525 --> 00:01:01.250
to comment on community forums and
the like.

19
00:01:01.250 --> 00:01:04.500
But you can at least make
those tools available.

20
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:06.280
Let's look at some of those tools.

21
00:01:06.280 --> 00:01:11.625
So user profiles are the source of it all.

22
00:01:11.625 --> 00:01:15.139
And we looked in detail on the first
course, the basic advanced, sorry,

23
00:01:15.139 --> 00:01:16.170
the basic advanced.

24
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:19.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> Basic SharePoint 2016 week.

25
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:23.210
So I'm not going to re-demo what's
already covered in that course.

26
00:01:23.210 --> 00:01:27.710
So if you want more demos,
go back or go to that course.

27
00:01:27.710 --> 00:01:29.720
But we will talk about some features and

28
00:01:29.720 --> 00:01:35.450
I'll show you some things that we haven't
yet demonstrated in an upcoming episode.

29
00:01:35.450 --> 00:01:37.340
But let's talk about what's available.

30
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:41.240
So we've got, if you think of repositories
of information about people in our

31
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:43.940
SharePoint world,
we've got Active Directory information.

32
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:46.838
There's no point in recreating that,
manually or otherwise,

33
00:01:46.838 --> 00:01:49.156
you're asking users to fill
out some kind of form.

34
00:01:49.156 --> 00:01:51.120
No, let's make it as simple as possible.

35
00:01:51.120 --> 00:01:55.500
Let's import data that already exists
about our users in Active Directory.

36
00:01:55.500 --> 00:01:56.640
And while we're at it,

37
00:01:56.640 --> 00:01:59.520
we have the capability of importing
from other repositories as well.

38
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:02.879
As long as we make an LDAP connection.

39
00:02:03.950 --> 00:02:05.680
So you might want to pull
in some information from

40
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:07.580
an HR database for example.

41
00:02:07.580 --> 00:02:10.440
But to keep it simple, let's just talk
about importing it from Active Directory.

42
00:02:10.440 --> 00:02:13.210
So typically we do a one-way import.

43
00:02:13.210 --> 00:02:16.010
Now for the past few versions
of SharePoint we've had

44
00:02:16.010 --> 00:02:18.880
the capability of doing
a two-way synchronization.

45
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:20.670
This could be dodgy.

46
00:02:20.670 --> 00:02:23.800
What we're saying there is,
at least for certain fields, or

47
00:02:23.800 --> 00:02:26.820
certain metadata, if you like,
about an individual user,

48
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:29.902
some of that data can replicate
back to Active Directory.

49
00:02:29.902 --> 00:02:35.370
Now, there's more fields of information
captured about a user in SharePoint.

50
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:40.280
Things like hobbies, alma mater,
skills, other kinds of

51
00:02:40.280 --> 00:02:43.680
reporting relationships that aren't
neatly captured in Active Directory.

52
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:48.062
So we have control whether we're
doing a one-way import, or

53
00:02:48.062 --> 00:02:50.855
a two-way profile synchronization.

54
00:02:50.855 --> 00:02:55.750
We can control exactly which fields
are eligible for synchronization.

55
00:02:55.750 --> 00:03:00.243
You can imagine that things can go south
quite quickly if users were interacting,

56
00:03:00.243 --> 00:03:03.697
their SharePoint personalization or
My Sites environment and

57
00:03:03.697 --> 00:03:07.682
just playing around making changes,
not realizing the implications.

58
00:03:07.682 --> 00:03:11.911
That for example, if they change their
name for a lark and SharePoint then, maybe

59
00:03:11.911 --> 00:03:16.620
that change goes to Active Directory and
it screws up some HR database connection.

60
00:03:16.620 --> 00:03:23.855
So you've got control, but that is
possible to do a two-way synchronization.

61
00:03:23.855 --> 00:03:28.846
All right, so we could also use,
I mentioned LDAP as a way to connect

62
00:03:28.846 --> 00:03:33.753
to an external source to connect
into SharePoint for populating or

63
00:03:33.753 --> 00:03:36.310
adding information about users.

64
00:03:36.310 --> 00:03:43.260
We can also use the BDC, the Business Data
Connector, or Business Data Connectivity.

65
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:45.890
So we talked about that in
a different episode and

66
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:50.040
the ability to connect into
any organized data source.

67
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:52.990
>> So it sounds a lot like, I think we
used the term middleware earlier when

68
00:03:52.990 --> 00:03:55.630
we were talking about
the Business Data Connectivity.

69
00:03:56.880 --> 00:04:01.115
>> Exactly, so not only are we restricted
to Active Directory imports or

70
00:04:01.115 --> 00:04:05.656
any organized data source we can make
an LDAP connection to, also the BDC.

71
00:04:05.656 --> 00:04:10.700
So really when you think about it,
no matter where critical user information

72
00:04:10.700 --> 00:04:15.993
is stored that you want to bring into
a SharePoint environment, you can do that.

73
00:04:15.993 --> 00:04:17.657
And that's a good thing.

74
00:04:17.657 --> 00:04:21.540
>> [LAUGH] It really is, as you said,
I mean why double up the work?

75
00:04:21.540 --> 00:04:26.280
Why have to recreate information that
already exists in an accessible source?

76
00:04:26.280 --> 00:04:27.080
>> Right.
>> Right.

77
00:04:27.080 --> 00:04:31.630
>> in terms of two-way profile
synchronization, you're definitely gonna

78
00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:36.660
wanna be very selective as to which
fields a SharePoint user can update

79
00:04:36.660 --> 00:04:41.560
that would propagate back to, say,
Active Directory or other data source.

80
00:04:41.560 --> 00:04:46.270
Think through the implications and
whether you even need to do that at all.

81
00:04:46.270 --> 00:04:48.713
>> Because maybe they're used to
using that familiar interface.

82
00:04:48.713 --> 00:04:51.896
Or there might be some security
considerations that you don't want people

83
00:04:51.896 --> 00:04:53.774
dealing with sensitive data necessarily.

84
00:04:53.774 --> 00:04:58.006
Or revealing information about themselves,
classification levels perhaps,

85
00:04:58.006 --> 00:05:00.814
in a SharePoint context or
being able to modify that.

86
00:05:00.814 --> 00:05:03.660
But you have a lot of
choices is the point.

87
00:05:03.660 --> 00:05:08.256
Which gets back to our
governance conversation that's

88
00:05:08.256 --> 00:05:12.568
been peppering the episodes
we've done this week.

89
00:05:12.568 --> 00:05:15.113
All right, so for the prerequisites,

90
00:05:15.113 --> 00:05:19.537
we covered some of this in the first
week but it's worth repeating.

91
00:05:19.537 --> 00:05:22.760
We wanna have a separate web
application to host My Site.

92
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:25.045
So if you're gonna enable
My Site's functionality,

93
00:05:25.045 --> 00:05:26.742
it definitely deserves its own web app.

94
00:05:26.742 --> 00:05:29.704
In fact, it's not unusual
to have multiple web apps.

95
00:05:29.704 --> 00:05:33.189
In other words, one web app per country or
world region for example.

96
00:05:33.189 --> 00:05:36.855
Because administrators generally
want to have local control or,

97
00:05:36.855 --> 00:05:39.282
I mean I realize
a continent's a big place.

98
00:05:39.282 --> 00:05:43.299
But the Europeans would want to have
control over their My Sites in a separate

99
00:05:43.299 --> 00:05:47.153
web application, North Americans
probably would wanna have control.

100
00:05:47.153 --> 00:05:51.737
For variety of reasons pertaining
to web app settings, backups, etc.,

101
00:05:51.737 --> 00:05:54.420
and different policies and standards.

102
00:05:54.420 --> 00:05:58.604
It makes sense to have multiple My Sites
regions, if you like, around the world,

103
00:05:58.604 --> 00:06:01.910
depending on the size of
your organization of course.

104
00:06:01.910 --> 00:06:08.290
We wanna set up a managed path for the My
Sites, a My Site host site collection.

105
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:11.410
We've gotta set up a user
profile service application.

106
00:06:11.410 --> 00:06:12.330
So again, we did this,

107
00:06:12.330 --> 00:06:17.100
I demoed this, in the first week,
the basic SharePoint administration week.

108
00:06:18.430 --> 00:06:19.482
All right.

109
00:06:24.405 --> 00:06:29.735
Now, in terms of property mappings, there
may be, let's say Active Directory for

110
00:06:29.735 --> 00:06:34.253
example, there may not be a one-to0one
relationship between a fee.

111
00:06:34.253 --> 00:06:37.738
In fact, there are definitely some fields
in SharePoint out of the box that don't

112
00:06:37.738 --> 00:06:39.826
map to an equivalent field
in Active Directory.

113
00:06:39.826 --> 00:06:43.139
So you get total control over
the mapping of the fields,

114
00:06:43.139 --> 00:06:45.830
constraints like the type
of data expected.

115
00:06:45.830 --> 00:06:49.600
Is it an integer,
is it a word that's expected, and

116
00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:50.740
a lot of other options as well.

117
00:06:50.740 --> 00:06:56.769
So again, you can shape exactly what is
being replicated to what data source.

118
00:06:56.769 --> 00:07:00.861
And in what manner and constraints
on the kind of input expected for

119
00:07:00.861 --> 00:07:02.185
a particular field.

120
00:07:02.185 --> 00:07:06.967
To make sure that we get the behavior we
want, that the field in the other data

121
00:07:06.967 --> 00:07:12.070
source is populated correctly after
the two-way synchronization process.

122
00:07:12.070 --> 00:07:15.360
>> Absolutely, I know a lot of systems
admins probably cringe when you say wait,

123
00:07:15.360 --> 00:07:20.210
they can fill out fields in a SharePoint
that would replicate back to

124
00:07:20.210 --> 00:07:23.060
Active directory or some other LDAP store.

125
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:26.910
But, as you said, with the proper planning
and constraints that SharePoint allows me

126
00:07:26.910 --> 00:07:30.290
to put in place,
I can keep my data store protected.

127
00:07:30.290 --> 00:07:33.110
>> Exactly,
another thing with the mappings is, and

128
00:07:33.110 --> 00:07:35.660
if you recall our discussion
on content types,

129
00:07:35.660 --> 00:07:39.250
this was a big reason to
standardize definitions of columns.

130
00:07:39.250 --> 00:07:45.790
Because what we call, say, the first name
field in SharePoint might be slightly

131
00:07:45.790 --> 00:07:50.060
different from what the equivalent first
name field is called in other data source.

132
00:07:50.060 --> 00:07:51.743
So you have to make sure
that names line up.

133
00:07:51.743 --> 00:07:56.985
And in many cases, manager, for example,
in SharePoint, might not actually

134
00:07:56.985 --> 00:08:02.168
correspond to what you think manager It
represents in that other data source.

135
00:08:02.168 --> 00:08:06.641
So, just because the names of
the profile properties are the same,

136
00:08:06.641 --> 00:08:10.721
it doesn't mean they're gonna
sync the way you want them to,

137
00:08:10.721 --> 00:08:13.233
or that you want to sort of translate or

138
00:08:13.233 --> 00:08:18.119
sync up that field with the same named
field in the different data source.

139
00:08:19.840 --> 00:08:22.280
So there's a SharePoint,
sorry, SharePoint.

140
00:08:22.280 --> 00:08:26.960
There's a Technet link if you want
default user profile property mappings,

141
00:08:26.960 --> 00:08:28.080
you can check out.

142
00:08:28.080 --> 00:08:28.940
And again, this will help.

143
00:08:28.940 --> 00:08:32.720
It's nice to see things on paper,
or at least on a screen, rather

144
00:08:32.720 --> 00:08:36.530
than be in the interface in SharePoint,
and if you don't know what you're doing,

145
00:08:36.530 --> 00:08:40.980
trying to navigate and scroll and
get options right from the interface,

146
00:08:40.980 --> 00:08:43.450
is probably not gonna give
you the best results.

147
00:08:43.450 --> 00:08:45.920
So this is, because there's so
many options for mapping,

148
00:08:45.920 --> 00:08:49.230
this is a good example of something
that you may wanna print out.

149
00:08:49.230 --> 00:08:53.380
Maybe circle some properties that you
think would be good candidates for

150
00:08:53.380 --> 00:08:54.180
synchronization.

151
00:08:54.180 --> 00:08:57.042
It's the kinda thing you wanna
bounce off other people, or

152
00:08:57.042 --> 00:08:58.827
maybe that decision is made for you.

153
00:08:58.827 --> 00:09:03.471
And then, you go into the interface, and
instead of scrolling through hundreds, or

154
00:09:03.471 --> 00:09:06.180
at least dozens of potential
property mappings,

155
00:09:06.180 --> 00:09:08.825
you know exactly the mapping
you're looking for

156
00:09:08.825 --> 00:09:12.521
and how you're gonna configure it
before entering the interface.

157
00:09:14.411 --> 00:09:18.999
Data type compatibility is another
consideration to evaluate.

158
00:09:18.999 --> 00:09:23.874
In other words, there may be an acceptable
input in a field in SharePoint that

159
00:09:23.874 --> 00:09:29.199
doesn't map well due to integer size, for
example, or just unexpected data type,

160
00:09:29.199 --> 00:09:34.690
or an incompatible data type in that other
directory source you're trying to sync to.

161
00:09:35.690 --> 00:09:38.410
>> Now, Mark, I know some of
the information in my user profile

162
00:09:38.410 --> 00:09:41.730
might not be appropriate for sharing
with everybody in the organization.

163
00:09:41.730 --> 00:09:44.760
Do we have ways of controlling that or
what's visible?

164
00:09:44.760 --> 00:09:46.940
>> Absolutely, and that's a great thing.

165
00:09:46.940 --> 00:09:49.090
Because we have privacy concerns and

166
00:09:49.090 --> 00:09:51.730
business rules about what
information gets exposed.

167
00:09:51.730 --> 00:09:54.760
So, for any given field in
the SharePoint's profile, for

168
00:09:54.760 --> 00:09:58.700
example, we can make it required or
optional, or

169
00:09:58.700 --> 00:10:02.490
even disable it so
that field doesn't even appear to users.

170
00:10:02.490 --> 00:10:07.710
And additionally, users have
control based on a privacy setting.

171
00:10:07.710 --> 00:10:11.030
So, not all the fields,
but many the fields,

172
00:10:11.030 --> 00:10:15.030
allow the user to control who
sees that particular information.

173
00:10:15.030 --> 00:10:18.330
If, for example, if I have a home
phone number, I haven't had one for

174
00:10:18.330 --> 00:10:19.741
20 years, that's another story.

175
00:10:19.741 --> 00:10:21.941
>> [LAUGH]
>> But a mobile phone number,

176
00:10:21.941 --> 00:10:23.311
a mobile phone number.

177
00:10:23.311 --> 00:10:25.411
I might only want my boss to have that.

178
00:10:25.411 --> 00:10:28.010
So, I can make that setting for
that field.

179
00:10:28.010 --> 00:10:30.170
>> Okay.
>> Other information may be,

180
00:10:30.170 --> 00:10:34.370
is appropriate for my colleagues,
that's another grouping of visibility.

181
00:10:34.370 --> 00:10:36.820
And everyone is another option as well.

182
00:10:36.820 --> 00:10:41.790
And the user, not for all the fields,
but for the vast majority of fields,

183
00:10:41.790 --> 00:10:45.580
each user gets to control who
can see what information.

184
00:10:45.580 --> 00:10:49.724
Home address, for example,
or hobbies or sun signs.

185
00:10:49.724 --> 00:10:54.344
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

186
00:10:54.344 --> 00:10:58.887
Now, a big part of why we go to this
trouble of establishing profiles in

187
00:10:58.887 --> 00:11:05.060
SharePoint, and the synchronization we've
talked about, is the concept of audiences.

188
00:11:05.060 --> 00:11:11.160
Now, a big misunderstanding exists for
some people.

189
00:11:11.160 --> 00:11:14.880
They think audiences and
security are the same thing, or

190
00:11:14.880 --> 00:11:16.070
have some kind of correlation.

191
00:11:16.070 --> 00:11:17.270
They don't.

192
00:11:17.270 --> 00:11:21.090
What audiences do allow us to
do is to target information

193
00:11:21.090 --> 00:11:26.040
to certain user populations based
on any criteria we specify.

194
00:11:26.040 --> 00:11:30.330
So, an example I'd like to use is let's
say we've got a company intranet page,

195
00:11:30.330 --> 00:11:33.445
and we have five offices
throughout the country.

196
00:11:33.445 --> 00:11:37.885
We can have information that's
important to disseminate for

197
00:11:37.885 --> 00:11:39.715
everyone in the company.

198
00:11:39.715 --> 00:11:42.955
But other information is really
only relevant regionally.

199
00:11:43.955 --> 00:11:48.945
For example, upcoming sales meetings or
even metrics that

200
00:11:48.945 --> 00:11:54.485
should only be seen by people at that
particular office, not all five offices.

201
00:11:54.485 --> 00:11:59.110
So it's much better to create
one intranet homepage, for

202
00:11:59.110 --> 00:12:03.290
example, rather than five different
ones just to expose slightly different

203
00:12:03.290 --> 00:12:05.990
information to each of the five offices.

204
00:12:05.990 --> 00:12:11.000
So by using audiences,
we can choose any single field or

205
00:12:11.000 --> 00:12:15.440
combination of fields, there's lots
of ways of setting up audience rules,

206
00:12:15.440 --> 00:12:19.680
to target information to users
who should see that information.

207
00:12:20.830 --> 00:12:26.200
This is good because if we want people to
adopt and increase their use of SharePoint

208
00:12:26.200 --> 00:12:31.480
and maybe start or have the Internet page
open all day long, or a place that they go

209
00:12:31.480 --> 00:12:36.290
to frequently, maybe a start page for the
browser, something like multiple monitors.

210
00:12:36.290 --> 00:12:40.570
The way to get that stickiness, or
the interest in users in going there,

211
00:12:40.570 --> 00:12:46.360
is to make that information timely, which
means expiring content that's out of date.

212
00:12:46.360 --> 00:12:48.850
And you can do that before publishing it.

213
00:12:48.850 --> 00:12:51.540
You can say, you know what,
expire this content on this date.

214
00:12:51.540 --> 00:12:56.700
The day after the annual general meeting,
for example, or may be a week after.

215
00:12:56.700 --> 00:12:58.730
So when people go there,
they're expecting, and

216
00:12:58.730 --> 00:13:02.800
they get, fresh content,
also relevant content.

217
00:13:02.800 --> 00:13:06.310
So, by taking the time and
showing appreciation for

218
00:13:06.310 --> 00:13:11.373
the time of our employees and showing
them regional content relevant to them,

219
00:13:11.373 --> 00:13:14.180
again, they're gonna be more
likely to want to go and

220
00:13:14.180 --> 00:13:17.770
stay and use other tools that we make
available on that intranet homepage.

221
00:13:17.770 --> 00:13:20.400
And when I say intranet homepage,
that's just an example.

222
00:13:20.400 --> 00:13:23.340
You can use audience targeting on any page

223
00:13:23.340 --> 00:13:26.812
in SharePoint if you think it's gonna
make the content more relevant.

224
00:13:26.812 --> 00:13:31.250
Another idea,
another example I like to use is KPI's.

225
00:13:31.250 --> 00:13:36.420
Maybe only VP level and
above employees should get to see KPIs.

226
00:13:36.420 --> 00:13:39.300
And they wanna see it on a page
that's frequented by the people.

227
00:13:39.300 --> 00:13:45.010
Again, we can expose a web part only
to those of a certain audience,

228
00:13:45.010 --> 00:13:49.712
and the audience we can declare as,
or define as VPs,

229
00:13:49.712 --> 00:13:54.630
and it would show up for
VPs based on their

230
00:13:54.630 --> 00:13:59.610
title which presumably would have
been pulled in from active directory.

231
00:13:59.610 --> 00:14:02.650
So, or any combination,
we can have multiple rules.

232
00:14:02.650 --> 00:14:06.950
So, maybe there's a rule for managers,
one for VPs, one for the west region.

233
00:14:06.950 --> 00:14:10.455
You can have multiple rules
to comprise an audience,

234
00:14:10.455 --> 00:14:11.810
it's only limited by your imagination.

235
00:14:11.810 --> 00:14:17.750
This means you have the capability to
target content as narrowly or as broadly

236
00:14:17.750 --> 00:14:21.580
as you want, again, making SharePoint
a more useful tool for everybody.

237
00:14:21.580 --> 00:14:22.270
>> Very good.

238
00:14:22.270 --> 00:14:24.980
And making it easier for us to administer
because then I don't have to make five

239
00:14:24.980 --> 00:14:27.130
pages for five different offices.

240
00:14:27.130 --> 00:14:28.440
>> Exactly, exactly.

241
00:14:28.440 --> 00:14:30.570
It probably wouldn't be us as admins,

242
00:14:30.570 --> 00:14:34.330
but somebody's gonna appreciate not
having to do that duplicate work.

243
00:14:34.330 --> 00:14:37.690
And then also, you get some
issues with making changes and

244
00:14:37.690 --> 00:14:39.790
you have to change it five times.

245
00:14:39.790 --> 00:14:42.718
Now, you could be using content rollups,
but that's a whole other discussion.

246
00:14:42.718 --> 00:14:45.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, what's next?

247
00:14:45.790 --> 00:14:50.050
Audiences, let's look
at social interaction.

248
00:14:50.050 --> 00:14:54.110
Now, there's been attempts at Microsoft,
they bought 5% of Facebook so

249
00:14:54.110 --> 00:14:59.120
you can see some of the Facebook-like
activity or tagging with @s and

250
00:14:59.120 --> 00:15:06.450
hashtags and that kinda thing, or general
social media activities we'd pursue.

251
00:15:06.450 --> 00:15:10.780
Now, Microsoft acquired Yammer,
the adoption of that was iffy.

252
00:15:10.780 --> 00:15:13.730
It's kind of a weird level of abstraction.

253
00:15:13.730 --> 00:15:16.676
Putting a social network
inside a social network.

254
00:15:16.676 --> 00:15:20.475
I mean, it's just, people didn't use it,
or it wasn't fully deployed.

255
00:15:20.475 --> 00:15:25.100
Cuz we have the same, or
very close tools in SharePoint already.

256
00:15:25.100 --> 00:15:27.370
So people have avoided Yammer for
that reason.

257
00:15:27.370 --> 00:15:30.440
So what do we have capabilities,
the My Sites.

258
00:15:30.440 --> 00:15:33.870
If we enable it, that means the user
has their own site collection.

259
00:15:33.870 --> 00:15:36.480
They can share documents
with whomever they please,

260
00:15:36.480 --> 00:15:40.310
they can use it as a repository,
reminder, task list, whatever they want.

261
00:15:40.310 --> 00:15:43.980
They can do some blogging from there.

262
00:15:43.980 --> 00:15:48.167
They can, it's a place to go, they can
find mentions if they've been tagged in

263
00:15:48.167 --> 00:15:50.117
some kind of content, for example.

264
00:15:50.117 --> 00:15:54.321
Maybe a discussion somewhere from
their MySite, they can see a feed,

265
00:15:54.321 --> 00:15:58.683
showing all the mentions or
hashtag they're interested in following.

266
00:15:58.683 --> 00:16:05.820
There's also likes as well and ratings,
those have been deprecated though.

267
00:16:05.820 --> 00:16:09.640
Community sites, I'm gonna have a demo for

268
00:16:09.640 --> 00:16:11.430
you in an upcoming episode
of community sites.

269
00:16:11.430 --> 00:16:15.020
It's kind of a news group feel,
discussion list.

270
00:16:16.410 --> 00:16:21.190
I often ask people in organizations,
approximately what percentage of

271
00:16:21.190 --> 00:16:25.340
the information they need to run their
business lives just in people's heads?

272
00:16:25.340 --> 00:16:27.760
In other words,
it's not documented anywhere.

273
00:16:27.760 --> 00:16:31.370
It could be a standard operating
procedure that everybody knows about,

274
00:16:31.370 --> 00:16:33.669
but some of those aren't
written down anywhere.

275
00:16:34.780 --> 00:16:37.958
So, typically the answer
is from 20 to 70%.

276
00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:42.904
So, 20 to 70% of the information
that employees need to do their

277
00:16:42.904 --> 00:16:47.956
jobs is not documented anywhere,
not on paper, not in some Word doc.

278
00:16:47.956 --> 00:16:52.864
So, this is a problem
because it can be tough

279
00:16:52.864 --> 00:16:57.920
to find areas of expertise
that people have.

280
00:16:57.920 --> 00:16:59.400
You might pass someone in the hallway or

281
00:16:59.400 --> 00:17:02.170
talk to them about football
game on the weekend.

282
00:17:02.170 --> 00:17:04.800
But not realize that
they have some expertise

283
00:17:04.800 --> 00:17:07.210
in an area that would really
make a difference to you.

284
00:17:07.210 --> 00:17:10.070
Maybe learning a new programming language,
for example, or they put on

285
00:17:10.070 --> 00:17:14.040
a conference before, or they attended
a conference you're thinking of attending.

286
00:17:14.040 --> 00:17:19.050
All kinds of information that is no
real convenient way to expose that,

287
00:17:19.050 --> 00:17:20.050
or it hasn't been til now.

288
00:17:20.050 --> 00:17:23.270
So, certainly with the different
fields available for

289
00:17:23.270 --> 00:17:27.405
SharePoint, I can expose my hobbies,
I can say all that matter.

290
00:17:27.405 --> 00:17:31.270
Projects that I've worked on,
awards I've received or

291
00:17:31.270 --> 00:17:33.960
recognitions, publications
is another thing.

292
00:17:33.960 --> 00:17:37.630
I mean there's not gonna be a publications
field in Active Directory, but

293
00:17:37.630 --> 00:17:40.650
there would be on my SharePoint My Sites.

294
00:17:40.650 --> 00:17:43.750
I can expose to people, they say,
Mark published this paper, great,

295
00:17:43.750 --> 00:17:44.410
I'll go check it out.

296
00:17:45.660 --> 00:17:50.450
So Wikis is one way to quickly
get knowledge disbursement,

297
00:17:50.450 --> 00:17:52.160
these community sites is another way.

298
00:17:52.160 --> 00:17:57.840
Like a discussion list, which we
probably all posted on reader response,

299
00:17:57.840 --> 00:18:00.540
newspaper articles, or online sites.

300
00:18:01.590 --> 00:18:05.950
It's a place where people can go to
discuss and comment on a common interest

301
00:18:05.950 --> 00:18:09.650
or article or a news event or
a political campaign or what have you.

302
00:18:09.650 --> 00:18:12.470
So, it's a way of getting
the conversation going.

303
00:18:12.470 --> 00:18:17.040
And keep in mind, a lot of organizations
now, they may not be large, but

304
00:18:17.040 --> 00:18:18.800
they're often geographically dispersed.

305
00:18:18.800 --> 00:18:23.670
What I mean is, maybe there is no actual
head office, it's an entirely virtual

306
00:18:23.670 --> 00:18:26.970
company, people working from wherever
there's an Internet connection.

307
00:18:26.970 --> 00:18:32.430
And a good cup of coffee, so in that case
there's no kind of water cooler talk.

308
00:18:32.430 --> 00:18:34.950
There maybe some message
board kind of environment.

309
00:18:34.950 --> 00:18:38.070
But these community sites again,
we can get discussions going.

310
00:18:38.070 --> 00:18:41.963
Now the question then becomes,
who is moderating the content?

311
00:18:41.963 --> 00:18:48.300
Because for obvious reasons we don't
want malicious words being approved.

312
00:18:48.300 --> 00:18:52.680
So but then you have to introduce
the concept of a moderator.

313
00:18:52.680 --> 00:18:57.400
Which means somebody, that's part of
their job, to authorize essentially or

314
00:18:57.400 --> 00:19:00.590
approve any comment from being
placed on the discussion boards.

315
00:19:00.590 --> 00:19:02.520
So that person, that moderator or

316
00:19:02.520 --> 00:19:06.150
moderators, become the bottleneck for
free flowing communication.

317
00:19:06.150 --> 00:19:08.260
So that's a factor to
keep in mind as well.

318
00:19:10.150 --> 00:19:15.330
So a community portal is a place to go for
a collection of these site collections or

319
00:19:15.330 --> 00:19:19.660
community sites, and
then a user could search from there.

320
00:19:21.010 --> 00:19:26.200
So again, the antisocial computing,
we joke about it but just because

321
00:19:26.200 --> 00:19:30.470
I have a SharePoint My Site set up,
I can be very stingy with my knowledge.

322
00:19:30.470 --> 00:19:36.520
In other words I know, but if I say I went
to this university, or I presented at

323
00:19:36.520 --> 00:19:42.460
this conference, that's gonna attract some
attention, maybe some demands on my time.

324
00:19:42.460 --> 00:19:45.670
Which is really part of my job
description, so I might say you know what,

325
00:19:45.670 --> 00:19:47.790
I'm gonna keep focused
on my tasks at hand.

326
00:19:47.790 --> 00:19:52.060
I'm not going to reveal this about myself
knowing that I'm gonna be interrupted for

327
00:19:52.060 --> 00:19:52.960
my primary purpose.

328
00:19:52.960 --> 00:19:56.690
Now, it may involve a culture change,
where people realize

329
00:19:57.710 --> 00:20:01.850
the more people that participate in this,
the better it is for everybody.

330
00:20:01.850 --> 00:20:03.682
So it may need a carrot and

331
00:20:03.682 --> 00:20:08.030
or stick to get people to buy into,
to share their wealth of expertise

332
00:20:09.540 --> 00:20:12.890
with other members of the organization
that could driver the enterprise forward.

333
00:20:16.420 --> 00:20:21.930
Okay, so, again we have a separate web
app for the my sites architecture.

334
00:20:21.930 --> 00:20:24.840
That's important at least one and
one per region,

335
00:20:24.840 --> 00:20:28.510
I recommend,
if you're a world wide organization.

336
00:20:28.510 --> 00:20:31.970
When the user creates the My Site for
the first time it takes a while

337
00:20:31.970 --> 00:20:35.090
to get created but
that becomes a site collection.

338
00:20:35.090 --> 00:20:38.720
Which may involve discussions about
quota and total storage space.

339
00:20:39.860 --> 00:20:40.550
>> All right Mark, so

340
00:20:40.550 --> 00:20:44.470
what kind of permissions does
a user need to create My Sites?

341
00:20:44.470 --> 00:20:47.740
>> Okay good question, so they need
to create personal site permission.

342
00:20:47.740 --> 00:20:52.440
Now by default, all authenticated
users would have this permission.

343
00:20:52.440 --> 00:20:56.640
What I recommend is having a test
department or division or a geographic

344
00:20:56.640 --> 00:21:02.650
location to ramp up with the My Site's
functionality first rather than everyone.

345
00:21:02.650 --> 00:21:07.640
Because there's gonna be lesson learned,
storage requirements are an issue.

346
00:21:07.640 --> 00:21:10.870
Now that people are essentially
site collection administrators,

347
00:21:10.870 --> 00:21:13.520
if they're on site collection they're
probably going to break things or

348
00:21:13.520 --> 00:21:15.840
experiment and
have increasing help desk calls.

349
00:21:15.840 --> 00:21:20.530
So rather than turning loose 10,000
people potentially with MySites,

350
00:21:20.530 --> 00:21:22.220
maybe start with a hundred.

351
00:21:22.220 --> 00:21:27.130
And then you'll get a sense of the support
required during the onboarding,

352
00:21:27.130 --> 00:21:34.610
if you like, of these hundred new
people using My Sites, all right.

353
00:21:34.610 --> 00:21:37.940
Now, every time we set up
a service application,

354
00:21:37.940 --> 00:21:40.260
there's at least one
database that's created.

355
00:21:40.260 --> 00:21:44.490
And there's also related databases
when it comes to My Sites.

356
00:21:44.490 --> 00:21:47.500
So there's the User Profile
service application.

357
00:21:47.500 --> 00:21:52.600
That has a profile database, a social
database and a synchronization database.

358
00:21:52.600 --> 00:21:55.930
So the profile database holds
information about the users.

359
00:21:55.930 --> 00:22:01.920
The social database has information
about tags or likes to manage that.

360
00:22:01.920 --> 00:22:03.950
And the synchronization database for

361
00:22:03.950 --> 00:22:07.609
synchronizing with the external
data sources like Active Directory.

362
00:22:08.740 --> 00:22:10.580
There's also the manage metadata service,

363
00:22:10.580 --> 00:22:16.410
this is useful because we can use
keywords, so maybe you want to,

364
00:22:16.410 --> 00:22:19.020
we've looked at managing metadata
service in other episodes.

365
00:22:19.020 --> 00:22:23.400
Maybe you want to constrain
users in terms of words or

366
00:22:23.400 --> 00:22:26.030
perhaps phrases they can
use in certain fields.

367
00:22:27.740 --> 00:22:31.320
Some fields lend themselves to that
more than others, like department or

368
00:22:31.320 --> 00:22:34.110
classification or rank, for example.

369
00:22:34.110 --> 00:22:37.670
Even job title, but that would probably
come from an active directory anyway.

370
00:22:37.670 --> 00:22:42.220
But other fields would make
more sense to freeform or

371
00:22:42.220 --> 00:22:44.380
no such constraint,
like a phone number field, for example.

372
00:22:46.510 --> 00:22:50.190
All right search service application
is highly recommended because,

373
00:22:50.190 --> 00:22:51.310
what I said earlier.

374
00:22:51.310 --> 00:22:55.110
Since so much of the information required
to run a company doesn't exist anywhere

375
00:22:55.110 --> 00:22:59.870
documented, now more of that information
can be exposed through MySites.

376
00:22:59.870 --> 00:23:03.310
So we want to make sure that
search is involved as well.

377
00:23:03.310 --> 00:23:06.270
So when I'm searching on
a particular topic not only am I

378
00:23:06.270 --> 00:23:09.650
getting results back
from actual documents and

379
00:23:09.650 --> 00:23:13.750
perhaps websites internally and externally
that are part of the crawl database.

380
00:23:13.750 --> 00:23:17.870
But also now, I'm gonna get people
results in my search results, and

381
00:23:17.870 --> 00:23:20.790
then I can hover over or
click on those and

382
00:23:20.790 --> 00:23:24.660
drill down and go to that person's
My Site, a personalization page.

383
00:23:24.660 --> 00:23:27.210
Based on a search result I clicked on,
again,

384
00:23:27.210 --> 00:23:30.880
that now before the My Sites I
would not have had that capability

385
00:23:30.880 --> 00:23:34.030
unless that person had published
something in relation to my search field.

386
00:23:34.030 --> 00:23:39.550
But now a search can include
any field in SharePoint

387
00:23:39.550 --> 00:23:45.180
populated on the personalization page for
the particular user.

388
00:23:47.820 --> 00:23:51.969
Now, there's several timer jobs related
to profile synchronization which

389
00:23:51.969 --> 00:23:52.874
are automatic.

390
00:23:52.874 --> 00:23:58.271
You may have multi-lingual
user interface requirements.

391
00:23:58.271 --> 00:24:04.359
So we've looked at that in another
episode, the multilingual capabilities.

392
00:24:04.359 --> 00:24:09.206
And you may want to restrict the kinds
of files that users are allowed

393
00:24:09.206 --> 00:24:11.174
to upload to their My Site.

394
00:24:11.174 --> 00:24:15.562
So if there's no good reason, for
example, for them to have video files,

395
00:24:15.562 --> 00:24:17.034
block those file types.

396
00:24:17.034 --> 00:24:23.226
Because you can imagine that's just gonna
be a massive bandwidth and storage hog.

397
00:24:23.226 --> 00:24:26.987
Now depending on the business, if your
business is involved with producing video

398
00:24:26.987 --> 00:24:29.778
then that would be silly to block
upload of those file types.

399
00:24:29.778 --> 00:24:33.632
But maybe not because maybe you
want anything that resembles work,

400
00:24:33.632 --> 00:24:36.900
if you're a video production company for
example.

401
00:24:36.900 --> 00:24:40.550
Maybe you don't want any of that content
being stored in your users' My Sites

402
00:24:40.550 --> 00:24:43.570
because maybe that's the main
output of what you do.

403
00:24:43.570 --> 00:24:47.582
So you want it stored somewhere, a file
server for example, where you can access

404
00:24:47.582 --> 00:24:51.361
it, edit, manipulate, delete, etc.,
and have total control over it.

405
00:24:51.361 --> 00:24:53.788
And remember,
when we're talking about block file types,

406
00:24:53.788 --> 00:24:55.653
those are set an a pure
web application basis.

407
00:24:55.653 --> 00:24:59.607
Which means if you have European,
North American, let's say

408
00:24:59.607 --> 00:25:04.530
South American My Sites hosts, to block
all those file types from appearing in

409
00:25:04.530 --> 00:25:10.127
any region requires setting those blocked
file types on each web application.

410
00:25:10.127 --> 00:25:13.153
>> It would be nice if there
was a sort of blanket, far and

411
00:25:13.153 --> 00:25:18.013
wide blocked file types capability, but
there's not, natively, in SharePoint.

412
00:25:20.109 --> 00:25:24.213
Okay, now to set up
the My Sites web application,

413
00:25:24.213 --> 00:25:29.610
we'll have to set up a DNS record and
a separate service account.

414
00:25:29.610 --> 00:25:31.604
You wanna registered that service account.

415
00:25:31.604 --> 00:25:37.330
So remember, separate web applications
very important for My Sites.

416
00:25:38.450 --> 00:25:42.375
You wanna create a My Site
host site collection and

417
00:25:42.375 --> 00:25:48.115
that is an enterprise type of site
template, the My Site host template.

418
00:25:48.115 --> 00:25:52.229
Then you want a wildcard-included
manage path, so

419
00:25:52.229 --> 00:25:56.535
any number of people's sites
below the My Sites host.

420
00:25:58.628 --> 00:26:01.601
And then we can connect that
web app to various service

421
00:26:01.601 --> 00:26:04.122
applications I discussed
a few minutes ago.

422
00:26:04.122 --> 00:26:08.280
And then, we want to enable
self-service site creation.

423
00:26:08.280 --> 00:26:11.417
So once that little button is exposed for
users,

424
00:26:11.417 --> 00:26:16.237
when they log in they'll see it on
SharePoint and they can click to enable or

425
00:26:16.237 --> 00:26:19.940
to start this self-service
site creation process.

426
00:26:19.940 --> 00:26:23.020
Remember, that's gonna lead
to extra storage, bandwidth,

427
00:26:23.020 --> 00:26:24.539
help desk calls potentially.

428
00:26:24.539 --> 00:26:26.687
So rather than choose the default,

429
00:26:26.687 --> 00:26:31.634
all authenticated users may be exposed
to a functionality, just a small subset.

430
00:26:31.634 --> 00:26:34.800
Maybe the IT users of
the western region for example.

431
00:26:36.080 --> 00:26:40.580
>> Now, Mark, is there a way that I can
restrict certain users from using tags or

432
00:26:40.580 --> 00:26:42.440
some of those other social features?

433
00:26:42.440 --> 00:26:45.240
>> Absolutely, so
things like tags and notes.

434
00:26:45.240 --> 00:26:49.013
Maybe you don't want to enable all that
functionality right away for all users.

435
00:26:49.013 --> 00:26:53.295
Again, sort of experimenting or maybe
that's just not the direction your company

436
00:26:53.295 --> 00:26:55.190
wants to go in, in terms of social.

437
00:26:55.190 --> 00:26:57.862
So you can block access
to that functionality.

438
00:27:01.931 --> 00:27:07.020
Okay, and then we also have privacy
settings for social features as well.

439
00:27:08.570 --> 00:27:13.229
So again, me as a user,
I can choose the visibility of things like

440
00:27:15.830 --> 00:27:19.090
my tags or
things like workplace anniversary.

441
00:27:19.090 --> 00:27:21.840
Maybe I don't want people to know that
I've been here 50 years, for example.

442
00:27:21.840 --> 00:27:23.234
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And

443
00:27:23.234 --> 00:27:26.086
in terms of the Ask Me About section,

444
00:27:26.086 --> 00:27:31.615
that's where it's getting sort of
introduction, ask me about this.

445
00:27:31.615 --> 00:27:36.785
Maybe once that's set, or
maybe someone else designs it for you,

446
00:27:36.785 --> 00:27:42.660
so maybe your manager says,
I don't want Fred to opt out of this.

447
00:27:42.660 --> 00:27:46.766
He will be asked about X, Y,
and Z cuz that's his expertise.

448
00:27:46.766 --> 00:27:50.395
And it's really important that other
people get a chance to know that and

449
00:27:50.395 --> 00:27:53.170
I'm saying this is part
of his job description.

450
00:27:53.170 --> 00:27:54.040
So I can say,

451
00:27:54.040 --> 00:27:58.780
once that About Me section is filled out,
it cannot be changed by Fred.

452
00:27:58.780 --> 00:28:03.740
So that's another way of forcing people
to buy into this knowledge sharing

453
00:28:03.740 --> 00:28:08.230
environment that you may
want to be creating.

454
00:28:08.230 --> 00:28:13.710
Now, I might not want people to know
which communities I'm participating in or

455
00:28:13.710 --> 00:28:15.570
whether I'm following a certain person.

456
00:28:15.570 --> 00:28:20.170
So again, me as a user,
I have control over who sees what about

457
00:28:20.170 --> 00:28:23.640
my social activities on
the various SharePoint sites.

458
00:28:25.490 --> 00:28:29.220
Birthdays as well, maybe some people don't
like their birthdays being celebrated.

459
00:28:29.220 --> 00:28:32.965
It's a reminder that they're not getting
any younger so I might want to hide that.

460
00:28:32.965 --> 00:28:36.588
Or maybe they just don't like surprises so
I can hide the birthday.

461
00:28:36.588 --> 00:28:40.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right.

462
00:28:40.770 --> 00:28:44.615
>> All right, Mark, great look at some
of the social computing features that

463
00:28:44.615 --> 00:28:48.291
are built into SharePoint that we can
choose to enable or not to enable.

464
00:28:48.291 --> 00:28:52.192
And a lot of the control that
we have over that and again,

465
00:28:52.192 --> 00:28:56.930
part of and a kind of a deeper look
at My Sites as well thrown in there.

466
00:28:56.930 --> 00:28:58.600
So we appreciate that, Mark.

467
00:28:58.600 --> 00:29:00.490
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

468
00:29:00.490 --> 00:29:03.210
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

469
00:29:03.210 --> 00:29:03.990
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

470
00:29:03.990 --> 00:29:04.643
>> And we'll see you next time.

471
00:29:04.643 --> 00:29:12.186
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Social Computing Features Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.171 --> 00:00:14.747
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode here

3
00:00:14.747 --> 00:00:15.950
at ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:15.950 --> 00:00:17.080
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:17.080 --> 00:00:20.198
And today,
we're doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

6
00:00:20.198 --> 00:00:22.071
And specifically, in this episode,

7
00:00:22.071 --> 00:00:26.330
we're actually continuing our thought
process on social computing features.

8
00:00:26.330 --> 00:00:27.170
This is a part two.

9
00:00:27.170 --> 00:00:30.220
So if you missed the first one,
make sure you go back and check that out.

10
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:35.760
In this one, we're going to move into
community type settings within SharePoint.

11
00:00:35.760 --> 00:00:38.760
And here to make a little more
sense of that than what I'm doing

12
00:00:38.760 --> 00:00:39.680
is Mr. Mark Ingram.

13
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:40.610
How are you doing, Mark?

14
00:00:40.610 --> 00:00:41.870
>> Good, Mike.
Thanks.

15
00:00:41.870 --> 00:00:43.488
Yes, communities.

16
00:00:43.488 --> 00:00:45.485
We're all one, or 1,000.

17
00:00:45.485 --> 00:00:46.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> But anyway.

18
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:49.230
We want a way to collaborate

19
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:52.786
discussions boards with people
that share common interestes.

20
00:00:52.786 --> 00:00:54.580
Now, presumably, this is work related but

21
00:00:54.580 --> 00:00:57.910
it could be a company baseball team,
what have you.

22
00:00:57.910 --> 00:01:02.110
So we have a bunch of features related
to communities that we'll look at.

23
00:01:02.110 --> 00:01:06.710
Community portal comprised
of multiple community sites.

24
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:12.490
And we'll look at community usage options,
membership, permissions levels, which

25
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:16.060
are a little different than your standard
SharePoint site permission levels.

26
00:01:16.060 --> 00:01:16.700
Why?

27
00:01:16.700 --> 00:01:19.610
Because we need moderators.

28
00:01:19.610 --> 00:01:23.861
If experience on the web has shown,
unmoderated content descends quickly.

29
00:01:23.861 --> 00:01:26.273
>> [LAUGH]
>> The race to the bottom.

30
00:01:26.273 --> 00:01:31.802
All right so the idea is to allow for
collaboration and to expose content and

31
00:01:31.802 --> 00:01:38.213
expertise that again people didn't really
know that existed in their organization,

32
00:01:38.213 --> 00:01:42.101
you can't meet everybody and
get their life story.

33
00:01:42.101 --> 00:01:45.595
However that person you pass in
the hallway might have some really useful

34
00:01:45.595 --> 00:01:48.300
information for
you to move your next project forward.

35
00:01:49.510 --> 00:01:55.840
So it's a way to classify discussions and
encourage discussions in your enterprise.

36
00:01:55.840 --> 00:02:00.120
Now presumably with generally
a business motivation, but it could be

37
00:02:00.120 --> 00:02:04.770
just letting off steam or just some kind
of social outlet for people as well.

38
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:09.770
We also have the ability to
like certain comments and

39
00:02:09.770 --> 00:02:12.230
then that will be more likely be promoted.

40
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:15.594
And so we get sort of the group knowledge,

41
00:02:15.594 --> 00:02:21.476
knowledge of the herd to help classify
which comments are of most value.

42
00:02:21.476 --> 00:02:25.116
So you probably seen this in
other community based sites, for

43
00:02:25.116 --> 00:02:28.686
example Microsoft,
some of the tech net communities were,

44
00:02:28.686 --> 00:02:33.096
you get a star rating based on the number
of correct answers given as voted by

45
00:02:33.096 --> 00:02:35.630
people that got benefit from your answer.

46
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:38.000
So that kind of functionality
exists as well.

47
00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:40.850
And you can even award badges as well,

48
00:02:40.850 --> 00:02:42.700
I don't know if you can
take those to the bank,

49
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:46.867
but it gives you a nice warm feeling
inside knowing you're a gold member.

50
00:02:46.867 --> 00:02:50.910
All right, or maybe there is some
financial benefit or it does translate

51
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:55.040
into some kind of formal recognition or
consideration for promotion, who knows,

52
00:02:55.040 --> 00:02:59.920
but it is a way of rewarding and
acknowledging who has been the most useful

53
00:02:59.920 --> 00:03:04.410
and valuable on these communities and
maybe it's a defacto help desk as well.

54
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:10.797
Or a channel there for resolving issues
that you may have with technology or

55
00:03:10.797 --> 00:03:15.979
some business process organization,
maybe assembly line situations.

56
00:03:15.979 --> 00:03:23.530
The uses for communities are really left
as limited by your imagination only.

57
00:03:23.530 --> 00:03:27.930
Best reply is another tag
option as well as likes.

58
00:03:27.930 --> 00:03:31.150
So again to help users that don't
have a lot of time scan through,

59
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:35.480
search discussions and
then maybe get a question answered that

60
00:03:35.480 --> 00:03:37.760
somebody already else had that
question and it was answered.

61
00:03:37.760 --> 00:03:43.876
So you can get a much faster answer
than by re-posing the same question.

62
00:03:43.876 --> 00:03:46.046
All right, so,

63
00:03:46.046 --> 00:03:51.660
now you might think about we just use
email we just use distribution list.

64
00:03:51.660 --> 00:03:56.190
Believe me if my golfing group is any
indication those list are annoying

65
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:59.530
getting thirty replies about whether
someone is available this Tuesday for

66
00:03:59.530 --> 00:04:01.530
golf, forget about it.

67
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:03.677
Email.
Let's keep things like it's away from

68
00:04:03.677 --> 00:04:05.059
email distribution lists.

69
00:04:05.059 --> 00:04:08.556
>> Hopefully everybody at ITProTV is
listening to you in regards to our

70
00:04:08.556 --> 00:04:10.221
kickball team, but I digress.

71
00:04:10.221 --> 00:04:12.680
[LAUGH]
>> Kickball, I've never heard of that.

72
00:04:12.680 --> 00:04:14.788
If we can maybe discuss that offline.

73
00:04:14.788 --> 00:04:15.482
>> Yeah.

74
00:04:15.482 --> 00:04:18.513
[LAUGH]
>> So besides the annoyance factor that

75
00:04:18.513 --> 00:04:23.992
comes at you through email, community is
the place you can go to when you're ready.

76
00:04:23.992 --> 00:04:27.042
Maybe you have some time, maybe you're
interested in helping some people out with

77
00:04:27.042 --> 00:04:29.110
replies, or you have a question to post.

78
00:04:29.110 --> 00:04:30.609
You get to go there on your time.

79
00:04:32.000 --> 00:04:36.270
Also, we have a very valuable history.

80
00:04:36.270 --> 00:04:40.750
So I had mentioned that in a different
episode about the knowledge walking around

81
00:04:40.750 --> 00:04:42.990
from long term employees.

82
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:47.760
Some of that is now captured and retained
because there is a history maintained for

83
00:04:47.760 --> 00:04:49.560
community discussions.

84
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:52.850
So again, compared to email say, if you
just joined email distribution lists,

85
00:04:52.850 --> 00:04:54.600
you wouldn't be privy to all
the previous discussions.

86

00:08:57.080 --> 00:09:00.880
Again, they're kind of dormant, waiting

00:09:00.880 --> 00:09:05.430
It would definitely be a mistake to say

161
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:08.770

00:09:08.770 --> 00:09:10.090

Because you're introducing some

to confuse users, and

00:09:14.600 --> 00:09:17.130

security risks as well.

166
00:09:17.130 --> 00:09:20.620
So don't go all willy-nilly there,
but the point is,

167
00:09:20.620 --> 00:09:25.230

168
00:09:25.230 --> 00:09:29.469

00:09:32.070 --> 00:09:35.470
Membership of a community is

00:09:37.418 --> 00:09:40.080

00:09:48.570 --> 00:09:51.728

00:10:00.840 --> 00:10:06.179

00:10:15.510 --> 00:10:18.340

00:10:28.160 --> 00:10:32.020
Owners still have full control of the

00:10:32.020 --> 00:10:34.496

00:10:34.496 --> 00:10:41.490
All right, so

00:11:03.820 --> 00:11:07.230

00:11:18.250 --> 00:11:20.920

00:11:39.310 --> 00:11:40.660

And who knows what benefit

00:11:56.580 --> 00:11:59.710

go over to the dc, because we're gonna
