319
00:20:42.130 --> 00:20:45.301
So I'm in my
Active Directory Administrative Center and

320
00:20:45.301 --> 00:20:46.760
I wanna create a new user.

321
00:20:50.178 --> 00:20:55.294
This will be the search service
admin web service application pool,

322
00:20:55.294 --> 00:20:57.975
one of the longest full names ever.

323
00:20:57.975 --> 00:21:00.770
[LAUGH]
>> Descriptive.

324
00:21:00.770 --> 00:21:02.940
>> Yes, well, I like to make it plain.

325
00:21:07.856 --> 00:21:11.500
I'm not even sure what the maximum
number of characters in this field is.

326
00:21:11.500 --> 00:21:12.730
I don't aim to find out.

327
00:21:12.730 --> 00:21:17.000
>> I know, at least we don't have to
log on with that account very often.

328
00:21:17.000 --> 00:21:20.528
>> That's true, well, the UPN log on
can be much more reasonable, yeah.

329
00:21:20.528 --> 00:21:21.745
>> Much more.

330
00:21:21.745 --> 00:21:24.035
[LAUGH]
>> Thankfully.

331
00:21:24.035 --> 00:21:31.059
>> [LAUGH] Search admin app pool,
okay, and the password.

332
00:21:38.927 --> 00:21:42.440
And password never expires,
user cannot change password.

333
00:21:44.742 --> 00:21:45.830
And OK.

334
00:21:48.585 --> 00:21:50.950
And onto another user now.

335
00:21:50.950 --> 00:21:57.408
This will be the search service
query web service, application pool.

336
00:22:00.627 --> 00:22:03.725
>> And again as he's making that,
we're following best practice, right,

337
00:22:03.725 --> 00:22:06.150
creating separate accounts for
the different services.

338
00:22:06.150 --> 00:22:08.000
That way if one becomes compromised,

339
00:22:08.000 --> 00:22:12.469
they're not all compromised, just a best
practice or standard approach to this,

340
00:22:15.130 --> 00:22:22.387
Port search query, @Pool.

341
00:22:25.135 --> 00:22:27.813
Password again.

342
00:22:31.420 --> 00:22:32.469
Excellent.

343
00:22:32.469 --> 00:22:36.449
And user cannot change,
password never expires.

344
00:22:38.910 --> 00:22:42.460
Another new user now, so

345
00:22:42.460 --> 00:22:47.200
B, the search service account.

346
00:22:47.200 --> 00:22:52.086
Whoops, and we'll call

347
00:22:52.086 --> 00:22:57.222
this one search service.

348
00:22:57.222 --> 00:23:05.248
[BLANK AUDIO] Okay, unusual.

349
00:23:05.248 --> 00:23:10.324
I'm using this Mac again today and
the key depth is minimal.

350
00:23:10.324 --> 00:23:11.230
>> It is, isn't it?

351
00:23:11.230 --> 00:23:13.520
>> Wow, it's like a souped up car or
something.

352
00:23:13.520 --> 00:23:16.520
>> You're gonna get used to it and
go back to that PC and go, what the heck?

353
00:23:16.520 --> 00:23:17.670
>> Man, my finger are weak now.

354
00:23:19.328 --> 00:23:25.380
[LAUGH] We'll have you converted
before the end of the week.

355
00:23:25.380 --> 00:23:26.665
>> Delirium has set in.

356
00:23:26.665 --> 00:23:30.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> I will not go to the Macs.

357
00:23:30.090 --> 00:23:31.870
I have iPhones, but I'm not getting a Mac.

358
00:23:31.870 --> 00:23:32.657
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

359
00:23:32.657 --> 00:23:37.818
now it's time to register some service
accounts as SharePoint managed accounts,

360
00:23:37.818 --> 00:23:44.277
which means I need to go back to my
>> SharePoint box.

361
00:23:44.277 --> 00:23:50.781
So under Security General Settings.

362
00:23:50.781 --> 00:23:55.668
I want to Configure Managed Accounts,
Add Registered Managed Account.

363
00:23:55.668 --> 00:23:58.311
So this one will be Real Town.

364
00:24:00.912 --> 00:24:03.613
And Search Admin App Pool,

365
00:24:13.662 --> 00:24:20.573
And okay And

366
00:24:20.573 --> 00:24:23.853
wanna register another
managed account now and

367
00:24:23.853 --> 00:24:26.813
this one will be
the search query app pool.

368
00:24:45.569 --> 00:24:48.425
And okay.

369
00:24:48.425 --> 00:24:50.855
And one more will be the search service.

370
00:25:08.593 --> 00:25:09.190
And okay.

371
00:25:13.736 --> 00:25:17.708
And now it's time to view the community
sites on the community portal.

372
00:25:17.708 --> 00:25:19.734
At last.

373
00:25:19.734 --> 00:25:23.520
[LAUGH]
Okay, so

374
00:25:23.520 --> 00:25:27.370
in fact this was expected
that we wouldn't load up.

375
00:25:27.370 --> 00:25:30.170
We have to run a search crawl first.

376
00:25:30.170 --> 00:25:30.900
I must say, though,

377
00:25:30.900 --> 00:25:34.875
I was expecting an error message
not just the blank white canvas.

378
00:25:34.875 --> 00:25:37.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sometimes error messages pop up,

379
00:25:37.230 --> 00:25:38.360
sometimes they don't.

380
00:25:38.360 --> 00:25:43.980
But the point is I was expecting to not
see what I needed until we run the crawl.

381
00:25:43.980 --> 00:25:47.280
So go back to my Essential Admin.

382
00:25:47.280 --> 00:25:51.770
I'll go back to Application Management and
Manage Service Applications.

383
00:25:53.070 --> 00:25:56.880
Now I wanna set up a new
search service application.

384
00:25:58.750 --> 00:26:02.647
Let's call this Railtown Search.

385
00:26:13.212 --> 00:26:18.174
Okay, and in the Search Service Accounts

386
00:26:18.174 --> 00:26:23.600
list I want my REAL_TOWN/searchService.

387
00:26:23.600 --> 00:26:24.760
Register managed account.

388
00:26:26.380 --> 00:26:30.640
And I'll set up in app pool for
this, scroll down a bit more there.

389
00:26:32.310 --> 00:26:34.217
And, let's call this SearchAdminAppPool.

390
00:26:38.414 --> 00:26:38.914
Whoops.

391
00:26:41.944 --> 00:26:47.587
Okay, and for my application pool for
search query and

392
00:26:47.587 --> 00:26:53.361
site settings,
this will be the search query app pool.

393
00:27:05.942 --> 00:27:06.530
Okay.

394
00:27:09.594 --> 00:27:13.129
Okay, so unlike some other
dialog boxes in SharePoint,

395
00:27:13.129 --> 00:27:16.530
this one actually gives us
some helpful information.

396
00:27:16.530 --> 00:27:19.810
We can see here that the search
service is configured and

397
00:27:19.810 --> 00:27:22.390
now the search service
application is being configured.

398
00:27:22.390 --> 00:27:25.870
It'd be nice of the standardized actually
to have some kind of progress part so

399
00:27:25.870 --> 00:27:29.440
you're wondering, okay they did that
click take when I clicked okay.

400
00:27:29.440 --> 00:27:30.340
What is happening?

401
00:27:30.340 --> 00:27:32.730
So people like some feedback,
it's reassuring.

402
00:27:34.120 --> 00:27:37.270
Okay so that search service
application was created.

403
00:27:39.940 --> 00:27:41.870
And I'll refresh this page here.

404
00:27:44.657 --> 00:27:51.507
Our service applications page, and here's
the Railtown search service application.

405
00:27:55.971 --> 00:27:56.552
Click that.

406
00:28:00.922 --> 00:28:02.643
It takes a while to load.

407
00:28:07.711 --> 00:28:08.670
Make sure I don't tweak that.

408
00:28:08.670 --> 00:28:10.869
Click on Content Sources under Crawling.

409
00:28:12.800 --> 00:28:17.770
All right, so the crawl of the local
SharePoint site is now complete and

410
00:28:17.770 --> 00:28:18.570
successful.

411
00:28:18.570 --> 00:28:22.870
So from there we can create
discussions on the community sites and

412
00:28:22.870 --> 00:28:26.040
configure the community
site participation.

413
00:28:26.040 --> 00:28:26.935
>> Fantastic Mark.

414
00:28:26.935 --> 00:28:31.532
Great look at, again, some were talking
about the social computing features that

415
00:28:31.532 --> 00:28:33.380
we find in SharePoint 2016.

416
00:28:33.380 --> 00:28:37.260
Ways to really enhance collaboration and
sharing of information.

417
00:28:37.260 --> 00:28:41.610
Getting your users to work together,
right, that's what it's all about.

418
00:28:41.610 --> 00:28:44.270
We're not going to start singing
Kum Ba Ya or anything like that.

419
00:28:44.270 --> 00:28:49.220
But then a great demonstration as well
is setting up that community portal and

420
00:28:49.220 --> 00:28:50.380
that community site.

421
00:28:50.380 --> 00:28:51.780
So we thank you for that, Mark.

422
00:28:51.780 --> 00:28:53.640
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

423
00:28:53.640 --> 00:28:56.350
Signing up for ITProTV, I'm Mike Roderick.

424
00:28:56.350 --> 00:28:57.615
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

425
00:28:57.615 --> 00:28:59.490
>> And we'll see next time.

426
00:28:59.490 --> 00:29:06.985
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Office 365 and SharePoint Online Registration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.206 --> 00:00:15.239
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.239 --> 00:00:19.474
I'm your host Mike Roderick and today
we're doing our Advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:19.474 --> 00:00:25.076
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be looking at Office 365 and

5
00:00:25.076 --> 00:00:28.000
SharePoint Online registration.

6
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:31.540
So we're starting to move from
the on-premises deployment of SharePoint

7
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:35.090
to that online or
cloud SharePoint deployment and

8
00:00:35.090 --> 00:00:37.390
here to help us with all of this is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

9
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:38.350
How are you doing, Mark?

10
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:39.640
>> Great, Mike, thank you.

11
00:00:39.640 --> 00:00:40.606
Yes.

12
00:00:40.606 --> 00:00:46.240
In our architectural module, our episode
right at the beginning of this series,

13
00:00:46.240 --> 00:00:49.080
we looked at four architectural models.

14
00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:52.290
And we've been working with
on-premises to this point.

15
00:00:52.290 --> 00:00:56.330
Now we're going to look at where, frankly,
almost all of the development occurs,

16
00:00:56.330 --> 00:01:00.030
from Microsoft's perspective, in terms of
introducing new functionality, namely,

17
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:01.110
the Cloud.

18
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.370
So, we'll look at Office 365,
SharePoint Online, but

19
00:01:04.370 --> 00:01:08.380
before we do any of that, we need to
actually register for an account.

20
00:01:08.380 --> 00:01:11.330
Now, when you actually go
through the procedure,

21
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:14.070
it will probably have changed from
what [LAUGH] I'm showing you.

22
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:14.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

23
00:01:14.580 --> 00:01:19.590
everything's subject to change not just
with the registration procedure but

24
00:01:19.590 --> 00:01:23.880
certainly working with Office 365
itself or whatever bundle you get

25
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:28.570
might have a different addition tomorrow
compared to today with the pricing plans.

26
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:31.980
You think of all these MBAs working
to figure out how to bundle,

27
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:36.340
extract the most value from people and,
so I'll show you that as well,

28
00:01:36.340 --> 00:01:38.740
just some of the many
options you can choose.

29
00:01:38.740 --> 00:01:42.590
So, this again comes down to
a planning consideration.

30
00:01:42.590 --> 00:01:46.940
So let's flip over to my screen
over here and I'm just starting.

31
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:48.910
In the beginning there was Google.

32
00:01:48.910 --> 00:01:50.580
A good place to start all searches.

33
00:01:50.580 --> 00:01:57.864
I'll go for Office 365 and
go to the sponsored link.

34
00:02:01.485 --> 00:02:02.930
All right.

35
00:02:02.930 --> 00:02:08.310
To be fair to Microsoft, although
there are a dizzying array of options,

36
00:02:08.310 --> 00:02:14.200
they do help guide you to the pricing plan
and the feature plan that's best for you.

37
00:02:14.200 --> 00:02:18.960
You can always move, you may wanna scale
up for example if you're doing a trial,

38
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:23.020
O365, a deployment of maybe 20 people
are trying it out and reporting back and

39
00:02:23.020 --> 00:02:27.140
then you're tweaking and then you're
gonna upgrade the licence say to an E3 or

40
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:28.080
an E5 licence.

41
00:02:28.080 --> 00:02:30.210
So you can see the plans and pricing.

42
00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:36.550
The ribbon area, below the ribbon,
O 365 Business, Business Premium.

43
00:02:36.550 --> 00:02:38.730
And again,
these are always subject to change.

44
00:02:38.730 --> 00:02:43.370
So you may have a key, like Skype for
business, for example.

45
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:44.630
That might be really important to you and

46
00:02:44.630 --> 00:02:47.500
maybe it doesn't appear in the bundle
you have so you have to switch bundles.

47
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:51.620
That sort of thing can be
quite common unfortunately.

48
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:53.220
Everything's subject to change.

49
00:02:53.220 --> 00:02:57.703
And, as you'd expect,
you got clear, up-front pricing and

50
00:02:57.703 --> 00:03:01.330
annual committment is cheaper
than a month committment,

51
00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:03.760
which is pretty basic
pricing business there.

52
00:03:03.760 --> 00:03:05.540
Now, it also gives you nice icons.

53
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:07.240
It helps you at a glance to
figure out what you're getting.

54
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:09.010
This is pretty good.

55
00:03:09.010 --> 00:03:11.980
Even the O365 business essentials.

56
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:14.250
You do get Office online so

57
00:03:14.250 --> 00:03:19.660
the ability to edit Office content without
having the client on your machine.

58
00:03:19.660 --> 00:03:23.400
And, what else do we have here,
so that's email and

59
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:27.430
conferencing, we've got O365 business,
business premium.

60
00:03:27.430 --> 00:03:32.370
So you can see that we get more
capabilities as we go up the ladder so

61
00:03:32.370 --> 00:03:35.350
Skype, some cloud storage and

62
00:03:35.350 --> 00:03:40.680
the ability to install client applications
as well free with your license.

63
00:03:40.680 --> 00:03:45.840
Additionally, you often get up to five
PCs that you can put the software on.

64
00:03:45.840 --> 00:03:50.360
So it's a nice trade-off between
actually paying for the product but

65
00:03:50.360 --> 00:03:53.280
getting a lot of licenses
to use the product.

66
00:03:53.280 --> 00:03:55.160
So it's pretty reasonable.

67
00:03:55.160 --> 00:04:00.710
And then there's gonna be
tables to look at as well and

68
00:04:00.710 --> 00:04:04.850
I'll show you a screen a little later
that's got a feature comparison.

69
00:04:04.850 --> 00:04:06.630
So again, it goes back to governance.

70
00:04:06.630 --> 00:04:12.540
Rather than wading through a table
with literally hundreds of lines and

71
00:04:12.540 --> 00:04:15.790
comparing options across pricing plans,
it's better to know in advance

72
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:19.850
what are the critical components you need,
and what might be nice to have, and

73
00:04:19.850 --> 00:04:22.600
then some of those options you're
not even gonna know what they are.

74
00:04:22.600 --> 00:04:26.800
So have a list of what you must have,
nice to have and

75
00:04:26.800 --> 00:04:28.912
then other,
perhaps that you don't care about.

76
00:04:28.912 --> 00:04:33.310
All right, so
are people going to be editing online?

77
00:04:35.410 --> 00:04:38.180
Is HD video conferencing a need for you?

78
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:39.710
So you have to decide this.

79
00:04:39.710 --> 00:04:43.385
And let's say we select
O 365 Business Premium.

80
00:04:43.385 --> 00:04:46.680
I'll say buy now.

81
00:04:46.680 --> 00:04:49.810
It tells me I already have
a subscription through work.

82
00:04:49.810 --> 00:04:53.430
So this can be a problem if you have
multiple identities in your life,

83
00:04:53.430 --> 00:04:56.400
or maybe you have a trial account
that's totally separate from work, and

84
00:04:56.400 --> 00:04:59.180
now you have to do a proper work trial.

85
00:04:59.180 --> 00:05:00.959
So you might encounter this screen.

86
00:05:00.959 --> 00:05:06.742
So I'll click on create a new account,
and they're going to sign me out.

87
00:05:09.470 --> 00:05:14.020
Recommending browsers be closed,
but I'm not gonna do that.

88
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:19.508
Okay, so, it's important to
choose the correct country.

89
00:05:19.508 --> 00:05:21.114
You might think it's a trial,

90
00:05:21.114 --> 00:05:24.465
I'll just play around and
choose Botswana or something.

91
00:05:24.465 --> 00:05:27.765
That could throw you for
a loop because not all the options or

92
00:05:27.765 --> 00:05:31.745
the same combinations of options
is available in each country.

93
00:05:31.745 --> 00:05:33.125
Different licensing arrangements.

94
00:05:33.125 --> 00:05:34.925
So, don't get cute with that.

95
00:05:34.925 --> 00:05:36.490
Just keep it what it is.

96
00:05:36.490 --> 00:05:38.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> So.

97
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:40.640
>> All right, so
we'll let Mark fill out that form,

98
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:43.580
we'll kinda hide his information
as he's filling it out.

99
00:05:43.580 --> 00:05:44.630
He likes you guys, but

100
00:05:44.630 --> 00:05:47.381
he doesn't really wanna receive
a whole bunch of phone calls though.

101
00:05:47.381 --> 00:05:48.549
>> [LAUGH]
>> You good, Mark?

102
00:05:48.549 --> 00:05:49.892
Got it all filled out I think?

103
00:05:49.892 --> 00:05:50.885
>> Yeah, we're good now.

104
00:05:50.885 --> 00:05:53.542
Thank's for
that security through obscurity.

105
00:05:53.542 --> 00:05:54.145
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

106
00:05:54.145 --> 00:05:54.780
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:05:54.780 --> 00:05:56.980
>> So, what happened was I filled out

108
00:05:56.980 --> 00:05:58.000
my name and address.

109
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:01.350
The address is verified, so if you're
thinking of using this as a trial and

110
00:06:01.350 --> 00:06:04.570
you don't wanna make it a real account
that you use in production and you think,

111
00:06:04.570 --> 00:06:06.795
well, I'll just put a fake address in,
that won't work.

112
00:06:06.795 --> 00:06:07.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

113
00:06:07.420 --> 00:06:09.150
I guess unless it's
a legitimate fake address.

114
00:06:09.150 --> 00:06:11.520
>> Right.
>> Because there's zip code verification

115
00:06:11.520 --> 00:06:12.720
and that kind of thing.

116
00:06:12.720 --> 00:06:14.400
So-
>> Use your neighbor's address, it's okay.

117
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:15.300
>> Or your ex's address,

118
00:06:15.300 --> 00:06:17.090
that always goes [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

119
00:06:17.090 --> 00:06:19.590
>> Yes, please send promotional material.

120
00:06:19.590 --> 00:06:20.870
Okay, that's silly.

121
00:06:20.870 --> 00:06:23.370
All right, so
now we're onto this screen here.

122
00:06:23.370 --> 00:06:25.230
It says Step 4, place your order.

123
00:06:25.230 --> 00:06:29.710
So this is the plan I originally clicked
on, the Office 365 Business Premium.

124
00:06:29.710 --> 00:06:33.654
And then I enter the number of users,
keep it at one.

125
00:06:33.654 --> 00:06:36.420
And it shows the taxes, which is nice.

126
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:39.842
And then if I have a discount code or
promo code, maybe I was at a tech,

127
00:06:39.842 --> 00:06:44.031
well, not tech, that doesn't happen
anymore, Ignite conference for example and

128
00:06:44.031 --> 00:06:47.276
the presenter was handling out cards
with the code on to get people

129
00:06:47.276 --> 00:06:50.190
to try Office 365 then
you click on that link.

130
00:06:50.190 --> 00:06:53.080
Have a promo or discount code and
enter the information.

131
00:06:53.080 --> 00:06:57.090

We gotta think it through,
it can live in deleted users for a while.

468
00:25:46.535 --> 00:25:50.610
Because it's quite possible we're gonna
wanna access contents of that mailbox.

469
00:25:50.610 --> 00:25:54.663
Or simply as I said,
attach the new user to that old user's

470
00:25:54.663 --> 00:25:59.135
mailbox.Cuz there's a lot of
conversation history in there,

471
00:25:59.135 --> 00:26:02.561
that will probably be of
use to the new employee.

472
00:26:02.561 --> 00:26:08.197
All right, under Data Migration,
this is a way of pulling

473
00:26:08.197 --> 00:26:14.650
information from our existing
email account into Office 365.

474
00:26:14.650 --> 00:26:18.300
That could take a while,
[LAUGH] as you can imagine.

475
00:26:18.300 --> 00:26:21.350
But there's a facility to do that.

476
00:26:21.350 --> 00:26:23.070
We find this a lot in Office 365.

477
00:26:23.070 --> 00:26:28.070
We'll also look at SharePoint Online
administration in a different episode.

478
00:26:28.070 --> 00:26:34.110
A lot of what we need to do in terms of
coexistence with on-premises services and

479
00:26:34.110 --> 00:26:37.500
server content,
we could administer from the cloud.

480
00:26:37.500 --> 00:26:40.800
So if you're wondering where to do this,
on prem or

481
00:26:40.800 --> 00:26:43.350
on the cloud, always start with on cloud.

482
00:26:43.350 --> 00:26:46.050
There may be things to do on the server,
on prem.

483
00:26:46.050 --> 00:26:51.648
But all Microsoft's money, research money,
almost all of it is going to developing or

484
00:26:51.648 --> 00:26:57.570
ongoing development, new features in the
Cloud services, O365, SharePoint Online.

485
00:26:57.570 --> 00:27:01.339
So start there, and then if you have
to run a script say on your on prem

486
00:27:01.339 --> 00:27:03.870
server you'll be given
guidance to do that.

487
00:27:03.870 --> 00:27:07.679
And you can typically copy and
paste PowerShell script and

488
00:27:07.679 --> 00:27:09.940
make some modifications on prem.

489
00:27:09.940 --> 00:27:12.941
So we're not gonna wait for
this data migration dashboard to appear.

490
00:27:12.941 --> 00:27:18.100
But this is again this is enabling
you to import your mail into O365.

491
00:27:18.100 --> 00:27:23.510
And the last thing I'll say for
this episode is on groups.

492
00:27:23.510 --> 00:27:27.750
So we have the ability to add a group,
there's that lonely computer again, and

493
00:27:27.750 --> 00:27:29.400
we have some options
when it comes to group.

494
00:27:29.400 --> 00:27:31.850
Do we want to make it an Office 365 group?

495
00:27:31.850 --> 00:27:33.950
Is it a distribution list?

496
00:27:33.950 --> 00:27:39.180
So we've looked at in other episodes,
the community site template

497
00:27:39.180 --> 00:27:43.020
as a better alternative to
distribution lists in some cases.

498
00:27:43.020 --> 00:27:46.991
But there still may be a need in your
organization for distribution lists,

499
00:27:46.991 --> 00:27:48.320
you can create it there.

500
00:27:48.320 --> 00:27:52.860
Let's see what happens if I
click on Office 365 group.

501
00:27:52.860 --> 00:27:57.628
The usual, what we'd expect,
whether we're doing it on prem or

502
00:27:57.628 --> 00:28:01.281
not, give it a name, and
let's call it Grouper.

503
00:28:01.281 --> 00:28:02.760
Is that a fish?

504
00:28:02.760 --> 00:28:05.340
>> It is, a very tasty one.

505
00:28:05.340 --> 00:28:06.910
>> A tasty fish, cool.

506
00:28:06.910 --> 00:28:09.625
[LAUGH] Doesn't taste like chicken,
let's call it groupergroup.

507
00:28:11.350 --> 00:28:14.460
I know, it's silly, so

508
00:28:14.460 --> 00:28:19.210
the portion of the email address after
the at symbol is already populated there.

509
00:28:20.308 --> 00:28:24.750
And I can give a description, and
then I can set privacy settings.

510
00:28:24.750 --> 00:28:27.700
Can only members, so
it's sort of a secret group that way,

511
00:28:27.700 --> 00:28:29.710
only members can see the group content.

512
00:28:29.710 --> 00:28:32.240
Or can anyone see that group content?

513
00:28:32.240 --> 00:28:37.730
Give it a language, and
then somebody needs to own the group and

514
00:28:37.730 --> 00:28:43.030
be able to send messages to the group,
maybe approve or reject member requests.

515
00:28:43.030 --> 00:28:44.320
Now we see this screen here.

516
00:28:44.320 --> 00:28:47.320
So adding a group,
your group is being created.

517
00:28:47.320 --> 00:28:49.640
It can take up to a minute for
the group to be ready.

518
00:28:49.640 --> 00:28:53.170
This is a very common
kind of feedback you get.

519
00:28:53.170 --> 00:28:57.960
During any changes, additions, deletions,
whatever you're doing in the cloud

520
00:28:57.960 --> 00:29:01.020
environment often it might take an hour or
more.

521
00:29:01.020 --> 00:29:03.480
In this case it was a very fast item,
less than a minute.

522
00:29:03.480 --> 00:29:05.630
It might take an hour,
two hours to provision.

523
00:29:05.630 --> 00:29:07.700
Especially when you're provisioning
SharePoint Online for the first time.

524
00:29:07.700 --> 00:29:12.261
You see this gray outline, and
then it says we're getting it ready.

525
00:29:12.261 --> 00:29:16.720
So don't expect instant results when
you're working O365 and SharePoint Online.

526
00:29:16.720 --> 00:29:19.899
But certainly by the next day or if you do
something at the end of the day at work

527
00:29:19.899 --> 00:29:22.000
when you come in in the morning,
it'll be ready.

528
00:29:22.000 --> 00:29:26.328
So you're not gonna get the instant
gratification that you're probably used to

529
00:29:26.328 --> 00:29:27.800
with on prem environment.

530
00:29:27.800 --> 00:29:32.734
Things go on, there may be a service
down which prevents you from creating or

531
00:29:32.734 --> 00:29:36.910
adding that new service like Skype for
Business, for example.

532
00:29:36.910 --> 00:29:40.880
But it does make it very clear in
the feedback in the dashboard there that,

533
00:29:40.880 --> 00:29:42.300
okay, it's in process.

534
00:29:42.300 --> 00:29:45.700
You're not left wondering, did that work,
do I have to redo anything?

535
00:29:45.700 --> 00:29:49.200
>> Fantastic, all right, really good look
there at the interface that we get once

536
00:29:49.200 --> 00:29:52.010
we've created that
Office 365 subscription.

537
00:29:52.010 --> 00:29:53.960
And then we go back in to administer that.

538
00:29:53.960 --> 00:29:55.460
So we thank you for that, Mark.

539
00:29:55.460 --> 00:29:57.790
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

540
00:29:57.790 --> 00:30:00.130
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

541
00:30:00.130 --> 00:30:01.041
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

542
00:30:01.041 --> 00:30:03.460
>> And we'll see you next time.

543
00:30:03.460 --> 00:30:11.500
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Office 365 Administration Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.905 --> 00:00:12.676
Hello.

3
00:00:12.676 --> 00:00:15.990
Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:15.990 --> 00:00:19.370
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick and today we
are doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:19.370 --> 00:00:22.060
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:27.360
we're gonna be continuing on with
our Office 365 administration.

7
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:30.500
We've already done a part one, so if you
missed that make sure you go back and

8
00:00:30.500 --> 00:00:34.120
watch our first, it'll make this
episode make a little more sense.

9
00:00:34.120 --> 00:00:38.530
Here to continue on exploring the
Office365 Administration Interface, and

10
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:41.500
some other really cool stuff,
is mister Mark Ingram.

11
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:42.230
How you doing Mark?

12
00:00:42.230 --> 00:00:43.550
>> Good, Mike.
Thanks very much.

13
00:00:43.550 --> 00:00:44.080
Yeah!
So

14
00:00:44.080 --> 00:00:47.780
when we finished off last time,
we were in the middle of groups.

15
00:00:47.780 --> 00:00:51.130
And now in this little bell
notification icon here,

16
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:54.890
in the upper right,
It reminds you that I've joined the group.

17
00:00:54.890 --> 00:00:56.600
Nice, its a grouper group.

18
00:00:56.600 --> 00:00:57.750
>> Good, grouper group.

19
00:00:57.750 --> 00:00:59.580
>> It's not grouper, is it?

20
00:00:59.580 --> 00:01:00.740
>> I don't think so.

21
00:01:00.740 --> 00:01:01.640
>> Okay.
Now if I click on that,

22
00:01:01.640 --> 00:01:03.680
it wants me to reauthenticate.

23
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:06.660
You can see a bunch of other
accounts that have used.

24
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:08.820
Now, It's not letting be close it.

25
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:09.580
Okay.

26
00:01:09.580 --> 00:01:14.059
That's odd that went somewhere
completely different.

27
00:01:14.059 --> 00:01:14.618
>> Nice!

28
00:01:14.618 --> 00:01:16.220
>> That's annoying!

29
00:01:16.220 --> 00:01:19.495
>> It's probably a little frustrated
we left it sitting during lunch.

30
00:01:19.495 --> 00:01:20.540
[LAUGH]
>> feels neglected!

31
00:01:20.540 --> 00:01:23.220
>> It was feeling lonely, so
now its going to mess with us I guess.

32
00:01:23.220 --> 00:01:27.400
>> So you might have seen
similar notifications working in

33
00:01:27.400 --> 00:01:31.300
server manager on-prem, for example, you
do something and it appears in task view,

34
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:35.680
and you can dismiss it, I dismiss all
here, because I don't need to be reminded.

35
00:01:35.680 --> 00:01:37.640
>> And it could be handy though.

36
00:01:37.640 --> 00:01:40.520
In this case, we were the ones
that added to the group, right,

37
00:01:40.520 --> 00:01:43.460
but what if you were added to a group and
it wasn't you that did the adding?

38
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:47.390
You log in, and hey, you're now part of
this group, and you can go explore and

39
00:01:47.390 --> 00:01:50.430
find new resources maybe that
are available to that group.

40
00:01:50.430 --> 00:01:55.480
>> Excellent point, and one of my
Facebook beef's somewhat off topic

41
00:01:55.480 --> 00:01:58.870
here is the ability of people to add me
to groups that I never gave consent too.

42
00:01:58.870 --> 00:02:00.490
So it's another reason to check.

43
00:02:00.490 --> 00:02:03.010
You might not want to
be associated with that

44
00:02:06.160 --> 00:02:11.280
bocci ball Friday league
>> Anybody been added to that group.

45
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:13.560
So, that's a good point.

46
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:16.180
So shared mailboxes is
next on the left here.

47
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:18.700
And the purpose of shared mailboxes.

48
00:02:18.700 --> 00:02:20.020
It's good for support.

49
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:23.560
Help desk kind of scenarios where maybe
you've got three shifts in a twenty-four

50
00:02:23.560 --> 00:02:24.520
hour period.

51
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:27.480
It doesn't matter who answers
the support reques just anyone.

52
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:31.870
So multiple people could have access to
the shared mailbox, either online here or

53
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:38.810
through their email client, and
handle the help desk request for example.

54
00:02:38.810 --> 00:02:42.560
Let's go to resources now, I gonna close
up the groups just to make the screen

55
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:46.020
little less cluttered and
rooms and equipments.

56
00:02:46.020 --> 00:02:48.840
So this might be familiar if
you were working with Exchange

57
00:02:48.840 --> 00:02:51.280
at all
>> The ability to

58
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:52.760
reserve rooms and equipment.

59
00:02:54.870 --> 00:02:58.320
I guess I haven't authenticated for
a while, so I have to reauthenticate.

60
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:04.020
Meanwhile, there's a traffic scene
in the background, how relaxing.

61
00:03:04.020 --> 00:03:07.065
[LAUGH] It wasn't totally crowded,
that's good.

62
00:03:07.065 --> 00:03:09.675
>> That was my password,
dot dot dot dot dot dot dot.

63
00:03:09.675 --> 00:03:11.197
>> Amazing!
I have to change it now.

64
00:03:11.197 --> 00:03:15.845
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Delirium is setting in.

65
00:03:17.095 --> 00:03:19.995
All right, so now I've authenticated
it back to where I was trying to get

66
00:03:19.995 --> 00:03:23.680
originally, and
I can click on Add Room, and

67
00:03:23.680 --> 00:03:27.750
then specify so a concept that might
be tricky to get your head around,

68
00:03:27.750 --> 00:03:30.779
if you're not normally
exchanging in background.

69
00:03:30.779 --> 00:03:32.562
Is that you can literally email a room.

70
00:03:32.562 --> 00:03:33.340
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

71
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:35.560
>> As a resource to reserve it,
or any assets.

72
00:03:35.560 --> 00:03:38.410
So maybe there's a funky vehicle
you need that there's only

73
00:03:38.410 --> 00:03:40.030
one of in the organization.

74
00:03:40.030 --> 00:03:45.940
You could also reserve that asset and
schedule it in

75
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:50.790
to a calendar application as well, similar
to with equipment here, projector is on.

76
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:53.710
Maybe a projector that can move
between rooms on a mobile cart,

77
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:55.280
they may wanna reserve that.

78
00:03:55.280 --> 00:03:58.659
So that's useful, and let's go to sites.

79
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:04.290
It's just gonna give an enumeration
of sites, very useful sometimes,

80
00:04:04.290 --> 00:04:08.160
if you forget the URL of where you're
trying to go, maybe you have it favorited,

81
00:04:08.160 --> 00:04:08.720
maybe not.

82
00:04:08.720 --> 00:04:12.180
Maybe you closed out the browser
tab accidentally and

83
00:04:12.180 --> 00:04:14.740
you can't remember exactly where
you were to get back to the URL.

84
00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:18.990
Well this way you get a listing of sites
here, and they're linkable as you'd expect

85
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:22.640
so I can just click on them, and
it also shows the sharing status.

86
00:04:22.640 --> 00:04:27.480
So, whether links are shared,
whether I can invite someone to

87
00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:33.270
participate in that site, or not, that's
useful, public website, this is cool.

88
00:04:33.270 --> 00:04:38.060
So, in this course, we've looked
at how useful SharePoint can be,

89
00:04:38.060 --> 00:04:42.230
in terms of being an Intranet portal,
also an Extranet portal, and

90
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:43.510
an Intranet portal-
>> Mm-hm.

91
00:04:43.510 --> 00:04:47.760
>> For different user populations
>> Employees, partners through Extranet,

92
00:04:47.760 --> 00:04:51.670
and maybe customers anonymously
accessing an Internet portal.

93
00:04:51.670 --> 00:04:56.490
Well, in this case, with Office 365,
we're using third party providers.

94
00:04:56.490 --> 00:05:01.960
And the providers that show up
on this screen relate to your

95
00:05:01.960 --> 00:05:05.410
original country that you entered when
you signed up for your own 365 account.

96
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:08.420
So, in other words, I sign up in the US.

97
00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:13.190
I think it was US, whatever it was,
it might have been Canada, William Canada.

98
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:18.110
Anyways, GoDaddy and Wix are the partner
organizations to create public sites and

99
00:05:18.110 --> 00:05:19.320
they're all kosher.

100
00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:23.200
They're experienced with setting people
up with O365 with integration for

101
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:29.090
the public facing site, so then you
can learn more by following links for

102
00:05:29.090 --> 00:05:31.399
those third party vendors.

103
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:35.990
Okay, I'll go back to where I was.

104
00:05:35.990 --> 00:05:37.840
So that's public website
mobile management.

105
00:05:37.840 --> 00:05:39.010
This is kind of neat because

106
00:05:40.140 --> 00:05:42.130
again organizations that
have moving to the cloud, so

107
00:05:42.130 --> 00:05:45.750
you might have been using System Center
Configuration manager on premises.

108
00:05:45.750 --> 00:05:51.410
For inventory,
deploying software and updates, and

109
00:05:51.410 --> 00:05:56.790
establishing security settings and
restrictions on company owned devices.

110
00:05:56.790 --> 00:06:01.840
Even the BYOD kind of environment where
the user brings their own device, but

111
00:06:01.840 --> 00:06:04.230
it's also used for business reasons.

112
00:06:04.230 --> 00:06:09.150
So we can, with Windows Intune,
we can in mobile device management,

113
00:06:09.150 --> 00:06:13.470
we can have control over those
devices from an internet portal here.

114
00:06:13.470 --> 00:06:17.690
So control in mobile access, the ability
to apply restrictions for example,

115
00:06:17.690 --> 00:06:22.360
require a pin or password when
the user Starts up their machine,

116
00:06:22.360 --> 00:06:25.120
the ability to block Bluetooth or
maybe wi-fi connections, so

117
00:06:25.120 --> 00:06:29.300
you get some kinda control
from the MDM Portal here.

118
00:06:29.300 --> 00:06:30.760
And then let's say an employee leaves,

119
00:06:30.760 --> 00:06:33.210
you want the ability to
wipe only corporate data.

120
00:06:33.210 --> 00:06:36.750
So I'm bringing my tablet for example,
to work for a three month contract,

121
00:06:36.750 --> 00:06:40.860
the contract ends and then the
organization can wipe just the corporate

122
00:06:40.860 --> 00:06:44.340
data and applications from my device,
not touching all my personal apps and

123
00:06:44.340 --> 00:06:48.820
data I brought into the organization
Before working for it.

124
00:06:48.820 --> 00:06:53.100
So the point is you can do this
remotely with mobile device management.

125
00:06:54.360 --> 00:06:54.980
Kind of cool.

126
00:06:56.360 --> 00:06:58.200
Now where was I?

127
00:06:58.200 --> 00:07:00.210
Key question I ask myself.

128
00:07:00.210 --> 00:07:03.710
So that's it for resources there,
now let's go down to Billing.

129
00:07:03.710 --> 00:07:06.850
So, here's where I can find out
my subscriptions as we look at

130
00:07:06.850 --> 00:07:10.410
in the different episode, there
are all kinds of subscription options.

131
00:07:10.410 --> 00:07:15.280
It's nice to get a handle
on what's active for me and

132
00:07:15.280 --> 00:07:19.410
the ability to also add subscriptions here
in the upper right by clicking on that

133
00:07:19.410 --> 00:07:22.910
button, and then let down the lower
left I can assign licenses.

134
00:07:22.910 --> 00:07:25.650
Remember, I'd only assign
one of a possible 25.

135
00:07:25.650 --> 00:07:30.430
So, here's where I can Move forward
with getting other people involved in

136
00:07:30.430 --> 00:07:36.370
the enterprise E3 trial,
more actions button down here.

137
00:07:36.370 --> 00:07:41.040
I can cancel the trial,
let's say I'm going a different direction,

138
00:07:41.040 --> 00:07:44.500
in that case I can choose
to Click on cancel trial,

139
00:07:44.500 --> 00:07:48.200
because maybe I'm actually able to go
ahead but I don't want to use the E3 plan.

140
00:07:48.200 --> 00:07:49.350
I want to use a different plan.

141
00:07:49.350 --> 00:07:51.848
So I'll cancel this trial and
try this plan.

142
00:07:51.848 --> 00:07:55.827
There's also ways of transitioning
between license types,

143
00:07:55.827 --> 00:08:00.186
different ways to go there, and
then there's a build section, and

144
00:08:00.186 --> 00:08:05.231
you can filter by say, a monthly A monthly
filter and the month of the year, and

145
00:08:05.231 --> 00:08:10.460
there's, like many things in the O365
interface, there's often a delay.

146
00:08:10.460 --> 00:08:14.380
In this case there's a 24 hour
delay between purchase and

147
00:08:14.380 --> 00:08:15.660
what you purchase showing up here.

148
00:08:16.930 --> 00:08:19.420
And then there's a Licences tab.

149
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:24.440
Here's my Office 365
Enterprise E3 license.

150
00:08:24.440 --> 00:08:28.760
If I click on purchase services, of course
Microsoft wants to make it easy for

386
00:21:30.960 --> 00:21:33.890
And then various tools, this is useful.

387
00:21:33.890 --> 00:21:37.860
We've got a Skype for
Business Connectivity Analyzer tool.

388
00:21:37.860 --> 00:21:40.850
This is really useful because there's so
many moving parts with online meetings.

389
00:21:40.850 --> 00:21:47.180
So many variables in terms of devices,
timezones, quality of signal,

390
00:21:47.180 --> 00:21:50.520
giving control to presenters, there's all
kinds of variables, so it's nice to have

391
00:21:50.520 --> 00:21:55.530
an Analyzer Tool which will take care of
the most common problems you may have and

392
00:21:55.530 --> 00:21:58.780
give prescriptive guidance, or
automatically take corrective action.

393
00:21:58.780 --> 00:22:00.910
There's also
Remote Connectivity Analyzing here.

394
00:22:00.910 --> 00:22:05.229
This is testing the connection
to Microsoft's O365 DNS servers.

395
00:22:06.520 --> 00:22:11.060
And also link for setting up Skype for
Business Online external communications.

396
00:22:12.110 --> 00:22:16.747
So this is for communicating via Skype
with users outside the organization that

397
00:22:16.747 --> 00:22:18.626
maybe involved in the meeting.

398
00:22:18.626 --> 00:22:23.544
There's a call quality dashboard as well,
so you can be aware of call quality

399
00:22:23.544 --> 00:22:27.150
issues before people start
IMing you during meetings.

400
00:22:27.150 --> 00:22:30.540
I can't hear you or the quality
is bad It's best to be proactive.

401
00:22:30.540 --> 00:22:35.180
So we've seen a lot of service
health dashboards in O365 so far and

402
00:22:35.180 --> 00:22:36.701
it would give reason.

403
00:22:38.717 --> 00:22:39.709
>> All right, Mark.

404
00:22:39.709 --> 00:22:44.381
Fantastic, again we're just
continuing a look on that Office 365,

405
00:22:44.381 --> 00:22:49.436
administration interface, and as well as
taking a look at some of the Skype for

406
00:22:49.436 --> 00:22:52.285
Business Integration with Office 365.

407
00:22:52.285 --> 00:22:54.975
So we thank you for that,
Mark, appreciate it.

408
00:22:54.975 --> 00:22:56.665
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

409
00:22:56.665 --> 00:22:59.205
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

410
00:22:59.205 --> 00:22:59.965
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

411
00:22:59.965 --> 00:23:02.335
>> And we'll see you next time.

412
00:23:02.335 --> 00:23:07.686
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: SharePoint Online Adminstration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.127 --> 00:00:12.681
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.890 --> 00:00:20.467
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing Advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.467 --> 00:00:24.572
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at the SharePoint Online

5
00:00:24.572 --> 00:00:25.650
interface, right?

6
00:00:25.650 --> 00:00:29.050
We've already spent some time dealing
with SharePoint On-Premises and

7
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:30.649
some other online technologies.

8
00:00:30.649 --> 00:00:33.565
Now we want to see what we can do with
the SharePoint Online administration

9
00:00:33.565 --> 00:00:34.540
interface.

10
00:00:34.540 --> 00:00:36.960
And here to guide us through that is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

11
00:00:36.960 --> 00:00:37.820
How you doing Mark?

12
00:00:37.820 --> 00:00:39.450
>> Good Mike, thanks very much.

13
00:00:39.450 --> 00:00:41.000
Yeah, let's continue on.

14
00:00:41.000 --> 00:00:45.432
So we've talked about Office 365
interfaces relating to Exchange,

15
00:00:45.432 --> 00:00:51.064
security and compliance, even Azure AD,
so no technology is an island.

16
00:00:51.064 --> 00:00:55.152
So even if you were charged solely
with SharePoint administration and

17
00:00:55.152 --> 00:00:59.723
were involved with no other technologies
you'd still need to know those other

18
00:00:59.723 --> 00:01:00.708
technologies.

19
00:01:00.708 --> 00:01:04.693
Because SharePoint interfaces so many ways
with different other, both Microsoft and

20
00:01:04.693 --> 00:01:06.232
non-Microsoft technologies.

21
00:01:06.232 --> 00:01:09.697
So now we've looked at those other
options there under admin centers,

22
00:01:09.697 --> 00:01:12.653
now we're gonna go and
open up the SharePoint admin center.

23
00:01:12.653 --> 00:01:16.652
And you'll see right away the differences,
and I'll talk about them and show you,

24
00:01:16.652 --> 00:01:18.682
between the SharePoint Online version and

25
00:01:18.682 --> 00:01:21.910
the On-Premises version which
we've been using up to this point.

26
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:30.007
So click on that link, and
we get to the SharePoint admin center.

27
00:01:30.007 --> 00:01:31.189
>> Mm-hm.

28
00:01:31.189 --> 00:01:37.205
>> So you can see right away that the
ribbon is minimalist compared to On-Prem.

29
00:01:37.205 --> 00:01:39.904
Now if you recall our
architecture conversation,

30
00:01:39.904 --> 00:01:42.106
might wanna go back and have a look-see.

31
00:01:42.106 --> 00:01:45.960
The different architectural
arrangements with SharePoint

32
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:50.590
from all on-prem to hosted in Azure
to hybrid, SharePoint Online.

33
00:01:50.590 --> 00:01:53.928
So SharePoint Online has
the least that we do and

34
00:01:53.928 --> 00:01:58.360
the most that Microsoft does in
terms of managing the back end.

35
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:02.286
So our options are limited because the lot
of the options that we'd see on-prem

36
00:02:02.286 --> 00:02:06.720
are automatically taken care of for us, in
fact that we have no control over those.

37
00:02:06.720 --> 00:02:10.434
We can certainly do things like buy more
storage, which is one of the options here,

38
00:02:10.434 --> 00:02:14.380
but from a DBA perspective, there's a lot
less to do, Microsoft handles that.

39
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:18.990
So right now I've got a few
site URLs listed here.

40
00:02:18.990 --> 00:02:25.770
That New reference beside each of the four
URLs listed will go away after a few days.

41
00:02:25.770 --> 00:02:29.820
And this is very useful because
in cloud you're paying for

42
00:02:29.820 --> 00:02:34.220
what you use so it's good to know
how many gigabytes you've used.

43
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:37.290
At this point I used a grand total of 0.

44
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:42.330
Server Resource Quota,
that is affected by things like CPU cycle,

45
00:02:42.330 --> 00:02:45.040
storage space, RAM, throughput.

46
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:47.239
It's one of those secret sauce

47
00:02:48.520 --> 00:02:52.670
measurements that comes up with
a nice number that you can see.

48
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:56.470
And then we also have
version information there.

49
00:02:56.470 --> 00:03:00.270
Okay so
let's create a new site collection.

50
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:04.690
Because why not,
a new private site collection.

51
00:03:04.690 --> 00:03:13.711
And give it a title,
let's call this one, After lunch.

52
00:03:13.711 --> 00:03:14.235
>> Hm.

53
00:03:17.004 --> 00:03:18.700
>> A funky new club.

54
00:03:18.700 --> 00:03:20.350
And now, so remember,

55
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:24.610
there's always gonna be differences
between online and on-prem, almost always.

56
00:03:24.610 --> 00:03:28.250
Here's an example of that,
we don't have the exact same number of

57
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:32.140
template options in the Collaboration
tab or the Enterprise tab.

58
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:37.280
One of the reasons is here we have a Team
Site SharePoint Online configuration.

59
00:03:37.280 --> 00:03:38.960
So there's a difference there.

60
00:03:38.960 --> 00:03:40.140
We're not gonna cover all of these.

61
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:43.200
I'm just showing you that there's
a different number of template

62
00:03:43.200 --> 00:03:44.900
options in some of these tabs.

63
00:03:44.900 --> 00:03:49.560
Let's keep it simple and
stick with the team site.

64
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:51.420
I know, it's very vanilla.

65
00:03:51.420 --> 00:03:58.000
And then, actually,
let's see if my admin account works.

66
00:03:58.000 --> 00:03:59.435
I may not have an admin account.

67
00:03:59.435 --> 00:04:01.220
[LAUGH] Better use me.

68
00:04:03.305 --> 00:04:07.465
My mind was in on-prem but
now we're in the online world.

69
00:04:07.465 --> 00:04:09.405
Okay, that resolved to me and

70
00:04:09.405 --> 00:04:14.405
now again, you don't have to know
exactly the makeup of these resources.

71
00:04:14.405 --> 00:04:17.065
So 5600 resources available,
what the heck does that mean?

72
00:04:18.180 --> 00:04:21.320
It's a combination of secret
sauce of resource usage.

73
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:25.820
The point is now we're establishing
300 out of the 5600 as a maximum for

74
00:04:25.820 --> 00:04:27.680
this new site collection
we're establishing.

75
00:04:27.680 --> 00:04:31.350
I can change that to 200 if I want,
if I'm feeling stingy or

76
00:04:31.350 --> 00:04:32.960
I need to create a lot
more site collections.

77
00:04:32.960 --> 00:04:36.660
So I change that, hit OK,
and you can see there,

78
00:04:36.660 --> 00:04:40.660
so you have to be a little more
patient than with on-prem.

79
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:43.470
Because up in the right here,
your site collections being created,

80
00:04:43.470 --> 00:04:44.910
it may take 15 minutes.

81
00:04:44.910 --> 00:04:49.710
So it may show up here and
be available, and it may not.

82
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:53.860
Notice how right now it's in black,
not hyperlinkable.

83
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:55.990
So we'll let that do it's thing and

84
00:04:55.990 --> 00:04:57.870
then eventually have a little
new icon next to it.

85
00:04:57.870 --> 00:05:03.240
Now I'll select a URL that does exist,
notice I have to select the check box or

86
00:05:03.240 --> 00:05:08.360
the line it's on, just like we would
in the on-prem version of SharePoint,

87
00:05:08.360 --> 00:05:13.450
to then expose the site collection
specific buttons on the ribbon.

88
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:20.207
Things like Owners, Sharing,
Server Resource Quota here.

89
00:05:20.207 --> 00:05:24.470
So this one had the default
of 300 resource units.

90
00:05:24.470 --> 00:05:28.567
Just like quotas in SharePoint or
for file storage on-prem,

91
00:05:28.567 --> 00:05:32.677
we can have an email sent to
the admin at x% of resource usage.

92
00:05:32.677 --> 00:05:36.095
So you're not suddenly finding one day,
I cannot upload this file and

93
00:05:36.095 --> 00:05:39.210
you find out it's because
you've exceeded your quota.

94
00:05:39.210 --> 00:05:42.190
And then you have to either upload
the file somewhere else or delete files,

95
00:05:42.190 --> 00:05:44.160
it's gonna slow down your work flow.

96
00:05:44.160 --> 00:05:48.310
This way, by getting an email, and
you can vary this number, 85%'s good.

97
00:05:48.310 --> 00:05:51.904
You'll have advanced notice that
your usage is increasing and

98
00:05:51.904 --> 00:05:56.604
you'll have to take action soon, buying
more storage, deleting some content.

99
00:05:56.604 --> 00:06:00.501
Or else the site will become
less than operational,

100
00:06:00.501 --> 00:06:04.600
shall we say,
when you hit 100% of the quota.

101
00:06:04.600 --> 00:06:07.909
So I'll cancel out of there,
I don't want to change the resource quota.

102
00:06:07.909 --> 00:06:12.920
Okay, Site collection upgrade settings,
let's check this out.

103
00:06:14.180 --> 00:06:18.985
And right now we've got
the 2013 experience version.

104
00:06:18.985 --> 00:06:22.670
And you see here it says, Site collection
already at the most current version,

105
00:06:22.670 --> 00:06:24.390
you do not need to upgrade it.

106
00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:26.210
Now you might say, what the heck?

107
00:06:26.210 --> 00:06:31.350
This is a SharePoint 2016 admin course,
you're showing me 2013 content.

108
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:34.320
I don't code the product,
that's the way it is right now.

109
00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:39.750
I also said something that all the dev
money goes into online improvements.

110
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:43.151
Well, this is an example, it seems to
be lagging behind the on-prem version.

111
00:06:43.151 --> 00:06:46.265
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, it is what it is.

112
00:06:46.265 --> 00:06:47.603
I can't believe I said that, but I did.

113
00:06:47.603 --> 00:06:49.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> The only time this week.

114
00:06:49.950 --> 00:06:53.432
And upgrade notifications, okay,

115
00:06:53.432 --> 00:06:59.030
now let's say the 2016 experience

116
00:06:59.030 --> 00:07:02.550
version comes out and then I'm not using
the most current version at that point.

117
00:07:02.550 --> 00:07:05.873
So this red ink here won’t
appear anymore because I'll have

118
00:07:05.873 --> 00:07:11.360
the opportunity to upgrade, if and when
I want to, from 2013 to 2016 for online.

119
00:07:11.360 --> 00:07:14.780
Well, that point I can send an email
to site collection administrators so

120
00:07:14.780 --> 00:07:17.550
they can choose on their
own schedule whether or

121
00:07:17.550 --> 00:07:19.655
not to upgrade their sites
to the 2016 version.

122
00:07:19.655 --> 00:07:24.420
So you have some flexibility, it's not
a command in control, one size fits all.

123
00:07:24.420 --> 00:07:28.410
Site collection admins have
the responsibility to choose whether or

124
00:07:28.410 --> 00:07:32.870
not to upgrade to the latest
version at that time.

125
00:07:32.870 --> 00:07:35.740
All right, recycle bin there,
and that's good for

126
00:07:35.740 --> 00:07:39.970
site collection, let's go to infopath now.

127
00:07:39.970 --> 00:07:47.110
Okay so, do you want to allow users
to browse or enable form templates?

128
00:07:47.110 --> 00:07:51.706
You could have exempt user agents,
so they're getting

129
00:07:51.706 --> 00:07:56.411
infopath forms as XML,
if they need to edit for example.

130
00:07:56.411 --> 00:07:59.818
This is kinda cool, Googlebot, Slurp.

131
00:07:59.818 --> 00:08:03.620
So if you use the info path, you'll be
probably familiar with some of those.

132
00:08:03.620 --> 00:08:05.243
Let's all say there.

133
00:08:05.243 --> 00:08:06.950
And User Profiles.

134
00:08:08.770 --> 00:08:11.489
This should start to look familiar
with your on-prem experience.

135
00:08:11.489 --> 00:08:12.690
>> Mm-hm.
>> Of SharePoint.

136
00:08:12.690 --> 00:08:15.150
So things like managing user properties.

137
00:08:15.150 --> 00:08:21.210
Over here on the right we've got five user
profiles listed with 110 user properties.

138
00:08:21.210 --> 00:08:25.760
One organization profile,
and a single audience.

139
00:08:25.760 --> 00:08:28.980
Here's where we can click
to set up my sites.

140
00:08:28.980 --> 00:08:31.240
How do you do that?

141
00:08:32.730 --> 00:08:34.910
Throwing caution To the winds.

142
00:08:34.910 --> 00:08:35.870
>> Let's do it.

143
00:08:35.870 --> 00:08:36.890
>> Let's do this.

144
00:08:36.890 --> 00:08:37.880
Okay, so.

145
00:08:37.880 --> 00:08:40.650
Search scope for finding people,
it could be all sites,

146
00:08:40.650 --> 00:08:42.320
it makes sense to leave it at people.

147
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:44.810
For documents, though,
we want the scope of all sites,

148
00:08:44.810 --> 00:08:49.340
not just a restricted subset as a search
scope, so we'll leave that there.

149
00:08:50.740 --> 00:08:55.570
And okay, so site naming, it depends
if you have a multi domain environment.

150
00:08:55.570 --> 00:08:59.670
If we do there could be a problem
because there could be a John Smith

151
00:08:59.670 --> 00:09:02.790
in Domain A and a John Smith in Domain B.

152
00:09:02.790 --> 00:09:06.070
And we need a way to resolve them, so

153
00:09:06.070 --> 00:09:10.110
the best way to do that would be
the third option, domain and username.

154
00:09:10.110 --> 00:09:14.390
In other words,
there's no possibility of a conflict,

155
00:09:14.390 --> 00:09:18.610
even if two people have the same name,
but in different domains.

156
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:22.110
Okay, then read permission level here.

157
00:09:23.150 --> 00:09:28.050
It's a somewhat unusual permission if used
on a parameter that is, everyone except

158
00:09:28.050 --> 00:09:32.620
external users as a read permission level.

159
00:09:32.620 --> 00:09:36.300
News feeds that can enable activities so

160
00:09:36.300 --> 00:09:42.405
that means I'll get information
about New events from people.

161
00:09:42.405 --> 00:09:44.225
Also from content I follow.

162
00:09:44.225 --> 00:09:45.865
We'll look at following a little later.

163
00:09:45.865 --> 00:09:51.155
We're going to get into more end user
perspective of SharePoint online and

164
00:09:51.155 --> 00:09:52.242
some apps we could use.

165
00:09:52.242 --> 00:09:57.332
Use as users, and then email notification.

166
00:09:59.452 --> 00:10:02.022
So you may want,
let's say you're following at,

167
00:10:02.022 --> 00:10:05.682
you're at a community say and you're
part of a conversation or discussion.

168
00:10:05.682 --> 00:10:08.962
You may want to get emailed when
there's a new piece of input.

169
00:10:08.962 --> 00:10:13.482
So for me, for example, Microsoft News
Group, I might be interested in a topic,

170
00:10:13.482 --> 00:10:18.030
completely forget about it, and then
two months later Someone posts a reply,

171
00:10:18.030 --> 00:10:20.210
maybe someone answers
a question that was asked,

172
00:10:20.210 --> 00:10:23.810
maybe they weren't allowed to answer
before and now there's new information.

173
00:10:23.810 --> 00:10:28.530
I totally forgot about the discussion, but
by subscribing to email notifications,

174
00:10:28.530 --> 00:10:31.090
it reminds me instantly yeah
I was interested in that and

175
00:10:31.090 --> 00:10:32.900
now there's an answer,
cool I'll check that out.

176
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:35.818
So we can enable email notifications.

177
00:10:35.818 --> 00:10:37.574
Site cleanup.

178
00:10:40.028 --> 00:10:43.734
When a user profile is deleted,
we have a 30-day period,

179
00:10:43.734 --> 00:10:48.096
during which we can access that content,
and often when someone leaves

180
00:10:48.096 --> 00:10:52.600
an organization there's a need for
the new person replacing that.

181
00:10:52.600 --> 00:10:56.630
Person that left to access some of
the content that the old employee had.

182
00:10:56.630 --> 00:11:01.530
So this way, it's sort of in limbo
until it's permanently deleted 30 days

183
00:11:01.530 --> 00:11:03.980
later after the My Site
is initially deleted.

184
00:11:05.380 --> 00:11:10.790
We can specify a secondary admin for
My Site, that might seem a little unusual.

185
00:11:10.790 --> 00:11:13.390
I think you can understand
the rationale for secondary admin for

186
00:11:13.390 --> 00:11:15.180
a regular team site, for example.

187
00:11:15.180 --> 00:11:18.770
The primary site collection
administrator's away, extended leave, then

188
00:11:18.770 --> 00:11:24.420
important emails can get answered by the
secondary site collection administration.

189
00:11:24.420 --> 00:11:29.170
Things like requests for access,
or potential deletion email.

190
00:11:29.170 --> 00:11:30.680
It's been six months.

191
00:11:30.680 --> 00:11:36.490
senses any activity, should we delete
this site or do we need to retain it?

192
00:11:36.490 --> 00:11:40.870
It kind of weird thinking, it's almost
like notify incase of emergency when you

193
00:11:40.870 --> 00:11:46.140
are traveling, so incase you are out of
commission someone else can respond on

194
00:11:46.140 --> 00:11:51.780
your behalf, even though it's your mysites
site collection we are talking about

195
00:11:51.780 --> 00:11:56.320
privacy settings,
should my sites be public or not?

196
00:11:56.320 --> 00:12:00.330
The default is yes,
actually default is private,

197
00:12:00.330 --> 00:12:01.990
right now it says make mysites public.

198
00:12:04.070 --> 00:12:12.550
Okay, so again you can allow users
to override settings or not.

199
00:12:12.550 --> 00:12:16.850
Things like activities,
workspace anniversaries, social tagging,

200
00:12:16.850 --> 00:12:19.100
content ratings And the like.

201
00:12:20.280 --> 00:12:21.037
Okay so I'll hit OK.

202
00:12:30.806 --> 00:12:32.330
And that's good for now.

203

So Publish Links to

What this means is,
let's say I'm going to save as.

So that it's very easy for the user in the

SharePoint library to save
that content to, as opposed to

00:13:06.030 --> 00:13:10.600

and start typing it in hassle, hassle.

212
00:13:10.600 --> 00:13:11.820
We wanna make it easier for users,

213

we can pre-populate the save as dialogue
box with links to document libraries.

214
00:13:17.550 --> 00:13:20.969
Very handy.
You wanna be nice to your users.

215
00:13:22.210 --> 00:13:23.280
All right.
>> Most of the time.

216
00:13:23.280 --> 00:13:23.880
>> Most of the time.

That's right.

So records management, a record is

00:14:49.505 --> 00:14:51.730
deleted are moved.

So once we set up our records center and

SharePoint administration course,

Now classifying the records is

That's what I call librarian skills.

00:15:42.150 --> 00:15:44.739
That would have to be set up in advance so
that,

00:15:45.760 --> 00:15:49.600
just like if you're sending a piece of

256
00:15:49.600 --> 00:15:52.350
I mean you trust that it's gonna get
delivered based on whatever systems and

257
00:15:52.350 --> 00:15:56.616
classifications that the organization
exists, the US Postal Service.

258
00:15:56.616 --> 00:15:57.691
Insert joke here.

>> [LAUGH]
>> But anyway, so

Now, the search option down here,

So again,

So some brand names,

00:16:40.360 --> 00:16:44.430
So maybe an old name for a product,

00:16:44.430 --> 00:16:45.760
you want to make those synonymous.

00:16:45.760 --> 00:16:51.320
So a search for either term will

272
00:16:51.320 --> 00:16:55.040
Authoritative pages so
again that first the basic SharePoint

admin course we discussed

Secure store service we discussed another

And we'll cover that in different episode.

Can you please make a note of that?

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't wanna have to try and

All right, now this is very

Do you want to share content with

00:17:43.660 --> 00:17:46.340
You could say no, do not share content.

290
00:17:46.340 --> 00:17:51.630
You could say, if the contact exist

00:17:51.630 --> 00:17:55.410
then they are for a reason, because
there's a supplier or a client Partner,

00:17:55.410 --> 00:17:58.140
consultant, what have you,
you can share with them but

00:17:58.140 --> 00:18:02.360
they have to have information

294
00:18:02.360 --> 00:18:07.130
Another option is to give users
the responsibility and choice as to who

295
00:18:07.130 --> 00:18:12.060
to invite to participate, and
share a document with, so that's

296
00:18:12.060 --> 00:18:16.530
another option allow users to invite and

00:18:17.550 --> 00:18:23.590
And then the last option here is allow

00:18:23.590 --> 00:18:27.170

so that means anyone

00:18:27.170 --> 00:18:30.320

00:18:30.320 --> 00:18:35.230
So, product catalog to the general public,
okay internal

00:18:36.310 --> 00:18:39.472
excel spreadsheet about margins and

00:18:39.472 --> 00:18:44.834
not okay.

00:18:44.834 --> 00:18:51.440
Now the warning here at the bottom under

00:18:51.440 --> 00:18:57.520
anonymous links keep that in mind that
users don't have to authenticate.

00:18:59.780 --> 00:19:04.170
Additional settings here, external users
must accept sharing invitations using

00:19:04.170 --> 00:19:06.390

00:19:06.390 --> 00:19:09.880
Sometimes I have an issue

00:19:09.880 --> 00:19:14.860
because they want me to sign in with

00:19:14.860 --> 00:19:19.480
to my business account, and it just

00:19:19.480 --> 00:19:22.750
So this is a way of restricting, or
making sure you're getting the invitation

00:19:22.750 --> 00:19:25.970
to share in some content or
to view some shared content,

312
00:19:25.970 --> 00:19:29.850
make sure the right person gets it

00:19:29.850 --> 00:19:32.790
So it's not just the person but
it's the person

00:19:32.790 --> 00:19:37.450
at the specific email account

315
00:19:41.030 --> 00:19:44.220
Okay, so OneDrive for Business.

00:19:47.150 --> 00:19:51.920
SharePoint online, do we want to

Sure we do.

Storage management.

We can allow for

The OneDrive for Business experience,

>> [LAUGH]
>> Classic experience,

it's sounds, wow, retro.

00:20:16.055 --> 00:20:18.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like a 66 Mustang Convertible, but no,

it just means the old one.

[LAUGH]

which is more streamlined
a little more user-friendly.

OneDrive sync button.

Do you want to show that or now.

Keep in mind if you're exposing

So, you can always come back later and

00:20:42.790 --> 00:20:45.640
Or as an organization you're still trying

00:20:46.880 --> 00:20:51.210
Okay, now SharePoint lists and

00:20:51.210 --> 00:20:55.630
again optimized for

00:21:01.080 --> 00:21:07.090
Now Office Graph Is very cool,

If you use Facebook graphs,

It creates connections with

344
00:21:21.030 --> 00:21:23.530
So, if you are looking for Fred Smith.

00:21:23.530 --> 00:21:27.530
Who's 35 years old and

00:21:27.530 --> 00:21:29.360
You can get that specific

347

So, off this graph,
the default is to allow access to it.

348
00:21:34.370 --> 00:21:37.200
And the more you use Share Point,
the more useful graph becomes.

349
00:21:37.200 --> 00:21:42.600
Because it uses your contacts, the people
you interact with and chat, or socially In

00:21:42.600 --> 00:21:48.140
the SharePoint context, documents you
create or co-author, documents you follow,

00:21:48.140 --> 00:21:52.290
all that information becomes just for
the mill if you like, so you're

00:21:52.290 --> 00:21:55.420
better able to serve up content that

00:21:55.420 --> 00:21:58.200
That's one of the applications

00:21:58.200 --> 00:22:00.440
More on that when we talk about Delve.

Enterprise Social Collaboration,

00:22:35.560 --> 00:22:37.770
Okay, so
global experience version settings,

00:22:37.770 --> 00:22:41.010

00:22:41.010 --> 00:22:44.690
That you've tested to work with an old

version, so lets say you are using 2010,

00:22:49.980 --> 00:22:54.310
then your son uses a 2010 sci collections,

00:22:54.310 --> 00:22:57.412
Do you want to prevent, at a certain time,

00:22:57.412 --> 00:23:02.251
old versions of SharePoint site
collections from being created?

00:23:05.482 --> 00:23:06.944
So, you have that option there.

00:23:08.981 --> 00:23:13.640
You could say, allow both the creation of

00:23:13.640 --> 00:23:17.920

Again, this is very much depending on any

to test, and verify in

00:23:25.620 --> 00:23:30.070
So just like the customizations

00:23:30.070 --> 00:23:34.540
So that will be reason to remain on
older versions of a site collection for

377
00:23:34.540 --> 00:23:35.920
many years potentially.

378
00:23:35.920 --> 00:23:39.270
So don't upgrade just because
the latest and greatest exists.

379
00:23:39.270 --> 00:23:44.790
Some organizations do every second upgrade
if you will from 2010 they move to 2016.

380
00:23:44.790 --> 00:23:49.080
Not directly, but
they have to go through 2013 intermediate.

381
00:23:49.080 --> 00:23:52.640
But they might skip the whole process
which might take a year or more and

382
00:23:52.640 --> 00:23:58.390
just upgrade every other version,
information rights management.

383
00:23:58.390 --> 00:24:01.420
You need Office 365 IRM service for this.

384
00:24:03.000 --> 00:24:09.200
That's a choice we talked about IRM

00:24:09.200 --> 00:24:13.600
So you can specify,
give users a link, show you,

And then you can require a site

388
00:24:27.311 --> 00:24:28.290
Okay.

389
00:24:31.459 --> 00:24:34.760
And you also have the ability
to block workflows.

390
00:24:38.300 --> 00:24:41.030
And whether or not to allow access apps.

391
00:24:41.030 --> 00:24:44.840
So if you're using Access and

then you would leave that at
the default which is enabled.

393
00:24:48.670 --> 00:24:52.590
I don't think I changed anything there,

Hybrid is a whole nother ball of wax,

00:24:59.543 --> 00:25:04.134
Okay, so, there's a couple considerations

396

also hybrid One Drive and sites features.

That's a separate architectural design

Hybrid was another one.

[INAUDIBLE] is another design,
and then finally Azure.

00:25:18.505 --> 00:25:22.930
[INAUDIBLE] host your

401
00:25:24.110 --> 00:25:28.060
Alright Mark, thanks for that tour of the
sharepoint online administrative center,

402
00:25:28.060 --> 00:25:30.760
and a look at some of the different
features we have available,

403
00:25:30.760 --> 00:25:34.070
some of the things we can do, as well

404

use that sharepoint online admin center.

00:25:37.930 --> 00:25:39.080
So, we thank you for that.

Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching,

00:14:40.880 --> 00:14:43.324
So there's Indian food with a soccer ball.

259
00:14:43.324 --> 00:14:47.487
I know it makes no sense,
but there it is, so

260
00:14:47.487 --> 00:14:52.230
a little emoji action
in your O365 interface.

261
00:14:52.230 --> 00:14:53.620
Now, Delve.

262
00:14:53.620 --> 00:14:57.633
In referencing this,
this leverages Office Graph technology.

263
00:14:57.633 --> 00:15:01.854
And I could click on Learn More, and

264
00:15:01.854 --> 00:15:07.950
it gets me to a nice link
on support.office.com.

265
00:15:07.950 --> 00:15:13.040
And often people say, especially if you're
new, it's just spun up this SharePoint

266
00:15:13.040 --> 00:15:16.040
online environment, so there's not gonna
be a lot of content there right away.

267
00:15:17.210 --> 00:15:21.102
So for people that are curious to
see what Delve can do for them,

268
00:15:21.102 --> 00:15:25.877
here's some recommendations is to create
a folder structure in OneDrive and

269
00:15:25.877 --> 00:15:27.871
start up loading some content.

270
00:15:27.871 --> 00:15:32.149
Also, storing and
sharing documents in SharePoint Online or

271
00:15:32.149 --> 00:15:37.340
Office 365 Is a way to start taking
advantage of what Delve has to offer.

272
00:15:38.790 --> 00:15:43.133
So right now it's rather sparse,
to say the least.

273
00:15:43.133 --> 00:15:44.034
There's a pop-up there.

274
00:15:46.659 --> 00:15:51.264
Okay, let's go to home again.

275
00:15:51.264 --> 00:15:51.792
All right, go back to where I was.

276
00:15:51.792 --> 00:15:57.446
And let's go to video now.

277
00:15:57.446 --> 00:16:01.758
So there's great video hosting
capabilities with various

278
00:16:01.758 --> 00:16:03.660
channels we can specify.

279
00:16:03.660 --> 00:16:07.200
So I can create a channel, give it a name.

280
00:16:08.860 --> 00:16:10.730
TV, that's available, okay.

281
00:16:12.120 --> 00:16:14.594
Create, you can't have
duplicate channel names.

282
00:16:14.594 --> 00:16:17.552
That's creating a channel now.

283
00:16:17.552 --> 00:16:22.411
So if you've used Vimeo or
other tools like that this won't

284
00:16:22.411 --> 00:16:26.890
be too shocking for you,
there's Channel Settings.

285
00:16:31.559 --> 00:16:34.340
Storage Metrics, I can click on here.

286
00:16:34.340 --> 00:16:37.250
So Site Collection, storage size.

287
00:16:37.250 --> 00:16:41.210
So if we're talking video we
have a restrictive quota.

288
00:16:41.210 --> 00:16:44.890
Then Vimeo's gonna get to
chomp that up significantly.

289
00:16:44.890 --> 00:16:45.550
>> What the heck does that mean?

290
00:16:45.550 --> 00:16:47.740
>> It's gonna conceal
a lot of your resources.

291
00:16:47.740 --> 00:16:49.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> Thank you for translating that.

292
00:16:49.500 --> 00:16:51.720
>> Yes, I have no idea why I said that.

293
00:16:51.720 --> 00:16:52.830
It just came out.

294
00:16:52.830 --> 00:16:56.988
All right, and then I can assign
permissions here, Owners, Editors, and,

295
00:16:56.988 --> 00:16:57.565
Viewers.

296
00:16:57.565 --> 00:17:02.220
And then I can expose
a download link to one, two or

297
00:17:02.220 --> 00:17:05.130
all three of those categories,
Owners, Editors and Viewers.

298
00:17:05.130 --> 00:17:08.860
Spotlight, which means I can
feature on the channel page so

299
00:17:08.860 --> 00:17:12.900
that the landing page of the channel,
I can feature a variety of videos there or

300
00:17:12.900 --> 00:17:15.100
at least thumbnails of those videos.

301
00:17:15.100 --> 00:17:22.160
And I can also enable Yammer conversations
with this channel, which I'm not gonna do.

302
00:17:22.160 --> 00:17:25.410
Now, Word shows a variety of traditional
Office apps that are available.

303
00:17:25.410 --> 00:17:29.970
This is cool, a little integration
here with Dropbox, perhaps

304
00:17:29.970 --> 00:17:34.285
somewhat surprising given Microsoft's
Office preference for OneDrive.

305
00:17:34.285 --> 00:17:40.730
But the CEO is recognizing it's
a heterogeneous world, right?

306
00:17:40.730 --> 00:17:42.990
It's good to play nice with others.

307
00:17:42.990 --> 00:17:45.860
So I could add a Dropbox account here.

308
00:17:45.860 --> 00:17:49.590
I can use Sway,
we're gonna talk about Sway a little bit.

309
00:17:49.590 --> 00:17:53.130
And then Format Painter, which is handy,

310
00:17:53.130 --> 00:17:55.590
I don't know,
it's new to the product, that's why.

311
00:17:55.590 --> 00:17:58.520
But you're probably used to
using the Format Painter for

312
00:17:58.520 --> 00:18:02.780
your full-featured versions of Word,
PowerPoint, so I'll say got it.

313
00:18:04.900 --> 00:18:08.761
And various formats here calendars,
blank formats, and

314
00:18:08.761 --> 00:18:14.036
there's also a nice shortcut here, so
if I want to save my content in OneDrive,

315
00:18:14.036 --> 00:18:17.062
so I can access it from any machine or
device.

316
00:18:17.062 --> 00:18:21.160
Then shortcuts to recently opened
documents, and recently saved and

317
00:18:21.160 --> 00:18:24.851
updated documents in OneDrive
will appear right on this page.

318
00:18:24.851 --> 00:18:25.980
Very handy.

319
00:18:27.500 --> 00:18:30.562
Similarly, get you to close out of there.

320
00:18:32.334 --> 00:18:36.440
We have a similar experience for
Excel and PowerPoint.

321
00:18:36.440 --> 00:18:43.236
OneNote we already looked at, and
let's go to Sway, as promised.

322
00:18:43.236 --> 00:18:47.063
If you're like me and not really
a graphic design guy or not really,

323
00:18:47.063 --> 00:18:49.210
don't have design chops.

324
00:18:49.210 --> 00:18:53.480
Sway makes it really easy to create
polished looking presentations that will

325
00:18:53.480 --> 00:18:55.130
wow people.

326
00:18:55.130 --> 00:18:58.100
So here we are at the Sway site,
this is very cool.

327
00:18:58.100 --> 00:19:03.090
I can create presentations,
interactive reports, and more.

328
00:19:03.090 --> 00:19:07.563
There's some nice examples.

329
00:19:07.563 --> 00:19:11.443
Just scrolling down the page I can send,
or share this presentation,

330
00:19:11.443 --> 00:19:13.960
or a document that I've
created with a link.

331
00:19:15.590 --> 00:19:17.874
So let's see what happens
when I click on Get Started.

332
00:19:21.662 --> 00:19:22.870
It takes a while to load up.

333
00:19:22.870 --> 00:19:26.390
In the meantime you've got
a nice hexagonal pattern.

334
00:19:26.390 --> 00:19:29.708
Reminds me of the guy that did those
really complex drawings where it looked

335
00:19:29.708 --> 00:19:30.770
like you were going up.

336
00:19:30.770 --> 00:19:31.964
>> Escher
>> Escher!

337
00:19:31.964 --> 00:19:33.817
Thank you, Escher drawings.

338
00:19:33.817 --> 00:19:37.762
A little Jeopardy here,
a little game show.

339
00:19:37.762 --> 00:19:42.528
Okay, so nice little tutorial here, or
this quick thing here, Adventures, so

340
00:19:42.528 --> 00:19:45.207
you can talk about your
going on a field trip.

341
00:19:45.207 --> 00:19:50.186
You got a little variety of combinations
of content types with pictures and text,

342
00:19:50.186 --> 00:19:52.650
even video you can utilize in your Sway.

343
00:19:53.690 --> 00:19:59.520
You can drag in content from YouTube,
Picasa, Bing, Flickr.

344
00:19:59.520 --> 00:20:01.630
Wherever the data is,
you can bring it in and

345
00:20:01.630 --> 00:20:07.010
create really cool content with minimal
effort, that's the key, minimal effort.

346
00:20:07.010 --> 00:20:11.350
Cuz if you're like me, plus,
it comes up with a suggested

347
00:20:11.350 --> 00:20:15.883
arrangement of design elements
on the page and it shows you.

348
00:20:15.883 --> 00:20:18.680
And you can say remix, and
get a different combination.

349
00:20:20.060 --> 00:20:23.924
So I'll say Create New, it takes
a few minutes to get to this page or

350
00:20:23.924 --> 00:20:28.281
probably a minute but it seems like
five minutes, and now I'm at the page.

351
00:20:28.281 --> 00:20:33.517
I won't actually create a Sway,
I'm just showing you the design I want so

352
00:20:33.517 --> 00:20:35.886
I can title a Sway, Sway Hey Hey!

353
00:20:35.886 --> 00:20:37.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> And add content.

354
00:20:37.920 --> 00:20:41.370
So various content types,
as mentioned before, image,

355
00:20:41.370 --> 00:20:43.845
video, tweets I can bring in.

356
00:20:43.845 --> 00:20:47.540
So whatever mish-mash or
mash-up I wanna create, I can do, and

357
00:20:47.540 --> 00:20:49.950
Sway makes sense of it and
presents it in a really cool way.

358
00:20:49.950 --> 00:20:53.460
And if I don't like it,
I can say hey, remix, that does that.

359
00:20:53.460 --> 00:20:55.250
So and then there is authors here.

360
00:20:55.250 --> 00:21:01.159
I can share it, the ellipses here, I can
duplicate the Sway then maybe modify it.

361
00:21:01.159 --> 00:21:08.475
So if I wanna make some slight change
there's various options on the menu for

362
00:21:08.475 --> 00:21:14.090
cards and design in various layouts and
then again remix.

363
00:21:14.090 --> 00:21:17.070
So if you don't like the assemblage,
you can just say do it again.

364
00:21:19.070 --> 00:21:21.220
So it's a fun tool to play around with,

365
00:21:21.220 --> 00:21:25.522
and it's part of something that your users
might like to do to create something

366
00:21:25.522 --> 00:21:28.274
that's not just your
standard PowerPoint deck.

367
00:21:28.274 --> 00:21:30.281
Maybe they're bored of creating those and

368
00:21:30.281 --> 00:21:33.570
they don't have the skills to
modify templates in PowerPoint.

369
00:21:33.570 --> 00:21:35.420
And they could come up
with a really funky,

370
00:21:35.420 --> 00:21:38.090
engaging presentation
with multimedia content.

371
00:21:39.400 --> 00:21:40.610
>> All right, fantastic.

372
00:21:40.610 --> 00:21:44.210
Mark, great look there at
the SharePoint Online user experience,

373
00:21:44.210 --> 00:21:48.240
what our end-users are gonna see
once we've set up SharePoint online,

374
00:21:48.240 --> 00:21:52.080
they browse in there, all the different
tools that they have at their fingertips.

375
00:21:52.080 --> 00:21:53.950
You can do some really
neat stuff with that.

376
00:21:53.950 --> 00:21:55.530
So we thank you for
that and the tour there.

377
00:21:55.530 --> 00:21:57.620
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

378
00:21:57.620 --> 00:21:59.959
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

379
00:21:59.959 --> 00:22:00.881
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

380
00:22:00.881 --> 00:22:02.482
>> And we'll see you next time.

381
00:22:02.482 --> 00:22:11.830
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Governance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.019 --> 00:00:10.019
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.954 --> 00:00:15.336
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.336 --> 00:00:20.038
I'm you host Mike Rodrick and today we
are doing our advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:20.038 --> 00:00:23.700
And specifically in this episode we
gonna be diving into the world of

5
00:00:23.700 --> 00:00:24.930
governance, right?

6
00:00:24.930 --> 00:00:27.550
We've talked about governance
in several episodes,

7
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:30.330
we've stressed its importance
all the way through, right.

8
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:35.290
From the planning phase at the very
beginning to our implementation phase,

9
00:00:35.290 --> 00:00:38.590
to our maintenance phase or,
you know, once we've got share point

10
