00:00:38.590 --> 00:00:41.600
infrastructure set up and
running, governance doesn't stop.

11
00:00:41.600 --> 00:00:44.360
It must continue,
it's a very important part.

12
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.967
And here to help us understand the details
on how it works is Mr. Mark Ingram.

13
00:00:47.967 --> 00:00:48.908
How you doing Mark?

14
00:00:48.908 --> 00:00:49.731
>> Thanks Mike.

15
00:00:49.731 --> 00:00:54.181
Yeah, so three key words in governance
we'll be looking at policies,

16
00:00:54.181 --> 00:00:56.120
procedures, and processes.

17
00:00:57.140 --> 00:01:01.230
A mistake many organizations make
with this SharePoint deployment,

18
00:01:01.230 --> 00:01:05.020
because it often costs a lot of money or
may be part of an enterprise agreement.

19
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:09.020
But in any event they think okay we sealed
out the big bucks it should just work now.

20
00:01:10.090 --> 00:01:14.390
Or if not it's IT's problem,
they'll figure out how to implement and

21
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:15.320
what to implement.

22
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:20.290
That is a colossal mistake and it's
going to be a recipe for aggravation and

23
00:01:20.290 --> 00:01:24.050
then people start blaming SharePoint for
why their deployment

24
00:01:24.050 --> 00:01:28.560
has gone when the truth of the matter
is it all starts with governance.

25
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:33.739
Even before planning for
scaling software, hardware requirements,

26
00:01:33.739 --> 00:01:39.172
whether your architecture model on prem,
in Azure, SharePoint online or

27
00:01:39.172 --> 00:01:44.626
a hybrid approach even before that,
governance needs to be established.

28
00:01:44.626 --> 00:01:48.058
And IT certainly has
an investment in that and

29
00:01:48.058 --> 00:01:53.659
should be involved in those decisions and
can be a valuable contributor,

30
00:01:53.659 --> 00:01:58.624
but the buy in has to happen at the C
level or the project is likely to

31
00:01:58.624 --> 00:02:03.138
either fail badly or
only be adopted by a fraction of the user

32
00:02:03.138 --> 00:02:08.450
population while leaving vast
capabilities unused in SharePoint.

33
00:02:08.450 --> 00:02:13.360
So we're banging the drum
of governance today.

34
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:18.050
As we go through this episode you might
not even be sure what governance is.

35
00:02:18.050 --> 00:02:20.990
Governance is who decides who decides.

36
00:02:20.990 --> 00:02:25.620
So a governance committee, for
example, would basically embolden and

37
00:02:25.620 --> 00:02:30.340
empower certain people to make decisions
on behalf of the organization.

38
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:35.440
Okay, so this, again, IT can implement and
have some input in governance,

39
00:02:35.440 --> 00:02:38.430
but governance has to
come from business units.

40
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:41.160
Because SharePoint is a tool for business.

41
00:02:41.160 --> 00:02:42.720
Especially because,

42
00:02:42.720 --> 00:02:47.810
workflow capabilities allow us now
to move a lot of other processes,

43
00:02:47.810 --> 00:02:52.790
maybe paper based or with some other
technology into a SharePoint context.

44
00:02:52.790 --> 00:02:58.200
Anything you can dream up technology wise,
we can implement as a part of a workflow.

45
00:02:58.200 --> 00:03:00.210
That could be some basic
approval workflows or for

46
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:04.710
publishing, to really complex
processes in the organization,

47
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:08.810
accessing all kinds of external databases,
internal sources.

48
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:10.960
So you can really tighten
up your workflow,

49
00:03:10.960 --> 00:03:15.420
whether they're producing widget say or
intellectual property or what have you.

50
00:03:15.420 --> 00:03:19.963
So we will look at the various
concepts of governance,

51
00:03:19.963 --> 00:03:24.211
key elements of governance,
and then planning for

52
00:03:24.211 --> 00:03:29.865
governance in your SharePoint
2016 environment, all right.

53
00:03:29.865 --> 00:03:34.248
So a misconception about governance,
people think it has something to

54
00:03:34.248 --> 00:03:37.750
do with security, or
governance equals permissions.

55
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:42.380
That is not the case, permission certainly
can support the governance plan,

56
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:45.110
we always want to keep in mind
the law of least privilege.

57
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:49.400
People should have access to the tools and
be able to do their job but

58
00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:51.640
we shouldn't grant
unnecessary permissions.

59
00:03:51.640 --> 00:03:53.810
For example not everyone needs
to be a farm administrator,

60
00:03:53.810 --> 00:03:56.890
typically only a very small
number of farm admins are needed.

61
00:04:01.082 --> 00:04:05.790
All right, so what does governance help
us avoid and why is it so beneficial?

62
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:11.550
We can have, just like urban planning, if
you're planning neighborhoods or cities or

63
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:17.730
regions, if there's no over-arching plan,
you're going to get a mish mash

64
00:04:17.730 --> 00:04:23.760
of neighborhoods and inefficiencies and
content sprawl, you can think of it as.

65
00:04:23.760 --> 00:04:30.120
So, we've certainly pitched the idea of
pruning content, deleting expired content,

66
00:04:30.120 --> 00:04:33.550
and certainly not moving, let's say you're
new to SharePoint, the last thing you

67
00:04:33.550 --> 00:04:38.250
wanna do is start transporting all
that old content into SharePoint.

68
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:41.600
Remember, you can search all kinds
of content sources right from

69
00:04:41.600 --> 00:04:44.700
within SharePoint while
leaving it where it is.

70
00:04:44.700 --> 00:04:46.890
So, what should be created in SharePoint?

71
00:04:46.890 --> 00:04:49.320
New collaborative content
is a prime candidate,

72
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:51.100
everything else can be indexed in place.

73
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:55.590
Okay, quality management policies for
the content.

74
00:04:55.590 --> 00:04:59.520
So, rather than just anyone and their dog
being allowed to create site collections,

75
00:04:59.520 --> 00:05:02.350
for example,
you might have some processes in place

76
00:05:02.350 --> 00:05:05.110
that determine who gets to
create site collections.

77
00:05:05.110 --> 00:05:07.890
You might have quotas in place,
these are governance decisions.

78
00:05:09.310 --> 00:05:11.060
Now, in terms of the look and

79
00:05:11.060 --> 00:05:15.540
feel of the site, you don't want everyone
with the capability to have a dramatically

80
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:18.440
different looking site collection for
their department.

81
00:05:18.440 --> 00:05:22.838
From a user perspective, it's confusing
and disorienting if it's a completely

82
00:05:22.838 --> 00:05:25.963
different experience navigating
different team sites or

83
00:05:25.963 --> 00:05:28.334
departmental sites in your organization.

84
00:05:28.334 --> 00:05:30.750
So that's also a governance issue.

85
00:05:30.750 --> 00:05:34.420
Very few people should have SharePoint
designer permission to be able to

86
00:05:34.420 --> 00:05:36.090
drastically modify the look and

87
00:05:36.090 --> 00:05:39.650
feel of SharePoint through things
like master pages, for example.

88
00:05:40.960 --> 00:05:43.520
Okay, escalation procedures.

89
00:05:43.520 --> 00:05:47.120
So you need to have a chain of
command when it comes to SharePoint.

90
00:05:47.120 --> 00:05:48.510
So disputes are resolved and

91
00:05:48.510 --> 00:05:52.280
if not, everyone knows who
to appeal to if you like.

92
00:05:54.670 --> 00:05:55.810
Okay and

93
00:05:55.810 --> 00:06:00.450
then does the implementation strategy
map correctly the business objectives?

94
00:06:01.740 --> 00:06:05.660
So you always want to figure out how
is SharePoint delivering value to our

95
00:06:05.660 --> 00:06:06.440
organization.

96
00:06:08.270 --> 00:06:11.620
And you also need to be in
compliance with various

97
00:06:12.940 --> 00:06:16.500
regulations determined by
the geography in which you operate.

98
00:06:16.500 --> 00:06:19.060
You might be a multi national
corporation subject to

99
00:06:19.060 --> 00:06:21.500
all kinds of different privacy
legislations, for example.

100
00:06:21.500 --> 00:06:27.710
Various standards may apply
in your line of business and

101
00:06:27.710 --> 00:06:30.390
depending on where you work.

102
00:06:30.390 --> 00:06:33.631
I don't see us getting any less
regulations going forward when it comes

103
00:06:33.631 --> 00:06:34.934
to privacy and compliance.

104
00:06:34.934 --> 00:06:36.730
>> It's probably just the opposite.

105
00:06:36.730 --> 00:06:41.060
>> Exactly, more, okay.

106
00:06:41.060 --> 00:06:43.850
There's also some optional
technologies you may want to use,

107
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:48.520
like document sets and document IDs,
which we discussed in another episode.

108
00:06:48.520 --> 00:06:50.950
So that's not something
that's essential to use,

109
00:06:50.950 --> 00:06:54.729
it may be of use in your organization so
again, that's a governance issue.

110
00:06:59.030 --> 00:07:04.160
Social computing features now impact or

111
00:07:04.160 --> 00:07:06.970
should be designed by governance as well,
or decided on.

112
00:07:06.970 --> 00:07:08.960
For example do we want
to allow social tagging?

113
00:07:08.960 --> 00:07:13.690
Do we want to allow hashtags,
mentions with the at symbol?

114
00:07:13.690 --> 00:07:17.710
For some organizations all that
is considered a distraction and

115
00:07:17.710 --> 00:07:20.460
taking away from the prime
focus of the business.

116
00:07:20.460 --> 00:07:24.720
Where as other organizations more embrace
that technology because a lot of people

117
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:28.300
already use LinkedIn, probably Facebook
and maybe some other social media sites.

118
00:07:28.300 --> 00:07:34.290
So they see no harm in using some of those
same social tagging concepts in-house and

119
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:35.690
in fact, they would actively encourage it.

120
00:07:36.720 --> 00:07:38.160
Should we deploy Yammer?

121
00:07:38.160 --> 00:07:40.240
That's a question that you
can decide as well, or

122
00:07:40.240 --> 00:07:43.160
just use the built-in social
networking in SharePoint.

123
00:07:45.380 --> 00:07:48.189
Okay, now let's say we have
a multi-farm environment.

124
00:07:49.810 --> 00:07:54.454
Or even if we have just a single farm,
how are we classifying metadata?

125
00:07:54.454 --> 00:07:59.587
So we talked in another episode about
content types, which is a unique

126
00:07:59.587 --> 00:08:05.171
grouping of metadata columns Who gets
to decide definitions for metadata?

127
00:08:05.171 --> 00:08:09.157
For, now, it's something might seem
obvious, like a customer field, for

128
00:08:09.157 --> 00:08:10.180
example.

129
00:08:10.180 --> 00:08:14.460
But the way that marketing defines, or the
information of interest to marketing in

130
00:08:14.460 --> 00:08:19.680
a customer field,
may be different from an order fulfillment

131
00:08:19.680 --> 00:08:23.820
division's interest in the customer field.

132
00:08:23.820 --> 00:08:28.160
So it's not like you can't have differing
definitions for some metadata, but

133
00:08:28.160 --> 00:08:30.752
you need to define, in most organizations,

134
00:08:30.752 --> 00:08:35.260
it behooves them to design
farm wide definitions for

135
00:08:35.260 --> 00:08:39.910
metadata so everyone knows this
customer field has these restrictions.

136
00:08:39.910 --> 00:08:41.550
It's a text field.

137
00:08:42.950 --> 00:08:46.030
Or you might have an ID number field,
for example.

138
00:08:47.170 --> 00:08:49.860
There's all kinds of different metadata
you could populate in site columns,

139
00:08:49.860 --> 00:08:52.740
standardizing definitions will
make everyone's life easier.

140
00:08:54.050 --> 00:08:58.310
That still allows for exceptions,
say, at a site collection level.

141
00:08:58.310 --> 00:09:02.940
But it makes sense, again,
to have a content type hub,

142
00:09:02.940 --> 00:09:07.832
which is a central site, you've defined
metadata columns and content types.

143
00:09:07.832 --> 00:09:11.260
And then, any site collection
in the organization can consume

144
00:09:11.260 --> 00:09:14.440
from those content types and
make additional modifications or

145
00:09:14.440 --> 00:09:16.480
add additional columns, if necessary.

146
00:09:16.480 --> 00:09:19.350
That, what I just described,
is a governance issue.

147
00:09:21.690 --> 00:09:23.550
Okay, records management.

148
00:09:23.550 --> 00:09:28.160
Do we wanna allow for things like in place
records management, where the record stays

149
00:09:28.160 --> 00:09:31.110
in the site collection or
document library where it is, for example?

150
00:09:31.110 --> 00:09:37.980
Or should records all be moved to a site
template type of records center enterprise

151
00:09:37.980 --> 00:09:42.160
template which is designed to handle
large numbers of records in one place?

152
00:09:42.160 --> 00:09:44.920
So, whether you're gonna have
in place records management or

153
00:09:44.920 --> 00:09:50.170
move it to a separate site,
that's a governance decision.

154
00:09:50.170 --> 00:09:52.950
What kind of customization
are you going to allow on sites?

155
00:09:52.950 --> 00:09:57.050
We talked about SharePoint designer, are
you gonna allow for Sandboxed Solutions?

156
00:09:57.050 --> 00:10:02.010
So, some custom code can run in
site collections, with limitations,

157
00:10:02.010 --> 00:10:04.630
which we've already talked
about in another episode.

158
00:10:04.630 --> 00:10:07.878
So, whether or not to allow sandboxed
solutions, also a governance issue.

159
00:10:10.735 --> 00:10:16.360
What are the key areas of governance
in terms of information architecture?

160
00:10:16.360 --> 00:10:18.910
We talked about metadata already.

161
00:10:18.910 --> 00:10:22.140
You might have,
in terms of content storage,

162
00:10:22.140 --> 00:10:24.970
you might have different
versions of the same document

163
00:10:24.970 --> 00:10:28.080
living in different parts of your
SharePoint farm infrastructure.

164
00:10:28.080 --> 00:10:29.660
That could be problematic.

165
00:10:29.660 --> 00:10:34.430
So even, for example, the context menu
when you can send to another depository,

166
00:10:34.430 --> 00:10:38.560
a document center, a record center,
you have the ability, or you could have

167
00:10:38.560 --> 00:10:43.180
the ability, to leave a copy in place and
make another copy at the destination.

168
00:10:43.180 --> 00:10:48.650
Or you could move that document and
leave a link, or simply move the document.

169
00:10:48.650 --> 00:10:51.400
So if you are going to, and
there may be legitimate reasons for having

170
00:10:51.400 --> 00:10:55.200
multiple copies of the same document
living in different places in the farm.

171
00:10:55.200 --> 00:10:55.700
>> Right.
>> But

172
00:10:55.700 --> 00:10:59.100
there needs to be a reason
why that is the case.

173
00:10:59.100 --> 00:11:02.770
Or some organizations might just
want a single copy of any document

174
00:11:02.770 --> 00:11:03.570
existing in the farm.

175
00:11:05.400 --> 00:11:09.610
Another governance decision is whether or
not to allow versioning.

176
00:11:09.610 --> 00:11:13.110
Now, we've talked about the improvements
in terms of shredded storage

177
00:11:13.110 --> 00:11:17.330
since SQL 2012,
which means that if we allow 10 versions,

178
00:11:17.330 --> 00:11:21.350
in the old days we used to have 10
times the file storage requirements.

179
00:11:21.350 --> 00:11:23.680
Now we don't have that,
thanks to Shredded Storage.

180
00:11:23.680 --> 00:11:28.270
But still, deciding on whether or not you
want versioning is a key consideration

181
00:11:28.270 --> 00:11:29.870
that should be decided by governance.

182
00:11:29.870 --> 00:11:33.260
Now, it's not like this governance
committee has to decide all this.

183
00:11:33.260 --> 00:11:35.860
What they do have to decide, though,
is who gets to make the decision.

184
00:11:35.860 --> 00:11:37.869
So, they might say, you know what,

185
00:11:37.869 --> 00:11:41.130
local divisions can make their own
decision on versioning versioning.

186
00:11:41.130 --> 00:11:44.840
Or maybe site collection
administrators have that capability,

187
00:11:44.840 --> 00:11:48.470
whatever they think is best is
fine in terms of whether or

188
00:11:48.470 --> 00:11:51.010
not they want versioning,
major versions, minor versions.

189
00:11:51.010 --> 00:11:54.440
So, remember, we have a delegated
administration model at SharePoint.

190
00:11:54.440 --> 00:11:58.050
We, as the farm admins, definitely do not
want to be making all these decisions.

191
00:11:58.050 --> 00:12:02.430
We want to empower more localized
administration through site collection

192
00:12:02.430 --> 00:12:03.200
administrators.

193
00:12:04.750 --> 00:12:05.250
Okay.

194
00:12:06.440 --> 00:12:10.175
Now, in terms of SharePoint 2016 farms and

195
00:12:10.175 --> 00:12:14.640
servers, occasionally you hear
about somebody getting fired, or

196
00:12:14.640 --> 00:12:17.850
at least reprimanded cuz they set
up a rogue wireless access point.

197
00:12:17.850 --> 00:12:21.230
They hid it under their desk, and they
thought, well, no one's gonna find this,

198
00:12:21.230 --> 00:12:25.270
not realizing it's quite easy to scan for
rogue wireless access points.

199
00:12:25.270 --> 00:12:29.908
That could be a serious concern if you're
dealing with sensitive information, and

200
00:12:29.908 --> 00:12:33.570
it might grant someone access to
a portion of the network where

201
00:12:33.570 --> 00:12:35.680
some data could be compromised.

202
00:12:35.680 --> 00:12:39.510
So, similarly,
we could potentially have rogue farms,

203
00:12:39.510 --> 00:12:42.750
especially if you're dealing with some
IT people that know how to set them up.

204
00:12:42.750 --> 00:12:47.723
They might just decide I'm gonna set up my
own farm, and not a responsible dev farm,

205
00:12:47.723 --> 00:12:52.415
but just a farm for their enjoyment to use
or maybe to send in their own governance

206
00:12:52.415 --> 00:12:57.069
permissions and inviting a few employees
to their private farm, if you will.

207
00:12:57.069 --> 00:13:00.390
So that's probably not good.

208
00:13:01.400 --> 00:13:03.610
You might have an issue with applications,

209
00:13:03.610 --> 00:13:06.430
especially if you have
a lot of customizations or

210
00:13:06.430 --> 00:13:11.450
applications running in your environment,
apps that may not play well with others.

211
00:13:11.450 --> 00:13:14.350
So, it could either,
they could either be poorly written and

212
00:13:14.350 --> 00:13:18.260
consume a lot of resources, and or they
could be legitimate security risks, again,

213
00:13:18.260 --> 00:13:22.950
exposing more sensitive data to
eyes that should not see it.

214
00:13:24.860 --> 00:13:30.110
Okay, and then another problem with
rogue servers is you might have,

215
00:13:31.670 --> 00:13:33.700
or just servers in general
in your SharePoint farm,

216
00:13:33.700 --> 00:13:38.880
inconsistent administration of
policies and compliance standards.

217
00:13:41.080 --> 00:13:43.310
You might have issues regarding training.

218
00:13:43.310 --> 00:13:48.060
So, obviously, I have a self-interest
in promoting training.

219
00:13:48.060 --> 00:13:51.430
However, the fact remains I can
have a self-interest in it, and

220
00:13:51.430 --> 00:13:53.620
it can still be true.

221
00:13:53.620 --> 00:13:56.332
We talked about the importance
of training end users and

222
00:13:56.332 --> 00:13:57.620
site collection administrators.

223
00:13:57.620 --> 00:14:00.630
Definitely farm administrators
need to be trained as well.

224
00:14:00.630 --> 00:14:04.120
For example,
they may not be backing up effectively, or

225
00:14:04.120 --> 00:14:07.980
they might just use the very
convenient wizard from central admin.

226
00:14:07.980 --> 00:14:10.040
Or they might have have
a PowerShell script, for example,

227
00:14:10.040 --> 00:14:14.680
to automate backup procedures
without realizing that to recover

228
00:14:14.680 --> 00:14:19.060
a fully functioning SharePoint farm,

229
00:14:19.060 --> 00:14:24.170
you need to backup more than just what's
available from the central admin console.

230
00:14:24.170 --> 00:14:27.380
Things like iOS certificates,
customizations,

231
00:14:27.380 --> 00:14:29.860
and more,
which we covered in another episode.

232
00:14:29.860 --> 00:14:33.060
So, as they say, a little knowledge
can be a dangerous thing.

233
00:14:33.060 --> 00:14:37.650
The admin might think, okay, I've covered
it all up because I do a full farm back

234
00:14:37.650 --> 00:14:41.500
up, and maybe some incrementals in there,
maybe have a third party tool.

235
00:14:41.500 --> 00:14:43.400
But the third party tool might
not capture everything and

236
00:14:43.400 --> 00:14:46.800
all the customizations you need
in case a total disaster strikes,

237
00:14:46.800 --> 00:14:49.980
tornado, you loose all your hardware,
you have to do a restore.

238
00:14:49.980 --> 00:14:55.050
And then that's not the time to,
we didn't back-up everything we needed.

239
00:14:55.050 --> 00:14:56.130
Which brings up another point.

240
00:14:56.130 --> 00:14:58.490
If you're not doing trial
restores periodically,

241
00:14:58.490 --> 00:15:01.640
how do you know your back-up
routine is accessible?

242
00:15:01.640 --> 00:15:04.050
You can't know, I promise you.

243
00:15:04.050 --> 00:15:05.350
You cannot know.

244
00:15:05.350 --> 00:15:08.480
Because there might be some
little aspect of the back-up,

245
00:15:08.480 --> 00:15:12.670
or besides just missing key components
related to your SharePoint farm backup,

246
00:15:12.670 --> 00:15:15.940
there might be something that's
reporting backing up successfully,

247
00:15:15.940 --> 00:15:18.990
the event viewer or maybe you've got
System Center Operations Manager,

248
00:15:18.990 --> 00:15:20.610
it's not reporting any
errors with your backup.

249
00:15:20.610 --> 00:15:24.710
If you don't do a trial restore, you can't
know the backup has been successful.

250
00:15:24.710 --> 00:15:27.540
And that might produce the dreaded RPE.

251
00:15:27.540 --> 00:15:28.680
>> Yes, we don't want that.

252
00:15:28.680 --> 00:15:30.400
>> No, the resume producing event.

253
00:15:32.170 --> 00:15:37.670
Okay, and then, in terms of customization,
another governance issue.

254
00:15:37.670 --> 00:15:39.610
What customization tools can be used?

255
00:15:39.610 --> 00:15:41.150
SharePoint Designer, 2013?

256
00:15:41.150 --> 00:15:42.810
Another tool?

257
00:15:42.810 --> 00:15:45.040
Remember, Info Path 2013,
SharePoint Designer 2013?

258
00:15:45.040 --> 00:15:48.290
Those versions aren't gonna be updated.

259
00:15:48.290 --> 00:15:52.310
They'll still work fine with
SharePoint 2016, vNext, etc.

260
00:15:52.310 --> 00:15:54.520
But do you want people using those tools?

261
00:15:54.520 --> 00:15:56.450
Who should have access to them?

262
00:15:56.450 --> 00:15:57.750
What about apps?

263
00:15:57.750 --> 00:16:00.413
Who gets to add apps to the site?

264
00:16:00.413 --> 00:16:03.358
Who gets to decide which apps get added?

265
00:16:03.358 --> 00:16:05.201
So, there's an app catalog for that.

266
00:16:05.201 --> 00:16:08.895
And you can certainly restrict access to
the Windows store for third party apps.

267
00:16:08.895 --> 00:16:13.295
Perhaps you or
somebody has to approve, one by one,

268
00:16:13.295 --> 00:16:17.140
all the apps that people may want to use.

269
00:16:17.140 --> 00:16:19.950
And if they have a need for another app,
they have to make a request.

270
00:16:19.950 --> 00:16:21.790
And there's a mechanism for that, as well.

271
00:16:21.790 --> 00:16:24.430
But generally, you don't want to just
open it wide to the Windows store,

272
00:16:24.430 --> 00:16:30.060
because there may be some unwanted
interactions with existing apps,

273
00:16:30.060 --> 00:16:32.150
or maybe the app hasn't
been tested thoroughly and

274
00:16:32.150 --> 00:16:35.390
it could produce some security
issues in your environment.

275
00:16:35.390 --> 00:16:40.200
So I always like to restrict
the number of apps users are using.

276
00:16:40.200 --> 00:16:44.570
Now a little aside here,
in the BYOD environment, people, remember,

277
00:16:44.570 --> 00:16:45.480
it's their own device.

278
00:16:45.480 --> 00:16:48.450
So let's say I bring my tablet in for
a consulting engagement.

279
00:16:48.450 --> 00:16:50.360
I have some personal apps and data and

280
00:16:50.360 --> 00:16:53.770
them presumably there'll be some
business apps and data on that device.

281
00:16:53.770 --> 00:17:00.000
A problem can occur is that as a network
admin you might not know all of

282
00:17:00.000 --> 00:17:05.370
the apps that are running on a particular
device that can access business data.

283
00:17:05.370 --> 00:17:08.610
So now, we have tools in the cloud so
we can get an enumeration,

284
00:17:08.610 --> 00:17:12.370
just like System Center
Configuration Manager on-premises,

285
00:17:12.370 --> 00:17:15.470
or Windows Intune in the cloud,
now we can have

286
00:17:15.470 --> 00:17:20.530
an enumeration of all the software
that's running on a particular device.

287
00:17:20.530 --> 00:17:25.370
Because these cloud services,
there's so many of them SASS,

288
00:17:25.370 --> 00:17:28.420
all kinds of CRM apps and more.

289
00:17:28.420 --> 00:17:32.160
So we always, as admins,
want to know the software that's running

290
00:17:32.160 --> 00:17:37.040
on machines that we're in a way
responsible for or that we're allowing to

291
00:17:37.040 --> 00:17:40.840
access some resources on prem or
in the cloud that we are.

292
00:17:42.670 --> 00:17:47.790
Okay, what about a source control system,
another governance issue.

293
00:17:47.790 --> 00:17:53.269
In terms of dev team, source control,
checking-in, maybe team foundation server,

294
00:17:53.269 --> 00:17:57.058
some such tool to get versioning for
your code development.

295
00:18:02.051 --> 00:18:06.670
Testing procedures for, and
verification for, site upgrades.

296
00:18:08.760 --> 00:18:12.340
Standards for packaging and
insulation of solutions and features.

297
00:18:14.350 --> 00:18:17.300
What about web parts, custom web parts?

298
00:18:17.300 --> 00:18:19.160
Will you have standards about those,

299
00:18:19.160 --> 00:18:24.260
should users be allowed to install
just any web part, or again

300
00:18:24.260 --> 00:18:28.140
should they be allowed to only install
web parts from a restricted gallery.

301
00:18:30.050 --> 00:18:33.020
Branding, what branding will be used?

302
00:18:33.020 --> 00:18:36.330
That's something again should be standard
across the organization, you don't want

303
00:18:36.330 --> 00:18:40.230
people making cute modifications of your
logo, because branding is very important.

304
00:18:42.120 --> 00:18:45.150
Let's look now to key elements
of a governance plan.

305
00:18:47.120 --> 00:18:50.610
So vision statements, some people
love them, some people hate them, but

306
00:18:50.610 --> 00:18:52.030
it doesn't hurt.

307
00:18:52.030 --> 00:18:58.308
You can set out what you wanna accomplish
in your SharePoint 2016 governance plan.

308
00:19:01.787 --> 00:19:04.941
And the vision statement makes sense
to do at the beginning of the project,

309
00:19:04.941 --> 00:19:06.640
not after because you forgot to do it.

310
00:19:06.640 --> 00:19:07.400
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

311
00:19:07.400 --> 00:19:09.370
>> After you've created the governance

312
00:19:09.370 --> 00:19:12.352
plan, it's probably too late for
a vision plan.

313
00:19:12.352 --> 00:19:16.282
Although if you're going to revisit
the governance plan in a year or two,

314
00:19:16.282 --> 00:19:19.982
or before the next major SharePoint
upgrade you're performing,

315
00:19:19.982 --> 00:19:24.552
it might be a good idea to create a vision
plan for governance at that point.

316
00:19:24.552 --> 00:19:29.310
What are the rules and
responsibilities for a governance plan?

317
00:19:29.310 --> 00:19:34.500
So if you've done any ITIL courses, the IT
Infrastructure Library based in London,

318
00:19:34.500 --> 00:19:39.940
England, they have some great policies and
procedures and methodologies.

319
00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:43.720
Whether it's deploying a software or
hardware refresh.

320
00:19:43.720 --> 00:19:47.690
Whether it's developing a project,
doing some kind of rollout.

321
00:19:47.690 --> 00:19:51.490
A lot of good standards, often they're
iterative, in other words it's a circle,

322
00:19:51.490 --> 00:19:54.670
you're never actually done, because when
you've finished implementing the previous

323
00:19:54.670 --> 00:19:59.380
project it's probably time to start
planning the next one, so but

324
00:19:59.380 --> 00:20:05.190
some questions to answer are who will
be responsible in SharePoint for

325
00:20:05.190 --> 00:20:06.710
the technical deployment?

326
00:20:06.710 --> 00:20:11.300
So the hardware and software,
sizing, acquiring that.

327
00:20:11.300 --> 00:20:13.330
Licensing, hardware, testing.

328
00:20:15.170 --> 00:20:21.370
Who gets to install new features, apps,
add-ins now as we call them in 2016?

329
00:20:21.370 --> 00:20:26.140
Who gets to setup new sites,
is that something that anyone can do or

330
00:20:26.140 --> 00:20:28.170
are only certain people
allowed to setup new sites,

331
00:20:28.170 --> 00:20:29.910
like site collection administrators for
example?

332
00:20:31.940 --> 00:20:33.810
What about service level agreements?

333
00:20:34.830 --> 00:20:36.380
What should they be?

334
00:20:36.380 --> 00:20:39.530
How much data are you willing to lose?

335
00:20:39.530 --> 00:20:42.824
If you say zero, that's gonna cost more
to influence that kind of hardware

336
00:20:42.824 --> 00:20:45.140
restructure then if you're
willing to live with,

337
00:20:45.140 --> 00:20:48.320
we can live with losing 30
minutes of data at the most.

338
00:20:49.320 --> 00:20:53.100
That gives you a little more flexibility
in terms of how you size a level of

339
00:20:53.100 --> 00:20:56.240
redundancy in a number of servers
running SharePoint in your environment.

340
00:20:58.550 --> 00:21:02.909
Who gets to grant permissions or access
to various site collections and sites?

341
00:21:06.250 --> 00:21:09.710
Can users modify Web parts
on sites that they manage?

342
00:21:09.710 --> 00:21:12.930
Or is that something that only
certain coders can do, for example?

343
00:21:15.630 --> 00:21:17.928
Who is responsible for
the management of metadata?

344
00:21:17.928 --> 00:21:21.040
Maybe reviewing metadata columns
periodically to make sure you're capturing

345
00:21:21.040 --> 00:21:21.688
the data you want.

346
00:21:21.688 --> 00:21:25.010
Standardizing of metadata.

347
00:21:25.010 --> 00:21:27.470
Incorporating various divisions
as we talked about before.

348
00:21:28.960 --> 00:21:31.960
What if there's a need for
a new content type?

349
00:21:31.960 --> 00:21:34.080
Who should that request go to?

350
00:21:34.080 --> 00:21:37.650
How does someone justify their need for
a request for new content type?

351
00:21:37.650 --> 00:21:40.190
Remember content types let
us do all kinds of things.

352
00:21:40.190 --> 00:21:42.580
In the farm.
I'm gonna avoid going down that rabbit

353
00:21:42.580 --> 00:21:43.772
hole, cuz I've talked at length.

354
00:21:43.772 --> 00:21:44.284
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

355
00:21:44.284 --> 00:21:46.290
>> But, I am a fan of content types.

356
00:21:46.290 --> 00:21:47.444
Maybe I'll get a t-shirt.

357
00:21:47.444 --> 00:21:49.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> I heart content types.

358
00:21:49.420 --> 00:21:54.832
>> There you go.
>> Yeah, okay, Now,

359
00:21:54.832 --> 00:21:56.960
so we should have various rules.

360
00:21:56.960 --> 00:21:59.160
Now, sometimes in a small organization,

361
00:21:59.160 --> 00:22:02.850
there may be somebody
wearing more than one hat.

362
00:22:02.850 --> 00:22:05.330
But you need executive level sponsorship.

363
00:22:05.330 --> 00:22:10.830
So C level ideally, or VP level,
because there is going to be inevitable

364
00:22:12.305 --> 00:22:15.635
delay and inertia getting this new
project off, especially if your

365
00:22:15.635 --> 00:22:19.605
company's been established for a long time
and you newly transitioned to SharePoint.

366
00:22:19.605 --> 00:22:21.265
People hate change and

367
00:22:21.265 --> 00:22:24.970
they're used to doing things a certain way
with whatever systems you have in place.

368
00:22:24.970 --> 00:22:27.520
You're asking them to
do things differently.

369
00:22:27.520 --> 00:22:30.810
The users are people involved in
your SharePoint deployment and

370
00:22:30.810 --> 00:22:35.250
decision making don't necessarily
know the benefits yet.

371
00:22:35.250 --> 00:22:37.840
Aren't sure if they can actually
realize then in SharePoint or

372
00:22:37.840 --> 00:22:40.900
how many years or months it will
take to realize those benefits.

373
00:22:40.900 --> 00:22:46.330
So when the project seems to be bogged
down, and enthusiasm is waning,

374
00:22:46.330 --> 00:22:49.840
you need someone at the C level or
VP level to champion the project.

375
00:22:51.320 --> 00:22:54.910
Otherwise, it's too easy for it to get
shuffled to the bottom of priorities and

376
00:22:54.910 --> 00:22:56.800
never actually occur.

377
00:22:56.800 --> 00:22:57.700
Governance committee,

378
00:22:57.700 --> 00:23:03.220
which has responsibility for
meeting your governance goals.

379
00:23:03.220 --> 00:23:05.410
Business owner would
certainly wanna be involved.

380
00:23:06.570 --> 00:23:10.410
And solution administrator would
be a good role to have as well.

381
00:23:11.540 --> 00:23:15.729
So managing what the governance committee
wants to put into action from a technology

382
00:23:15.729 --> 00:23:16.496
perspective.

383
00:23:18.824 --> 00:23:23.178
Then from lower down the hierarchy
in terms of site collections and

384
00:23:23.178 --> 00:23:25.755
sites we want to site sponsor an owner.

385
00:23:28.180 --> 00:23:31.740
So maintain the integrity
of content on pages.

386
00:23:33.090 --> 00:23:35.200
A site steward if you will.

387
00:23:35.200 --> 00:23:38.370
So just someone that's
responsible if there's errors or

388
00:23:38.370 --> 00:23:42.950
broken links on a page for example,
they're responsible for maintenance and

389
00:23:42.950 --> 00:23:48.690
keeping the subject matter timely,
as an Internet page, for example.

390
00:23:48.690 --> 00:23:53.550
Site designers, it's always good
to have a customer champion, so

391
00:23:53.550 --> 00:23:56.240
a site user champion.

392
00:23:56.240 --> 00:23:58.720
This is someone that represents
the interests of the rank and

393
00:23:58.720 --> 00:24:01.060
file employees that will be
interacting with the systems,

394
00:24:01.060 --> 00:24:03.460
especially if you're putting all
kinds of new workflows in there.

395
00:24:03.460 --> 00:24:06.190
You have to look at things
from a customer perspective.

396
00:24:06.190 --> 00:24:08.590
Now, if it's just internal use,

397
00:24:08.590 --> 00:24:13.210
the SharePoint deployment,
then your customers are the employees.

398
00:24:13.210 --> 00:24:15.214
So often they're neglected,

399
00:24:15.214 --> 00:24:19.916
because too much emphasis can be placed
on prettying up the interface and

400
00:24:19.916 --> 00:24:24.927
having nice ego shots of smiling people
at the expense of actual usability for

401
00:24:24.927 --> 00:24:28.087
the end user, or
if you're actually selling and

402
00:24:28.087 --> 00:24:33.327
if your customers are gonna be visiting
your SharePoint site or your products for

403
00:24:33.327 --> 00:24:38.218
example, you really needed someone
to champion from their perspective.

404
00:24:41.615 --> 00:24:45.405
There is so much more to say,
we're gonna need a second episode.

405
00:24:45.405 --> 00:24:48.280
[LAUGH] I'm gonna pass it back to Mike.

406
00:24:48.280 --> 00:24:53.080
>> All right Mark we appreciate
that first look at governance, and

407
00:24:53.080 --> 00:24:56.800
some of the things that we have to think
about, what governance is, in the end,

408
00:24:56.800 --> 00:24:59.890
responsible for
within our SharePoint deployment.

409
00:24:59.890 --> 00:25:03.290
We thank you for that, hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching, signing off for

410
00:25:03.290 --> 00:25:05.210
ITProTV, I'm Mike Roderick.

411
00:25:05.210 --> 00:25:05.950
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

412
00:25:05.950 --> 00:25:07.942
>> And we'll see you next time

413
00:25:07.942 --> 00:25:16.680
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Governance Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.452 --> 00:00:15.382
Hello!
Welcome to another exciting episode here

3
00:00:15.382 --> 00:00:16.174
at IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:16.174 --> 00:00:20.970
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today we
are doing our Advanced SharePoint 2016.

5
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:23.650
And specifically in this episode,
we're actually doing a part two.

6
00:00:23.650 --> 00:00:28.520
We're continuing on with our governance
episodes, and here to help us,

7
00:00:28.520 --> 00:00:30.360
of course, with that, is Mr. Mark Ingram.

8
00:00:30.360 --> 00:00:31.470
How are you doing, Mark?

9
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:32.540
>> Good, thanks, Mike.

10
00:00:32.540 --> 00:00:34.720
Right on.
So let's look at some diagrams.

11
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:37.200
A diagram is worth a thousand words.

12
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:39.085
You're gonna get 1000 words and
the diagrams.

13
00:00:39.085 --> 00:00:42.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, if we can go to my screen please,

14
00:00:42.670 --> 00:00:47.450
I'm using a TechNet article
as a starting point.

15
00:00:48.530 --> 00:00:51.390
Now, you're gonna say,
wait a minute Wait a minute, it says 2013.

16
00:00:51.390 --> 00:00:54.630
That's ok because the principles for

17
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:57.890
SharePoint 2013 are directly
translatable to 2016.

18
00:00:57.890 --> 00:01:03.360
In Microsoft there's often a lag in
updating some diagrams and content.

19
00:01:03.360 --> 00:01:05.000
Sometimes, you get the drop down link,

20
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:08.603
I'll show you here where it says other
versions, and it goes [LAUGH] even older.

21
00:01:08.603 --> 00:01:09.550
>> [LAUGH]
>> SharePoint 2010.

22
00:01:09.550 --> 00:01:13.930
But, Microsoft is very good,
I've found lately,

23
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:18.510
if I go at some resource in TechNet,
there's almost always a way to get to

24
00:01:18.510 --> 00:01:22.990
the same kind of guidance for a different
version, whether it's a server product, or

25
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:27.360
what have you, SharePoint Exchange,
Windows Server, so that's very helpful.

26
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:30.700
>> They've done a really good
job recently with that so.

27
00:01:30.700 --> 00:01:31.735
>> Thank you for that Microsoft.

28
00:01:31.735 --> 00:01:32.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

29
00:01:32.860 --> 00:01:35.150
>> You do a search and
you find a document on an older version,

30
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:38.920
and you just cannot find that same
document for the current version.

31
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:41.820
Now they got that little dropdown list,
and you can switch versions.

32
00:01:41.820 --> 00:01:42.372
Fantastic.

33
00:01:42.372 --> 00:01:44.750
All right, so what do you got for
us for governance there.

34
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:45.780
>> It's a beautiful thing.

35
00:01:45.780 --> 00:01:47.180
Okay, so again,

36
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:51.430
this 2013 guidance is directly
applicable to your 2016 deployment.

37
00:01:51.430 --> 00:01:56.620
Zuma is a cool tool,
because it's a rather dense poster.

38
00:01:56.620 --> 00:01:58.500
It should be printed two by three feet,
frankly.

39
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:00.930
What we're gonna do is we're
gonna zoom in on portions of it.

40
00:02:00.930 --> 00:02:03.730
So I've got that all setup but
I wanted to say where I'm starting from so

41
00:02:03.730 --> 00:02:06.670
if you wanna grab it and
you wanna print this poster as well.

42
00:02:06.670 --> 00:02:12.470
So I'll go now over to my PDF reader and
this is to help you

43
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:15.830
visualize some of things we talked about
last episode and certainly this episode.

44
00:02:15.830 --> 00:02:20.510
Three different areas of governance
segments to be concerned with.

45
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:23.220
And maybe you have the same committee
responsible for governance for

46
00:02:23.220 --> 00:02:26.400
all three, or
maybe you subdivide the committee.

47
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:30.460
IT governance in terms of software and
services, hardware refresh cycles,

48
00:02:30.460 --> 00:02:33.100
software deployment and
support, that sort of thing.

49
00:02:33.100 --> 00:02:35.940
We've got information management,
so the actual content and

50
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:38.100
data, how is it going to be stored?

51
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:42.850
Provisions, stored in the cloud
around PRIM or combination.

52
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:50.800
Upgrades the software to allow for,
say power pivot or

53
00:02:50.800 --> 00:02:55.240
some new tools, a new way of using data,
and then application management.

54
00:02:55.240 --> 00:03:00.490
So if you have devs in house, we're
working on either Sandbox solutions or

55
00:03:00.490 --> 00:03:02.310
apps, add ins.

56
00:03:02.310 --> 00:03:05.870
Some kind of custom code,
adding features to your farm.

57
00:03:05.870 --> 00:03:07.960
There's a whole governance area for that.

58
00:03:07.960 --> 00:03:09.600
That's represented by the green bar.

59
00:03:09.600 --> 00:03:12.720
Now, also very useful, diagram on
the right hand side of your screen,

60
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:14.080
governance and site types.

61
00:03:14.080 --> 00:03:20.250
So we don't need total lockdown control,
say, over someone's team site.

62
00:03:21.310 --> 00:03:25.550
Some governance, for sure, but generally
the more people who are involved with

63
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:30.090
utilizing or reviewing content created,
the more governance is required.

64
00:03:30.090 --> 00:03:33.100
So I like to use the MSN.com portal,
for example, or

65
00:03:33.100 --> 00:03:38.700
any new source you might go to, often has
millions of readers or tens of millions.

66
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:43.610
So governance is critical there because,
the content creation, editing,

67
00:03:43.610 --> 00:03:46.870
dissemination, probably passes
through several stages and

68
00:03:46.870 --> 00:03:48.160
may be several different forums.

69
00:03:48.160 --> 00:03:52.570
So dev test stage and production and so,
the more people that are potentially

70
00:03:52.570 --> 00:03:56.470
affected, it makes more sense to have
more governance and control over that.

71
00:03:56.470 --> 00:04:02.320
So, on the far left here, we have personal
sights, projects and work spaces,

72
00:04:02.320 --> 00:04:06.320
team sites, so we're moving up the
hierarchy here, the little stair steps.

73
00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:08.990
And then, so,
some kind of Internet home page,

74
00:04:08.990 --> 00:04:13.140
even an intranet page would affect more
people and require more governance.

75
00:04:13.140 --> 00:04:18.270
So, they often say if you need a total
lock-down environment, where no

76
00:04:18.270 --> 00:04:22.815
one can do anything without a multi-page,
paper-based request to do something.

77
00:04:22.815 --> 00:04:24.080
>> [LAUGH]
>> SharePoint's probably not

78
00:04:24.080 --> 00:04:25.585
a good tool for you.

79
00:04:25.585 --> 00:04:27.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now,

80
00:04:27.030 --> 00:04:32.480
let's get specific with IT Governance, so
in this next section I'll show you here,

81
00:04:32.480 --> 00:04:36.660
notice how there's a tradeoff with these
different sections we'll be looking at

82
00:04:36.660 --> 00:04:40.090
between centrally managed and
locally managed.

83
00:04:40.090 --> 00:04:45.510
IT governance leans a little to the left,
if you will, toward centrally managed.

84
00:04:45.510 --> 00:04:49.740
So we have things like an IT service
governance, a section there for

85
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:53.350
farm governance,
communications policies is essential.

86
00:04:53.350 --> 00:04:54.520
Anytime we're making a change,

87
00:04:54.520 --> 00:04:58.340
or we're moving users to
the SharePoint farm concept, at first.

88
00:04:58.340 --> 00:05:02.510
We need to let them know in advance, so
they dont return to work, the day after

89
00:05:02.510 --> 00:05:06.340
a holiday on a Tuesday and say, ooh my
goodness everything's changed, my workflow

90
00:05:06.340 --> 00:05:10.830
is different, what's this Share Point
portal stuff, team sites, nobody told me.

91
00:05:10.830 --> 00:05:13.580
That's no good, so communication
has to be a big part of your plan,

92
00:05:13.580 --> 00:05:15.300
you want to get some buy in.

93
00:05:15.300 --> 00:05:18.540
One way to do this is you can have
different methods of training it

94
00:05:18.540 --> 00:05:22.350
can be a video tutorial, lunch and learn,
a series of emails in the months and

95
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:25.230
weeks leading up to, I mean not too many,
but a couple months out,

96
00:05:25.230 --> 00:05:29.490
one month out a week out and with
helpful links in those emails as well.

97
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:33.450
The kind of emails people are gonna want
to favorite and save, maybe print out for

98
00:05:33.450 --> 00:05:34.290
future reference.

99
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:40.800
And also, how we want to use
interact with the system.

100
00:05:40.800 --> 00:05:47.900
So that could be, for example, using,
think of SharePoint as guard rails.

101
00:05:47.900 --> 00:05:51.270
So assets in governance and farm admins.

102
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:54.950
We provide some kind of context,
a road to drive on if you'd like.

103
00:05:54.950 --> 00:05:57.860
But, there's also the sandbox
element where there's

104
00:05:57.860 --> 00:06:00.680
got to be some area of play
in experimentation as well.

105
00:06:00.680 --> 00:06:03.680
So we can tell people what we
expect them to do, and we have some

106
00:06:03.680 --> 00:06:07.470
test sites where they can play around,
and just get familiar with the product,

107
00:06:07.470 --> 00:06:11.220
or maybe some VM spinoff where
it's a practice environment.

108
00:06:11.220 --> 00:06:13.640
They get access to a VM for
an hour a day or something.

109
00:06:13.640 --> 00:06:14.570
They can do whatever they want.

110
00:06:14.570 --> 00:06:15.820
>> And they know it's not permanent,

111
00:06:15.820 --> 00:06:20.000
it's a test environment, okay so what
do we need to governance specifically,

112
00:06:20.000 --> 00:06:24.530
well policies related to security,
infrastructure, Web apps,

113
00:06:24.530 --> 00:06:29.260
data protection, so
where are we storing backups for example?

114
00:06:29.260 --> 00:06:33.330
In the cloud,
off site Site policies so under

115
00:06:33.330 --> 00:06:38.330
what circumstance does a site die, in
other words, when do we de-provision it?

116
00:06:38.330 --> 00:06:41.570
Is it after a certain number
of months of lack of use or

117
00:06:41.570 --> 00:06:44.330
a year after the site got created,
especially with the project site.

118
00:06:44.330 --> 00:06:47.740
The project is done, let me save some
documents about best practices and

119
00:06:47.740 --> 00:06:49.380
we can shut down that site.

120
00:06:49.380 --> 00:06:51.020
Do we need quota management?

121
00:06:51.020 --> 00:06:56.415
Do we need a way of asset classification?

122
00:06:56.415 --> 00:07:01.270
And think of potential risks
in terms of data leakage.

123
00:07:01.270 --> 00:07:03.740
How will that impact your business?

124
00:07:03.740 --> 00:07:07.550
What about if we're asking people
to do things in a new way,

125
00:07:07.550 --> 00:07:10.090
what if that service is not available now?

126
00:07:10.090 --> 00:07:13.090
So the only way to accomplish
certain workflow tasks, for example,

127
00:07:13.090 --> 00:07:14.290
is through SharePoint.

128
00:07:14.290 --> 00:07:17.210
But there's a service that's
down they can't work.

129
00:07:17.210 --> 00:07:19.450
I mean if we thought through
the implications of that.

130
00:07:19.450 --> 00:07:23.040
So that leads us to service level
agreements, which I always say that if

131
00:07:23.040 --> 00:07:25.450
you don't have a formal service level
agreement you have an informal one.

132
00:07:25.450 --> 00:07:29.250
In other words get this running ASAP or
start looking for another job.

133
00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:32.670
But it's much better to have formal
service level agreements, and

134
00:07:32.670 --> 00:07:36.260
this is a government task,
sorry, governance tasks.

135
00:07:36.260 --> 00:07:40.320
So in other words, how much data are we
willing to lose if the database goes down,

136
00:07:40.320 --> 00:07:41.840
how many hours do we have to restore it.

137
00:07:41.840 --> 00:07:44.070
You know what are the standards
by which we can measure.

138
00:07:44.070 --> 00:07:48.077
It's good to have measurement then you can
say okay, yes the database crashed, but

139
00:07:48.077 --> 00:07:51.134
we told you we should have made
it a high availability scenario.

140
00:07:51.134 --> 00:07:54.631
You didn't provide budget for
that, we promised that we could,

141
00:07:54.631 --> 00:07:59.019
with the resources we have and the farm
design number of servers, we promised that

142
00:07:59.019 --> 00:08:03.024
we could restore any content Say from
a site collection within four hours,

143
00:08:03.024 --> 00:08:07.250
it took us three hours twenty minutes so
we're within the SLA's agreed upon.

144
00:08:07.250 --> 00:08:10.560
Then there's no yelling or
pulling out hair.

145
00:08:10.560 --> 00:08:14.100
You may want to adjust the service
level agreements in the future but

146
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:17.410
it's good to know what the rules are,
how the game should be played.

147
00:08:17.410 --> 00:08:21.580
Are we gonna block installations
of unauthorized software?

148
00:08:21.580 --> 00:08:22.790
What about patching?

149
00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:24.260
How do we test patching?

150
00:08:24.260 --> 00:08:30.170
We have some VMs spun up to test the
impact of hotfixes and SharePoint patches.

151
00:08:31.220 --> 00:08:33.070
What about site collection upgrades?

152
00:08:33.070 --> 00:08:34.450
Under what circumstances or

153
00:08:34.450 --> 00:08:39.840
when are we gonna upgrade from the
previous version site collections to 2016?

154
00:08:39.840 --> 00:08:44.170
Load balancing, how do we measure
the success of the deployment?

155
00:08:45.560 --> 00:08:48.410
From a user perspective
whats successful to them?

156
00:08:48.410 --> 00:08:52.970
Fast page loading time is great but what
are the standards, one second average,

157
00:08:52.970 --> 00:08:54.988
two seconds, a quarter of a second?

158
00:08:54.988 --> 00:08:59.720
Users get very antsy when they don't get
instant results after clicking a button.

159
00:09:00.810 --> 00:09:03.910
That brings us to our next section
on information management.

160
00:09:03.910 --> 00:09:07.680
Let's look at some of
the governance elements there.

161
00:09:07.680 --> 00:09:12.760
So notice now our little
pendulum here has switched over.

162
00:09:12.760 --> 00:09:15.948
It's slightly biased towards
the loosely managed side.

163
00:09:15.948 --> 00:09:22.240
So webpages, lists,
who should access what content.

164
00:09:23.970 --> 00:09:27.230
Now not just internally, but externally.

165
00:09:27.230 --> 00:09:30.550
Do you have and
extranet arranged with partners?

166
00:09:30.550 --> 00:09:34.160
Do you have sites hosted
in SharePoint online

167
00:09:34.160 --> 00:09:37.590
as a way of collaborating
with external users?

168
00:09:37.590 --> 00:09:41.590
What about if you wanna make a,
for example, a product catalog or

169
00:09:41.590 --> 00:09:44.770
a price list available to
your customers externally?

170
00:09:44.770 --> 00:09:47.980
Presumably with anonymous
access from a browser,

171
00:09:47.980 --> 00:09:49.880
that has to be considered as well.

172
00:09:49.880 --> 00:09:55.800
Versions, we talked about in
the part one governance episode.

173
00:09:55.800 --> 00:09:59.220
Navigation, who's responsible for
designing navigation?

174
00:09:59.220 --> 00:10:02.810
Nothing drives users more nuts than
not knowing where they are and

175
00:10:02.810 --> 00:10:04.800
how to get back to where they were.

176
00:10:04.800 --> 00:10:08.170
So, a bread crumb trail
near the top is useful.

177
00:10:08.170 --> 00:10:11.330
Tabs, quick launch options
on the left-hand side.

178
00:10:11.330 --> 00:10:14.650
Remember, the implementation
of what we're talking about

179
00:10:14.650 --> 00:10:17.340
isn't necessarily that difficult.

180
00:10:17.340 --> 00:10:20.440
But someone has to decide
what should occur.

181
00:10:20.440 --> 00:10:22.070
How do we want users to navigate?

182
00:10:23.560 --> 00:10:25.580
What is their publishing strategy?

183
00:10:25.580 --> 00:10:28.250
Do we have a multi-stage approval process?

184
00:10:28.250 --> 00:10:33.470
Can content creators
chose when to publish or

185
00:10:33.470 --> 00:10:36.730
do they always need an editor and
an approver to sign off?

186
00:10:36.730 --> 00:10:39.610
Somebody has to decide what the work
flow's going to look like in

187
00:10:39.610 --> 00:10:40.419
terms of publishing.

188
00:10:41.450 --> 00:10:45.000
I'm gonna scroll over now, alright.

189
00:10:46.720 --> 00:10:54.280
So in terms of content information stored
by users can IT manage that information?

190
00:10:54.280 --> 00:11:00.360
In other words maybe IT's not responsible
for backing up content in my sites.

191
00:11:00.360 --> 00:11:04.430
So users know that, hey, you're on
your own, you can use Scratchpad, but

192
00:11:04.430 --> 00:11:08.946
serious business work should only be saved
in document libraries which normally get

193
00:11:08.946 --> 00:11:09.597
backed up.

194
00:11:11.255 --> 00:11:14.570
How are we presenting data?

195
00:11:14.570 --> 00:11:16.790
Is it some kind of visual display?

196
00:11:16.790 --> 00:11:19.170
Do we pretty it up using apps?

197
00:11:19.170 --> 00:11:24.940
And BI tools for example like Power BI,
which we will look at in another episode.

198
00:11:26.410 --> 00:11:30.340
Metadata, do we require
tagging of content?

199
00:11:30.340 --> 00:11:33.050
Can metadata happen automatically?

200
00:11:33.050 --> 00:11:37.440
In other words there's no field or
drop down menu for the user to select.

201
00:11:37.440 --> 00:11:43.230
But metadata gets automatically populated
based on say a field or in a form or

202
00:11:43.230 --> 00:11:49.610
the title of a document or the author or
some such metadata like that.

203
00:11:49.610 --> 00:11:54.490
Do we have unique security needs for
any of the content?

204
00:11:54.490 --> 00:11:59.060
What about language specific
versions of the content.

205
00:11:59.060 --> 00:12:02.700
This may not be a concern for
you if you're in a unilingual country but

206
00:12:02.700 --> 00:12:06.900
if you're a multinational organization
obviously you wanna have the content

207
00:12:06.900 --> 00:12:10.940
translated or at least some of it for
localization purposes.

208
00:12:11.990 --> 00:12:16.780
Okay, permission structures for
sites, who decides on that?

209
00:12:18.790 --> 00:12:22.538
How do I make sure that unauthorized
users aren't seeing content?

210
00:12:22.538 --> 00:12:27.310
Now for the various document types you see

211
00:12:27.310 --> 00:12:31.510
near the lower right of the slide,
look at all these spokes.

212
00:12:31.510 --> 00:12:38.290
Looks like some kind of artificial flower
design, or a ceiling light or something.

213
00:12:38.290 --> 00:12:44.310
So, various rules could apply to different
types of content that get created.

214
00:12:44.310 --> 00:12:48.230
So, we have different rules for videos
versus blogs and wikis for example, or

215
00:12:48.230 --> 00:12:48.850
external data.

216
00:12:50.030 --> 00:12:51.380
Now, there's always a tradeoff.

217
00:12:51.380 --> 00:12:57.730
Last thing I wanna show you on this
segment is prioritising content.

218
00:12:57.730 --> 00:13:01.600
So there's always a trade-off between
availability, access and redundancy.

219
00:13:01.600 --> 00:13:04.710
That's what this little
dial is showing here.

220
00:13:04.710 --> 00:13:07.110
So if we make something

221
00:13:07.110 --> 00:13:10.160
more highly available it's more
likely there's gonna be redundancy.

222
00:13:10.160 --> 00:13:13.170
In other words, duplicate copies
of the data in the organization or

223
00:13:13.170 --> 00:13:16.810
maybe On Prem and in the Cloud.

224
00:13:16.810 --> 00:13:20.900
Access, the more people that have access
presumably the less security there is

225
00:13:20.900 --> 00:13:22.760
because more people can
access the content and

226
00:13:22.760 --> 00:13:25.120
can do things that maybe
we don't want them to.

227
00:13:25.120 --> 00:13:27.350
So there's always a trade off there.

228
00:13:27.350 --> 00:13:30.160
The next section to consider
is application management and

229
00:13:30.160 --> 00:13:31.770
custom solutions.

230
00:13:31.770 --> 00:13:33.370
So I'll show you here.

231
00:13:33.370 --> 00:13:36.830
Again, this tends is near the middle.

232
00:13:36.830 --> 00:13:40.830
It's tends towards more strictly
managed versus loosely managed.

233
00:13:40.830 --> 00:13:43.460
Things like customizations,
custom app creation.

234
00:13:45.460 --> 00:13:51.090
Who gets to, we're having a pilot or
test environment for customizations.

235
00:13:51.090 --> 00:13:52.490
How are they being packaged up?

236
00:13:52.490 --> 00:13:53.260
In a package?

237
00:13:53.260 --> 00:13:54.120
In a solution?

238
00:13:55.280 --> 00:13:56.070
As an app?

239
00:13:57.210 --> 00:13:58.780
Who's gonna support the code?

240
00:13:58.780 --> 00:14:00.460
It's one thing to create the code.

241
00:14:00.460 --> 00:14:04.850
But the real work often begins after
the applications out in the wild in

242
00:14:04.850 --> 00:14:05.640
the organization.

243
00:14:05.640 --> 00:14:08.060
There's some feedback if you like,
from users,

244
00:14:08.060 --> 00:14:11.510
or maybe the app crashes,
you need ongoing support.

245
00:14:11.510 --> 00:14:16.760
So if it's something you've hired,
maybe you paid someone to design the app,

246
00:14:16.760 --> 00:14:18.030
or they're no longer with the firm.

247
00:14:18.030 --> 00:14:20.030
Somebody needs to be able to
support that application.

248
00:14:21.460 --> 00:14:26.750
In terms of life cycle management for
custom solutions controlling source code,

249
00:14:26.750 --> 00:14:31.040
same with Visual Source Safe,
some kind of versioning there,

250
00:14:31.040 --> 00:14:33.590
especially with a multi dev environment.

251
00:14:33.590 --> 00:14:37.220
And the ability to test solutions
in a pre-production environment,

252
00:14:37.220 --> 00:14:39.910
you don't wanna test on your
actual production users.

253
00:14:39.910 --> 00:14:45.206
There's really no excuse now, with
the inexpensive nature of virtualization,

254
00:14:45.206 --> 00:14:49.808
a lot of organizations have some sort
of Hyper-V or VSX Server On Prem so

255
00:14:49.808 --> 00:14:53.873
it's very easy to spin up and
destroy VMs on an as needed basis so

256
00:14:53.873 --> 00:14:56.969
there's no excuse not
to test pre production.

257
00:14:56.969 --> 00:15:01.530
Branding, what theme will be
approved maybe enterprise wide?

258
00:15:01.530 --> 00:15:03.980
Maybe divisions should have some
control over their branding.

259
00:15:03.980 --> 00:15:08.500
Are you gonna use design manager or
SharePoint Designer?

260
00:15:08.500 --> 00:15:10.210
That's another close choice as well.

261
00:15:10.210 --> 00:15:13.650
And then solutions or apps for SharePoint?

262
00:15:13.650 --> 00:15:17.570
So do we want to bundle
the custom functionality

263
00:15:17.570 --> 00:15:19.890
as a solution which we've been able to do?

264
00:15:19.890 --> 00:15:23.960
Or now the more modern way is packaging
that functionality as an app?

265
00:15:23.960 --> 00:15:27.610
When I say functionality, I mean that
can be some kind of video player.

266
00:15:27.610 --> 00:15:30.210
It could be a new button on the ribbon.

267
00:15:30.210 --> 00:15:32.460
It could be some custom list.

268
00:15:32.460 --> 00:15:38.160
Really, any of the major elements of
SharePoint you could customize or extend

269
00:15:38.160 --> 00:15:42.640
the functionality of, and then package it
up in the form of a solution or an app.

270
00:15:42.640 --> 00:15:45.520
And then who gets to deploy the solutions?

271
00:15:45.520 --> 00:15:48.080
Or who decides when this
solution will be deployed.

272
00:15:48.080 --> 00:15:51.350
These are all governance issues.

273
00:15:51.350 --> 00:15:54.065
Let's wrap up this section with
some best practices for governance.

274
00:15:54.065 --> 00:15:56.262
So like many things in SharePoint,

275
00:15:56.262 --> 00:16:00.731
policies should be reviewed periodically
to evaluate against what your

276
00:16:00.731 --> 00:16:04.996
expectations were when you created
the policies in the first place.

277
00:16:04.996 --> 00:16:06.211
Okay, so.

278
00:16:06.211 --> 00:16:11.564
Again, have an executive sponsor and
a strong governance committee.

279
00:16:11.564 --> 00:16:14.716
You don't wanna over complicate
the governance model,

280
00:16:14.716 --> 00:16:19.577
you don't wanna stifle people's innovation
and make them have a multi-stage request

281
00:16:19.577 --> 00:16:22.810
format just to do something
simple like create a new site.

282
00:16:25.160 --> 00:16:30.445
So don't over design your
SharePoint deployment.

283
00:16:30.445 --> 00:16:33.542
Make sure that people that have
various permissions know what their

284
00:16:33.542 --> 00:16:35.730
responsibilities are for
those permissions.

285
00:16:35.730 --> 00:16:37.620
For example,
site collection administrators.

286
00:16:37.620 --> 00:16:39.360
Make sure they're trained,
they know what they're doing,

287
00:16:39.360 --> 00:16:43.629
and they know the capabilities they have
in terms of granting or denying access.

288
00:16:45.700 --> 00:16:51.402
How will you ensure your governance
plan is being executed the way you want?

289
00:16:51.402 --> 00:16:56.428
Now certain site collections, document
libraries, etc, might be more critical

290
00:16:56.428 --> 00:17:01.620
to monitor from a governance perspective
and operational perspective than others.

291
00:17:02.630 --> 00:17:07.002
So again, you prioritize the workload,
what's critical, I mean an HR policy and

292
00:17:07.002 --> 00:17:08.670
finance, for example.

293
00:17:08.670 --> 00:17:12.265
You don't want the users with the ability
just to search for salary information,

294
00:17:12.265 --> 00:17:12.902
for example.

295
00:17:12.902 --> 00:17:17.805
Whereas, maybe old product information is
not such a security risk in terms of if

296
00:17:17.805 --> 00:17:20.050
someone had inappropriate access.

297
00:17:20.050 --> 00:17:24.330
So in terms of your auditing time,
you wanna audit access, for example,

298
00:17:24.330 --> 00:17:26.540
to the most sensitive parts of
your SharePoint deployment,

299
00:17:26.540 --> 00:17:28.359
the most sensitive data repositories.

300
00:17:30.020 --> 00:17:34.198
Okay, so some common pitfalls you might
encounter relating to governance.

301
00:17:36.162 --> 00:17:40.076
Not defining policies into differentiating
policies that may be required,

302
00:17:40.076 --> 00:17:44.280
different policies for
different divisions, departments, teams.

303
00:17:44.280 --> 00:17:47.620
If you're a multinational conglomerate,
for example, and using SharePoint

304
00:17:47.620 --> 00:17:51.580
throughout, you're gonna have different
entities in different countries,

305
00:17:51.580 --> 00:17:55.220
in different industries, subject to
different compliance regulations.

306
00:17:55.220 --> 00:17:59.409
And maybe more or
less strict from a governance perspective.

307
00:17:59.409 --> 00:18:02.620
Now you might give people, again,
permissions to do certain things.

308
00:18:02.620 --> 00:18:05.780
But without training, it's like giving
them the keys to the Ferrari and

309
00:18:05.780 --> 00:18:07.980
they have their learner's license.

310
00:18:07.980 --> 00:18:12.724
The results are probably not gonna be good
or they could be very expensive [LAUGH].

311
00:18:12.724 --> 00:18:15.569
>> Yes [LAUGH].

312
00:18:15.569 --> 00:18:20.300
>> Okay, now maybe it comes
down to educating users often,

313
00:18:20.300 --> 00:18:24.930
as well, in terms of list items, so a user
might think I've got a product list here

314
00:18:24.930 --> 00:18:30.440
with 30,000 products available
from widgets to window cleaners.

315
00:18:30.440 --> 00:18:35.110
And they might think I'll just create one
giant list in SharePoint, so not realizing

316
00:18:35.110 --> 00:18:39.990
that there's realistic limits as to
how long any given list should be.

317
00:18:39.990 --> 00:18:44.050
Not planning for scale and
growth can be a gotcha as well,

318
00:18:44.050 --> 00:18:46.600
so you might start small and
departmentally.

319
00:18:46.600 --> 00:18:51.343
And expand your SharePoint deployment, add
on more functionality that SharePoint has.

320
00:18:51.343 --> 00:18:58.570
Search, Record Center,
Document Center, custom workflows.

321
00:18:58.570 --> 00:19:02.260
And over time your SharePoint deployment
becomes potentially unwieldy or

322
00:19:02.260 --> 00:19:05.380
you need to really start having
separate dedicated servers.

323
00:19:05.380 --> 00:19:12.270
Or more than one server for search,
for caching, web front end,

324
00:19:12.270 --> 00:19:15.070
some kind of high availability on
the back end with SQL storage.

325
00:19:15.070 --> 00:19:16.890
So by failing to plan for

326
00:19:16.890 --> 00:19:22.908
the anticipated growth in your SharePoint
deployment, that could bite you.

327
00:19:22.908 --> 00:19:26.837
And that is a governance issue,
making sure you thought that through,

328
00:19:26.837 --> 00:19:31.027
where do we expect our SharePoint
environment to be at one year, two years,

329
00:19:31.027 --> 00:19:32.549
etc and planning for that.

330
00:19:32.549 --> 00:19:35.832
We talked about the importance
of doing proper backups and

331
00:19:35.832 --> 00:19:39.120
testing recovery to make sure
your backups are adequate.

332
00:19:40.470 --> 00:19:45.550
And again, this being overbearing
could be a problem as well in terms of

333
00:19:45.550 --> 00:19:49.360
stifling any kind of creativity,
or new ideas,

334
00:19:49.360 --> 00:19:52.020
or new functionality in
your SharePoint deployment.

335
00:19:54.270 --> 00:19:57.870
Okay, in terms of implementing governance,
site templates,

336
00:19:57.870 --> 00:19:59.710
you might wanna get some
customizations there.

337
00:19:59.710 --> 00:20:06.360
Quotas, workflows, deciding what features
should be enabled at different levels.

338
00:20:06.360 --> 00:20:10.430
So that's why you definitely need some
IT expertise on a governance committee.

339
00:20:10.430 --> 00:20:14.060
Because we have features, for example,
we can enable at the farm level, web apps,

340
00:20:14.060 --> 00:20:15.310
site collections, site level.

341
00:20:16.590 --> 00:20:19.200
Should we allow for
self service site creation?

342
00:20:19.200 --> 00:20:21.250
For some organizations,
that opens up a can of worms,

343
00:20:21.250 --> 00:20:22.950
they don't wanna go there for others.

344
00:20:22.950 --> 00:20:25.630
That is one of the prime drivers
of SharePoint, the ability for

345
00:20:25.630 --> 00:20:30.760
users to create their own sites, add some
content, maybe modifying customized pages.

346
00:20:31.930 --> 00:20:33.883
Site use confirmation and deletion,

347
00:20:33.883 --> 00:20:37.185
do you wanna just let the SharePoint
infrastructure grow wild?

348
00:20:37.185 --> 00:20:41.630
Or do you wanna have some constraints on
how long a site collection can live for?

349
00:20:43.590 --> 00:20:46.350
Do you want to enable My Sites?

350
00:20:46.350 --> 00:20:49.520
Some organizations, yes, absolutely,
other organizations, forget it,

351
00:20:49.520 --> 00:20:50.910
we're not doing My Sites.

352
00:20:50.910 --> 00:20:54.700
Opens up a whole can of worms,
we don't wanna go there.

353
00:20:54.700 --> 00:21:02.460
Document management, versioning, content
approval processes, these must be decided.

354
00:21:04.210 --> 00:21:09.800
Auditing policies, blocked file types,
do you want to prevent, say, AVI type

355
00:21:09.800 --> 00:21:14.180
files or video or audio content from being
uploaded in your SharePoint environment?

356
00:21:14.180 --> 00:21:18.981
Or on particular web applications, say,
if you have a web app hosting My Sites.

357
00:21:18.981 --> 00:21:22.031
Do you wanna prevent users
uploading multimedia content,

358
00:21:22.031 --> 00:21:24.350
which simply adds a lot
to the storage space.

359
00:21:24.350 --> 00:21:27.480
You might have a concern there about
copyright infringement as well.

360
00:21:27.480 --> 00:21:29.580
Again, depending on your business,
if you're making music or

361
00:21:29.580 --> 00:21:33.900
videos, obviously you don't wanna block
that kind of content from being uploaded.

362
00:21:33.900 --> 00:21:38.020
Anywhere, probably, in your organization,
My Sites or otherwise.

363
00:21:38.020 --> 00:21:38.937
Are you gonna allow for

364
00:21:38.937 --> 00:21:41.550
sandbox solutions which have
been deprecated in this version?

365
00:21:41.550 --> 00:21:45.867
So that's custom code that can run and
is restricted in terms of

366
00:21:45.867 --> 00:21:50.352
the number of server resources it
can use in any 24 hour period.

367
00:21:50.352 --> 00:21:52.910
As measured by CPU, RAM, bandwidth and

368
00:21:52.910 --> 00:21:55.853
other impacts on
the SharePoint deployment.

369
00:21:55.853 --> 00:21:59.215
So how are sandbox solutions
gonna be governed,

370
00:21:59.215 --> 00:22:01.680
are you going to allow them, even?

371
00:22:02.690 --> 00:22:06.060
Apps, are you gonna use
a catalogue on site,

372
00:22:06.060 --> 00:22:10.240
are you gonna have apps in the cloud
in some kind of hybrid environment?

373
00:22:10.240 --> 00:22:12.620
Should users be able to create and
add their own apps, or

374
00:22:12.620 --> 00:22:14.240
only choose from an approved list?

375
00:22:15.450 --> 00:22:19.470
So these are some of the governance
issues you should consider, and

376
00:22:19.470 --> 00:22:23.550
I'm gonna pass it over to the one and
only, Mike Rodrick [LAUGH].

377
00:22:23.550 --> 00:22:25.400
>> All right, we appreciate that Mark,

378
00:22:25.400 --> 00:22:29.560
again, a great look at governance and
how important it is.

379
00:22:29.560 --> 00:22:36.113
And where it fits into our SharePoint
2016 deployment and our infrastructure.

380
00:22:36.113 --> 00:22:39.490
And you can see,
just about everywhere, right?

381
00:22:39.490 --> 00:22:41.410
A very important part,
so we appreciate that,

382
00:22:41.410 --> 00:22:44.280
Mark, hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

383
00:22:44.280 --> 00:22:46.870
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

384
00:22:46.870 --> 00:22:47.650
>> I'm Mark Ingram.

385
00:22:47.650 --> 00:22:49.820
>> And we'll see you next time.

386

episodes.title: Hybrid Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

00:00:12.263 --> 00:00:15.775
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.775 --> 00:00:17.073
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing our Advanced SharePoint 2016.

4
00:00:17.073 --> 00:00:20.021
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:20.021 --> 00:00:25.020
we're gonna be focusing in on
some of the hybrid features.

Right, we've looked at the couple
of the different models way back in

00:00:27.558 --> 00:00:28.171

00:00:28.171 --> 00:00:31.853
We talked about the four different models,

9
00:00:31.853 --> 00:00:36.342

00:00:36.342 --> 00:00:39.759

enterprises are gonna have part of those

resources of the SharePoint deployment's
gonna be out there in the cloud.

12
00:00:42.990 --> 00:00:45.560
Other parts of it are gonna
still be on-premises.

13
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:47.270
Hence the hybrid deployment, right?

14
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:48.600
And that's what we're
going talk about today.

00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:51.310
And here to do that with us is Mr.
Mark Ingram.

00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:51.874

00:01:12.528 --> 00:01:14.580
here this episode.

how much authentication do they need?

00:01:28.875 --> 00:01:30.251
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

Settings > Services & add ins.

00:01:33.877 --> 00:01:38.222
Now, I mentioned in a different episode,

But there is different tracks,

Some people want to be on the cutting

00:01:53.160 --> 00:01:56.118
Others, what they call now

00:01:56.118 --> 00:01:58.920

You don't want those organizations just,

what can possibly [LAUGH] go wrong?

00:02:05.872 --> 00:02:08.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, bad.

So there's different servicing rings for

00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:19.900

00:02:48.030 --> 00:02:53.930

00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:58.240

Let's see what happens when I click Next.

00:04:09.820 --> 00:04:12.289

00:04:13.420 --> 00:04:14.053
Okay, so

Configure hybrid OneDrive and

It used to say, we recommend you close all

So the idea is you might have

Natural language careers.

So, if you watch if you're a sports fan,

For example here's a Budget Tracker.

Wow.

P is for PowerApps,
